Sex, Freedom, and Power in Imperial Germany, 1880–1914

This is a study of the intense, complex, and escalating debate over sexuality
and sexual morality that roiled politics in Germany between 1880 and 1914.
That debate was grounded in the rapid evolution and growing complexity
of German society – the multiplication of cultural groupings, professional
associations, and social movements; the emergence of new social groups,
social milieus, and professions; the rapid development of the media and
commercial entertainments; and so on. All parties involved understood it
to be a debate over the most fundamental question of modern political life:
how to secure both national power and individual freedom in the context of
rapid social and cultural change.
Edward Ross Dickinson is professor of history at the University of California
at Davis. He previously taught at Victoria University of Wellington, New
Zealand, from 1991 to 2000, and at the University of Cincinnati from 2002
to 2007. He is the author of The Politics of German Child Welfare from the
Empire to the Federal Republic (1996) and of numerous articles in Central
European History, German Studies Review, European History Quarterly,
Journal of the History of Sexuality, Gender and History, History Workshop,
Journal of Modern History, German History, and Dance Chronicle.

Introduction
Sex, Politics, Modernity I

Sex was a big problem in twentieth-century Germany. Who should have it,
with whom, how often, under what conditions, and for what purposes? What
should be done about those who had it under the wrong conditions, for the
wrong purposes, the wrong way, with the wrong partners, too often, too
early, or too late? When and where should people talk and write about it,
to what audiences, and what should they say or not say? From the middle
of the 1880s until almost a century later, these were important questions for
German politics; in fact, during that century German public life was regularly
roiled by intense debates over issues relating to sex and reproduction – over
pornography and censorship, prostitution and venereal disease, marriage and
divorce, contraception and abortion, the birthrate, homosexuality, and so on.
Taken together, these debates constituted one of the most important political
and cultural conflicts in twentieth-century German history.
This book examines the first and formative phase of this long struggle to
define the role of sex in German society. In the three decades before World
War I, Germans had to come to grips with the ways in which very rapid processes of technological, social, and cultural change were transforming sex –
for example, by enabling cheap mass reproduction of graphic images (including photographs) and a massive expansion of popular literature, by creating
entirely new forms of entertainment like the cinema or recorded music, or
by making contraceptives increasingly cheap and available. Very rapid urbanization created a new urban commercial nightlife of new scale, intensity, and
character. The growth of the white-collar middle class and rapid upward social
mobility, rising working-class incomes, the emergence of a mass working-class
movement, and particularly the expansion of women’s employment and the
sudden growth of the women’s movements threw relations between the classes
and the sexes into disarray and called into question the sexual power and privilege of middle-class men. Quite suddenly, Germans were confronted with a
1

2

Sex, Freedom, and Power in Imperial Germany, 1880–1914

question that seemed of enormous importance: what place would and should
sex have in a modern society?
The debate over that question generated an enormous volume of spoken
and printed verbiage and became virtually inescapable for any member of the
educated public. Each of the major ideological and political communities in
Germany put sexuality at the core of their anthropology, their conception
of what human beings are like and how they relate to each other. At a moment
when organizing a working modern society was clearly the question of the
hour, this in turn meant that sex seemed a profoundly important and urgent
issue. The most popular socialist work in the German Empire, for example,
was August Bebel’s Woman under Socialism (1879), which held that sexual
liberation was an integral part of the coming social and democratic revolution.
Conservative Christians in both the Conservative Party and the (Catholicdominated) Center Party saw the patriarchal family, with its clear division of
gender roles and its highly restrictive sexual mores, as the foundation of social
order and the state. Many liberals saw conservative Christians’ attempts to
impose their own peculiarly restrictive moral pedagogy (for example, through
censorship) as a dangerous and fundamentally tyrannical attack on the freedom
of art and of public opinion, both of which liberals regarded as foundational to
a free society. The debate over sexual morality and sexual practices was central
to the ongoing struggle in Germany in this period over the most fundamental
questions of political principle and political organization: over how to define
and to secure the freedom of the citizen and over how to guarantee the national
power that, most believed, ultimately defended that freedom.
This broad debate over sexuality and politics became increasingly intense,
embittered, and continuous over the thirty years examined in this book. That
was partly because the social, technological, and cultural revolutions only accelerated over this period. But it was also partly because the debate itself had a
dynamic of its own, in which opposing ideas and movements sparked intensifying responses in an escalating cultural and political feedback loop. At the
outset the reform of mores and legislation concerning sexuality was the project
of a relatively small group of Christian activists, facing both profound hostility
to their radical ideas and a powerful taboo against speaking about sex at all.
By the turn of the century, a bitter debate over censorship dominated parliamentary business for months on end. Between about 1902 and 1908, there was
a massive outpouring of discussion and of organizational initiatives around
issues of morality, decency, and reproduction, much of it among ideological
communities vehemently opposed to some of the core values championed by
conservative Christians. In the five years before World War I, the tone and volume of the confrontation between these different groups and agendas escalated
rapidly. By 1912 and 1913, as war loomed, issues of sexual and reproductive
behavior were increasingly understood to be central to the question of national
power – what constituted it, what it was for, and how to build or preserve it.
In that context, issues relating to sexuality, decency, and reproduction were

Sex, Politics, and Modernity I

3

debated with particular urgency, even fury; and the number and importance of
related legislative and administrative initiatives rose rapidly.
This pattern was by no means unique to Germany; very similar debates
were fought out throughout Europe, its colonial sphere, and North America.
Historians of modern Western societies have therefore long been drawn to
the assertion that these debates about sexuality are characteristic of European
and American modernity – of societies experiencing the very broad complex of
economic, social, cultural, and political changes that reshaped European and
American societies between the middle of the nineteenth (or, some argue, the
middle of the eighteenth) and the last third of the twentieth century. There is,
various historians have suggested, a distinctive connection between sexuality
and modernity: a particular transformation of sexuality is one of that broader
complex of changes or indeed is constitutive of important social and cultural
aspects of modernity.
The single most influential argument of this kind was made by Michel Foucault, who argued at the end of the 1970s that changes in ideas about and
practices of sexuality were foundational to the creation of the modern social
order in Europe in the two centuries after about 1750. Sexuality as a set of ideas
and practices, Foucault argued, was produced and deployed as perhaps the crucial technology of governmentality (how societies govern themselves) from the
late eighteenth century onward. The power/knowledge of sexual experts who
developed ways of administering life (that is, both individual bodies and populations or demographics) was a new modality of social discipline – a new
way of constructing a conceptual and social order that limited, constrained,
and defined options for individual and collective behavior – and thus was one
of the pillars of a new social order. Foucault’s assessment of this new system
of discipline, this new mode of ordering society, was extraordinarily grim. He
regarded National Socialism as a particularly “cunning” transitional combination of the old regime order of blood (power based on the efficient distribution
of death by the sovereign) and the new order of sex (power based on the management of life by experts); mass sterilization, mass public health propaganda,
and mass murder were “paroxysms” of the new “disciplinary power” over
sex/life, in which a complex of interrelated modern institutions, including both
the state and various fields of social science and social work, took upon itself
responsibility for managing (improving, purifying, and protecting) the physical
qualities of both individual bodies and the entire national population.1
Lawrence Birken, writing ten years after Foucault, offered a very different
analysis of the relationship between sexuality and modernity. Birken argued
that the modern conception of sexuality was directly connected to the emergence of democracy in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. The disintegration of a holistic premodern worldview in which different people had
1

See Michel Foucault, The History of Sexuality: An Introduction, vol. I (New York: Vintage,
1990), here esp. p. 149.

4

Sex, Freedom, and Power in Imperial Germany, 1880–1914

particular, different characteristics, rights, and social – and sexual – functions,
and its replacement by a new worldview in which all people are characterized by desire and pursue their pleasures in an open market, was foundational
to the emergence of the idea of equal and universal democratic, rights-based
citizenship. The valorization of desire as universal and productive was central not only to the development of a modern sexual culture but also to the
development of the consumer economy (which is founded on desire for things,
not for bodies), and thereby to the construction of the political economy of
modern democracies. As a transitional ideological formation characteristic of
the shift from a protoindustrial economy of scarcity to an industrial economy
of abundance, sexology did seek to defend sexual difference and normative
“heterogenitality” (Birken’s term for the heterosexual family). Nevertheless, its
own logic was ultimately and unavoidably a democratizing one; and in three
rapid, successive stages in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries,
it moved inexorably toward the “extension of the democratic model to the
furthest conceivable limit,” at which every human being has equal rights, and
the desires and needs of every individual are as valid and important as those
of every other. The disintegration of restrictive conceptions of sexuality and
sexual morality corresponded to, and indeed underlay, the articulation and
realization of “a succession of increasingly less restricted, symbolic definitions
of citizenship” in the political sense.2
The almost exactly diametrical opposition between these two conceptions
of the relationship between sex and politics in the modern Euro-American
world is symptomatic of a broader divergence in historians’ assessment of the
political potentials of modern societies. As A. Dirk Moses put it in an essay of
2008, whereas some have seen modernity as a “byword for material and intellectual advancement, national liberation and international peace, individual
freedom and enlightenment,” others have seen modernity as the age of “racist
utopias and totalizing visions of purity, soulless bureaucracy and the omnipotent state.”3 Mark Roseman pointed to the same pattern in 2011: “In rejecting
older modernization theories’ normative assumptions” about the emancipatory
logic of modernity, he suggested, “we have often produced a new moralizing
counter-narrative about modernity’s ‘fatal potential.’”4
2

Lawrence Birken, Consuming Desire: Sexual Science and the Emergence of a Culture of Abundance, 1871–1914 (Ithaca, NY: Cornell University Press, 1988), pp. 95, 133, 132.
3 A. Dirk Moses, “Genocide and Modernity,” in The Historiography of Genocide, ed. Dan Stone
(Basingstoke: Palgrave MacMillan, 2008), p. 157.
4 Mark Roseman, “National Socialism and the End of Modernity,” American Historical Review

Young-Sun Hong, “Neither Singular nor Alternative: Narratives of Modernity and Welfare in
Germany, 1870–1945,” Social History 30 (2005): 133–153; Dennis Sweeney, “Reconsidering
the Modernity Paradigm: Reform Movements, the Social and the State in Wilhelmine Germany,”
Social History 31 (2006): 405–434.

Sex, Politics, and Modernity I

5

This is a problem that has been particularly acute for historians of Germany,
because the disastrous rise and self-destruction of National Socialism has posed
the question whether totalitarianism and mass murder are logical or even necessary outcomes of modernization – or not. According to Hans-Ulrich Wehler’s
influential account based on modernization theory, published in 1969, Germany’s disastrous early twentieth-century history was at root the result of
Germany’s imperfect modernization – the fact that while economy, society,
and culture were modernizing rapidly in Germany in the late nineteenth and
early twentieth centuries, its political structure was not.5 More recently, numerous historians have understood the German catastrophe as a product not of a
deficit of modernity but of a particularly virulent form of modernity. The process of economic, social, and cultural modernization was particularly rapid and
comprehensive, and hence stressful, in Germany; and this made many Germans
especially susceptible to the appeal of radical social engineering projects.6 Modern German history was, in short, a case study in the dangers of “an extreme
form of technocratic reason” and of “early twentieth-century modernity’s dark
side.”7
In recent years, a growing number of historians have begun to express dissatisfaction with the tendency toward teleology in both these models. Modern
societies, they hold, are very complex and are unlikely to be characterized by
any unitary “logic” of development. They have, evidently, multiple and contradictory potentials.8 Twentieth-century Germany was home to both National
Socialism and one of the most successful liberal-democratic welfare states on
the planet. Both were modern, in the sense that they built on the whole complex
of changes that make up modernization – scientific and industrial development,
mass political participation, the growth of the mass media, and so on. With
respect specifically to sexuality, modernization leads to the retreat of prohibitions and conventions in sexual life; but it also leads to the expansion of
regulation and normalization by experts, agencies, and the media. Reasoning
from such dichotomies, some historians argue that the concept of modernity
is not a very useful one. As Mark Roseman put it, “the basic ingredients of
modernity allow for such massively varying societal outcomes and such huge
5

Hans Ulrich Wehler, The German Empire, 1871–1918 (Dover, NH: Berg, 1985).
See, e.g., Peter Fritzsche, “Did Weimar Fail?” Journal of Modern History 68 (1996) and “Nazi
Modern,” Modernism/Modernity 3 (1996); Detlev Peukert, “Der ‘Traum der Vernunft,’” in
Max Webers Diagnose der Moderne, ed. Detlev Peukert (Göttingen: Vandenhoeck & Ruprecht,
1989); Detlev J. K. Peukert, “The Genesis of the ‘Final Solution’ from the Spirit of Science,” in
Reevaluating the Third Reich, ed. Thomas Childers and Jane Kaplan (New York: Holmes &
Meier, 1993).
7 Joan Quataert, “Introduction 2: Writing the History of Women and Gender in Imperial
Germany,” in Society, Culture, and the State in Germany, 1870–1930, ed. Geoff Eley (Ann
Arbor: University of Michigan Press, 1996), p. 103.
8 See Edward Ross Dickinson, “Not So Scary After All? Reform in Imperial and Weimar
Germany,” Central European History 43 (2010): 149–172.
6

6

Sex, Freedom, and Power in Imperial Germany, 1880–1914

differences between successive epochs as to give modernity very little explanatory power” at all.9
This book starts from the premise that there is another, more fruitful question we can ask about the political potentials of modernization – including
its sexual-political potentials. We cannot dispense with the terms “modernity”
and “modernization,” because they are there, as brute historical facts, measurable in statistics on steel production, beer consumption, membership in professional organizations, participation in elections, print runs and circulations, and
so on and so forth, endlessly, across all realms of social, economic, political,
scientific, and cultural life. But modernity “explains” why particular things
happened in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries only in the sense that it
is the medium in which they happened – a condition, not a cause, of their
occurrence. Rather than asking what modernity “causes” (or “explains”),
therefore, we really should ask this: what does modernity make possible?
Once we ask this question, the logic of modernity becomes obvious; indeed,
the conundrum becomes the answer to the conundrum. What modernity “does”
is to generate multiple new possibilities. Modern politics is the reaction to and
struggle over the new and complex set of societal choices created by those
possibilities. If we give up the job of reducing the complexity of modernity to a
unitary, coherent dynamic or logic (as, for example, Birken and Foucault seek
to do), then we immediately create a new and much more interesting job for
ourselves: to figure out the dynamics of the complexity modernity generates.
This book, then, explores the ideas, social foundations, and development
of, and the interactions between, multiple competing movements that championed quite divergent proposals for reformulating the place of sex in German
society in response to the transformation of modernization, between 1880 and
1914. The three central findings of the following chapters may be summarized,
schematically, as follows.
First, the debate over sexual morality and sexual practices was cast by all
participants explicitly in political terms. Sexuality, sexual practices, and sexual
morality were understood to be directly and profoundly related to fundamental
political principles. In particular, again, sexuality was central to all parties’
understandings of how to combine power with freedom, both at the individual
level (and even within the person, as psychological characteristics) and in the
formal, constitutional sense. Furthermore, sexuality was a political issue also
in the sense that different positions in the debate over sex corresponded in very
concrete and tangible ways to the interests and agendas of particular social
groups – such as the clergy, doctors, teachers, the police, cultural and media
entrepreneurs, and so on.
Second, what was of decisive importance in this field was not that the
debate was moving in any particular direction, toward any particular crisis
or resolution, but rather that it was moving in all directions at once. It was
9

Roseman, “National Socialism and the End,” pp. 700–701, 689.

Sex, Politics, and Modernity I

7

characterized by the progressively clearer and more forceful articulation of
a rapidly proliferating menagerie of positions. And the champions of every
one of those positions were able, to one degree or another, to gain leverage
on public opinion and public policy (whether at the national, state, or local
level, and whether in the courts, in legislative bodies, or through administrative
agencies). From the historians’ perspective it is this rapid intensification and
diversification of the debate and the struggle to control policy that is most
significant, not the particular commitments of any one group.
Third, the debate between these rapidly multiplying positions, seen as a
whole, was a dynamic system. The individual groups and discourses engaged
evolved rapidly precisely because they were in dialogue and often confrontation with one another. The conflicts among them intensified their efforts to
mobilize their potential constituencies – and their success in doing so. Many
of them also shifted ground quite substantially in response to such conflicts,
or as they mobilized wider and less homogeneous constituencies. Quite often
they fractured as a result of such shifts, generating still further positions and
organizations. Ultimately, the fragments began to coalesce again into broader
camps or groupings – a development that only further ramped up the intensity
of conflict and mobilization. This is the real story of this period. What was
most important was not the articulation and advance of inherently dangerous
or inherently democratic ideas but the simultaneous and ramifying advance of
a large number and variety of ideas, a steady expansion of the dialogue and
debate among them, and the escalating mobilization of social groups in support of them. This is the political logic of modernity – a logic of intensifying
cultural, social, and political plurality and mobilization.
There is a very substantial historical literature on the politics of sexuality in
late nineteenth- and early twentieth-century Germany. Most of the intellectual
developments, reform movements, legislative debates, and key figures discussed
in the following chapters have been the subject at least of a few articles, and
often of multiple substantial monographs. Many of these studies, in addition
to recounting the history on which they are focused, also draw conclusions
about the relationship between their particular objects of study and the wider
discussion of the political potentials of modernity. This book is therefore in
part a work of synthesis, drawing on this very large specialist literature.
The agenda of this book is different from that of most of these more specialized studies, however. Most of the scholarly literature focuses on particular
movements, and often on assessing the political potentials – positive or negative – of particular sets of ideas about sex. This study aims instead to assess
the political potentials of the debate as a whole, as a dynamic system. Those
potentials cannot be read only from inside individual movements; they were
determined instead by the interaction between those movements, by the complexity not of ideas but of the conflicts between ideas.
Examining the activities and ideas of the many groups studied in this book
from this fresh perspective – “against” or in parallel with one another, and

8

Sex, Freedom, and Power in Imperial Germany, 1880–1914

with close attention to the broader context of the debate as a whole and to
the consequences for their thinking and activism of interactions between multiple different groups – has required systematically going back to the sources,
reexamining even publications and archives that have been relatively intensively
studied (as well as many that have not). Unfortunately, that has in many cases at
least partially obscured my debt to the scholarly literature. Often, for example, I
first followed the research trail left by specialists who have examined particular
organizations or ideas to the relevant archives, publications, or personalities,
and I then built out from there. The reader willing to consult the footnotes
will find references to the specialist works I consulted. But of course, in addition, and more broadly, this book builds on, and is a product of, some two or
three decades of very active, indeed vibrant, scholarly discussion and research
in the modern history of sexuality, and the questions – and excitement –
it has generated. In particular, this book has been inspired and informed by the
very lively engagement with social theory characteristic of the literature on the
history of sexuality (which I have addressed in a number of other publications).
But given the aims of this book – to bring to life in a sense an entire world
of ideas and organizations, in all its complexity, its interconnections, and its
entanglements – the approach taken here is necessarily and deliberately highly
empirical.
In particular, this book also deliberately eschews the aim of understanding
the relationship of the debate over sex in the 1900s to the origins of National
Socialism, or to its rise to power in the 1930s. Again, this has been one of
the central concerns of the literature on the history of sexuality specifically
in Germany, as well as a focus of interest in the discussion of social theory
more broadly. My research has convinced me, however, that the period before
1914 has to be understood on its own terms. World War I was a caesura of
enormous importance in German history, specifically too in the history of the
politics of sexuality in Germany. But the particular nature of the impact of
the war and its consequences (up to and including the Great Depression and
Nazism) was determined by the structure of the society that passed through
those crises, and by the potentials it harbored. Ironically, therefore, ending this
book in 1914 is actually the most effective way accurately to reconstruct the
continuities between 1880 and 1933. We must reconstruct the world of 1913
to understand how it differed from that of 1930; and only once we do can we
understand why its parts – people, movements, and institutions – responded as
they did to the challenges they faced between 1914 and 1929.
This book is divided into three parts. Part I examines the various organizations that championed one or another variety of sexual conservatism in
Imperial Germany. Some of these groups, particularly of conservative Protestant men, were formed very early on in the development of the debate over
sexual morality, in the 1880s, and persisted right down to 1914; others, particularly of Catholic men, formed after the turn of the century and flourished
only in the last six or seven years before the war. These groups are addressed in

Sex, Politics, and Modernity I

9

Chapters 1–3. A second wave of conservative morality organizations emerged
in the 1890s and 1900s; in particular, in this period both conservative religious
women’s groups and politically and theologically liberal women’s organizations transformed the debate over morality. All these groups, and their impact
on the ideas of conservative religious men, are addressed in Chapter 4. Chapter 5 discusses the successes and failures – in legislatures and city halls, in
the courts, and in public opinion – of this broad range of moral conservative
organizations.
Part II examines the various organizations that championed one or another –
and often quite divergent – varieties of sexual radicalism. Most of these groups
formed between the late 1890s and 1905; and most of them also passed through
an important period of crisis, adjustment, and radicalization between 1907
and 1910. Chapter 6 examines the evolution of Social Democratic thinking
regarding sexual morality, which was foundational for sexual radicalism of all
varieties early on and continued to be crucially influential right down to 1914.
Chapter 7 examines the homosexual rights movement that took organizational
form in 1896/1897. Chapter 8 examines medical doctors’ organized campaign
against venereal disease, starting in 1902. Chapters 9 and 10 examine the
ideas and activities of the sex-reform movement that took organized form in
1904/1905. All five chapters trace a process of evolution and radicalization
driven by a whole set of internal conflicts and crises in the years between 1906
and 1910.
Part III examines the broad and escalating confrontation between these various groupings as it developed after about 1908. One development of this period
was the emergence of the diffuse but important – and very vocal – new science
of sexology (Sexualwissenschaft), and its bifurcation into bitterly opposed left
and right factions as a consequence of a growing confrontation with sex reform
and the women’s movements, on the one hand, and moral conservatives, on
the other. This is the topic of Chapter 11. Chapter 12 lays out the broader
escalating complex of confrontations between these three loose groupings –
religious moral conservatives, socialist and democratic sexual radicals, and
men committed both to the exclusive authority of science and to masculine
privilege.
The conclusion, finally, lays out the key findings of this study and returns to
an assessment of the more theoretical questions addressed in this introduction.
It elaborates an explanation of the book’s findings that is rooted in the social
and institutional history analyzed in the body of the book. And it offers some
reflections on the deeper structure of Germans’ thinking about sex and politics
in the period before World War I, and of the ultimate stakes that those involved
in the debate over sexual morality thought they were playing for. Ultimately,
beneath all the complexity of the debate, it suggests, those involved believed
that the “problem” of sexuality posed a stark question: what does it mean to
be, or to fail to be, human? The answer to this simple question, it turned out,
was not simple; and it got ever less simple over time.

10

Sex, Freedom, and Power in Imperial Germany, 1880–1914

Again, this book tells a very complex story. But it embraces that complexity
because we understand the political dynamics of modernity only when we
understand the full range of possibilities that modernization created. This book
explores one important thing that modernization made possible: the very rapid
proliferation of a remarkably diverse set of understandings of what the fact
that human beings reproduce sexually means for politics – politics at the level
of the state, politics at the level of interpersonal relations, and the internal
politics of the self. That proliferation in turn created an intense, escalating,
and ramifying set of political conflicts, with its own potentials. In the broadest
terms, the conclusion of this book is that the decisive political potential of sexual
modernity lies not in the politics of sexuality, in the sense of a particular political
tendency or agenda (say, democratic or totalitarian), but in the multiplicity of
tendencies and agendas it enabled and in the interactions among them. Perhaps
a somewhat convoluted formulation will sum this point up efficiently: what
was most important was not the politics of sexuality but the politics of the
politics of sexuality.

part i
MORAL REFORM, 1880–1900

1
Christian Men and Morality

I. The Origins and Structure of the Men’s Morality Movements,
1848–1914
The beginnings of modern forms of Protestant moral activism formed part of
the response to the perceived moral challenge of the French Revolution and
Enlightenment rationalism. That response was intensified by the social crisis
of pauperism in the 1840s and the Revolution of 1848. The Inner Mission,
an umbrella organization of Protestant lay associations formed in the latter
year, gave the charitable and moral reform efforts of conservative Protestants
an institutional focus in the 1850s and 1860s, and their expansion was further
fueled by the processes of urbanization, industrialization, class formation, secularization, and political transformation in the following decades – all of which
were regarded by conservative Christians as facets of an ongoing social-spiritual
decay. In the third quarter of the century, the Inner Mission was active in a wide
range of fields, from care for orphaned or delinquent children, to Bible study
and urban missions, and to temperance and religious and friendly societies for
Protestant workers.
From its inception the Inner Mission took an intense interest in matters of
sexual morality and public decency, and particularly in prostitution. The first
Protestant charitable shelters and homes for fallen girls and reformed prostitutes dated from the 1830s; there were eighteen such institutions in Germany
by the end of the 1870s, forty-nine by 1900, and eighty-eight by 1911.1 And
from the end of the 1860s, the Inner Mission was engaged in an intensifying
campaign to persuade the government to do something about the problem of
1

“Die Rettungsarbeit in den Anstalten für die verirrten Töchter unsres Volkes,” Fliegende Blätter
aus dem Rauhen Hause zu Horn bei Hamburg (hereinafter Fliegende Blätter) 57 (1900): 239;
Friedrich Mahling, Die Innere Mission (Gütersloh: Bertelsmann, 1937), p. 644.

13

14

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

prostitution, which was tolerated under the Criminal Code (Reichsstrafgesetzbuch [RStGB]) of 1871 as long as women in the sex trade conformed to local
police regulations.2
Because the Protestant Church was an established church, however, the
growing prominence of this issue put the clergymen who made up the majority
of the leadership of the Inner Mission in a difficult position. They were in effect
part of the authoritarian government, yet regulation was one of the institutions
of that state. As the leader of the most influential Protestant morality association
put it in 1910, the agitation of the Inner Mission had therefore necessarily been
“diffident” and “much too respectable and academic.”3 What was more, at
least in the early years of the movement, the prevailing code of sexual morality
and public decency made it appear potentially outrageous to discuss matters
such as prostitution in any public venue.4 In particular, well into the early years
of the twentieth century, it was widely regarded as in itself sexually immoral to
address the subject of sexual immorality before mixed audiences; but women
played a crucial role in the Inner Mission and in the churches.5 Some topics, as
one Berlin activist put it, simply could not be discussed “in the house of God.”6
By the mid-1880s, therefore, it clearly made sense to establish an organizationally autonomous and exclusively male Protestant morality movement. In
1885 the West German Morality Association (Westdeutscher Sittlichkeitsverein
[WSV]) was formed in Mönchen-Gladbach in the Rhineland under the leadership of Pastor Ludwig Weber – a leading figure in the conservative Protestant
workers’ associations and close associate of Adolf Stoecker in the Christian
Social movement.7 Two years later a similar group, the Men’s Alliance for Combating Public Immorality (Berliner Männerbund zur Bekämpfung der Unsittlichkeit [BMBU]), was organized in Berlin, under the leadership of Wilhelm
Philipps and other close associates of Stoecker and the Christian Social Party,

Christian Men and Morality

15

and with close ties to Stoecker’s Berlin city mission.8 For the next half-century,
these two organizations would form the backbone and organizational focus
of the Protestant morality movement in Germany. In the summer of 1889 a
number of similar groups agreed to form the General Conference of German
Morality Associations (Allgemeine Konferenz der deutschen Sittlichkeitsvereine
[AKDS]), with Weber as chairman.9 By the turn of the century there were fortyeight Protestant morality associations in Germany. Most joined the AKDS, as
did most of the provincial associations of the Inner Mission and a large number of parish councils (more than 200 by 1899).10 The organization held an
annual conference, distributed tens of thousands of leaflets and flyers annually,
published a regular newsletter (the Korrespondenzblatt), submitted numerous
petitions to governments at all levels (national, state, and local), and maintained
close ties with related Protestant associations.
The rapid consolidation of the Protestant men’s morality movement was
catalyzed in part by a desire to retain the initiative in a field in which they faced
growing challenges to their cultural authority from no less than three different
groups. One was a diffuse and localized set of nondenominational morality
associations, which were also emerging in the early and middle 1880s. Some
of these groups grew out of the temperance movement, which was organized
on interconfessional lines; others arose in more liberal Protestant circles.11 The
second group was the Social Democratic Party of Germany (SPD). For the most
part, the SPD confined itself, in its early years, to arguing that prostitution was
a by-product of capitalism and would disappear with it. But August Bebel’s
Woman under Socialism, which was first published in 1878, also offered the
beginnings of a coherent materialist alternative to Christian sexual ethics. Bebel
was one of the founders and most popular leaders of the SPD, and the book
achieved enormous popular success, seeing twenty-one printings by 1893.12
Finally, at the beginning of the 1880s, the international movement against
the regulation of prostitution, which had its origins in England in the 1860s,

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

began to gain influence in Germany as well. In 1875 the British, Continental
and General Federation for the Abolition of Prostitution as a Legal or Tolerated Institution (known as the International Abolitionist Federation [IAF])
was organized, and in 1880 what was effectively the first German chapter
was formed in Berlin, under the leadership of Gertrud Guillaume-Schack.13
This last group was probably the most immediately important challenge to the
AKDS, not least because the IAF appears to have been attractive to a number
of women’s rescue associations close to the Inner Mission.14
In the early 1880s Protestant activists sustained close ties to the IAF; Ludwig
Weber was even a member of the executive commission of the organization
until 1887. The principles propagated by the IAF were, however, in some
respects quite threatening to conservative Protestants. The liberal Protestants
who dominated in the IAF argued that the individual had the right to do
whatever she or he wished with her or his own body, short of compromising
the rights and well-being of others; the job of the state was not to enforce
morality or particular religious values but to defend the rights and freedoms
of the citizen. The organization therefore argued for the complete decriminalization of prostitution. Theologically conservative Protestants in Germany’s
established churches, in contrast, assumed – as Ludwig Weber put it in 1892 –
that “the state is the guardian of God’s commandments.”15 Until the early
1890s they supported, albeit with growing ambivalence, some form of regulation; thereafter they concluded that all prostitution should be criminalized.
(Confusingly, only the IAF position – in favor of both abolition of regulation
and decriminalization of prostitution – was referred to at the time as “abolitionist.” Conservative Protestants too favored the abolition of regulation; but
they were almost never called “abolitionists.”)
Conservative Protestants also looked askance at the leading role played by
women in the IAF. Their view was that women’s “principle task” in matters of morality “will of course always be the purification and cleansing

of . . . family life”; beyond that women should devote themselves to “silent
service,” for example, in protecting or rescuing their endangered and fallen
sisters. It was specifically men’s work to “fight with sharp sword against the
monster of vice” through public and political action.16 The founders of the
WSV accordingly decided that women could not be full members. None of this
was compatible with the principles and practice of the IAF, and in fact Weber
was – as he put it in 1910 – “thrown out” of the IAF executive committee in
1887.17
Conservative assumptions regarding gender soon came to be embodied in a
careful division of labor within the AKDS. Protestant women’s groups, gathered into the Women’s Association for the Improvement of Morality (Deutscher
Frauenverein zur Hebung der Sittlichkeit [DFHS]), formed in 1887, met with
the annual AKDS conferences; but the two sexes met mostly in separate sessions, hearing different speakers on often quite different topics. Before the
turn of the century the women’s sessions were addressed almost exclusively by
male pastors and focused almost exclusively on women’s domestic roles; their
journal, published from 1892 onward, was edited by a male pastor; and their
organization itself was headed by a male pastor.18
The origins of the Catholic men’s morality associations lie in the second
wave of the formation of the broader German morality movement at the end
of the 1890s, which saw the emergence of a whole range of women’s, Catholic,
Jewish, and interconfessional organizations. The issues on which these new
groups focused included not only prostitution but also broader cultural concerns sparked by the flourishing of the new urban mass culture. This second
wave is discussed in the next chapter. It is appropriate to discuss the Catholic
men’s groups here, however, because their agenda and activities were in key
respects quite similar to those of the Protestant men’s organizations created
more than a decade earlier.
The Catholic men’s morality movement emerged as part of the broader
flourishing of Catholic lay associational life after the abandonment of the last
vestiges of the Kulturkampf – the Prussian state’s assault on political Catholicism – in the late 1880s. The movement emerged first in the Rhineland, where
the Catholic community was more cosmopolitan than in the south and east, and
only later spread to Bavaria and the eastern Catholic diaspora. The Cologne
Men’s Association for Combating Public Immorality (Kölner Männerverein
für die Bekämpfung der öffentlichen Unsittlichkeit [KMV]), formed in 1898,
remained its permanent organizational core. Formally interconfessional, these

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

organizations were very much dominated by Catholics.19 Just as the AKDS
had very close ties to the Christian Social movement and to the Conservative Party, the KMV had close ties both to political Catholicism and to
the Catholic charitable establishment, including the Popular Association for
Catholic Germany (Volksverein für das katholische Deutschland, founded in
1890) and the national organization of Catholic charities (Deutscher Caritasverband [DCV], founded in 1897). Also like its Protestant counterpart, the
Catholic men’s morality movement built on a long tradition of rescue work
among women’s religious orders.20 Partly due to tensions between the more
progressive Rhineland Catholic community and the Church, the Catholic movement developed relatively slowly in its first decade. A national association of
Catholic men’s morality groups was not formed until 1907; once formed, it
did not publish its national journal, Der Volkswart, until 1908; and a full-time
general secretary was only hired in 1912. Thereafter, however, its growth was
explosive: it had only 16 member associations in 1912 but grew to 131 by
the outbreak of World War I; two-thirds of these were in the Rhineland and
Westphalia.21
Neither the Protestant nor the Catholic morality associations were large
organizations by the standards of the day. The Protestant men’s organizations
had somewhere between 10,000 and 20,000 members by 1910.22 The Catholic
men’s groups achieved a similar size only in the last years before the war; even
in 1912, their journal, Der Volkswart, had a circulation of only 1,600.23 Both
Protestants and Catholics published much larger aggregate membership figures
based on total membership in associations that joined as corporate bodies.
The KMV, for example, reported that, in addition to individual memberships,
seventy-three Catholic organizations – with a total membership of 15,000 –
joined; in Munich corporate membership of twenty-five other associations

added 50,000.24 Such figures for corporate memberships were not entirely
fictional, because both Protestant and Catholic morality associations appear to
have been well integrated into their respective broader associational communities. But clearly the men’s morality movements, more narrowly defined, numbered, all told, in the low tens of thousands of members. Both the Volksverein
and the Protestant League (Evangelischer Bund, formed in 1886), in contrast,
numbered in the hundreds of thousands by 1914.
The social position of the membership of the morality associations, however, helped to give them much greater influence than membership figures
suggest. Available membership lists indicate that between a third and a half
(depending on the locality) of the men involved in the Protestant associations
were clergymen and church officials, often of quite high rank; a quarter to a
third were government officials and military officers, again often in quite senior
positions; another quarter were businessmen, teachers, doctors, and artisans;
and perhaps one in ten were members of the nobility.25 The governing board
of the AKDS was even more heavily drawn from the governing elite: around
the turn of the century some two-thirds of its members were members of the
clergy, 20 percent were civil servants, and 10 percent were military officers.26
The Catholic movement was a less elite group; in particular it included fewer
members of the nobility, and teachers rather than the clergy played a larger
role in the active leadership. But it was still clearly dominated by prominent
members of local communities. Of the 118 chairmen of the individual chapters
of the KMV in 1913, 38 were teachers and academics; 23 were lawyers, judges,
or jurists; 16 were doctors; 11 were members of the clergy; 11 were members
of parliament or city councils; 9 were businessmen or artisans; and 4 were
members of the nobility.27 Of the individual members of the Munich men’s
morality association at its founding in 1906, a fifth were clergy and a fifth were
civil servants or members of municipal or state parliaments, a quarter were
teachers or academics, and another quarter were businessmen, professionals,
and artisans. Again, many of these men were members of the urban or regional

elite – university professors, judges, members of parliament, newspaper editors,
doctors, high officials in the church bureaucracy, and so on.28
Ties to the Christian church establishments also gave the morality movements financial and organizational resources far beyond what one would expect
for groups of this size. The Catholic bishops issued pastoral letters in 1909 and
1913 in support of the morality movement, for example, and the annual conference of German Catholics announced its support for the morality associations
already in 1905.29 On the Protestant side, again, a number of parish and
provincial church authorities joined the AKDS as corporate members, and the
AKDS was supported by church synods and by the church hierarchy, as well
as by the Inner Mission.30
Equally important, the morality movements often acted locally as, effectively, coordinating bodies for activities related to the preservation of public decency and morality that were in fact supported by a broad range of
confessionally oriented associations. Although individual chapters of Catholic
and Protestant morality movements had membership in the low hundreds, for
example, they were often able to draw audiences in the low thousands to public
meetings on specific issues.31
On both sides of the confessional divide, moreover, the men’s morality movement had very powerful political connections at the national level. Key figures
in both movements were members of the national parliament (for example,
Adolf Henning, general secretary of the AKDS from 1895 to 1902). Other
prominent parliamentarians were supporters (including, for example, Adolf
Stoecker; Reinhard Mumm, a key second-generation figure in the Christian
Social movement; Franz Hitze, one of the founders of the Volksverein and the
DCV; and Hermann Roeren, a leading figure in the predominantly Catholic
Center Party). Regionally, leading members sat in state parliaments, for example, in Prussia and Bavaria. The presence of these men in the state and national
legislatures gave their organizations an influence, at critical junctures, far out
of proportion to their relative size.32

II. Prostitution, the Men’s Morality Movement, and the State
For the great majority in the Protestant men’s morality movement, prostitution
was the single most important moral problem of the age. Under §361.6 of
the Criminal Code (Reichsstrafgesetzbuch [RStGB]) it was illegal to practice
prostitution if one were not registered with the police as a prostitute or did
not obey the regulations the police authorities issued. Each city had its own
rules, and systems varied considerably. Some large cities had brothels (which
were technically illegal); some had compulsory registration but no brothels;
others had only voluntary registration. Whatever the specific system adopted,
a large proportion of cities – particularly bigger cities – did have some form of
regulation; one survey in 1887 found that of 706 responding cities and towns,
218 enforced some form of regulation.33
Police regulations concerning prostitution were draconian. They required
that registered prostitutes submit to regular (often twice-weekly) medical examinations and subjected unregistered prostitutes to criminal penalties and in
many cities to compulsory registration (and subsequent regular inspections) at
the discretion of the police.34 They permitted compulsory medical examination
of women suspected of engaging in prostitution and provided for compulsory
treatment (in locked wards) of women found to be infected. In most towns,
they stipulated many locales (near schools or churches, in houses where minors
resided, and so on) where prostitutes were not allowed to live or loiter, or
public spaces they were not allowed to enter (certain streets, districts, theaters,
museums, parks, libraries, zoos, racetracks, music halls, and so on).35
The rationale for this system was complex. Whereas men were commonly
held to be dominated by an aggressive and potentially overwhelming sex drive,
most women were believed to be essentially uninterested in sex. What was
more, most men of the middle and lower-middle classes found it impossible to marry before their late twenties, because before that age they could
not afford to support a family, and contraceptive knowledge was rudimentary. There was therefore a period of some years during which most middleclass men’s sexual “needs” could not be met within the respectable familial
social order. Yet before World War I the weight of medical opinion held that
long-term celibacy compromised the physical and mental health of any normal young man, and that masturbation had frightful consequences for the
33

See H. Stursberg, Die Prostitution in Deutschland und ihre Bekämpfung (Düsseldorf: RheinischWestfälische Gefängnisgesellschaft, 1887); Abraham Flexner, Prostitution in Europe (New
York: Century, 1914), pp. 29, 130, 168–169.
34 Flexner, Prostitution, pp. 26–27; Anna Pappritz, “Die Parias unserer Gesellschaft,” Frauenbewegung 7 (1901): 131.
35 See Bäumer and Lange, Handbuch, pp. 156–161; Flexner, Prostitution, pp. 415–428; Wilhelm
Hammer, Zehn Lebensläufe Berliner Kontrollmädchen (Berlin: Seemann, 1905), pp. 22–26;
Dr. Stachow, “Die Kontrollstrasse in Bremen,” Zeitschrift für Bekämpfung der Geschlechtskrankheiten (hereinafter ZBG) 4 (1905): 84–85.

22

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

mental and physical health, up to and including epilepsy, madness, suicide,
and homosexuality.36 Equally important, it was also widely believed that men’s
sexual desires, if not gratified in an orderly manner, could become psychologically overwhelming, leading them to seduce or even rape respectable girls and
women. The whole system of regulation was made all the more acceptable
by the widespread belief that – as one particularly crass exponent argued in
1900 – some women were “born whores,” being “sensual creatures,” “lazy,”
and “work-shy.” Some psychiatrists held that most prostitutes were simply
“retarded . . . abnormal . . . degenerate,” psychopathic or “for the most part
creatures born with wicked tendencies.”37 In fact, in many cases, proponents
of the system explicitly portrayed prostitutes as aggressors against the more
vulnerable male. In 1899, for example, one prominent expert on venereal diseases argued that the prostitute’s business “consists in the exploitation of the
physiological-psychological weaknesses of men.”38
Not surprisingly, then, around the turn of the century a very large proportion
of men seem to have paid for sex. Surveys published in 1910 and 1911 reported
that some 93 percent of medical students and doctors had first had sex with a
prostitute.39 Another study found that, of men infected with STDs in Hanover
in 1907 and 1908, about nine out of ten had been infected through intercourse
with a woman whom they paid for sex.40 A third study, published in 1914,
found that 60 percent of men had first had sex with a prostitute.41
As one might expect, given the extent of the sex trade, the system of regulation was designed not to suppress prostitution but only to minimize the

23

damage it did to moral and physical health. Most important, compulsory
medical inspection and treatment aimed to combat the spread of venereal
diseases – which, in the absence of antibiotics, were effectively incurable. The
system was expressly intended, too, to be sufficiently unpleasant and restrictive
for prostitutes to discourage “normal” young women from entering the industry. And above all it was meant to remove prostitutes from the streets, thereby
(in theory) helping to protect morality.
The image of the sinful, incorrigible, and dangerous prostitute was not without appeal to conservative Christians; women who refused to be “rescued,”
in particular, could be stigmatized in this way. Within the AKDS, however,
the dominant opinion was vehemently opposed to regulation, and by 1892 the
Inner Mission adopted this view as well.42 In fact, the leadership of the AKDS
rejected every one of the arguments advanced in defense of regulated prostitution and characterized the whole system as beneath contempt.
As a public health measure, they argued, regulation was worse than worthless. Given the onerous nature of police regulations, women sought by every
possible means to avoid being caught and registered as prostitutes by the police.
As a result, critics generally argued that only about 10 percent of women who
made all or part of their living in the sex industry were registered.43 In any case,
it would have been simply impossible to arrest and inspect the huge number
of women – estimates ranged from 200,000 to 330,000 before World War I –
who practiced prostitution without police approval.44 In Berlin each police
doctor examined 1,500 to 2,000 women each month; in Hamburg police doctors neither wore gloves nor washed their hands between examinations, and
women often simply did not come to the required examinations.45 In any case,
obviously any system of inspection and compulsory treatment that targeted
only prostitutes and not their clients was bound to fail, because the latter
would merely continually reinfect the former. In order to be really effective,
the AKDS argued in 1904, the system of regular compulsory medical examinations would have had to encompass all those who engaged in extramarital
sex – about 20 percent of all women and 30 percent of all men.46 As Friedrich
Bohn, general secretary of the AKDS from 1904 onward, remarked in 1914,
the whole system was “from a hygienic standpoint just as ludicrous as the
deepest, darkest medieval superstition.”47

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

The Protestant morality organizations held regulation to be equally ineffective in securing public order and safety. Pastor Phillips of the BMBU dismissed
as a “vulgar lie” (gemeine Lüge) the idea that men were incapable of controlling their sexual drives and that abstinence was harmful for men; others called
variously it a “crazy notion,” a “demonic delusion,” a “laughable assertion,”
and an insult to decent men.48 Far from protecting innocent girls and women,
prostitution, particularly in brothels, merely accustomed men to abusive sexual
practices and actually stimulated their aggressive sexual desires. As Bohn put it
in 1912, brothels were “schools of perversity and of the most horridly vulgar
acts.”49 Regulated prostitution therefore resulted in a greater number of rapes
and assaults than would otherwise have been the case.50 There was, furthermore, a widespread conviction in the morality movements that the brothels
were fed by a thriving trade in deceived or abducted girls and young women
(Mädchenhandel, or traffic in girls).51 A system of debt-peonage made it impossible for women to escape many brothels, with prostitutes charged exorbitant
amounts for rent, board, clothes, infractions of the house rules, and so on.
And even women who did manage to find “respectable” jobs, leave the sex
industry, and be deregistered were frequently fired when the police showed up
to make sure they were not lying about their new employment.52 As Ludwig
Weber put it in 1888, then, “many prostitutes are made true slaves of vice only
by regulation.”53
In fact, the slavery metaphor was in constant use in the men’s morality
movement throughout the period before World War I.54 Regulation, Protestant
men argued, constituted a gross assault on the natural and civil rights of women.
As Adolf Henning, general secretary of the AKDS from 1895 to 1902, argued in
1897, it was a “profound injustice” that women involved in the sex trade were

subject to arbitrary arrest and medical inspection, whereas the men who paid
them were simply ignored by the police. This was an abrogation of “equality
before the law, the first principle of constitutional law.”55 And what made the
slavery metaphor most attractive was the idea that, in principle, the system of
regulation treated women as things, as a mere means to an end – “objects for
the satisfaction of lust, . . . second-class beings, even white slaves,” as the AKDS
put it in a 1904 petition.56 This was by definition ethically intolerable.
As for the general population, Henning held that the toleration of registered
prostitutes made many urban spaces effectively “markets of lechery, meat markets”; even on the street, “in larger cities prostitution thrusts itself upon the
notice of the disinterested observer against his will.”57 Some observers warned
that immature girls took registered prostitutes, who “do not need to work
and yet wear such nice clothes,” as role models.58 And the AKDS’s petition of
1904 argued that regulation “confuses the moral conscience of the populace”
by giving the impression that prostitution was not wrong and immoral but
necessary and legitimate.59
Regulation therefore undermined the legitimacy of the state and its institutions more generally; for as Heidelberg’s morality association argued in a
petition of 1902, licensed prostitution “stands . . . in irreconcilable contradiction with the very idea of the state, which should serve morality and the true
welfare of the nation.” As a result of regulation, therefore, “respect for the
state . . . is damaged in the most severe way.”60 As Wilhelm Philipps told a
conference of the Inner Mission in 1903, “the principle of the ‘necessary evil’
logically turns the state into a procurer and pimp.”61
Ultimately, however, what was decisive for the Protestant morality campaigners was not that regulation was ineffective or unjust but that it was sinful.
It was, as Henning put it, an instance of “disregard for divine order in sexual
life.”62 As the AKDS’s 1904 petition argued, Christianity held that prostitutes
too “are and remain human beings, beings with immortal souls.” Regulation
was therefore an “atrocious sacrilege, which . . . cries out to heaven and makes
a mockery of any sense of moral and legal order.”63

26

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

In contrast to their Protestant counterparts, the Catholic men’s morality
campaigners remained divided and rather ambivalent regarding regulation –
indeed, this was by far the most important difference between the two groups.
There were voices within the Catholic morality movement that condemned
regulation as vehemently as Protestants did. The first issue of Der Volkswart
in 1908, for example, carried an article that deplored the fact that regulation
“robs some of one’s fellow human beings of their dignity, and degrades them
to the level of animals.”64 In 1912, Joseph Mausbach, one of the leading
Catholic moral theologians of his day, told the national Catholic conference
(Katholikentag) that “the state’s authority must avoid anything that is the
equivalent of the legalization of vice, an amnesty for the seduction of youth, an
offence against public decency.”65 On the whole, however, it appears that the
majority in the Catholic men’s organizations accepted the idea that some form
of regulation of prostitution was needed. They held that most of the deficiencies
of the existing system could be corrected by adopting the “barracks” system
(Kasernierung) – confining women in the sex trade to particular neighborhoods
or dead-end streets. Under such a system, women could be more systematically
subjected to medical oversight and removed from public view, and more direct
control over the trade would allow the police to prevent the egregious financial
exploitation of women, or the recruitment of minors. The Catholic men’s
associations did not formally take a position on the question of prostitution
before World War I, and Der Volkswart carried an extensive series of articles in
1910 in which both advocates and critics of regulation and Kasernierung were
given a voice.66 Nevertheless, again, it appears that the majority in Catholic
circles regarded some form of more stringent and restrictive regulation as the
proper approach to prostitution.
But prostitution was also simply not as important within the Catholic movement as among Protestants. Catholics were more concerned with immoral
images, texts, and performances and came to a consideration of prostitution
rather late. The KMV formed a special commission on the prostitution question only in 1905, and the organization did not task its executive committee
with developing an explicit position on the issue until 1914.67

Christian Men and Morality

27

The Catholic position on prostitution might be characterized, then, as in
some sense more “conservative” than that of the Protestant morality movement. The latter, in contrast, adopted what amounted to a radically utopian
program for the complete suppression of the sex trade. In its 1904 petition,
the AKDS argued that selling sex should be made illegal under all circumstances (and that police regulation should be abolished); that girls under age
twenty-one found to be selling sex should be forcibly returned to the care of
their parents, guardians, or if necessary a reformatory or “rescue” institution;
that prostitution should be made not a misdemeanor (Übertretung) but a crime
(Verbrechen) against morality, in the same category as, for example, rape or
incest; that accordingly the standard penalty should be raised from maximally
six weeks to months or even years; and that, on completion of this prison sentence, women convicted of selling sex should be confined to the workhouse,
where they could be reeducated in “order, hard work, and a regular life.”68
The leadership of the morality movements was by no means completely blind
to the potential social origins of prostitution. Contemporaries were convinced
that the sex trade was growing rapidly in the decades around the turn of the
century, and it was commonly argued that a major reason for this growth was
the economic vulnerability of young and inexperienced women moving from
rural areas to urban centers, or of young women in downwardly mobile social
groups, such as artisans.69 As Samuel Keller put it in a speech to the AKDS
in 1891, “girls are almost always in such a situation that at any moment the
possibility can arise that their chastity is endangered . . . for the sake of earning
their bread!”70 And denunciation of the “hunger wages” paid to women was a
common theme in discussion of prostitution from the very outset, for example,
in the Inner Mission’s petition of 1869.71
Particularly in the early 1890s, a number of important figures in the Protestant men’s morality movements explicitly favored better professional training
for women, the principle of equal pay for equal work, and even the unionization of female workers to fight for higher wages.72 The Inner Mission discussed
the “goals and limits imposed on the women’s movement by the gospel” at its
1897 conference and came to quite measured conclusions, arguing that within

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

the limits imposed by “the natural characteristics given to woman by the order
of creation” it was “a Christian duty, in particular for men, not to establish
any arbitrary limitation . . . on women’s choice of profession or professional
activity, indeed to support and encourage her in every way.”73 Some Catholic
activists would later take up the same call.74 The morality campaigners also
regarded the “housing question” – the fact that the working classes lived in
almost unbelievably crowded conditions – as a particularly grave threat to
morality, because it made physical modesty a practical impossibility.75
And yet, the standard argument of male morality reformers was actually
that, although social conditions could contribute to the undermining of morality, individuals were vulnerable to the moral dangers of their social environment only because they were themselves not morally strong. Der Volkswart,
for example, argued in 1910 that the “deepest cause” of prostitution was
defective “strength of will”; “social conditions, late marriage of young men,
deprivation among girls etc. can then be added as secondary causes.” The
real answer to the problem, therefore, was less to address those social causes
than to ensure the “deeper penetration of the Christian faith, which with its
eternal spiritual ideas and powers is most effective in tempering momentary
desires,” into society and into the hearts of individuals.76 Protestants made
a similar argument. “All immorality,” one AKDS speaker observed, “comes
from one common source, the sinful urges of the human heart. Social conditions, be they ever so good, do not have the power to protect man from the
temptation within. Social conditions, be they ever so miserable, cannot rob
him of his moral self-determination.” As Ludwig Weber put it in 1903, “we
are no materialists, and therefore do not over-estimate the influence of socialeconomic factors.”77 The problem of prostitution could only be resolved by a
“religious-moral reformation.”78
The problem was that contemporary developments in the broader cultural
environment in which the morality campaign operated suggested that nothing
was further from people’s minds than such a spiritual revival. The most obviously dynamic and widespread cultural developments of the period seemed to
be headed in precisely the opposite direction. Increasingly conservative Christians understood the phenomenon of prostitution to be only the most important
product of a much broader moral crisis – the accelerating “sexualization” of
73

public discourse, which, they believed, fueled the lust and cynicism that fed
the sex trade. In the early years of the morality movement, concern with this
broader cultural phenomenon was primarily important to Protestants as part of
their analysis of the origins of prostitution. Increasingly, after 1900, however,
the tone of cultural life more broadly became an independent concern, pursued
in tandem with and not merely as a corollary to the campaign against prostitution. For the Catholic men’s morality movement that emerged at the turn of
the century, this broader cultural complex was in fact the primary motivation
for public activism.
For men in the morality movements of both confessions, this broader sexualization of public culture was merely the most visible and virulent expression of
a deeper, underlying evil: the growing influence of a purely secular, materialist
understanding of the world. The evils of prostitution, then, told them that what
their society needed was to turn to God; but all around them, people seemed
to be turning away from God.
Chapter 2 examines their analysis of this trend.

2
“A Spirit of Insubordination”
Popular Culture, Modernism, and Morality

I. The Demoralization of the Masses: Popular Culture
Germany passed through a dramatic cultural transformation in the two decades
around the turn of the twentieth century, characterized among other things by
the emergence of a whole range of new forms of entertainment and socialization, particularly in large cities.1 Those new media and new cultural forms were
enabled by new technologies, new marketing techniques, rising real incomes
among skilled workers and the white-collar middle class, universal literacy, and
urbanization. They were also encouraged by liberal legislation of the 1870s that
reduced interference by censors in all kinds of cultural production.
Of particular importance was the massive expansion of the print media,
enabled by the development of wood cellulose paper, the high-speed rotary
press, cheap methods of photographic reproduction, and innovations in marketing and advertising from the 1870s onward. The number of periodicals
published in Germany more than tripled between 1880 and 1914, as did the
number of books published annually between 1870 and 1914. The number of
newspapers published in Germany almost tripled between 1862 and 1885 and
then rose by a further 40 percent by 1914; and the average circulation rose by

“A Spirit of Insubordination”

31

230 percent.2 For middle-class Germans who had long regarded print culture
essentially as their own cultural preserve, both the extent and the tone of the
new mass market print media were an awful shock; they were “popular” not
only in that they achieved a new level of penetration of the potential market but
also in that they appealed to less refined tastes and interests. Among cultural
conservatives, much of popular print fiction, in particular, came to be labeled
“smutty and trashy” literature – Schmutz- und Schundliteratur.
The term “Schmutz” or “filth” was often used to refer to print pornography.3 But conservative Christians were actually more concerned about the
rapid rise and much greater extent of sales of cheap serialized popular novels
and serial stories in pamphlet form – which the they called “Schund” or “trash”
(in English, pulp fiction). The term was used to describe detective stories,
romances, cowboy-and-Indian stories, colonial tales, and adventure literature
in general, which appear to have made up the bulk of popular reading in the
late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, just as they do today. Often these
works appeared in serialized form; they were sold not only in bookstores but
in barbershops, street kiosks, and railway station newsstands, and by door-todoor salesmen (Kolporteure). By the turn of the century, Der Volkswart put
the total number of readers of “trash” at about 20 million – the great majority
of the reading public.4
Also of concern, however, were the popular and middle-brow humoristic
weeklies that proliferated from the 1890s onward. The most notorious and
well-known of these were Simplicissimus and Jugend; but there were scores of
less well-known regional and local examples – by one count in 1913, in fact,
there were no fewer than 250.5 Sensationalist reporting in mass-circulation
dailies, particularly on lurid crimes and public sex scandals, was also regarded

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

as a threat to moral discipline, as was the content of much of the advertising
that helped fuel the expansion of the daily and weekly press.6
As the popular print media expanded, the campaign against such “trashy”
literature was an increasingly central concern for the morality movement.
Teachers in particular were active in local committees established to vet books
targeted at the youth audience; but trade unions, charitable associations, and
religious groups also played a role. Already in 1891, the poet, novelist, and critic
Otto von Leixner established the Association for Popular Literature (Verein
für Volksliteratur) to encourage distribution of “good” reading matter; and in
1904 he and leading figures in the morality movement established the Popular
League for Combating Filth in Word and Image (Volksverein zur Bekämpfung
des Schmutzes in Wort und Bild) as a clearinghouse for such efforts.7
Of almost equal concern, particularly to Catholics, was the proliferation of
“indecent” images, particularly from the middle of the 1890s onward. The use
of mildly off-color cartoons and photographs in the humoristic weeklies, for
example, was particularly abhorred by conservatives; but still more maddening was the development of a mass market for photographic nudes, called in
German Aktphotos. Again, the number of such images sold was, by the standards of the day, enormous. The Munich police reported having confiscated
18,000 Aktphotos between July 1904 and July 1905 and believed that this was
a tiny proportion of production and sales in the city.8
The single most striking example of the expansion of commercial popular
culture was the development of the cinema. Starting with a few traveling shows
in the 1890s, by 1914 there were some 2,500 to 3,000 cinemas in Germany,
and an estimated 1.4 million to 2 million people went to the movies daily.
Karl Brunner, a leading campaigner against Schmutz and Schund in all forms,
characterized the growth of the cinema as a cultural revolution unique “in the
whole cultural history of the human race.”9

33

These new cultural forms were, however, only those that were most obviously the product of technological innovation. Conservative observers found
other forms profoundly unsettling, even if less spectacularly and obviously
“modern.” Of particular importance was the emergence of what might broadly
be called a modern urban nightlife, centered on a whole range of new institutions offering commercial entertainments and new sites for socialization and
enabled by the growth of the urban infrastructure – in particular mass transit
and electric lighting. These included “night-cafes,” bars offering live music and
entertainment (often referred to as Tingel-Tangel), dance halls, restaurants,
variety and cabaret theaters, and so forth.10 The mixture of sometimes crude
or racy entertainment with alcohol in these settings was particularly disturbing
to conservatives; but the new musical culture they fostered and fed off of –
centered around new musical forms such as jazz and tango, fueled by the marketing of “hits,” and sustained in part by a new technology, the phonograph –
also seemed problematic. More traditional forms of entertainment, however,
were also flourishing in this period; there were, for example, three times as
many theaters in Germany at the end of the 1890s as there had been in
1870.11
The content of many of these new forms of entertainment and socialization
disturbed cultural conservatives. In some cases, again, the term “Schmutz” was
applied to works that appear to have been more or less pornographic.12 In the
1890s, for example, Berlin publishers advertised such titles as French Delicacies, The Female Model in Its Historical Development, Amor in the Harem, and
Jesuit Affairs.13 Actual pornography was, however, of far less concern to conservative cultural critics than Schund – publications that, without actually being
explicitly pornographic, were nonetheless sexually suggestive, sensationalistic,
and lurid. Individual titles listed in Karl Brunner’s classic study of Schund (Our
Nation in Danger, 1911), included “The Murdered Chansonette,” “The Battle
over the Harem Girl,” “The Mysterious Coffin,” “The Butcher of Girls,” “Dr.
Quartz, a Devil in Human Form,” “The Adventured of a Hanged Man,” and so
on.14 Many such works offended because they presented fundamentally asocial
and exaggerated sexual fantasies – as, for example, in the case of one passage,

in a publication of 1890, in which when two lovers held hands it was “like
fire . . . , an electric current, a magnetic fluid!”; they “fancy themselves free of all
rules” and proceed to enjoy “all the highest earthly happiness.”15 One speaker
at a Saxon conference of the Inner Mission in 1904 focused particularly on
sexually sensationalistic Schmutz, citing titles such as “Sexual Aberrations!,”
“Crimes Against Morality throughout Ages, with Many Illustrations,” “The
Urge to Sin,” and “Memoirs of a Bachelor.”16
But critics were even more disturbed by the seeming obsession of popular literature with violence. As Karl Brunner put it in 1911, trashy literature
consisted generally of nothing more than “murder and homicide, dynamite
explosions, revolver-shots, stabbings, arson, mistreatment of women, skulls,
robbery, break-ins,” and their action included little more than “beating, fighting, shooting, stabbing, killing, robbing . . . seducing women etc.” And Der
Volkswart found a Karl May novel to be the “pinnacle of trash” not because it
depicted one rape and four seductions but because it included 2,293 murders
and two cases in which men were tickled until they went mad.17 Still worse
were publications that combined sex and violence – “blood and lust,” as Der
Volkswart put it in 1908, or, in the words of the leading Protestant anti-Schund
campaigner Ernst Schultze a year later, “sensuality and blood-lust.”18 Stories
that combined violence, misogyny, and racism were the absolute nadir. Brunner
singled out, for example, a Sherlock Holmes story in which the detective, tracing the missing wife of a college professor, discovers that she has been served
up to patrons of a restaurant renowned for its delicious sausages. The story
closed with Holmes’s remark that, since she was a lesbian, the woman had been
worthless in life but had at least become useful to humanity by the manner of
her death and disposal. In another story, concerning the Boxer Rebellion, Brunner objected to the implicit racism of scenes in which a prisoner receives twenty
blows of the rod on the lips (“but he was just a Chinaman,” was Brunner’s
sardonic aside), Holmes sinks a knife into the throat of a criminal (again “just
a Chinese”), and two crowds are blown up with bombs (“– just Boxers”).19
Conservative critics objected to precisely the same aspects of popular cinema as it emerged after the turn of the century: popular film was violent, salacious, sensationalistic, and crude. Critics were particularly concerned about
