the impact of such fare on children.20 Such fears were not stilled by titles like
“The Man with Two Wives,” “The Whore,” “The Red Light Quarter,” “Slave
of Love,” “Sinful Love,” “Express Train of Love,” and “Adultery, Decently
Depicted.”21 But the combination of prurience and violence was again the
focus of critics’ concern. In a 1914 work summarizing criticisms of the cinema, for example, Albert Hellwig cited a Swiss survey that found that Bern’s
schoolchildren had, in the course of the year, seen in the cinema scenes of men,
women, and children beating each other; of people being shot, stabbed, strangled, beheaded, poisoned, bombed, cast from high places, ground up, hanged,
burned, buried alive, tortured, suffocated, and bound to railroad tracks; of
arson, dueling, suicide, drowning and starvation; and of seduction and adultery. This, Hellwig felt, was too much sex and violence.22
Other visual media were almost equally objectionable. For example, in
1906 Ludwig Kemmer, one of the founders of the men’s morality association in Munich, was especially outraged by a series of photographic images
depicting sexual acts involving three children and a man in priest’s robes,
and by series depicting “Schoolgirl Gymnastics,” “Precocious Girls,” “Ruined
Youth,” “Boarding-School Girlfriends,” and pregnant women climbing out of
champagne cases.23 The morality campaigners were also annoyed by the sale
of reproductions, in postcard form, of Renaissance and modern nudes, and
by humorous postcards with erotic themes.24 And cultural conservatives were
repelled, too, by the prevalence of erotic and violent themes in daily newspapers. Already in 1889, for example, the Korrespondenzblatt was objecting to
headlines such as “Love-Drama with a Tragic End,” “Attacked by Pimps,” and
“Berlin’s Night Life.”25
At least as bad as the stories newspapers carried, however, were the advertisements they relied on. Conservative Christians found scandalous personals advertisements seeking “marriage” partners – for example, advertisements
seeking an “older, affluent gentleman, high civil servant or doctor” or even a

pastor, or a “ballerina bride” or a “really pretty, if poor girl, aged 17–21.”26
Advertising for contraceptives and abortion services, massage parlors, and
“educational” influences – a code word for sadomasochistic sexual services –
were equally bad.27 The morality campaigners frequently expressed outrage,
too, at the use of erotic, immoral, and cynical themes in advertising more
generally. The emergence of display windows as a key medium of marketing
in the last third of the nineteenth century was a nagging but important irritant for morality campaigners, who deplored the “impudence of the shameless
displays” (in the words of Hermann Roeren) they often contained.28
Furthermore, the whole apparatus of urban nightlife seemed to moral conservatives to be positively dripping with eroticism. “Beauty contests,” for example,
were widely regarded by educated Christians as profoundly immoral because
they “make of woman a display for lustful men’s eyes.”29 Popular music,
increasingly spread by the gramophone, could also give offence – as did one
song of 1912 that included the lyrics “I am a tyrant, almost a sadist / That’s
why I’m of such interest!”30 Cabaret and variety theaters, too, appeared to
cultural conservatives to offer a great deal of cynical and immoral entertainment, including among other things lewd songs, jokes and double entendres,
skits, and even reproductions of classical sculpture by actors clad only in a
layer of bronze paint.31 Of particular concern to moralists were the so-called
Animierkneipen, bars with female waiters who drank with the customers and
were often paid only a commission on the price of the alcohol consumed. Such
establishments, the Korrespondenzblatt remarked, were the “greatest markets
of vice in Berlin”; Der Volkswart called them “notorious dens of iniquity.”32
And conservative Christians regarded the modern commercial dance hall with
profound skepticism, particularly because modern social dances encouraged
people to, as one put it, “mimic . . . the unspeakably saucy motions of the body
used until now only as a form of advertising by whores.”33
All in all, it seemed to the morality campaigners that – as Joseph Mausbach
put it in a speech to the Katholikentag in 1912 – “today a lustful, exploitative
eroticism permeates all the pores of social life”; or, as the AKDS journal held

in 1911, all of society was suffering an “epidemic” caused by the “sexual
bacillus,” by the “cult of the sensual.”34
It was this universal eroticization of public life that explained, in the eyes of
the morality campaigners, the prevalence of sexual indiscipline. The emergence
of the modern, informal “couple” or “relationship,” formed often within the
new informal and commercial public sphere, was one more sign of moral decay
for those who saw formal courtship as part of the serious business of founding
a family and getting on with life. And the “relationship” was made possible,
of course, by the spread of effective methods of contraception – the wares
offered in all those “rubber goods” advertisements the morality campaigners
deplored.35 But even within marriage, conservative Christians saw contraception as abhorrent and unnatural. God, they believed, intended sex to lead to
conception; sex for any other purpose was immoral. As one critic put it in the
AKDS journal in 1894, “sexual intercourse serves exclusively the purpose of
conceiving children; that is simple, natural, and biblical.”36 Using one’s reproductive capacity “arbitrarily,” for mere “pleasure and enjoyment,” another
held in 1899, was “a disgraceful abuse of God’s gifts” equivalent to masturbation, child abuse, and whoring; it was “not love, but animalistic and devilish
instinct.”37 Catholics were even more vehement. In August 1913, the annual
conference of the German Catholic episcopate blamed “unbridled lust, coldly
calculating selfishness and greed, cowardly fear of effort and sacrifice” for the
spread of contraception, which they held “sacrilegiously resists the will of the
Creator, does violence to nature, frustrates the primary purpose of marriage,
desecrates it, disfigures it, strikes it barren.”38
But again, the morality campaigners were concerned as much with violence
as with sex in cinema and popular literature; and they were convinced that
reading or watching such stories produced real-life violence, as well as reallife sex. Thus, for example, Karl Brunner believed that Schund and Schmutz
in print and film induced young people to imitate their heroes, committing
robberies and assaults, running away, seducing girls, and even forming criminal
gangs.39 Ernst Schultze, a prominent anti-Schund campaigner, believed that
trashy literature inspired sex crimes, arson, murder, and theft, and that some

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

readers committed suicide when they discovered that they were not as invincible
as their fictional role models.40
In fact, the fear that popular culture undermined its audience’s sense of reality, that it was generating a generalized loss of a simple grasp of the real potentials and possibilities of life, underlay more specific fears that it was encouraging
sexual disorder, crime, and violence. The cultivation of an aesthetic of the sensational and fantastical, the morality campaigners feared, fostered a fundamentally amoral and adventurist ethic. Thus the Bavarian Ministry of the Interior
reported in 1910 that, according to teachers’ experience, trashy literature “over
stimulates the imagination . . . takes away [pupils’] sense of truth and reality,
makes them inattentive and idle, coarse, and violent.”41 Karl Brunner observed
that Schund was nurturing a generation with “overheated imagination . . . that
has lost all sense for sober reality, that no longer has enough healthy good sense
to distinguish between good and evil.”42 Indeed, cultural conservatives were
convinced, as the teacher and Schund-critic Heinrich Wolgast put it in 1899,
that “the sense of reality . . . has a very considerable moral side to it,” because
“truthfulness has one of its chief supports in the sense of reality.”43 Good taste,
realism, and morality were inextricably bound up with one another.
The forms of modern popular culture were, however, as disturbing as its
content. For one thing, many of the new commercial entertainments were
heterosocial – they brought men and women together, in anonymous, public,
and informal settings. For the upper and middle classes of the period, who were
accustomed to a very high degree of segregation of the sexes, this simple fact
was itself profoundly troubling. The cinema was the apotheosis of this kind of
invitation to immorality: young men and women, girls and boys, came together
to sit in close proximity, in the dark, and watch immoral stories unfold.
More important, however, was the fact that so much of modern popular
culture was commercial – that its producers and distributors were motivated
not by any higher aesthetic, moral, intellectual, or educational purpose or inspiration but simply by the desire to make money.44 In fact, critics held that it
was because modern popular culture took the form of a business activity that
its producers resorted to erotic and sensational content – simply because it
sold. The entrepreneurs who created and organized modern commercial entertainments were merely “speculating” on the sensual “instincts” or “desires”
of their buyers. Thus the Korrespondenzblatt observed in 1887 that the publishers of Schmutz were selling “immorality in the service of Mammon”; in
1908 Hermann Roeren deplored the “doings of business speculators without

conscience” who were ruining Germany’s youth by selling pornography; in
1910 the Protestant and Catholic morality associations of Cologne submitted
a protest against the “profit-hungry speculators” who organized “beauty contests”; and in 1913 Ernst von Wolzogen deplored the “base exploitation of
lasciviousness” by “industrial barons of the worst sort.”45
The morality campaigners believed, finally, that the new popular culture
market made immorality obvious and ubiquitous in a way it had not been
in their own youth. People were no longer ashamed of immorality, trashy
taste in literature, or low-brow entertainments; standards and codes that had
once moved people to engage in such activities furtively were being swept
away by the conditions of the mass market, in which, so to speak, everyone knew that everyone was doing it. Thus Adolf Henning observed in 1889
of prostitution that “whereas this plague used to creep around in the dark,
it now comes out of its dark dens boldly. . . . That’s the real scandal of the
century!”46 And for the Protestant theologian Ludwig Lemme, speaking before
the AKDS fifteen years later, the modern city was a place where “depravity goes
openly” on posters, in display windows, in bars, in amusement halls, and so
on.47 In the same year, the journal of the Catholic charities, Caritas, complained of the “ever more shameless public presence of immorality”; and in
their 1909 pastoral letter on immorality, the Catholic episcopate warned that
“one is reminded of heathen times . . . , when one sees how vice ventures into
the light of day with unconcerned manner, as if it were something completely
natural and obvious.”48 In fact, some cultural conservatives conceived of the
morality movement fundamentally as a movement of self-defense against a
new public sphere that was not merely corrupt but aggressively so. In 1892,
for example, one morality campaigner in Leipzig characterized the display windows of stores in his city as a form of “ocular rape.”49 Franz Weigl, one of
the organizers of the men’s morality movement in Munich, deplored the new
“milieu of aggressive mass journals, brochures, albums, books” about sexual
topics and insisted that the aim of the Catholic men’s associations was not
“to attack personal freedom” but rather to defend “the freedom of those who

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

want to raise their sons and daughters . . . in the spirit of traditional notions of
discipline and honor, morality and respectability.”50
Ironically, of course, the agenda of the morality movement was not to cover
up immorality again but rather to eradicate it, precisely by making it more
visible. The morality associations were agitational organizations; their goal
was to talk about immorality, to point it out, and precisely to bring it to
people’s attention and make them think about it. The position of the morality
campaigners was – as the BMBU’s Korrespondenzblatt announced in its first
issue – that it was only due to the “foolish reluctance to call dirty things by
their proper names” that the moral problem had “become so great that even
the bravest almost lose heart.”51 Ten years later Adolf Henning argued that the
task of the AKDS was “to bring light into the darkness . . . by way of publicity”
by “ever and again pointing to the danger of growing immorality for the whole
of our nation.”52 And in some cases the practices the morality campaigners
decried were in fact not new at all. In 1909, for example, the church council
(Oberkirchenrat) of Prussia remarked on the “bitter struggle” of rural pastors
against the “prevailing opinion . . . that premarital sexual intercourse is not
disgraceful, as long as in case of pregnancy the girl is taken to bride” – a
traditional practice apparently some centuries old.53 Regulated prostitution
too had a long history; so did the artistic nude. The morality campaign, in
other words, was a self-consciously modern movement, using modern tools –
in some cases to fight quite entrenched or traditional practices.
Modern – but not democratic. The morality campaigners were determined
to defend the cultural authority of Germany’s social elite – that is, themselves.
In fact, they often thought of themselves as the protectors of a broad category
of persons they believed to be vulnerable to the seductions of immorality, as
not fully developed moral subjects. That category included the young, women,
and also the working classes generally, who were regarded as “uncultured”
(ungebildet). Thus Ernst Schultze, for example, sought to protect “the souls
of children and the intellectually immature” and deplored the fact that trashy
literature sold door to door was “very often read by wives not only without, but
even against the will of their husbands.”54 In 1911, the Korrespondenzblatt
found it right and proper that the police should have enforced the removal
of a replica of the Venus de Milo from the facade of a respectable house in
Spandau, because such statuary should not be exposed to “the view of the
street mob.”55 In 1909 the editors of Der Volkswart found it disturbing that

medical texts treating sexual perversions were published in German, not Latin,
because that meant that even “the man in working-class dress” could read
them.56 Catholics in particular did sometimes argue – as one did in 1908 –
that “poison is poison, for the educated as for the uneducated.”57 The more
common assertion, however, was that uneducated and unrefined people were
particularly at risk.
In fact, in many instances it becomes clear that fundamentally the morality
campaigners believed that the thoughts and feelings of the uneducated were
by definition of no value. Only one thing was of positive value in their world:
Bildung – by which they meant the cultivation of aesthetic and moral refinement and of intellectual “individuality” (Persönlichkeit). The culture of the
uneducated, in contrast, was not culture at all. It was crude, ugly, out of control, irrational, animalistic, wrong, and not legitimate. And so were popular
entertainments. Joseph Mausbach deplored the “frightful crudity and thoughtlessness” of the audience for popular entertainments.58 Another Catholic critic
observed that movie theaters were “places of entertainment. And of institutions of entertainment in which those whom one generally calls ‘the people’
amuse themselves, and that turn a profit . . . , one can, these days, be a little
bit suspicious.”59 And Otto von Leixner remarked, in 1891, that in all his
reading of popular literature, “I have never once found a character that sought
happiness in the quiet consciousness of pure intentions and inner, intellectual
riches.”60
The morality campaigners were unwilling to allow standards of decency and
morality to be governed by the market, then, because the market was made
up of people whose “demand” was not legitimate. The market was unrefined,
uncultured, common, stupid, and primitive. And those who catered to it deliberately played on and exacerbated those characteristics. As Karl Brunner put
it, the market for trashy film was merely an expression of “cleverly stirred-up
mass instincts.”61 Ernst Schultze saw popular culture as nothing but “repulsive speculation on the lowest instincts of humanity.”62 One Catholic critic,
writing in Der Volkswart in 1909, argued that the profits of the commercial
entertainment industry depended on “awakening the ‘beast’ in man.”63
By the turn of the century, the development of “moral statistics” (the statistical investigation of social phenomena relating to crime and sexuality) gave
the morality campaigners what seemed to be an increasingly solid scientific

foundation for this fear. The rate of venereal infection was shockingly high;
the fertility rate fell by a quarter between 1891 and 1914; the rate of criminal
offenses against morality rose by 60 percent; and the rate of divorce tripled.64
What was particularly terrifying for the morality campaigners, however, was
that it appeared by the 1890s not only that their values were losing purchase
on the masses, trumped by plebian, market-driven commercial culture, but
also that they faced a self-conscious intellectual and political revolt within
Germany’s social elite – in high culture and among a middle class increasingly
itself oriented not toward the values of the conservative social order but toward
those of a commercial, technical, and democratic age.
II. Christianity, the Arts, and the Intellectuals
In some cases high culture no less than popular culture seemed to the morality
campaigners to be veering toward the lewd and semi-pornographic. A particularly illustrative case is the craze for nude or semi-nude dance as a spectator entertainment, which started with Isadora Duncan’s early appearances in
1903 and 1904 and steadily gained momentum over the next decade. Conservative Christians saw Duncan’s success, as one commentator remarked, as
“notarized proof of [moral] decline.”65 The performances of “She,” “Mata
Hari,” Mary Wigman, Adorée Villany, Gertrud Leistikow, Olga Desmond,
Maud Allan, and others, all in various states of undress or half-dress, were
greeted with escalating outrage, and there were repeated scandals surrounding
various performers between 1907 and 1912.66 The audience for modern dance
was clearly affluent; one critic even argued that ticket prices were affordable
only for the “upper ten thousand.”67 In other cases, the immorality of the wellto-do took less self-consciously sophisticated forms: for example, more
“refined” and expensive pornographic images and texts – sometimes dressed
up as pseudohistorical or pseudoanthropological studies, or as limited publications of erotic “classics” of Western European literature – or the middle-brow

43

humorous journals marketed to a “sophisticated” middle-class audience, in
which, Otto von Leixner claimed, “mindless, dull lustfulness rules all.”68
Of deeper concern than such entertainments, however, was a broader shift
in German aesthetic codes in this period. The fascination with sexuality and
gender conflict that suffused realist and naturalist literature before World War I
was particularly frightening. The prominent and provocative playwright Frank
Wedekind in particular conducted a drawn-out battle with censors in Munich
over his various plays focused on themes of sexual perversity, obsession, suicide, murder, and general moral turpitude. Other objectionable works included
those of Gustav Strindberg, Henrik Ibsen, Emile Zola, Oscar Wilde, Gerhardt
Hauptmann, Hedwig Dohm, Hermann Sudermann, and Leo Tolstoy, to name
only the most prominent. As one critic put it at a decency trial in Munich
in 1909, many modernist plays seemed to be mere “pornodrama” that “aims
at nothing more than to stimulate lust” in order to sell tickets.69 Modernist
literature, in short, was for conservative critics effectively glorified Schmutz.
The development of modern painting and sculpture was no less disturbing.
The morality campaigners for the most part did defend the nude in what they
felt was “true art”; but the modern art market made it increasingly difficult to
determine what was true art and what was mere commercial speculation on
sensual impulses. Thus the editor of Der Volkswart wrote in 1908 that “we fight
the nude not as such” but only where it “appears likely to affront the sense of
shame of a large proportion of the people and to have a demoralizing influence
on the youth.”70 But as the influential journal Die Grenzboten had observed
four years earlier, in fact, there was in all nudity a “dangerous proximity to
sensuality.”71 Protestants too sometimes found the modernist obsession with
nudity exaggerated – as when one critic, scandalized by an exposition of works
from the art colony in Darmstadt in 1901, remarked that “that was all we
were lacking – that the upper classes take pleasure in ugly displays, and so
undermine the foundations of their own authority and of their own work for
the moral elevation of the people.”72
Fundamental to this response to the content of modern art was a philosophical disagreement regarding the proper function of art more broadly. Many
cultural conservatives believed that aesthetic realism, which addressed social
problems, ethical dilemmas, and human failure with depressing consistency,
was by its very nature immoral. A deeply engrained belief in the direct relationship between aesthetic beauty and ideal truth – as opposed to mere earthly
68

quoted in Roeren, Die öffentliche Unsittlichkeit, p. 15.

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

and quotidian truths, which were regarded as inessential and ephemeral – was
central to conservative Christian thought in this period. Equally central was
the belief that it was the proper function of art to communicate ideal truths,
sublime and transcendent truths, to the viewer (or reader) through the medium
of the beautiful – as one critic put it in 1891, “to preserve through their art the
ideal values from which the nation derives strength and vigor and greatness.”73
By focusing on adultery, conflict, divorce, suffering, sickness, failure, corruption, suicide, and the general squalor of the human condition, the moderns
were betraying this proper role of art in the economy of the human spirit and
thereby contributing in a much more fundamental and damaging way to the
general demoralization of society than mere popular Schmutz ever could.
Of course, the champions of artistic modernism did not share this view at all.
They were convinced that they, too – or rather they particularly – were engaged
in a serious quest for the refinement of the human spirit and the betterment
of the human condition. In fact, many of the artistic moderns were pursuing a
strategy that should have sounded familiar to the morality campaigners: as one
group of booksellers put it in a petition of 1893, to “lead people to a better
life” by “holding up a mirror to the times” to reveal the “ugly and bad.”74 As
the Christian morality movements stepped up their attacks on “immoral” art
in the 1890s, therefore, they increasingly came into conflict not merely with
the stubborn logic of the market also but with an opposing intellectual system
and the social organizations and cultural networks that sustained it.
Even more shocking, after the turn of the century the morality movements
were increasingly opposed by a growing set of organizations that sought to
restructure sexual life in Germany in accordance not with Christian teaching
but with a new scientific worldview. The Scientific Humanitarian Committee
(Wissenschaftlich-humanitäre Komitee [WHK], formed in Berlin in 1897 by
Magnus Hirschfeld and others) agitated for the repeal of §175 of the RStGB,
which penalized homosexual acts between men – a campaign that Wilhelm
Philipps of the BMBU, for example, dismissed in 1903 as “an assault on
the morality of our nation.”75 The Society for Combating Venereal Diseases
(Deutsche Gesellschaft zur Bekämpfung der Geschlechtskrankheiten [DGBG],
formed in 1902) argued for a new, medicalized approach to the regulation of
prostitution. Worst of all, the League for the Protection of Motherhood (Bund
für Mutterschutz [BfM]), formed in 1905, agitated for a more permissive sexual “New Ethic” and such innovations as sex education, the abolition of laws

against unmarried cohabitation, divorce law reform, the legalization of abortion, and so on. But Christians were often horrified too by the ideas advanced
by the more amorphous new discipline of sexology, whose exponents advanced
conflicting and at times quite bizarre proposals for the revision of the German
sexual order.
To make matters worse, there were clear and direct connections between
artistic modernism, the scientific (or scientistic) philosophical position that
underlay the various sex-reform movements, and a much broader popular
health and “wellness” movement. Many on the political and cultural left in this
period argued that the nude in art was the embodiment of aesthetic and moral
truth freed from stifling and hypocritical prudery and prurience. It was prudery
and shame that made people immoral; a forthright, honest, and unproblematic
appreciation of the natural, aesthetic qualities of the human body was therefore
the best medicine against lustful thoughts. As one advocate put it, chaste and
natural nudity would have an “ennobling influence on every person . . . who
has even a trace of aesthetic sensibility and takes even just a little pleasure in
beauty.”76 The German nudist movement – yet another emerging movement
explicitly opposed to conservative Christian moralism – was aggressive in advocating such views; but they were central too to the appeal of modern dance, and
of the “life reform” (Lebensreform) movement more generally (including vegetarianism, dress reform, natural healing, fitness, and various self-help regimes).
Such ideas appealed in particular to a significant segment of the lower-middle
class: of the 450 members of one nudist organization in 1911, for example,
more than half were businessmen, artisans, engineers and architects, or whitecollar employees; only 14 percent were public officials or military officers, and
another 10 percent were teachers.77
But of course it was not only in nudist circles that a “natural” relationship
to the body was advocated. The years before World War I saw a lively debate
among German educators, for example, over sex education in the schools.
Supporters argued, as one article in the Zeitschrift für Schulgesundheitspflege
( Journal for School Medical Care) of 1907 held, that the existing “repressive
system” (Vertuschungssystem) forced young people to gain “half-knowledge
from impure sources” and contributed to sexual immorality and sexual endangerment through ignorance.78 By the years immediately prior to World War I,

some cautious experiments were in fact being made with sex education in the
schools. There was a growing body of popular literature for adults concerning “sexual hygiene” or “the hygiene of married life”; and public lectures by
traveling speakers, often accompanied by anatomical models and slides, were
another primary method of popular sex education.79
The loosely organized “neo-Malthusian” movement, which argued that the
use of contraception was a necessary and entirely laudable means of avoiding individual poverty and social immiserization, offered probably the largest
number of such lectures. The neo-Malthusians produced a flourishing popular
literature on contraception and sexuality, under such titles as “Fewer Children
and Happier Marriages: A Cry of Humanity,” “Secrets of Marriage,” or “The
Physiology of Love.”80 There was a lively market for such ideas: Anna FischerDückelmann’s guide to “The Sexual Life of Woman,” which advocated the use
of contraception to avoid the relentless cycle of pregnancy and childbirth, sold
600,000 copies in its first year in print.81
Such views were of course seconded by the producers and distributors of
contraceptives – for example, in the professional journal of German apothecaries, which published a letter in 1908 arguing that condoms were a “blessing
for the nation” because they helped prevent poverty, venereal disease, and
abortion.82 By the eve of World War I, the idea that the use of contraceptives
was simple common sense appears to have been widespread in German society,
and even quite mainstream organizations were willing to support it openly. In
1913, for example, the journal of the liberal Hirsch-Duncker trade unions told
its readers that the use of contraceptives was “not an immoral action per se,
but rather the result of a great sense of responsibility toward the children one
has already brought into the world.”83
For conservative Christians, again, such ideas were anathema. The German
episcopate, in its pastoral letter of 1913, excoriated those who recommended
such a “behavior counter to God and nature” and the “accursed industry” that
“lends them criminal assistance.”84 Protestants concurred: the Protestant theology professor and morality campaigner Friedrich Mahling insisted in an article
in the Korrespondenzblatt in 1909 that contraception no less than prostitution
or sexual perversion was “an expression of the dominion of sensuality over the

spirit, and therefore degradation of humanity . . . , therefore a contradiction of
God’s will . . . therefore a sin.”85
Conservative Christians in the morality movement were convinced that all
these ideas and initiatives had common roots in modern philosophical materialism and rationalism and in the growing faith in the natural sciences as the
source of truth and of moral precepts. The morality campaigners frequently
referred to this complex of ideas as “Naturalismus” (naturalism). They sometimes traced its intellectual origins back to the Enlightenment, but more frequently they blamed two key nineteenth-century figures for its prevalence:
Friedrich Nietzsche and Charles Darwin. Both the idea of the struggle for survival and the idea(l) of the “will to power,” they believed, were marvelous
excuses for people to seek gratification and gain without consideration of the
good of others. As Der Volkswart put it in 1911, in consequence of Nietzsche’s “superman nonsense” (Herrenmenschdünkel), “every no-good punk
who breaks the bounds of common decency in the heat of sexual passion thinks
himself a titan and is . . . seen by many as a banner-carrier for a wonderful new
age, a new culture.”86 More important, some feared that the anti-Christian,
Nietzschean, and Darwinist forces in their society were engaged in a concerted
struggle against Christian values. As the Korrespondenzblatt put it in 1900,
“the struggle rages between the divine-moral and the human-immoral worldviews,” and “unconscious anti-Christianity and self-conscious enmity toward
the moral principles of the Christian view of life” had formed an “armed
alliance” against Christianity.87
Despite such fears of cultural Armageddon, however, cultural conservatives
were most uncomfortable precisely with the plurality of opinions in modern
society. They were accustomed to thinking of the truth as unified and timeless, and of the social order as founded on that unified and eternal truth.
The extraordinary intellectual and cultural creativity of their society looked to
them merely like a chaotic and confusing proliferation of deviationisms. They
often described it by using the term “ferment” (Gärung) – which for them
had negative connotations of decay, disorder, and the danger of explosion.
Thus Ludwig Weber, for example, wrote in 1901 of the need to reestablish a
“unified and constructive” public opinion in place of the existing “fragmented
and fragmenting” one, by bringing “a Christian national spirit” once again “to
dominance” in the face of “materialism, pessimism, humanism, aestheticism,
Romanism and evangelical Christianity.” Ludwig Lemme, speaking before the
AKDS three years later, presented a similar catalog, and a similar program.
Looking around him, he saw socialists, communists, aesthetes, “humanitarian fantasists,” social theorists, materialists, “every architectural style from
85

Friedrich Mahling, “Grundzüge einer evangelischen Sexualethik,” KB 23 (1909): 51.
“Ein Skandal auf der hygienischen Ausstellung Dresden 1911,” Volkswart 4 (1911): 179.
87 “Pressstimmen,” KB 14 (1900): 59; Stölzle, “Zum monistischen Kriegsschauplatz,” HPB 142
(1908): 133, 139.

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

Roman to the most complex Jugendstil,” jewelry in every design “from Egyptian tomb-art up to the newest product of the hunger for novelty,” and, as
for Weltanschauungen, “the whole evolution since the ancient Greek philosophers. . . . In this chaotic confusion,” he concluded, “the Christian world-view
alone provides a firm standard.”88
The philosophical horizons of the Catholic morality campaigners were narrower than those of their Protestant counterparts, and Catholics were of course
always aware of the fact that they were themselves in the minority in Germany.
But quite similar judgments were common in the broader Catholic intellectual
milieu. Thus, for example, the Austrian Jesuit pedagogue Robert von Nostitz, in 1900, deplored the “jungle darkness of chaotic world-views” of the
present age.89 Others deplored the “alienation from God in our century,”
as expressed in “French liberalism, socialism, communism and anarchism,”
Nietzscheanism, “rationalism and atheism, hedonism and suicide-mania, precociousness and jaded spirits, perversity and madness, male decadence and
female emancipation.”90
The central problem, as moral conservatives saw it, was that intellectual
variety militated against the beneficial effects of moral authority. Already in
1889 one Protestant commentator had remarked in the journal of the Inner
Mission that the “waves of daily reading” to which people were now exposed
“wash away so many tried and true principles, sacred truths!” Increasingly,
“eternal truths” appeared to be merely “views just as open to discussion as the
hypotheses of the natural scientists and the political opinions of the parliamentarians . . . the press teaches us to interest ourselves for everything thinkable
and unthinkable, to find that most interesting which is least our business.”91
Two decades later, the pedagogue and moral philosopher Friedrich Wilhelm
Foerster, whose essay on sexual ethics and sexual pedagogy became one of the
key texts of the morality movement after its publication in 1907, complained
that “today every Tom, Dick and Harry thinks himself called upon to establish
his own theory regarding the most difficult questions of human life. . . . [T]he
ethical realm is, so to speak, free game – a playground for the most unprincipled dilettantism and superficial conceits.”92 Jean Bornträger, who in 1912

“A Spirit of Insubordination”

49

published a study of the decline of the German birthrate that was highly influential and widely cited within the morality movement, objected to the fact that
people were increasingly becoming accustomed to “feeling themselves superior
to the eternally unchanging commandments of morality,” daring to “construct
and act on their own moral judgments according to their own standards.”93
As one Protestant critic put it in the AKDS journal in 1911, then, the sheer
variety of opinion was an expression of the “tendency to insubordination”
that characterized “the whole intellectual tendency” of the times; and because
the spirit of disobedience necessarily extended to disobedience to the ultimate
authority, God, the result could only be moral, intellectual, and political disaster. The “subjectivism” of the age, the idea that “there are no universal truths
and no universal moral norms,” turned “public life . . . into a playground for
arbitrariness, selfish pursuit of interests and chaotic passions.”94
Again, there is a certain irony here, because the morality campaign was
itself one instance of the broader proliferation of nongovernmental organizations, philosophical currents, and “movements” in Germany in this period.
The formation of the morality movement in fact falls squarely into the period
of takeoff in the number of such organizations all across Europe – in the late
1880s and early 1890s.95 More to the point, the morality campaigners themselves quite self-consciously adopted the forms and methods that drove the
growth of the new public sphere and the cultural diversification they deplored.
Thus in 1889 one activist in the Inner Mission suggested that the solution to
the problem of “reading frenzy” and the disintegration of old certainties was
for conservative Protestants to start their own publications, so that the daily
press was not left to “the opponents of the Christian world-view.”96 Ten years
later, the Korrespondenzblatt would remind its readers that “if one wants to
gain any influence at all over the great masses of the people in our times, when
everything is hashed out in public,” then they must themselves enter the public
sphere and use its forms and potentials. “The daily press and mass meetings,
public discussion and agitation, these are in our times the necessary means of
gaining influence over popular opinion.”97
For the morality campaigners, then, it was only the mobilization of some
people that was desirable; only one kind of “public opinion” was acceptable.
There were large groups of people whom the morality campaigners thought
in Central Europe, 1890–1930 (Ithaca, NY: Cornell University Press, 2008), pp. 98–102, 106–

should not be active in public in any degree or capacity at all. Those groups
were the same groups that they categorized as “intellectually immature” and
therefore at risk of moral corruption: youth, women, and workers. In fact,
although the publications and speeches of the morality campaigners bristled
with broad-gauge denunciations of rationalism, materialism, and individualism, in practical terms they focused on two threats to what they conceived of
as the proper social order: Social Democracy and the women’s movement.
And yet, the morality campaigner’s analysis of the threat posed by these two
movements was hardly simple minded. In fact, they embedded their critique
precisely in a vehement rejection of masculine privilege and of capitalism.
Eerily, on occasion they reached what must have been, for them, a rather
frightening conclusion: that the insurrection of subaltern groups in their society
was in fact caused, perhaps even justified, by the moral turpitude of their
superiors.
Chapter 3 turns to this analysis.

3
The Politics of Morality, Class, and Gender

I. Christian Men and the Politics of Gender
Even by the standards of the time, the great majority in the men’s morality
organizations had a profoundly conservative vision of women’s proper role in
society, and of the proper relationship between the sexes. Indeed, the Christian
men’s morality organizations rejected women’s agitation for equal rights with a
vehemence that sometimes seemed to border on rage. This was particularly true
of Protestant men, whose intellectual traditions legitimated almost no female
roles other than that of housewife. Even the existence of the Protestant orders
of deaconesses, which did much of the day-to-day caregiving work in Protestant
charitable institutions, only just registered as a second-best alternative in their
rhetoric. Their position throughout the period before World War I was simply –
as the Korrespondenzblatt put it already in 1889 – “that woman belongs
in the house.”1 And these men had a profoundly patriarchal understanding
of what it meant for a woman to be “in the house.” A wife was not her
husband’s partner but his helpmeet (Gehülfin). This role was understood to
be the precondition for the very existence of the family. As one author put it
in the Korrespondenzblatt in 1899, “if woman as mother does not give her
children an example of obedience, the father cannot be head of the family. The
family disintegrates. It must be a fact in the home: the man rules woman and
the household.”2
The male Protestant morality campaigners did understand that some women,
at least in some stages of their lives, would not be completely occupied with
child rearing and homemaking. A commission established by the Inner Mission
in 1885 even went so far as to concede that it was “a necessary and in itself
1
2

“Vermischtes,” KB 3 (1889): 54.
G. Közle, “Der Mann als Familienvater,” KB 13 (1899): 69.

51

52

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

not objectionable result of modern economic development” that more and
more women worked outside the home. It insisted, however, that the state,
employers, and the charities had an obligation to ensure that the associated
moral and social dangers were counteracted – by protecting women’s morality,
banning them from jobs that were not compatible with their alleged physical
capacities and inner “nature,” and giving them “opportunity . . . to prepare
themselves for their calling as housewives.”3 And many men in the morality
movement in fact regarded even conventional forms of women’s work outside
the home not only as a moral danger but as itself essentially immoral. An
article in the Korrespondenzblatt in 1890 summed up this view well, arguing
that “woman must never seek to go beyond the boundaries of the calling
established for her by God.”4 Again, the morality campaigners did sometimes
argue explicitly that women should get equal pay for equal work; but they did
so, as the leading conservative Protestant theologian Reinhold Seeberg put it
in 1907, in part because this “appears to be the best, indeed probably the only
means of getting the woman, especially the married woman worker, out of
the factory again and returning her to her family and her duties as wife and
mother.”5
Catholics generally took a more pragmatic view of women’s work, but they,
too, often believed that anything but the single-earner family was not really
normal. Many demands of the women’s movement might be “justified” by the
prevailing social conditions, one Catholic commentator believed in 1901; but
those conditions themselves reflected a “sickness of society,” and the radical
emancipatory women’s movement was a “degeneracy” that threatened the
“basic cell of the social organism, the family.”6
Even where the male morality campaigners were willing to imagine women
working, their understanding of women’s roles outside the family was hardly
less restrictive than their understanding of what was required of them in it.
Ludwig Weber summed up this understanding of women’s broader social role
in an article in the Korrespondenzblatt in 1903. He conceded that “the demand
for the subordination of woman under man in the gospels is relevant only
within the marital relationship.” But he also insisted that “Christian morality
establishes limits for the activity of woman in social life, over and above the
moral commandments that are valid for both sexes.” These limits made it
“completely hopeless and downright harmful for woman” to try to impose
equal rights and equal participation for women in “all areas of professional,

social and political life.” Christianity required “loving service” of women “not
just within the home but also outside the home.”7 This was, of course, also the
Protestant men’s understanding of the role of women in the morality movement
itself – “silent service in the rescue of her fallen, and the protection of her
endangered sisters.”8
Many of these men, therefore, regarded the women’s movement as a product
of the moral decay of the age, of individualism, selfish pleasure seeking, materialism, and the spirit – as Seeberg put it in 1913 – of “rebellion against . . . the
order of nature.”9 Der Volkswart, in 1911, even saw it as an expression of
“the most brutal egotism” among women.10
And yet, at least within the Protestant men’s morality movement, such
denunciations were in fact less common than denunciations of arrogant, shameless, and immoral men. The leaders of the Protestant men’s morality association explicitly, consistently, and vehemently excoriated men’s behavior; and
they quite clearly believed men to be the primary authors of the sexual misery
of the age. Indeed, the single most important theme in the discourse of the
Protestant men’s morality movement, from its very outset, was the denunciation of the double standard of sexual morality. As the first pamphlet of the
WSV put it in 1885, the double standard “makes a mockery of all justice and
morality, and has to go. Whether it’s professional vice in the woman’s case or
habitual vice in the man’s, both are equally damnable.”11 From that moment
forward, with almost numbing frequency, the Protestant men’s morality movement denounced the double standard as unjust, illogical, and counter to God’s
commandment. Samuel Keller, first general secretary of the AKDS, was particularly vehement in a speech in 1892: “We’re still Christians, after all. . . . There
is after all only one savior for all human beings, only one grace. . . . The sins of
man and woman are equal before God.” Anything else was an “injustice that
cries out to heaven.”12 Again, an important part of this view was an explicit
rejection of the idea that men could not control their sexual urges; as Keller
put it, “that which one would gladly believe to be true, one believes most
easily.” Those who made this argument were secretly motivated simply by the
desire to continue exploiting prostitutes for their own pleasure – indeed, “the
economic interests of the slave-owners of North America were not so pervasive, not so effective, as the sensual interest of men are among our opponents

here.”13 He could only agree to the continuance of regulated prostitution, he

Keller’s suggestion was not unique. Friedrich Bohn observed in 1914 that
even after the abolition of the system of regulation, effective control of venereal
disease would require the “long-term internment” of incorrigible prostitutes,
and that “the same measure will be called for also for men who are known
to be . . . spreading disease.”14 Even the Catholic Volkswart, which took an
ambivalent position on regulation, did quote approvingly a leading Protestant
activist’s demand (in 1911) that men as well as women should be subject to
examination.15
The Protestant morality campaigners further asserted that seduced and abandoned girls made up a large proportion of all prostitutes, and that the men who
hired prostitutes therefore were merely cynically taking advantage of women
first plunged into misery by the lies and heartlessness of still worse men. As the
Korrespondenzblatt put it in 1890, “people speak today often of the Woman
Question. But the Woman Question is actually the Men Question. It’s men who
cast women down into misery.”16 In the early years of the Protestant morality
movement, its spokesmen imagined all sorts of ways to punish such characters – for example, by imprisoning for not less than one month anyone who
“causes a female person to permit immoral actions . . . by exploiting her material need.”17 And regardless of what the law said, the morality campaigners
continually insisted that respectable society must shun sexually predatory men.
Keller, as usual, was particularly fiery, demanding that the proper response to
a man boasting of his “conquests” would be to “throw these words in his face:
‘Scoundrel! Miserable cad!’”18
“Whoring” (Hurerei) and seduction were not the only male behaviors
that the Protestant men’s organizations denounced, however. The Korrespondenzblatt regularly carried articles excoriating the full range of male misdeeds,
reporting on both national scandals and “trivial” instances of men’s vulgarity
and sexual aggression. In 1904, for example, it welcomed the introduction of
the first plainclothes police detail in Berlin dedicated to catching men who persecuted women with indecent advances. Later that year it reported on the case
of a man who harassed two young women on a train so relentlessly that they
tried to pull the emergency brake and leaped from the train – concluding that

there are such men in Germany.”21 Wilhelm Philipps saw infanticide as “a
terrible accusation against men.”22
Protestant men were also horrified by what they saw as the prevailing contempt for women. Men were, of course, the primary consumers of pornography; and although the morality campaigners mostly deplored the effect of
such images on the men, whose lust and misdeeds they allegedly incited, at
times they also expressed their shame at the fact that pornography objectified
and denigrated women – it was “an impudent insult to the female sex,” as
Friedrich Wilhelm Foerster put it.23 Others objected to variety theaters on the
grounds that “respect for woman” was “quite systematically annihilated in
these venues,” or to modernist literature because it caused “countless readers”
to lose “their sacred awe of woman.”24
The Protestant morality campaigners were also aware that the consequences
of all this objectification of women were not born only by women working in
the sex trade. One held in 1908, for example, that “anyone who recognizes that
men and woman have equal rights will not belong to the many unreasonable
men who think that they can demand sexual favors of their wives.”25 The
Protestant morality campaigners in particular sometimes asserted that birth
control was objectionable also because it was a means for husbands to avoid
the social and financial consequences of their sexual exploitation of their wives –
because, as the same critic put it, contraceptives reduced the wife to a mere
“plaything of the man.”26 And a particularly heinous sign of male egotism was

the fact that wives were not infrequently infected with venereal diseases by their
husbands. Not surprisingly, the AKDS supported the proposal to imprison men
who knowingly infected their wives.27
In short, these men were ashamed and outraged at the behavior of their sex.
Indeed, all in all, as Weber put it, “the demoralization . . . of the nation is more
the fault of men than of women”; or, in Wilhelm Philipps’s formulation, men
“bear by far the greater responsibility for the moral ruination of our nation, and
on top of that like to . . . shift the blame onto the weaker sex. . . . A miserable,
despicable way to behave!”28
There was of course a rather narrow and demanding conception of “real”
or “true” manhood implicit in this broad-gauge condemnation of masculine
behavior. Men no less than women had a “natural calling,” with its own
strict demands and duties. At the heart of their understanding of “true” manliness was the concept of moral and social “strength” (Kraft or Stärke), and
of the moral obligation that it created. Real masculinity was expressed in selfdiscipline, in the ability to do one’s moral duty. This ideal of manly self-control
was ubiquitous in the publications and speeches of the male morality campaigners, both Catholic and Protestant, usually in abbreviated form – for example,
in the use of the adjective “manly.” Thus representatives of both confessions
called on their colleagues to show “Christian manliness,” “a proud ideal of
manly strength and vigor,” “real German manly outrage,” “strict and manly
self-discipline,” “manly standing up for piety and love of God, for morality
and justice,” and “the true manly courage” that allows one to “overcome
oneself.”29 As one essay on the sixth commandment put it in 1902, “Christianity does not know of the right, but only of the duty of the strongest.”30
This was, of course, not precisely true; in fact the morality campaigners
held that one gained rights precisely by performing one’s duties. In 1899, for
example, the Korrespondenzblatt explained that it was the “natural right of
any man” to have a family, and “in every man lies the calling and the will to
rule”; but “only he who fulfills his duty has a claim to this right.” A man had
to provide; he had to set an example of Christian faith and lead his family to
God; and he had to be chaste. Men who were not “have no right to a family.”31

Samuel Keller went one step further, insisting that “only chaste men are normal
men”; and Ludwig Weber even determined that unchaste men were not fully
human but rather “dragged down into the filth of animal nature.”32
Denunciations specifically of male misbehavior were far less common and
incendiary in the publications and speeches of the Catholic morality campaigners than in those of their Protestant counterparts. Again, the Catholic movement
was more narrowly focused on the moral dangers posed by immoral images and
texts; prostitution and, particularly, the image of the prostitute as victim played
a much lesser role among Catholics than among Protestants. Fundamentally,
however, Catholics were just as much aware of the widespread abuse of male
privilege and power in their society as were Protestants, and they regarded it
with equal contempt as the source of sexual and social disorder. Two articles
in Der Volkswart in 1913 sum up this view well. The first characterized feminists as “desperadoes” who wished to increase their own numbers by sowing
discord between husbands and wives.33 On the same page, however, a second
article pointed out that whereas misogynists blamed women for society’s ills,
“in thousands and thousands of cases it’s the men who seduce women and
girls, abuse them, buy and sell them, rape and assault them.” Fundamentally,
it held, men had brought feminism on themselves by neglecting their own
moral duties. The only answer was for “both, men and women, to subordinate
themselves to the moral law, and for each to acknowledge the honor of the
other.”34
As Ludwig Lemme put it to the AKDS in 1904, then, the morality campaigners’ ideal was a society of “humility, self-denial, pity, compassion” for all; or, in
Der Volkswart’s phrasing in 1911, of “strictness toward oneself . . . , renunciation . . . loyal fulfillment of duty . . . , selfless love, active sacrifice and heroic selfconquest.”35 The men’s morality movement dreamed of a society governed –
in the words of a speaker at the AKDS’s annual conference in 1892 – by “love
and justice . . . , good will and compassion . . . , honor and consciousness of
duty,” in which there was a place for everyone and everyone was in their place,
and in which everyone understood “that we are all obligated in solidarity as
the conscience of the community, that we bear a common responsibility.”36

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

II. Christianity and Class: The Specter of Socialism
Conservative Christians believed that this ideal of morality, justice, compassion, and solidarity was threatened above all by Social Democracy. Indeed, the
threat of socialism was omnipresent in their analysis of contemporary immorality; for in their view socialism was nothing less than enslavement by choice and
principle to anarchic, selfish sensual lust. Socialism was moral crisis turned into
a self-conscious political movement. This conviction rested on the fundamental philosophical difference between the two groups. The SPD, committed to
historical materialism, was in a sense the organization that best represented
the materialist spirit of the age – which conservative Christians regarded as the
root of the moral crisis of their time. The two groups were critical of many of
the same things – for example, regulated prostitution, the triviality of popular
entertainments, and the predatory sexual behavior of men. But their analyses
of the origins of such deplorable phenomena were diametrically opposed. One
Protestant observer summed up the disagreement succinctly in 1895: while
Social Democrats argued that the origins of the widespread sexual disorder
of the day lay “solely in the existing system of private property,” conservative Christians insisted that it was “actually rooted in the lack of Christian
conviction and religious-moral seriousness.”37
The connection in conservative Christian minds between materialism and
immorality was in fact so close that before the turn of the century the morality
campaigners appear at times to have been unable to imagine that socialists
would not support regulation. Thus in 1892 Samuel Keller argued that if it were
true that men had to have sex or their health would suffer, “then that party
that wants to create free love in its future state is right.”38 In the following year,
the journal of the WSV made the same connection: Social Democratic ideas
about love and marriage “undermine the most elementary structures of social
and political life,” it observed; “but the exceptional legislation on prostitution
is already doing that.”39 And as late as 1910 Der Volkswart referred to Erich
Wulffen, a district attorney, prominent criminologist in the field of sex crimes,
and defender of regulation, as “the DA with the Red Flag.”40
In fact, the morality campaigners were convinced that Social Democracy was
rooted in sexual immorality. This was particularly true in the early years of the
morality movement; as the SPD was gradually integrated into the political life
of the Empire, the rhetoric moderated, and the – later – Catholic movement
generally did not make the connection between sexual license and socialism as
explicitly as did the leadership of the Protestant movement in its early years.
And yet, the idea did persist. Thus the first pamphlet published by the WSV in
37

1885 argued “that Social Democracy and anarchism, which threaten the whole
political order, have their roots in this mire” of prostitution; and in 1913 Der

allies, the enemies of Christianity, and the frightening spread of immorality”
were all part of the same “moral abyss” into which Germany was falling.41
At the root of this association was a particular understanding of the relationships between and among desire, morality, and authority. Both socialism
and fornication, the morality campaigners believed, were expressions of unconstrained, uncontrolled desire for purely selfish and straightforwardly material,
or physical, gratification. It was this uncontrolled desire that led to the revolt
against authority; for authority – moral in the individual, political in social life –
was what constrained selfish desire. Thus, the Christian morality campaigners
were literally authoritarians; they believed that moral, political, and social
order is made possible only by legitimate authority. Indeed, the authority of
moral law and its representatives and agents in church and state was what
made human beings truly human, and truly social. Without legitimate authority, explicitly acknowledged and freely obeyed, people were merely a bundle
of animalistic passions and desires and were capable only of creating a chaotic
dog-eat-dog world of limitless selfishness.
Christian conservatives expressed this belief in a formula that appears over
and over again in their publications and speeches: that morality can be defined
as the dominion of the spirit over the flesh. The body, in their view, is the
seat of amoral instinctual drives; as Ludwig Lemme put it in 1904, “selfishness
resides in the flesh.”42 Moral behavior is the product of the triumph of the law
(human and divine) over the animal instincts, of spiritual order over material
chaos. Thus Friedrich Mahling asserted in 1907 that man’s essential human
task was to “master with the spirit the body in all its expressions and drives.
That is moral living. That man lives a moral life whose spirit rules his flesh.”43
In an influential essay on “Modern Education and Sexual Morality” in the
following year, Friedrich Paulsen, professor of philosophy and pedagogy in
Berlin, made the same argument: a human being was not simply “a system of
natural drives . . . a unique species of animal” but a spiritual being; to fail to
recognize that would be to “subject oneself to the contempt that mankind has
always felt for regression into merely animal existence.”44
Catholics used precisely the same terminology, albeit more sparingly. The
most influential statement on the Catholic side was probably a 1907 essay by

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

Friedrich Wilhelm Foerster – who was not Catholic himself but was highly
sympathetic to Catholic intellectual traditions and influential in the Catholic
morality movement. On this matter Foerster asserted “that nature is less than
human,” and that our mere physical nature “does not contain within itself
it own proper boundaries, awaiting them instead from the spirit.”45 Joseph
Mausbach, too, in his speech to the Katholikentag of 1912, explicitly spoke of
“moral self-control, the dominion of the spirit over the flesh.”46
Conservative Christians believed that it was the function of social and political authority and institutions to safeguard this dominion of the spirit over the
flesh. The state, the law, the churches, and the social order represented and
embodied a higher law and the common good, above and beyond the selfish
desires of the individual. The political order, in short, was not distinguishable
from moral order; the former embodied and enforced the latter. The foundation of morality was therefore the ability to obey. Friedrich Paulsen summed
up this belief economically, arguing that one of the “great imperatives” of
education must be “learn to obey! Obey, that is, not submit superficially to
outward coercion, but rather to freely take up into your own will the will of
those better and more insightful than you.”47 Joseph Mausbach made the same
point: the individual could only achieve “unshakable firmness” of the spiritual
self “against the temptations of sensuality . . . if it honors the laws of moral and
social order as the expression of the divine will.”48
The problem with Social Democracy was that it was self-consciously both
materialist and democratic. Because it taught the centrality and legitimacy
of material needs and aspirations, in socialism – as Der Volkswart put it in
1913 – “the animal instincts are not repressed but rather cultivated”; and
its political teachings “undermine respect for the authorities established by
God.” The result was moral disaster: “Whoever does not respect laws, whoever
acknowledges neither an earthly nor an eternal judge, falls victim to his own
passions.”49
Revolutionary socialism undermined morality, then; but immorality likewise encouraged revolutionary sentiment. As the Korrespondenzblatt argued in
1887, sin was the origin of “revolutionary tendencies . . . against all human and
divine order.” Hence “vice . . . undermines the foundations of the state. . . . If
a man rebels in such impudent manner against God’s explicit commandment, how should he have respect for [merely] human order?”50 As Ludwig
Weber put it in 1892, “we are in a condition of creeping revolution”

61

because fornication “gnaws . . . at all respect for higher divine and human
order.”51
In this sense, socialism worked in very much the same way that popular
culture did: it excited the sensual instincts; it accustomed people to thinking of
happiness in shallow, material terms; it cultivated self-indulgence and violence.
And “trashy” popular culture likewise encouraged disrespect for authority and
fed the spirit of disobedience. Thus Otto von Leixner complained in his seminal
essay on trashy and immoral literature in 1891 that in most such publications
“the upper classes are depicted as hard-hearted, pleasure-seeking, spoiled”;
such literature “nourishes hatred against the haves” and “contempt” for the
existing “order of the world” among the have-nots. It was only in light of “the
widely spread and spreading notions and passions among the lower classes”
(that is, Social Democracy) “that one can recognize what kind of influence the
majority of such novels have.”52 Others complained that “continual reveling in
blood and horror must deaden the moral sense, must tear the belief in divine and
human justice, in divine and state authority from the heart” of the reader, or
that Schund encouraged “mistrustful aversion to all authority, overestimation
of one’s own person, a tendency toward adventurism.”53
By the same logic, contraception too was a political danger, for the same reason – that it encouraged “unbridled thirst for sensual pleasure, lust heightened
by the experience of fulfillment” (in the words of Reinhold Seeberg), cultivating “disloyal crudity and lack of character” (in the words of F. W. Foerster).54
Little wonder, then, that socialists sponsored public addresses on contraception, or that the birthrate was lowest precisely in larger cities, where the Social
Democratic Party had its greatest electoral success.55 And prostitution offered
men the opportunity for unconstrained sensual gratification and was therefore
conducive to the spread of socialism – a movement that, as the morality campaigners saw it, preached a doctrine of unconstrained gratification of material
desires.
It was similarly only logical to the morality campaigners that a doctrine
that fed fundamentally on selfish sensual/material desires should be opposed to
what they saw as the foundational institution of the social order: the family.
At least some Social Democrats sang the praises of institutions in which child
rearing would be socialized and the unpaid domestic labor of women replaced

by professionalized communal services – communal day care, communal
kitchens, communal baths, and so on. But moral conservatives argued that
it was in the family that people learned to respect authority, in the person of
their parents; and it was also here that people – adults as well as children –
learned to subordinate their selfish individual desires to the ethical imperative of care for others, and hence first became capable of living in an ordered
society. Marriage was, Ludwig Weber insisted, “a school of mutual devotion”
and of “love and caring for others.”56 Joseph Mausbach offered a characteristically Catholic version of the same concept in 1912: marriage “should
elevate all lowly drives through Christian respect and love, temper all legal
demands [for sex] with sensitivity, consideration and forbearance.”57 A petition against brothels lodged by Heidelberg’s Protestant morality association
in 1902 summed up the implications of this model pithily: “The preservation
of the sanctity of marriage and an orderly and happy family life are the most
important foundations on which the well-being of the state and nation are
built.”58
Beyond this socializing and moralizing role of the family, however, the
Christian morality campaigners also believed that sexual morality specifically
was the single most fundamental foundation of morality more broadly. Learning to control the physical passion of sexual desire was the foundation and
precondition for learning to control all other passions. The sexual instinct
was the most powerful of the primal, carnal instincts – the “most important
basic human instinct of all,” as Fritz Schultze put it in 1897.59 Victory here
required the cultivation of a moral discipline that would make other challenges
child’s play; failure here would pave the way for moral failure in every other
respect, would break the moral will more generally. Wilhelm Brinkmann made
this point forcefully in a speech to the AKDS in 1892: the simple fact was,
he believed, “that without sexual purity morality itself cannot exist.”60 Fifteen years later, a leading morality advocate in Munich was equally succinct:
“True morality is tested and proven most deeply in the regulation of sexual
relations.”61 Another Catholic observer argued in 1909 that “general morality
grows out of specifically sexual morality.”62 For the moral personality, in short,
sexuality was a question of life or death. And it was for this reason that sexual
disorder was so devastating for the moral fiber of the nation. As Heidelberg’s
anti-brothel campaigners put it, the prevalence of brothels was a key reason

“why discipline and morality, loyalty and faith are sinking in our nation, and
crude and unscrupulous selfishness are spreading.”63
Obviously, a key assumption of the morality campaigners was that merely
natural sexuality was fundamentally brutal and destructive. This was particularly true of men’s sexuality – they frequently referred to “male brutality,” or
the “brutal male pleasure-seeking,” or the potential for a “brutal indulgence
of masculine desires” as the likely outcome of the triumph of a “naturalistic”
moral code.64 Ludwig Weber held that the root of both sexual lust and bloodthirstiness was “the desire to enforce the right of the stronger at the expense of
the weaker.”65 Friedrich Wilhelm Foerster held that sexuality was “demonic,”
it was by nature uncontrolled, without limits, and it did not stop – which was
why immorality so frequently degenerated into perversity.66
This was the case fundamentally because the body was always in revolt
against the moral will, always attempting to overthrow the dominion of the
spirit and subject the individual to its own power. Thus the Protestant morality campaigners variously observed that fornication made its practitioners
“slaves of sin”; that the great danger of the “sins of unchastity” was that
they “make one unscrupulous . . . [and] extinguish all enthusiasm for the ideal;
there remains only carnal pleasure-seeking, which drives its slaves with demonic
power from sin to sin”; that prostitution made men “slaves and servants of their
lusts”; and that “only by learning to master ourselves, to avoid being slaves to
our instincts, can we become as free . . . as it is possible to be in this world.”67
Catholics used very similar language. In its pastoral letter to German Catholic
youth in 1909, for example, the episcopate urged young men to “be heroes,
fight for your freedom. . . . Master the sensual instincts with the scepter of reason, with the hero’s sword, the will.”68 And Joseph Mausbach told the annual
Catholic conference in 1912 that monogamous marriage was the best “safeguard of freedom” against the “tyranny of uncontrolled whims and passions.”
Real freedom was only possible “if the higher moral self is able to control the
lower, instinctual self.”69
This conception of inward, moral freedom had explicit political implications. On the one hand, it meant that the morality campaigners saw their own
attempt to use the law and the police to counter cultural change precisely as a

defense of (moral) freedom. On the other hand, they believed that people who
were not inwardly free, who had not broken the tyranny of their own desire,
could not create free institutions. Instead, they would be forced to seek power
over others, in order to satisfy their material, animal lusts. Enslavement to
desire would eat away at the fabric of order, justice, and liberty. Thus some
warned that the general loss of moral backbone was producing a loss of civil
courage and willingness to suffer for one’s principles in public life – as did
one Catholic cultural critic, who, in 1910, feared that the old “German ‘manly
pride before the thrones of kings,’ before ministers – that’s all past”; it was
being replaced by opportunistic “Byzantinism and servility.”70 Ultimately, the
result would be dictatorship and/or chaos. Ludwig Lemme, at the Inner Mission’s 1904 conference, painted a frightening picture of the consequences of
the decline of religiosity and Christian morality and the rise of an ethic “that
seeks to derive morality from evolutionary biology”:
Crude unleashing of the wildest passions. Indiscipline and pleasure-seeking among
the masses. Brutal violence of the powerful. Misery among the vulnerable. Dissolution of marital relationships. Division of families. Mistrust and fear everywhere.
Treacherous tyranny of a soldateska become aware of the power of spear and
sword. Soldier-kings who come to the throne through treachery, and fall through
treachery again.71

In 1910 Wilhelm Kuhaupt wrote that the ideas of Darwin and Nietzsche, in
which the “struggle for existence” was the “driving force of evolution,” would
reduce the world to “one great armed camp, in which death and destruction
have the upper hand. The egoistic will to power, bent on domination and
exploitation, puts a sword in every hand.”72
On occasion the morality campaigners made this argument explicitly regarding Social Democracy, which they saw as the political arm, so to speak, of that
spiritual crisis that was so evident in popular culture and the arts. Socialism was
to politics as sexual lust was to man’s moral personality: a demonic, chaotic
force in revolt against order, love, and reason, seeking to create a tyranny that
would crush human dignity beneath the weight of ungoverned physical passions. As Otto von Leixner put it, “behind the beautiful words of the apostles
of the new teaching lurks lust for power – they want to put themselves on
the throne from which they are trying to cast down all the powers that be.”73
In fact, there is a rather precise homology between the morality campaigners’
anthropology and their sociology: the (socialist) working class was the social
equivalent of the “animalistic,” instinctual, insatiable passions in the individual
person, and the ruling class was the social equivalent of the “spirit,” of man’s
reason and spiritual calling.

This model of socialism, finally, also explains why it was precisely the combination of sex and violence in popular culture that moral conservatives found
objectionable. Revolutionary socialism was both immoral and violent. Those
products of popular culture that implicitly glorified both immorality and violence, therefore, were most likely to be conducive to the spread of socialist ideas.
III. The Immorality of Capitalism
And yet, it would be a profound mistake to see the morality campaigners as
defenders of the social status quo in Germany in 1900; for as we have seen
in the case of the culture industry, they were hardly enamored of capitalism
either. Indeed, they believed that much of the moral decay of German society
was the product precisely of the convergence of amoral, vulgar, materialistic,
and sensationalistic conceptions of “fun” and of happiness among the poor
with the business acumen of unprincipled cultural entrepreneurs – whether the
organizers and marketers of popular culture or the modernist elite in “high”
culture. Beyond that, however, they were also intensely critical of the behavior
of the wealthy in their society more generally. In fact, whereas they believed
that the working classes were infected with a terrible mental disorder called
“socialism,” they also believed that the upper classes were infected with a
similar disease, which they often called “mammonism.” The latter was no
better than the former; in fact, the morality campaigners often argued that
socialism was merely the product, the logical consequence, of mammonism.
Socialism was, so to speak, the mammonism of the poor; and they had caught
it from the rich.
Prostitution was a classic example and important symbolic instance, for the
morality campaigners were convinced that brothels and white slavery were
big business. Reports of the obscene profits made by brothel owners were
in fact one of the classic rhetorical gestures of the antiregulation movement
before World War I.74 More broadly, the morality campaigners held prostitution to be rooted in the whole culture of commercialism and materialism. Thus one speaker at the 1905 conference of the AKDS admitted that
prostitution was rooted in the “great economic need – indeed subjection” of
women; but that in itself was merely an “outgrowth of the prevailing naturalistmammonist” spirit of the age. The “roots of prostitution” were to be found in
the broader cultural “soil thoroughly poisoned by mammonism.”75 More concretely, the sums earned by brothel owners were driven in part by the greed and
moral turpitude of those entrepreneurs in the culture industry who fed sensual
74

Friedrich Bohn, Unsere Forderungen zum Vorentwurf des neuen Strafgesetzbuches (Berlin:
AKDS, 1910), pp. 6, 9; Friedrich Bohn, Bordelle und Mädchenhandel (Berlin: AKDS, 1907),
pp. 6–8.
75 Hans Brennecke, Wie ist der Kampf gegen die Geschlechts-Krankheiten zu führen? (Berlin:
AKDS, 1905), pp. 19, 20.

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

lusts – the merchants of pornography, suggestive films, and racy literature,
and those who paid their employees (models, waitresses, pieceworkers, shop
girls, servants, etc.) the starvation wages that drove them to prostitution.76 The
morality campaigners were also convinced that prostitution served the desires
specifically of well-to-do men, asserting – as did the Swiss historian and cultural
critic Otto Henne am Rhyn at the turn of the century – that governments did not
abolish brothels and stop the traffic in women precisely because “it’s all about
the satisfaction of the sexual lusts of rich and distinguished gentlemen.”77 They
were particularly incensed by employers’ use of their authority and financial
power over the female employees for their own sexual profit; a number argued
from the 1890s in favor of the introduction of a paragraph in the Criminal
Code that would punish this form of sexual exploitation.78
However, the morality campaigners saw the sexual exploitation of workingclass women as only one limited instance of a much broader pattern of immoral
exploitation and inhumanity among the wealthy. The predatory immorality
of rich men was just one product of the broader inhumanity of capitalist
culture as a whole, which valued money above all else. Wilhelm Brinkmann,
for example, blamed the “misery, isolation, and hopelessness” of the working
classes on the “lack of love, of sympathy, of compassion” of the upper class,
their “selfishness” and “self-serving . . . lack of justice and uprightness.” It was,
he charged, “unscrupulous greed and hunger for profit that has eroded the
moral ground under the feet of the workers,” while the “arrogance and waste,”
the “provocative manner,” and the “boastful egotism” of the upper classes
made poverty and suffering all the more painful by contrast.79 “Riches and
power spark the passion of envy,” Lemme told the AKDS in 1904, and “the
hunger for power, the lust for pleasure, and envy – they are the recruiters
for Social Democracy.”80 Just as the Woman Question was really a product
of men’s behavior, the Social Question was at bottom a question about the
morality of the upper classes, not that of the working class.
Beyond mere greed and hard-heartedness, however, the morality campaigners believed that the most fundamental problem of their society was that the
modern industrial capitalist order was itself founded on immoral and unjust
principles. The modern social order, as Brinkmann put it, was founded on
mere “economic laws,” which “do not correspond to justice” because they
