“serve . . . exclusively the production of goods, not their just use, more greed
and the interests of individuals than justice.”81 Lemme repeated the charge:
the capitalist social order, he believed, was essentially the product of modern,
rationalist, materialist ethics; there was nothing in these principles to “hold
people back from the wild . . . chase after gold, from sensual pleasures limited
only by considerations of one’s own health, from mockery of the highest
spiritual values.”82 The general secretary of the AKDS summed up this vision
of capitalist modernity in the organization’s journal in 1896: “Money is the
ideal of modern times . . . , it is the state within the state. . . . Money is the
authority of our times, it’s the brain of the world, it has legislative power, it has
creative force . . . it demands the rights of a sovereign, to which we are all to
be subject.”83 This was Mammonismus – life under the dictatorship of money.
Catholics often used the same sort of language. In 1908, for example, one
Catholic critic wrote in the journal of the KMV that “our economic and commercial system is ruinous for civilization. In it people fall victim to Mammon;
wisdom and virtue have to give way before cheap production and the piling-up
of capital. . . . Their tendency is to make the rich mean and heartless, the poor
careless and vicious.” The result was “universal oppression and extermination of the weak by the strong”; but even the capitalists themselves became
mere “cogs in the machine. The sense of inner freedom dies in them . . . , they
become incapable of thinking great thoughts or following high ideals. . . . We
are the slaves, not the masters of our work.”84 And the influential conservative
Catholic journal Historisch-Politische Blätter carried an article in 1910 that
held that “the modern economy contradicts ethics and justice in its fundamental principles.” The liberal “‘natural law’ of supply and demand, free competition as regulator of the distribution of wealth make power, not justice,
more and more the foundation of social life.” It was “unjust and an affront to
human intellect when in the arena of economics not the human spirit but mere
material – called money and capital – exercise dominion.”85 Capitalism itself
was the dominion of the flesh over the spirit writ large, the social equivalent of
individual slavery to sin.
By the 1900s, as the morality movement became more mainstream and
more successful, the anticapitalist rhetoric of its spokesmen moderated. Fiery
general denunciations of the upper classes became less common; anticapitalism
was increasingly expressed through the specific rhetorical gesture of criticizing
the “business” of immorality – the profits of brothels and the tendency of
publishers and film companies to “pursue the bottom line at the expense of
higher community values” (in the words of Karl Brunner) or to indulge in

Brinkmann, “In wie weit,” p. 135.
Lemme, “Der Einfluss,” pp. 58–59.
83 A. H., “Die Lohnbewegung im Konfektionsgewerbe,” KB 10 (1896): 27

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

“crude speculation on the sensual instincts of half-grown boys and girls” (in
the words of one correspondent in Der Volkswart in 1909).86 Nevertheless,
fundamentally the morality campaigners remained committed after 1900 to
the same broader analysis: capitalism encouraged and indeed required people
to put money above values, selfishness above the commonweal, and desire
above love. It was at bottom this tyranny and joylessness of capitalist society
that explained the hunger for entertainment that the morality campaigners saw
as underpinning the flourishing of commercial popular culture. The boredom
of industrial labor, the grimness of the industrial urban environment, and
the hectic, exhausting pace of modern life fostered the taste – the need –
for sensationalism, for pure distraction. Emilie Altenloh’s 1914 study of the
sociology of the cinema delivered a concise articulation of this theory. Most
people in industrial society, she believed, “are integrated as little components in
the great economic mechanism. . . . The free, independent sphere over which the
person rules sovereign has been shrunk to a minimum.” Only a “very thin upper
crust” had retained the “inward freedom” that gave them the wherewithal to
entertain themselves. Everyone else had to seek out entertainments that offered
“distraction and entertainment.”87
For the morality campaigners, then, socialism and capitalism, the women’s
movement and men’s predatory sexual behaviors, and nude dance performances for the rich and eroticized violence for the poor were all just expressions of the same thing: the modern tyranny of materialism and selfishness over
spirituality and community. The specific emphasis of the morality movement
evolved over time; the fundamental message did not.
IV. Christianity, Nation, and Race
The morality campaigners held that the phenomena they deplored were, in addition to being wrong and immoral, also essentially treasonous. They weakened
the moral fiber and hence the power of the nation. Protestant moral conservatives in particular often called their own values “German,” rhetorically placing those who did not share those values outside the nation. Thus the general
secretary of the AKDS argued in 1894 that “to live German is the same as to
live . . . chastely”; Ludwig Weber remarked that many of the products of modern popular and high culture “throw mud on everything holy to the German”;
Karl Brunner believed that the modern cinema “continually . . . undermines the
soil in which the good old German character is rooted.”88 Often the morality
86

87 Emilie Altenloh, Zur Soziologie des Kino: Die Kino-Unternnehmung und die sozialen Schichten
ihrer Besucher (Leipzig: Spamer, 1914), pp. 48, 97,
88 Fritz Patzschke, Die Stellung der Studentenschaft zur deutschen Sittlichkeitsbewegung (Leipzig:

The Politics of Morality, Class, and Gender

69

campaigners sought to identify immoral behavior with foreigners, and specifically with the French. They frequently chose to use novelists like Zola, painters
like Fantin Latour, and performers like Adorée Villany as their examples of
modern immorality in the arts (although others, like Ibsen, Tolstoy, and Bocaccio, also appeared in their analyses). They held France to be the source of most
pornography and of frivolous films. They recalled Napoleon’s role in bringing
regulated prostitution to Germany. They called contraception a “French vulgarity.” And they pointed out that rationalism, socialism, and revolution all
had their origin in France as well. Thus the Korrespondenzblatt observed in
1890, for example, that the German women’s movement had its origins in “the
idea of emancipation, which came over to us from revolutionary France,” and
it argued in favor of evaluating the whole matter from a “Christian-German”
perspective.89 Twenty-three years later, the journal summed up its view succinctly: “The rot pushes in continually from the west.”90
This “rot” was a threat to national security, the morality campaigners
believed, because sexual self-discipline was the foundation for all discipline,
and specifically of the capacity for self-sacrifice for an ideal. Sexual morality
was therefore the essential and indispensable source of the martial virtues –
obedience, self-sacrificing courage, and the capacity to bear physical and psychological hardships. A nation of cynical, soft, morally and physically selfindulgent weaklings could not field a military force capable of the determination
and endurance necessary for victory. One military officer summed up this view
at the 1890 meeting of the AKDS: the “moral force of the army,” derived
from the “moral virtue” of the troops, was the decisive factor in determining
an army’s ability to win wars.91 One critic of Schund argued in 1904 that
“since in the final analysis moral force and moral virtue win victory, the military power of our nation is endangered by immoral literature.”92 And Ernst
Lennartz, general secretary of the KMV, argued in his 1908 study of nude
dance that as a matter of national security the authorities simply had to step in
to contain the spread of nudism, because “at any moment our nation may be
forced to face a bloody test of its moral force.”93

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

The morality campaigners also argued, however, that there was a direct relationship between moral and physical health. Immorality robbed people of their
physical vitality as well as their moral “force” or “energy” (Kraft). The negative
impact of sexually transmitted diseases within the military was only the most
obvious case of this connection; an immoral way of life led to more generalized
“softness” and “weakliness” of constitution (Verweichlichung, literally “going
soft”). But immorality also weakened the nation economically, because it was
expensive – for example, 300 million marks annually were wasted on prostitution, 110 million marks on venereal diseases, and 50 million marks annually
on Schund.94
But the most important way in which immorality decreased the material
power of the nation was through its impact on the birthrate. Already in 1887,
for example, the BMBU urged that any “rational government” had to combat
immorality, “if only to secure the necessary number of healthy recruits.”95 As
the pace of demographic change accelerated after about 1905, the morality
campaigners became increasingly obsessed with the decline of the birthrate.
The AKDS’s Korrespondenzblatt carried seven stories on the birthrate in 1912,
but thirteen in the first six months of 1914 alone.96 In the view of the morality
campaigners, selfish, materialistic, self-indulgent men and women were making
use of birth control to turn their marriages into an orgy of animalistic pleasure
seeking without responsibility and were thereby compromising the security of
the nation.
The definitive enunciation of the conservative Christian theory regarding the connection between immorality and the decline of the birthrate was
Jean Bornträger’s 1912 study, “The Decline of the Birth Rate in Germany.”
Bornträger argued that the decline in the birthrate was the product of the use
of contraceptives and abortion to limit fertility, which in turn was the result
of “the turning away from religion and old time-honored views and customs
among ever wider circles, and the modern spread of materialist, rationalist,
monistic and other world-views.” The decline in the birthrate, then, was simply the biological expression of “the crassest egotism and materialism and lack
of any healthy sense for what is really valuable in life.”97 Bornträger proposed a
whole palette of positive economic and welfare measures to encourage fertility –
including preferences for married men and particularly those with children in

p. 17; Abraham Flexner, Prostitution in Europe (New York: Century, 1914), p. 38; Ernst

public sector hiring, a tax on single men, rent subsidies and tax credits for
families with children, public housing subsidies, expansion of prenatal and
maternity benefits under the social insurance system, school lunch programs,
infant welfare programs, and so forth. But he also offered negative proposals:
stricter censorship of advertising, public addresses, and publications on contraception; harsher punishments for selling or advertising contraceptives; restrictions and taxes on the production and importation of contraceptives; official
discouragement of the women’s movement and married women’s employment;
the general suppression of frivolity (holidays, carnivals, festivals, amusement
parks, and bars); state support for evangelization and religious associations;
and protection of the youth from “immature materialist theories of all kinds,”
including evolutionary theory and socialism.98
Obviously, there was the potential for this populationist, biological understanding of the power and well-being of the nation to take an explicitly racist
turn; and in fact the morality campaigners occasionally did explicitly argue in
racial terms. Bornträger, for example, remarked on the fact that of the earth’s
1.7 billion inhabitants, 947 million were Asian and only 566 million white –
and that nonwhites had a higher rate of population growth. Within Europe the
“overly numerous Slavs” and especially the Russians were a threat.99 The first
pages of the Korrespondenzblatt’s 1913 volume, too, warned against the same
menaces – “the yellow . . . races,” Buddhism, Islam, and “Slavism.”100
And yet, neither racism nor imperial ambition was an essential element
of the morality campaigners’ thinking. Bornträger’s comments on race, for
example, took up one page of a 168-page publication; and such statements
were quite rare in the publications and speeches of the morality campaigners.
What is more, they were often rather ambivalent about imperial expansion and
colonial rule, not least due to sexual scandals involving colonial administrators
and soldiers.101 Already by 1901, the AKDS’s journal was warning against
the “intoxication” of national power and the “demoralizing influences that
are inevitably bound up with any colonial policy.”102 And Catholics were
even more critical. A particularly striking example is an article of 1907 in a
journal edited by one of the founders of Munich’s men’s morality association;
it savaged those who sought to “spread civilization by the firing-squad” and
held that “the black race is neither physically nor morally originally a lower or
less worthy one. . . . [We] hold the African to be . . . a human being, with every
attribute of the human species.”103 As for the Slavs, in 1902 Hermann Roeren
took time out from the morality movement and his parliamentary activities to

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

publish a lengthy pamphlet denouncing the Prussian state’s “Germanization”
program in Prussian Poland as merely a cover for “Protestantization.”104 Nor
were Catholics as likely as Protestants to blame their coreligionists in France
for immorality in general.
Racism as a set of explicit ideas (rather than merely prejudices) was ultimately simply not compatible with conservative Christian principles. Conservative Christians regarded people always and above all as spiritual beings.
Racism saw individuals first and foremost as physical beings. This is why combinations of sex, violence, and race were, for conservative Christians, the very
worst that popular culture had to offer.
One form of ethnic prejudice, however, most certainly was prevalent at
least within the Protestant morality movement, in which there was a powerful undercurrent of anti-Semitism. By the 1880s and 1890s, anti-Semitism
was tainted by its exploitation by populist peasant rabble-rousers; but the
Protestant morality movement never really escaped from its origins in Adolf
Stoecker’s anti-Semitic Christian Social movement. Prejudice against Jews was
seldom explicitly expounded at any length in the publications and speeches of
leading Protestant morality campaigners; but it peeked through with moderate
frequency in offhand remarks, thinly veiled references, and a selective deployment of facts that, while preserving a modicum of deniability, nevertheless got
the message across to those in the know. Thus the annual report of the AKDS
for 1888/1889 observed that the uproar over their activities in the “so-called
‘liberal’ papers, governed by the Jewish-materialist spirit” was the best evidence that they were making an impact.105 At a major conference on immoral
literature in Cologne in 1904, one speaker remarked that the idea of approaching “a Mosse or a Levysohn” (two prominent Jewish publishers in Berlin) to
seek support in the campaign against immorality in print was laughable – a
reference to the stereotype of the unscrupulous Jewish merchant of filth.106 In
1891 the Korrespondenzblatt, remarking on a scandal involving two Jewish
bankers in Berlin, had observed that the Social Democratic press would make
more of such affairs if it were “not so Jewified itself.” Other articles blamed
Jews for importing Jewish “white slaves” from Galicia into the prostitution
market, or for “hunger wages” paid to women in the garment industry.107
Such remarks fed on and nurtured a tradition of paranoid anti-Semitism that
was (usually) not explicitly propounded in the movement, but that was clearly
familiar and congenial to at least some of its leaders and activists. But the antiSemitism of the Christian Social movement also had shaped the terms of the
104

Hermann Roeren, Zur Polenfrage (Hamm: Brer & Thiemann, 1902).

The Politics of Morality, Class, and Gender

73

Protestant morality movement’s critique of modernity at their origin; for the
Christian Social movement identified both unscrupulous capitalism and Social
Democracy with what Adolf Stoecker called the postreligious “perversion of
the Jewish national spirit.” As Stoecker put it, only this could explain why
“on the one hand the worst representatives of the mammonistic spirit are
Jews . . . and that on the other hand the worst representatives of revolution
were also Jews.”108 Stoecker even used the term “un-German” as a synonym
for “Jewish” and contrasted it to the “Christian-German spirit.” In the context
of the history of the movement, then, all these familiar terms – mammonism,
un-German, revolution, German-Christian, and so on – carried, or at least
could carry, an anti-Semitic message.
It is certainly not fair to say that the entire political and social analysis
advanced by the Protestant morality movement was merely a secret code for
anti-Semitism. The Protestant morality campaigners believed that immorality
was nearly universal among (nominally) Christian German men; they were
convinced that France was a – or even the – primary font of immorality; they
did not suggest that Darwin or Nietzsche were Jews (although Marx certainly
was, as far as they were concerned); and they had a complex understanding of
the historical processes of social change that had created their “mammonistic”
society and its values. What is more, the Catholic morality campaigners shared
at least nine-tenths of the same analysis of the evils of modernity, but their
speeches and publications were virtually devoid of the kind of anti-Semitism in
which their Protestant counterparts indulged.
Nevertheless, it is clear that for a substantial proportion of the Protestant
morality campaigners, anti-Semitism was a kind of metaphor, part of a whole
field of associations in which Jews, the city, the press, white slavery, sweatshops and hunger wages, socialism, child sexual abuse, modern art, capitalism
and stock market speculation, the radical women’s movement, contraception,
philosophical and artistic modernism, sex reform, and so on were all held
together by a particular affect. All these things came from Outside; they were
all the product of someone else, of the Other – not Us, but Them. This prejudice obviously had its origins not in racist but in religious thinking; but equally
obviously it took explicitly ethnic form in this period.
In fact anti-Semitism as a metaphor was actually far less common in the
speeches and publications even of the Protestant morality movement than were
three other metaphors that conveyed a very similar message. The most common
of these were water metaphors. Germany was being overwhelmed by “muddy
floods of immorality”; the “waters of the deep gurgle and undermine the foundations of the strength and therefore also of the greatness of the German
nation”; a “disgusting tide” of “filth in word and image . . . is pouring over
108

Adolf Stoecker, “Die Anfänge der antijüdischen Bewegung in Berlin: Eine Jubiläumsbetrachtung,” in Reden und Aufsätze von Adolf Stoecker, ed. Reinhold Seeberg (Leipzig:
Deichert, 1913), pp. 144, 145, 150.

74

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

our . . . nation”; a “high tide of trash” was rising; women’s emancipation was
a “swamp-plant” that grew “in the swamp of animalistic vice.”109 Slightly less
common were disease metaphors: the “sexual bacillus” was causing a “true
epidemic” of eroticism; indecency was “a kind of spiritual syphilis”; trashy
literature was a “pestilence”; immorality was a “spiritual plague”; philosophical materialism was “spreading like an infectious disease.”110 Somewhat less
common again were poison metaphors, which usually appeared in combination with one or both of the other two: immorality was described as “creeping
poison”; “a flood of foul-smelling mud is flooding over our land, poisoning
everything” and seeking to “infect” its victims; a “poisonous stream of temptation and demoralization” was pouring from the popular press.111
These metaphors were sufficiently pervasive to be, in aggregate, quite disturbing – as they no doubt were intended to be. References to plague, poison,
waves, floods, streams, mud, swamps, suppurating sores, plague boils, cancer,
and various things poisonous (plants, mushrooms, fangs, and miasmas) were
scattered liberally throughout the publications and speeches of the morality
campaigners. In each case, immorality was portrayed as an alien, malevolent,
and insidious force from outside the boundaries of the nation, indeed of the
human community itself.
Usually the morality campaigners described what they considered valuable
and worthy of protection in much less fruity language. What was worthy of
protection was “ideal,” it was “spiritual,” it was “high” and “pure.” Particularly with reference to the family and youth, they sometimes used vegetable
metaphors: the family was a “garden,” love or children were “flowers,” young
men and women “blossomed.” The single most common positive metaphor
in their vocabulary, however, was that of war – which they used to describe
themselves. The morality movement was a “holy war” or a “crusade against
immorality”; the morality campaigners were a “small host of loyal men” and
“courageous fighters”; they must “rally around the banner of Christianity and

75

the church”; a good morality campaigner must be like a soldier – he must not
worry about success or failure but only “stand and fall at the post entrusted to
him by his commander, loyal and brave unto the death.”112
The use of one of the four horsemen of the apocalypse in this positive sense
seems odd; and yet given the metaphors used to describe the threat, it makes
sense. Immorality was an insidious, amorphous invading enemy of the nation;
those who fought it must be solid, upstanding, alert, and uncompromising
in its defense. It makes sense too in that the morality campaigners believed
that in fighting immorality they were striving to preserve the foundation of
the nation’s power, of its ability to wage – literal – war. They were, then,
defending the nation’s freedom not only from “slavery” to sin but also from
foreign domination. In their own eyes, they literally were soldiers for God and
country.
In this respect the extent to which the men’s morality campaign reflected the
particular social interests of its members is striking. The morality campaigners
were mostly men of the “old” educated and professional middle class – the
Bildungsbürgertum. The vast majority had chosen a life of public service –
whether in the churches, the schools, the courts, the military, or in some cases
municipal, state, or national government. Public service and education defined
their social status. They were mostly members of the social elite; but for the most
part they were not the originators, organizers, or beneficiaries of the cultural,
economic, and social transformations of their times. In fact, most of the changes
going on around them at best rendered their own status less lofty by creating
new sources of cultural and social authority – most importantly innovation,
money, and expertise. To the extent that they did point an accusing finger
at particular social groups, they singled out the three most closely identified
with change: the industrial working class, the commercial and industrial elite,
and working women. And the use of martial rhetoric and imagery was part
of this broader pattern, obviously; only men were subject to conscription,
and the military was the ultimate guarantor of the life of the conservative
state.
By the years just before the outbreak of World War I, however, this kind of
rhetoric was increasingly problematic. For it was by then unmistakably clear
that this social stratum was in important ways divided against itself. Upperand middle-class men faced “insurrection” not only from the lower orders
or from vulgar and amoral nouveaux riches but also among women of their

own class. Increasingly, in fact, conservative Christian men were losing control
of the language and, to some extent, of the agenda of “their” movement.
They conceived of that movement as fundamentally “manly,” even martial;
but increasingly that conception was being challenged by women of their own
class and community who saw morality as, fundamentally, women’s business –
and not men’s.
Chapter 4 turns to this development.

4
Religion, Women, and Morality

I. Women’s Transformation of the Morality Debate, 1900–1914
For most of the decade and a half before 1900, the public debate over sex and
morality was dominated by the Inner Mission and the AKDS, which championed a relatively consistent and unified body of ideas. After the turn of the century this relative organizational and intellectual unity was radically fractured.
The creation of the Catholic men’s morality movement was one instance; but
the formation of a broad spectrum of women’s associations between 1899 and
1904 was even more important, both because the new women’s organizations
were in aggregate much larger and because in some cases they advanced radically different interpretations of some of the issues and problems central to the
discussion of morality and decency. And despite the multiplicity of positions
they represented, by the years immediately prior to the outbreak of World
War I, the agendas of the various women’s organizations were clearly converging. Whereas in 1904 what was most apparent was the dramatic fracturing of the morality movement, by 1914 it was clear that, with respect
to many of the issues of central concern to moral conservatives, the resulting fragments were being reorganized around two coherent alternative perspectives: that of men, and that of women. On the other hand, particularly among conservative Protestants and Catholics, there were very close
organizational and personal ties between confessional women’s and confessional men’s organizations. It therefore proved impossible even for quite
conservative men to escape the influence and implications of the growth
of women’s activism. After about 1905, women began to exert increasing
influence over their male counterparts; and by 1913 some of the central
tenets of the men’s morality movement, which were in place since the beginning of the 1890s, were beginning to be called seriously into question –
particularly with respect to the issue of prostitution.
77

78

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

By 1914, then, the discussion of sexual morality, gender roles, and reproduction among moral conservatives in Germany had arrived at a somewhat
ambivalent condition. There was no longer a unified conservative Christian
morality movement at all; and some important positions and agendas that had
seemed quite stable in 1900 appeared rather shaky. On the other hand, the
massive proliferation of organizations and their growing memberships were
giving the discussion of morality a new weight and public importance. One of
the important aims of the early morality campaigners had been to break down
the culture of silence and tacit tolerance they believed to have been prevalent
in 1880; that aim, at least, had clearly been accomplished by about 1905. The
men’s morality movement had established the importance of its agenda for the
broader public. But in doing so it had helped to generate energies that rapidly
demolished its ability to dictate the terms in which the central issues of concern
to it were debated.
As we have seen, women had become involved in the discussion of morality
issues, independently of men, at least two decades before 1900. Most of the
practical work of “rescue” associations with women in the sex trade was done
by female Protestant deaconesses and Catholic women’s religious orders. By
the time of the formation of the first men’s morality associations, then, there
were considerable numbers of middle-class women directly engaged in their
charitable work with the problem of prostitution. These women’s views, however, closely resembled those of the men’s morality movement. The single most
influential women’s initiative before the mid-1890s was the Youth Protection
Association (Verein Jugendschutz [VJS]), formed under the leadership of Hanna
Bieber-Böhm in Berlin in 1889. The petitions her organization submitted to the
national parliament and the emperor in 1892 and 1894 advocated measures for
the suppression of vice no less draconian than (and probably largely based on)
those advanced by the AKDS – such as the elimination of regulation in favor
of criminalization of all prostitutes.1 In the latter year Bieber-Böhm played
an important role in the formation of a national umbrella organization of
women’s associations of all kinds, the League of German Women’s Associations (Bund deutscher Frauenvereine [BDF]); and she became chair of the BDF’s
own committee on morality issues (Sittlichkeitskommission). The measures the

79

BDF advocated in its 1895 petition to the national parliament closely echoed
those of the earlier VJS petitions.2
This conservative approach had been challenged by the IAF, which favored
the decriminalization of prostitution; and in the 1880s Gertrud GuillaumeSchack, as a member of the upper nobility, was able to stir up considerable
controversy. But Guillaume-Schack was drawn to socialism, fell afoul of the
antisocialist laws in 1885, and ultimately had to leave the country.3 In 1897,
however, Anita Augspurg and her partner Lida Gustava Heymann, leading figures in the radical women’s movement in Hamburg, formed the first of a new
wave of abolitionist associations; it was soon followed by further local organizations in Berlin (under Anna Pappritz), Dresden (under Katharina Scheven),
and other major centers.4
These organizations were able – despite substantial police harassment, particularly in Hamburg – to mobilize relatively broad support.5 One important
reason was that they benefited from a number of egregious cases of arrest and
abusive treatment of respectable women by the morals police. This development was itself most probably the product of the rising number of younger,
single middle-class women employed in white-collar jobs, and hence likely
to be out on the streets unchaperoned. Cultural changes associated with the
consolidation of the new urban nightlife, shopping, and more informal styles
of interaction between the sexes also played a role. Women protested such
arrests in a number of unprecedented mass meetings in 1897 and 1898.6 Bitter
parliamentary and public debates over the reform of the Criminal Code (the lex

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

Heinze debate) and the sections of the new Civil Code of 1900 (the Bürgerliches
Gesetzbuch) relating to marriage and family law were critically important in
mobilizing women as well. The abolitionist movement also benefited from the
formation, at the end of 1899, of the Union of Progressive Women’s Associations (Verband Fortschrittlicher Frauenvereine [VFF]), which advocated a more
uncompromising approach to women’s emancipation than the main stream of
the BDF and made the issues of morality and prostitution central to its agenda
from the outset.7
By 1902, then, Katharina Scheven was able to launch an independent abolitionist journal (the Abolitionist); and in 1904 a national coalition of local
associations (the Deutscher Zweig – German branch – of the IAF [DZIAF]) was
formed. By 1912 it had sixteen member associations and some 1,200 members,
about 15 percent of them men.8 At the annual national conference of the BDF
in 1902, the abolitionists triumphed over Bieber-Böhm and her more conservative associates: Scheven replaced Bieber-Böhm as head of the BDF’s morality
commission, and the organization adopted abolitionism. By 1905, the BDF
rejected criminalization of prostitution as a “monstrous injustice.”9
The formal membership figures for the DZIAF or the circulation numbers
for its journal – 1,200 members and 1,600 copies in 191210 – are therefore
deceptive, as its agenda was supported by much of the broader women’s movement. Support was particularly vehement in the so-called radical faction within
the BDF, which pushed a more rights-based and less service-oriented agenda
than the competing “moderate” faction. It is no coincidence, for example,
that the BDF formally adopted the demand for women’s suffrage at the same
1902 meeting at which it adopted abolitionism, because there was considerable overlap between the DZIAF, the VFF, and the German Association for
Women’s Suffrage, which was formed also in 1902 under the presidency of
Anita Augspurg.11
The men’s morality movement regarded these developments with horror.
Partly in response, the AKDS made a considerable effort to mobilize conservative Protestant women. Women’s morality associations associated with

81

the AKDS formed their own umbrella organization, the DFHS, in 1887; it
had 12,000 members in 1898.12 From 1892 onward the AKDS published a
separate journal for these organizations; it was edited by male pastors, most
articles in it were by men, and particularly in its early years it echoed the
agenda and tone of the Korrespondenzblatt almost precisely. Like the men’s
morality movement, Protestant women’s morality organizations were embedded in a dense network of related associations that, although not specifically
devoted to morality issues, took active interest in and occasionally supported
their work – for example, the German branch of the International Union of
Female Friends of Young Women (Verein der Freundinnen junger Mädchen
[VFJM]), which was involved in preventive morality work through its hostels
for female labor migrants, or the Protestant Women’s Auxiliary (Evangelische
Frauenhilfe), which was formed in 1899 largely to support the social work of
the Protestant orders of deaconesses, and by 1912 was the largest Protestant
women’s organization in Germany, with close to 250,000 members.13
By the turn of the century, however, many in the leadership of the AKDS
were convinced of the imperative need to create a more activist conservative
Protestant counterweight to the emerging nonconfessional women’s movement.
At its 1898 conference, the AKDS leadership decided to support the creation
of an organization that would address the broader Woman Question as a
whole rather than focusing more narrowly on charitable and church affairs.
The German-Protestant Women’s League (Deutsch-evangelischer Frauenbund
[DEF]) was formed in June 1899 at a meeting of men and women close to
the Inner Mission. Ludwig Weber and Pastor Mätzold, his proxy within the
AKDS, were the group’s longtime “spiritual advisors” (geistige Beiräte).14 The
DEF was viewed with profound suspicion by more reactionary figures within
the Protestant milieu, and it grew slowly – it had some 10,000 members by

1910, and 16,000 by 1914. That was, however, quite a respectable membership
among organizations of the women’s movement; the German General Women’s
Association (Allgemeiner Deutscher Frauenverein) had only 19,000 members in
1908, and the VFF only some 2,000.15 The DEF was not concerned only with
the morality issue; it did not form its own morality commission until 1907,
and its national leadership was engaged in a whole range of issues such as
women’s education and legal rights, legal aid, charities and social reform, and
professional interests. Of the thirty-seven (out of ninety-seven) local chapters
engaged directly with morality issues in 1910, most focused on preventive
social work with young women.16 Nevertheless, morality and in particular
prostitution were central and increasingly important concerns; Paula Mueller,
the organization’s president, even called the morality question the “core point
of the Woman Question” in 1906.17 Mueller herself was a high-profile figure in
the debate surrounding virtually every issue relating to sexual morality before
World War I. She was very active in the AKDS (which accepted women as
members after the Law on Associations was changed in 1908 to allow women
to participate in political meetings and organizations) and played an important
role within the Inner Mission.
Until the end of the 1890s, Catholic women’s involvement with moral
issues appears to have been largely confined to the rescue efforts of the
women’s religious orders and the preventive work of young women’s religious
associations.18 Beginning in the early 1890s, as part of the general flourishing
of lay organizations within the Catholic charitable milieu, lay Catholic women
in numerous cities began to become active, particularly in such work. The most
prominent example was the Catholic Welfare Association for Women, Girls,
and Children (Katholischer Fürsorgeverein für Mädchen, Frauen und Kinder
[KFV]), founded in 1899 in Dortmund under the leadership of Agnes Neuhaus.
By 1912 the KFV was perhaps the single most influential and effective Catholic
welfare association in Germany, with seventy-three local chapters and thirteen shelters for single mothers.19 Catholic women were also involved in “preventive” work for the protection of girls (Mädchenschutz), particularly immigrants to larger cities. in 1895 in Munich; thereafter similar associations, using the name Marian
Girls’ Protection Associations (Marianische Mädchenschutzvereine [MMSV]),
spread rapidly; and a national association was formed in 1905.20 Activist
Catholic women launched an important journal, Die christliche Frau, in 1902,
under the direct auspices of the umbrella organization of the Catholic charities,
the DCV. And after extended negotiations at the annual conferences of German Catholics (Katholikentag) and of the DCV in 1903, the Catholic Women’s
League of Germany (Katholischer deutscher Frauenbund [KDF]) was created
in November of that year.21
Throughout its existence, the KDF would scrupulously avoid any deviation
from established Catholic social teaching, refusing to take clear positions on
critical issues of the day on which the Catholic intellectual establishment had
not reached consensus. This was true, for example, in particular of the issue
of prostitution. Like the Catholic men’s morality movement, the KDF largely
sidestepped the issue, instead focusing its activity in the field of morality on
public art and performances, trashy literature, the cinema, the urban “relationship,” and so forth – issues about which there was virtual consensus among
confessional Catholics. And the problem or crisis of morality was simply less
central to the public voice of the KDF than was true in the case of the DEF.
Partly as a result, it avoided the kind of intense hostility that the DEF faced
within the conservative Protestant milieu; and it was able to expand its membership and activities much more rapidly. By 1912, it had 40,000 members.22
The Jewish Women’s League (Jüdischer Frauenbund [ JFB]), also formed in
1904, achieved an even higher rate of membership among its potential members: by the outbreak of World War I, it had some 35,000 members, perhaps
one in five adult German Jewish women. As was true in the case of the DEF
and the KDF, morality issues played a key role in motivating its formation.
The central focus of the JFB was in fact the “white slave trade.” The B’nai
B’rith in Hamburg, Germany’s largest port, had become involved in monitoring the traffic in women already in 1897 and called a national conference of
Jewish charities on white slavery in 1902; in the same year, the second International Conference on the Suppression of the Traffic in Women and Children
met in Frankfurt. Bertha Pappenheim, a leading member of Frankfurt’s Jewish
charitable community, attended both meetings and came away convinced that

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

Jewish women needed a national organization dedicated to combating prostitution and white slavery. The issue was of particular concern to Germany’s
Jewish women’s organizations because poor Jewish women from East-Central
Europe made up a large proportion of those recruited into the international
traffic in women at the time.23 Like the KDF, the JFB avoided the question of
regulation, preferring to focus on preventive social and rescue work. Pappenheim in particular, however, made an important contribution to the discussion
of prostitution among women.24
The social makeup of all these women’s organizations was quite similar to
that of the male morality movements. The DEF in particular was founded on
the activism of very affluent and socially prominent women; on occasion its
leadership even openly identified with the “upper ten thousand.”25 The wives
of church officials played important roles in the Protestant women’s organizations, as did the nobility.26 Catholic women’s organizations were slightly
less upper class, with stronger representation particularly of teachers. But the
first MMSV in Munich was headed by a countess; and members of powerful
Catholic families in the Rhineland played important roles in Mädchenschutz
and in the KDF.27 The JFB was dominated by women of the affluent Jewish community of Frankfurt. Most of the abolitionist leadership came from
similarly well-to-do families.28
II. Women, Christianity, and Morality: Familiar Themes
Given this common social background, it is hardly surprising that in many
respects the analysis of the moral condition of their age advanced by the

Religion, Women, and Morality

85

women’s morality movements was quite similar to that presented by their
male counterparts. Male and female morality campaigners inhabited, in many
respects, a shared “culture” of moral activism.
The exception was the “radical” faction in the women’s movement. Whereas
the majority in the DZIAF belonged to the moderate faction of the nonconfessional women’s movement, a minority of prominent radicals played an
important role in the early history of that organization. These women were
adherents of left-liberalism or a vaguely defined democratic socialism, nonconformist or even agnostic in their religious beliefs, and intensely critical of the
order of gender relations in their society. From its foundation in 1895, the
journal Die Frauenbewegung, the voice of the radical faction, heaped contempt on the Christian morality movements, regarding them as crabbed, selfrighteous, and fundamentally un-Christian. The grande dame of the radicals,
Minna Cauer, for example, remarked in her report on the 1897 conference
of the AKDS that the principles of the morality campaigners were “not compatible with the views of a true Christian” and “almost fanatical,” remarking
particularly on their tendency to wish “death and destruction to the women’s
movement!”29 In 1900 Die Frauenbewegung characterized the morality campaigners as “dark powers . . . making furious efforts to contain the spirit of freedom in our national life.”30 The DEF was merely another attempt to stifle “the
free development of the spirit” that was the real precondition for the development of the women’s movement.31 The journal did publish some conciliatory
statements by conservative Protestant women shortly after the formation of
the DEF; but by 1905 it had concluded – unsurprisingly – that “for us . . . the
‘women’s movement’ associated with the church has no value whatsoever.”32
The opposite extreme was represented by conservative Protestants in the
DFHS, who had essentially no voice independent of that of their male colleagues. But the publications of the DEF followed a very similar line. Its leaders
were well integrated into the conservative Protestant milieu and particularly
the Inner Mission, and they shared its analysis of the moral status of their
society, of the origins of the moral crisis they perceived, of its likely outcome,
and of the proper means of resolving it. Thus, for example, Paula Mueller
was convinced that the “moral rebirth of national life depends upon winning the German people once again for Christian faith.”33 The Countess of
Münster, also a leading figure in the DEF, held that Nietzsche and Haeckel

“exercise a fateful attraction on the great mass of the discontented and unstable,” and that this explained the prevalent “burning hatred for Christianity.”34
And the journal of the DEF was convinced, in 1908, that the rich set a bad
example because they “can’t get enough of luxury” and “entertainments” and
“sneer at traditional moral rigor.”35
Protestant women closely echoed the AKDS view on prostitution as well.
Thus a petition to the national parliament from a women’s morality association
in Westphalia in 1890 presented all the familiar arguments – that women were
turned into “slaves” by the system; that regulation made the sex trade appear
legitimate; that under existing law “in a certain sense one could . . . accuse
the police of procuring”; that in the tolerated brothels “everything that makes
human beings human disappears . . . , nothing remains but the animal instinct of
sensual pleasure”; and that prostitution undermined men’s “moral sensibility,”
resulting in more rather than fewer sexual assaults on women.36 Another petition from the national DFHS presented in the same year warned that immorality
led to “impious licentiousness and revolutionary alienation from God.”37 Two
decades later Paula Mueller would observe that her organization “opposes
regulation . . . in the first instance because it makes a mockery of the divine
commandment of the immortal value of every human soul,” that regulation
constituted an “official sanction of the business of commercial vice,” and that
brothels were “true breeding-grounds of vice and crime” and of “frightful
degeneracy and vicious aberrations.”38
Protestant women took familiar positions as well on modern fashion, trashy
literature, suggestive dances, sexual harassment, suggestive advertising, the general decline of moral rigor, and so on.39 Mueller believed that the “confusion
of true art with pseudo-art” was a major cause of moral decline; and the DFHS
journal observed in 1902 that modern literature was not art but “modern lies,
modern cowardice.”40 The 1904 volume of the DEF’s journal – the Evangelische Frauenzeitung – carried articles on “trashy” entertainments and the way
the average citizen wasted money on frivolities (two billion marks were spent
annually in the cinema, for example); on a particularly heinous case of child
sexual abuse in Breslau; on the sexual adventurism of students; on the possibility of putting more aggressive restrictions on Animierkneipen; and on women’s
“unpatriotic” and “lascivious” modern fashions. The same volume set forth

the DEF’s demands regarding the revision of the Criminal Code, which were
very similar to those of the AKDS – including raising the age of consent, adding
employers to the list of those who could be punished for using their authority to force others into immoral acts (the “employer paragraph”), making the
knowing transmission of venereal diseases a crime, and abolishing regulated
prostitution.41 The social ideal that underlay these views was also the same
as that propagated by the men’s morality organizations: “self-discipline and
self-control for man and woman,” as Paula Mueller put it in 1911, or, in 1914,
“self-sacrificing chivalry . . . for man and self-denying devotion for woman.”42
Again, Catholic women organized in the KDF were much more reticent
about immorality than their counterparts in the DFHS or the DEF. When
they did speak out on such issues, however, their views were quite similar.
Hedwig Dransfeld, who served as a kind of spokeswoman for the KDF on the
morality question even before she became chair of the organization in 1912, is
a particularly striking case. The modern age, she contended, was characterized
by a “confusion of opinions more colorful and muddled than almost any other
age has seen.” Modern literature was “unprincipled in a downright frightful
degree” and was guided only by a desire “to make a sensation at any cost.”43
Schund and Schmutz publications were sources of “spiritual infection” that
spread the “sexual over-excitation and confused ideas” of the age. Trashy
literature could lead people into “appalling crimes”; it “excites the imagination
and the senses in disordered fashion and makes one incapable of perceiving real
life.” Specifically in sexual matters, it was “seductive” and “ruinous.” Such
works were dangerous for “half-grown youth or the uneducated woman” and
the “broad mass of the people.”44 It all derived, she held, in 1914, from the
“elimination of the religious element from public and private morality” and
from the fact that in the modern age “material is God, and the spirit . . . has
become a servant where it should rule.”45
Dransfeld’s essays and speeches were atypical; most of the Catholic women’s
leadership was far more restrained and sought to encourage Catholic women to
take part in the morality crusade in specifically “feminine” ways – by educating
their children in moral restraint and religious faith; protecting sexual life with

the “cloak of sacred modesty”; not tolerating questionable books, pictures, or
statues in their homes; boycotting stores that sold immoral books and pictures;
and so on.46 Despite the gender-appropriate packaging, however, the message
was fundamentally the same: modern society was corrupt, destructive, and
unstable because it was godless.
The moderate majority within the nonconfessional women’s movement,
including in the DZIAF, advanced views far less similar to those of conservative men. Most of these women were liberal Protestants and were profoundly
estranged from some of the views of their theologically conservative counterparts. Anna Pappritz of the IAF, for example, was horrified by the efforts of the
morality campaigners to pass more restrictive censorship legislation – which
she saw as an attempt to censor anything that “represents liberal tendencies
in religious or political respect” and as a product of “inner unchasteness,”
which caused people to “suspect every form of nudity and naturalness of being
indecent.”47 Many liberal Protestants found the beliefs and attitudes of their
orthodox colleagues outdated and overly restrictive and deplored the undertone of anti-Semitism in their publications and speeches.48 Katharina Scheven
even offered an explicitly secular justification for her (sexually conservative,
politically liberal, and feminist) beliefs, regarding it as a “great advantage”
that her creed “does not claim to be revealed truth”; and she argued that
the moral catastrophe of her society was the product not of a falling away
from God but of men’s power.49 A deep political difference also divided these
two Protestant communities; most of the moderate leadership were left-liberals
who supported votes for women, rather than conservatives, who were, at best,
ambivalent about women’s suffrage.50
On two fundamental practical issues directly related to the problem of
immorality, moreover, there was an important difference between the conservative morality movement and moderate or liberal Protestant women. The
first was the straightforward liberal principle that the state is a creature not of
morality but of law, and that its function is not to force people to be good –
to enforce moral order – but to secure the rights of the citizen. Fundamental to
this form of liberalism was the understanding that the survival and flourishing
of the good society is the result not of the omnipresence of authority but of
46

Mumbauer, “Der Anteil der Frau am Kampfe gegen die öffentliche Unsittlichkeit,” CF 5 (1906):
24, 63, 82.
47 Anna Pappritz, “Wie ich zu meiner Arbeit kam,” LAB, HLA, B-Rep 235-13, pp. 59a, 87.

Religion, Women, and Morality

89

the maximization of the citizen’s freedom to engage in the pursuit of his or
her own rational self-interest. The second was their emphasis on the idea that
regulation was unjust because it affected only women and thus breached the
principle of equality before the law.
The two most influential leaders of the DZIAF, Katharina Scheven and Anna
Pappritz, summed up that organization’s position in a pamphlet on criminal
law reform in 1909. Regulation was unacceptable “from a legal standpoint,
because it represents an unjustified encroachment on civil liberty, and it is
unjust, because it affects only one party to a shared act, the woman.”51 Criminalization of prostitution would merely further reinforce the double standard
on which regulation was built, because “punishment would only affect the
woman, while the man, who is in many cases the more guilty party and in all
cases an accomplice, would go unpunished.” The state should intervene only in
cases of coercion or of the abuse of minors, cases of procuring, or cases in which
overly raucous solicitation created a disturbance of public order and an endangerment of public decency. Otherwise, sex was “a private concern of the individuals, whose freedom the state would impugn in outrageous fashion if it set
itself up as judge and warder of . . . sexual life.”52 As one speaker at the DZIAF’s
1906 conference put it, it was the right of any citizen to dispose of his property as he wished, for example, by hiring a prostitute. In prostitution women
merely disposed of their bodies as they wished – “and who can deny them
that?”53
In an important programmatic essay printed in the Abolitionist in 1913,
Katharina Scheven made explicit the political allegiances these ideas implied.
Scheven was optimistic about the development of modern culture and society, welcoming “the great movements that have taken up the struggle against
social injustice and for the liberation of humanity from outward and inward
servitude . . . : the women’s movement, the morality movement, the temperance movement, and last not least the workers’ movement.” Of the concept
of class struggle that inspired the latter, she remarked that “I for my part
deeply deplore it”; but she insisted that the movement itself was inspired by “a
profound ethical meaning, a vital idealism.”54 Such language must have nonplussed conservative Christians, who identified the socialist movement with
materialism, not idealism.
This was not an isolated case. Although most of their Christian counterparts
regarded contraception as profoundly immoral, for example, some moderates

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

viewed it with genuine ambivalence. The Abolitionist did carry some articles
critical of contraception – for example, one in 1911 argued that the use of contraceptives was driven by “solely egotistical” motives and was a demographic
and hence military disaster for the nation.55 Yet Anna Pappritz, in 1906, supported the “regulation” of births to ensure that mothers had a rest period of
at least two years between deliveries; and Katharina Scheven suggested that
the IAF’s “rejection of interference by the state in sexual relations . . . logically”
implied acceptance, for example, of doctors’ advocacy of the use of condoms.56
The abolitionist approach to venereal diseases demonstrated a similar pragmatism. For the men’s morality campaigners, venereal diseases were not really a
“problem” to be resolved at all, because if there were no fornication, there
would be no venereal diseases. They therefore did not think much about actually treating or preventing these diseases. The abolitionists, in contrast, developed quite concrete proposals in this direction. They argued for “free and
humane hospital treatment,” the creation of a system of free policlinics and
outpatient services, and the inclusion of venereal diseases among those covered by the public insurance system (which under existing law were classified
as self-inflicted injury and were not covered or only partially covered).57 The
proper way to combat prostitution and venereal diseases, Scheven argued, was
not to cast prostitutes out of society through the use of discriminatory laws
but to “constantly re-integrate this group into the national organism through
special welfare measures.”58
Despite such differences, however, most of the “moderates” were liberal
Protestants and also had a great deal in common with their more conservative
coreligionists. Again, up until 1902, the BDF’s position on prostitution was
virtually the same as that advocated by the AKDS.59 Bieber-Böhm’s “suggestions for combating prostitution,” which were adopted by the BDF in 1895,
advocated confining “our straying sisters” to reformatories for a period of one
to two years. And in order to cut off recruitment to the sex trade, Bieber-Böhm
also proposed stricter measures against “immoral books, pictures, displays,
closing of questionable dance locales, the worst sort of night-cafes, TingelTangel, questionable ‘girl pubs’ and wine-bars with private rooms,” the raising
of the age of consent, the “employer paragraph,” and criminalizing the knowing transmission of venereal diseases. Although the BDF did adopt abolitionism

in 1902, it continued to support much of this broader repressive program.60
Many in the IAF, too, supported stricter censorship and other repressive moral
legislation – as when, for example, Anna Pappritz welcomed new legislation
against Schmutz in 1914 that many other political liberals saw as an assault on
the freedom of German culture.61
And the moderates agreed with conservative Christians on a number of
fundamentally important postulates. They shared the view that the double
standard of sexual morality was indefensible and the root cause of the sexual
chaos they saw all around them. They rejected the idea that prostitution was
a necessary evil, denouncing it as “ridiculous,” a transparent cover for “selfishness,” for “the simple motive of lust or whim.”62 They held that men bore
the greatest responsibility for the sexual chaos of their society – that, as the
Abolitionist put it in 1905, the “moral anarchy” created by the double standard was simply a product of “men’s lack of discipline in sexual matters.”63
They saw regulation as fundamentally contrary to the legal and constitutional
principles of modern society – a glaring failure to make the transition from
the “old police-state to the modern state founded on law [Rechtsstaat]” (in the
words of Scheven).64 The DZIAF argued in a petition to the Ministry of Justice in August 1904 that it “contradicts the modern social sense that the state
declares some people to be a diversionary target for the desires of others, labels
them as second-class beings, as slaves.” Tellingly, virtually the same phrasing
had appeared in an article by Anna Pappritz published in the BDF’s journal in
December 1903, in an AKDS petition of March 1904; and in a BDF petition in
early 1905.65

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

Like conservative Christians, abolitionist women were acutely aware of the
class dynamics of prostitution, seeing regulation as “only motivated by the
desire to secure ‘healthy goods’ for the young men of their own circles, for
propertied, educated men” (in the words of Pappritz).66 They too believed that
regulation was ethically indefensible because it reduced women to the status of
mere things, indeed to “slavery.”67 They too argued that regulation represented
a “fateful incitement to immorality” for young men, making prostitution seem
“permitted and natural and moreover not dangerous.”68 Brothels in particular were “sites of moral brutalization”; rape and child abuse therefore “lie
along a line of continuity with prostitution,” and the state that regulated prostitution was therefore the “intellectual author of these crimes.”69 The pimps
and hangers-on who gathered around the tolerated brothels “represent a terrible social danger.”70 Some even believed that regulation generated corruption
in the police – an argument that was occasionally confirmed by sensational
scandals within vice squads.71
In any case, in the following year the Abolitionist declared that the “low
moral level in every area of our cultural life is largely determined by the fact
that vice is officially licensed and legalized.”72 Particularly fatefully, it undermined family life by disrupting marriages and generally “poisoning . . . relations
between the two sexes.”73 It accustomed men to the greater “variety” of
“polygamy freed from any responsibility,” taught them “loathsome practices”
and “perverse inclinations” that estranged them from their wives, and disgusted women with men’s “naked and crass” selfishness.74 And all this served
no good purpose, because regulation was completely ineffective as a public
health measure.75
Abolitionist women largely concurred, as well, with the conservative Christian diagnosis of the deeper moral crisis of their society. As the Abolitionist
put it in 1906, the fight against prostitution was at the same time a fight
“against all the dark forces that are corrupting our national and political life:

injustice, arbitrariness, exploitation of the weak, selfishness, pleasure-seeking
and low sensuality.”76 The moderates too believed that “civilized humanity is
without doubt sexually over-stimulated today” due to “alcohol, the sensually
excited hot-house atmosphere of big-city entertainments, regulated prostitution . . . , filth in literature and art” – and the decay of “inherited unquestioned standards, sacred custom, religious traditions” (in the words of Alice
Salomon).77 They too held that modernity was characterized – as Gertrud
Bäumer, a leading moderate who became chair of the BDF in 1910, put it in
1909 – by a deplorable “diversity . . . that produces new [philosophical] systems, new world-views, every day.”78
Abolitionists often shared, finally, more conservative women’s understanding of the broader implications of sexual immorality. Anna Pappritz, for example, believed that immorality in this one area could only fuel immorality in
every other aspect of life; for a person accustomed to committing immoral
actions in his sexual life “will not hesitate to give free rein to his selfish wishes
at the expense of other people in other respects, as well.”79 Katharina Scheven
echoed conservative Christian critiques of capitalism in 1913, arguing that the
“miserable social distress” of poor women “is commercially exploited by modern industrialism,” that prostitution was a “rank capitalist weed,” and that
the “frightening growth of sexual vice and perversity in every form” was a
product of the growth of the “big-city Lumpenproletariat” under the influence
of “capitalism and industrialism.”80
Not surprisingly, then, abolitionists and more conservative women often
were able to cooperate on some of the key initiatives of the morality campaign. In late 1910, for example, a broad coalition of women’s organizations
formed the Central Committee of the German Women’s Organizations for
Combating Trash and Filth in Words and Pictures, which brought together
representatives from the BDF, the IAF, the KDF, the KFV, the DEF, and teachers’ organizations.81 Similar coalitions formed locally as well – in 1910 in
Munich, for example, the IAF, KDF, DEF, and other organizations collaborated in protesting against Animierkneipen, and in Frankfurt the IAF and the
DEF even cooperated with the Catholic men’s morality association; in Danzig
in 1909 the IAF, DEF, KDF, and VFJM jointly established an employment

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

agency for young women.82 Organizational ties between the DEF and the IAF
in particular were strong; and the language of activists in the two organizations
was sometimes strikingly similar.83
On the face of it, this convergence appears rather odd. The moderates were,
after all, committed to an extensive range of social and legal reforms that
would have revolutionized gender relations in Germany: votes for women, fully
equal access to education and the professions, and reforms of family law that
would establish gender equality within the family. Many conservative Christian women and most Christian men rejected this program. But again, the two
movements actually shared an important religious common ground. Most abolitionists subscribed to some variety of non-conformist liberal Protestantism; a
few were liberal Jews or – as in the case of Alice Salomon – Jewish converts
to liberal Christianity; and these women’s arguments for women’s liberation
were rooted precisely in a gendered variant of the conservative Christian view
of the moral crisis of modernity. The capacity for childbearing and their natural
role in child rearing, they argued, gave all women a particular psychological,
spiritual, and emotional constitution, an affinity for life and organic relationships (as opposed to mechanical structure, which corresponded to masculinity). Women were nurturing; they were emotional; they were generous; and
they were characterized by warmth, feeling, a natural tendency to be attentive
to others’ needs, and a natural willingness to subordinate their own needs to
those of others or of the community as a whole. It was woman’s special mission to bring these values and capacities to bear on social life in general, rather
than realizing them only within their own families; and it was on this basis
that they argued for women’s rights. The reform of family law was necessary
to secure women’s influence within the family; reforms of constitutional law,
educational systems, the professions, the churches, and other institutional and
legal systems were necessary to secure their influence in society as a whole – to
make “the independent female citizen,” as Helene Lange, the godmother of the
moderate faction within the BDF, put it, “the representative of motherliness in
politics.”84
These women argued that German society desperately needed this motherly influence because it was suffering from a pathological predominance of
male values and characteristics. Their list of those values and characteristics
roughly corresponded to the conservative Christians’ list of the godless values of
modernity: rationality, materialism, self-assertion, aggression, pleasure seeking,

moneymaking, organization, and hunger for power. Without the humanizing influence of women, these male qualities degenerated into rigid adherence
to ideologies and ideological conflict, selfishness, violence, irresponsible lust,
greed, and amoral materialism – all those fundamentally amoral behaviors that
conservative Christians deplored.
The moderate leadership thus had an almost messianic understanding of
the social and moral mission of women. Gertrud Bäumer, for example, characterized what men did – science, technology, economics, and the intellect –
as superficial “civilization,” which was all very nice but secondary; it became
really meaningful only when it “becomes a means of creating the most perfect
possible people, nourishment for the growth of the soul.” This latter was the
special province of women, whose mission was “of course in the end what is
essential”: “culture” – the life of the spirit, the heart, the emotions, and the
cultivation of genuine Persönlichkeit (individuality).85 The leading Bavarian
moderate feminist Ika Freudenberg had made an almost identical argument in
the journal of the moderate faction of the BDF, Die Frau, five years earlier,
arguing that men were all about “force of arms . . . business and transport . . . ,
science and technology” and the mechanization of work, life, and even art,
whereas women’s job was the “perfection of real [eigentlichen], personal life.”
And whereas man’s tendency was to “put a low value on his own life and the
lives of others,” women’s job was “to sustain life.”86
Fundamentally, then, the moderates understood the women’s movement to
be an effort to secure the dominion of the spirit over the flesh – which was how
they, too, defined morality. For example, Marianne Weber, wife of sociologist
Max Weber and an influential figure in the moderate women’s movement,
argued at the Protestant Social Congress conference of 1907 that
wherever moral ideas arise at all, the physical needs of the sexual sphere and the
demands of spiritual culture can come into conflict with each other. A general
harmony between the elemental forces of the “natural” and the “should” of the
moral will has never and nowhere existed. On the contrary, there is immanent
in the undisciplined, “natural” physical instinct always the tendency so strongly
to intrude into the psychic realm that it destroys our equally natural instinct and
capacity for its moralization.87

Again, sex was a matter of life and death for the moral personality. Gertrud
Bäumer even quoted with approval the contribution of another speaker at the

conference who warned of the “unbelievable demonic power of the sexual drive
to drag down even spiritual, refined individuals into animalistic sensuality” –
although in an essay of 1910 she seemed to exempt women, citing another
author’s remark that the “strict sexual discipline of the Christian centuries”
had given them “a natural independence with respect to the naked instinctual
needs.”88 But culture aside, monogamy also had its origins in “the biological
connection between love and motherhood in women”; for women, “the sexual
question is really the tension between the demands of their feelings of love and
the erotic life of men” – which was not spiritual, emotional, or procreative but
simply physical and hedonistic.89 As Helene Lange argued in Die Frau in 1905,
“the whole women’s movement is, in its deepest meaning, a struggle for the
validity of moral ideals in contrast with external material force.” The Christian
ideal of monogamy was actually “a victory of Woman over the polygamous
instincts of men.”90
There was an important difference, of course, between the views of the moderate women’s movement and those of conservative Christians. The Christian
men’s morality movement believed that men were particularly responsible for
the moral catastrophe all around them; but they believed that only the reconstitution of patriarchal authority would bring about the restoration of moral
order. Many in the women’s movement believed that only the full emancipation of women, the final abolition of the outdated forms (legal, social, and
attitudinal) of patriarchal culture, would do so.
Yet in practical terms the moderate women’s movement was in some cases
quite willing to contemplate taking rather draconian measures to stem the flood
of immorality. This was so even where such action would be taken primarily
against other women. A good example is the concern of the moderate women’s
movement with the Waitress Question (Kellnerinnenfrage) – the belief that
women who worked in bars, cabarets, restaurants, and cafes were simply in
the anteroom to prostitution, and that their moral endangerment required protective intervention. The rapid expansion in the number of such establishments
in the last decade or two of the nineteenth century shocked and outraged many
bourgeois women. By 1910 the situation appeared sufficiently critical to move
Camilla Jellinek, an influential figure in the BDF and head of its law reform commission, to draw up a petition that – “in the name of the dignity of woman” –
asked the Ministry of the Interior and the national parliament to outlaw the
employment of women as waiters in bars and restaurants.91

This was by no means the only response of the moderate women’s movement
to the “problem” of waitressing. Ika Freudenberg in particular vehemently
rejected Jellinek’s proposal to eliminate one of all too few opportunities for
women’s employment.92 In 1900 Freudenberg had helped to launch a waitresses’ union in Munich, and a number of leading moderates – including
Salomon, Lange, and Pappritz – were part of a failed effort to form a similar
organization in Berlin in the same year.93 Such efforts met with little success,
however; and the petition of 1910 might be seen as the product of bourgeois
women’s realization that self-help efforts would not be effective in improving
the working conditions and wages of waitresses.
Waitressing was not a unique case. Anna Pappritz even went so far as to
demand the “banning of all places of entertainment that are nothing more
than veiled brothels” – including, for example, “indecent displays and performances” that had no “artistic value” but merely served “commercial hunger
for profit.”94 In 1908 the Abolitionist carried a liberal Protestant pastor’s
denunciation of “immoral literature” printed on cheap paper, published in
mass editions, and presenting “exciting narratives” in “miserable German”;
“allegedly scientific or medical texts on sexual matters and perversions”; and
“newspaper accounts of murder and robbery.” Against all these things it was
self-evidently necessary, the author believed, to “proceed with decision and
ruthlessly” in order to stop the “ruiners of the nation” who “fill their pockets
by producing, publishing, and distributing such smut.” Such things, “which
speculate on peoples’ low, less-than-human instincts for the sake of money,”
must be rooted out “without mercy or pity.”95
Again, much of the leadership of the radical faction and particularly of the
VFF had little sympathy with such views, rejecting them as morally authoritarian and “churchified” (as Die Frauenbewegung put it in 1905).96 They were,
however, clearly in a minority. In fact, the controversy over the sexually radical
New Ethic advanced by some of these women after 1905 (a subject explored
in Chapter Nine) rapidly polarized the DZIAF and allowed the moderates
around Katharina Scheven and Anna Pappritz to consolidate their control of
the organization. Some of the radicals shifted the focus of their activism to
the issue of women’s suffrage; others abandoned the DZIAF in favor of the
new sex-reform movement. By 1908 the DEF joined the BDF; in contrast, the
main sex-reform organization, the League for the Protection of Motherhood

(Bund für Mutterschutz [BfM]) was refused membership in that organization.97
III. From Silence to Solidarity: Morality as Women’s Business
There is one further important respect in which conservative and liberal women
shared common ground: both groups faced powerful organizational and cultural obstacles in advancing their ideas in public. Women in both groups produced much less verbiage than did their male counterparts – fewer articles,
fewer speeches, fewer conference reports, and far fewer books. The central reason for this should be obvious: men simply had incomparably greater financial,
organizational, and intellectual resources than did women. The leaders of the
men’s morality organizations included clergymen and in fact often high church
officials, professors of theology, judges, military officers, directors of charitable
institutions, or civil servants. They could build on institutional frameworks that
were very powerful and very wealthy. Most had university educations. Most
women had few or none of these resources. Married women also carried the
entire burden of running their households – which is why almost all German
women’s organizations were dominated by unmarried, widowed, or childless
women, in particular teachers (who in most German states were fired upon
marriage).98
Beyond this, there was also enormous resistance in German society around
the turn of the century to the very idea of women speaking about sexuality
at all. Gertrud Guillaume-Schack opened an address in 1882 by remarking
that “perhaps it will have surprised you, that a matter so difficult to handle
as the morality question should be discussed in public, and perhaps yet more
that I, a woman, want to speak about it.”99 At the BDF’s first conference in
1895, the organization’s board attempted to prevent any public discussion of
its petition to the national parliament on prostitution, because it dealt with
“very awkward matters”; and when Bieber-Böhm addressed an international
women’s conference in Berlin in 1896 on the subject of “The Morality Question – A Public Health Issue,” some women in the audience promptly got up
and left.100 After the turn of the century women became more accustomed to
speaking about such matters, even in public. But more conservative women
continued to find doing so painful. Katharina Scheven remarked in 1904 that it
“is still regarded in many educated circles as unbecoming to know about these
97

things, mush less to talk about them.”101 Even as late as 1909, speaking at
the annual conference of the Inner Mission, Paula Mueller told the assembled
Protestant notables that “we are well aware that it affronts the sensibilities of
the best men and women, if in these matters women too raise their voices in
public.”102
This cultural code could have important legal consequences, for women also
faced stubborn resistance from men who believed that such matters were none
of their business. The extreme case was that of Gertrud Guillaume-Schack, who
was tried for gross misconduct because she dared to speak out on prostitution
at all.103 Anita Augspurg had to fight a protracted and bitter struggle against
the police in Hamburg in the years immediately after she refounded the German
branch of the IAF in 1898. The police closed down her public addresses on the
subject of the regulation of prostitution because, as a representative of the city
put it in the national parliament, the open discussion of sexuality, particularly
where young women were present, constituted a “more serious threat to public
decency” than the existence of the brothels themselves. The school authorities
also shut down the sex education sessions the Hamburg IAF had begun holding
for young people graduating from the city’s schools, in 1901.104
More conservative Protestant men, in fact, so objected to public appearances
by women that they regarded the mere foundation of the DEF as a deplorable
“concession to the modern Zeitgeist.”105 In 1912 and 1913, the DEF leadership engaged in a bitter debate with conservative Protestant men about its
position on women’s suffrage – which it rejected for political reasons (because
the SPD was very successful in organizing working-class women) but not on
principle.106 The KDF and the JFB were more cautious in their approach to controversial topics and questioned traditional conceptions of women’s roles less
aggressively; but they too faced resistance within their communities. In 1908,
for example, the KDF petitioned for the right for women to address the annual
conference of German Catholics (the Katholikentag) – and was denied.107 As
