Moral Reform, 1880–1900

the reaction against the women’s movements intensified in 1912 and 1913,
Ellen Ammann, leader of the KDF’s Bavarian branch, remarked in a particularly
candid letter (to her mother) that “the whole [KDF] is threatened” by men in the
Volksverein, who regarded the women’s organization as “too independent.”108
The formation of the JFB and in particular the demands of its chair, Bertha
Pappenheim, that women be given a voice in the government of their congregations sparked the creation in 1907 of a rival organization of more conservative
Jewish women, supported by influential male colleagues.109
The hostility of men to women’s engagement with questions of sexual morality may, moreover, also have derived in part from the fact that women across
the ideological spectrum had a much narrower conception of what the problem
was than did their male counterparts. The moral crisis addressed by women’s
organizations consisted primarily of one thing: prostitution. There were echoes
of conservative men’s understanding of the connection between sex and politics
in women’s speeches or publications; but the connection between sexuality and
socialism, between sexuality and capitalism, and between trashy literature and
political radicalism were not of central interest to women, as they were for men.
“For women,” as Gertrud Bäumer put it in Die Frau in 1907, the “tragedy”
of sexual life was men’s incapacity to maintain the boundary between spiritual
love and “purely animalistic” sensuality – “to maintain which is, for every
person, a rule of spiritual self-preservation.”110
This narrower focus among female morality activists had two important consequences. The first was that even more conservative women were concerned
to a greater degree with the specific social origins of prostitution than with its
roots in the broader moral condition of the age. As we have seen, conservative
Christian men were very much aware of the financial imperatives that drove
women into the sex trade; but they saw those problems as a consequence of the
disintegration of the patriarchal social order, the erosion of religious conviction
and hence of Christian family life, the crisis of social authority, the triumph of
philosophical materialism and selfishness, and so forth. For women, the misery
of the working class in general and the pervasive discrimination against women
in the labor force in particular were the heart of the issue.
This was particularly true, of course, in the DZIAF. Prostitution was,
as the Abolitionist put it in 1906, simply “a symptom of our faulty social
organization.”111 Abolitionists looked to social reform, not religious revival or
12 January 1913, Archiv des katholischen deutschen Frauenbundes (hereinafter AKDF),
1-33-1, Katholikentage I.

109 Klausmann, Politik, pp. 182–186.

Religion, Women, and Morality

101

the police, for a solution. Above all else, that meant just and adequate wages and
equal access to education, employment, and the professions for women.112 Pappritz and Scheven summed up the social reform program of the DZIAF in their
1909 pamphlet: they held that “prostitution is primarily called forth by demand
from the side of men, and that it is often social distress that forces women to
meet this demand with the corresponding supply.” The proper response was
not use of the criminal system but protective legislation for women workers,
“organization of women workers, in order to secure for them a living wage,”
and better access for women to education and vocational training.113
The abolitionists were quite aware that this perspective put them at odds
with the men’s morality movement. In an article of 1903, Scheven stressed the
positive achievements of the Protestant men’s morality movement in bringing
“ethical demands” to bear against the “purely sanitary and policing standpoint” of the defenders of regulation. But the Christian morality movement,
she believed, did not understand that prostitution was
above all a social ill and hangs together with our social order, capitalism, industrialism, militarism . . . and that one of its main causes is the economic, legal, and
moral dependence and lack of freedom of women. . . . Prostitution is seen too
much as a sin and a vice, the increase of which is traced back to falling away
from God, and which one must fight by calling on religious-moral influences and,
where they don’t suffice, the criminal law.

More important than such religious or legal measures, she believed, was “a
transformation of our social conditions . . . above all the economic and political
emancipation of woman.”114
This position was reinforced as women became more active in social work
from the late 1890s onward. Anna Pappritz, for example, published an influential collection and interpretation of short biographies of women working in
the sex trade based on the case notes of a female police assistant, in 1907.
On the basis of these examples from “real life,” she concluded that both the
“apostles of morality” and “social policy experts of the school of Lombroso”
(who argued that prostitutes were simply “born whores”) were mistaken, and
“that in almost all cases economic causes, that is need, social misery, deliver
the girls into prostitution.”115 Moral categories were simply inadequate tools
for understanding the social phenomenon of prostitution.
In consequence, abolitionists tended to be more exclusively critical of men.
Conservative Christian men very clearly identified men’s anarchic sexual behavior as the sexual problem of the age. But they embedded their critique in a much

broader analysis of deeper ills of which they believed it to be an expression –
materialism, selfishness, lack of religious conviction, and so on. Abolitionists
less frequently portrayed men’s behavior as an expression of any deeper problem. More often, they believed simply that men as a species were, in moral
terms, contemptible. The sexual problem of the age was not men who had
been seduced by the moral and philosophical evils of the times; it was just men.
As one article in Die Frau remarked in 1905, “the man is the man’s worst
seducer.”116 In fact, whereas Christian men identified sexual anarchy with
scoundrels, libertines, seducers, and wastrels, there was a markedly stronger
tendency in the women’s movements to see immoral and antisocial behavior
as characteristic not of problem men but in fact of the average man. This was
particularly true in the case of the radicals in the abolitionist movement. Thus
the leading sex reformer Helene Stöcker, for example, held that “in sexual
matters the average man is still not a civilized person, but a crude barbarian,”
and the enormously successful women’s novelist Gabriele Reuter believed that
“the relationship of most men to women is an unending chain of hypocrisies,
untruths and insincerities.”117 But the moderate leadership was scarcely less
vehement. Already in 1895 Hanna Bieber-Böhm had asserted that 99 percent of
young men “lead an immoral life before marriage.” Katharina Scheven believed
that “the average member of our male public” was essentially a sexual predator. The DZIAF’s petition to the national Ministry of Justice in 1904 argued
for the “employer paragraph” on the grounds that the “lax moral conceptions of the average man” meant he could not be trusted with authority over
women.118
Specifically, abolitionist women shared with most educated Germans in this
period the belief that whereas women were by nature monogamous, men were
by nature polygamous – or, perhaps more accurately, indiscriminate. As Alice
Salomon put it, men had a “tendency . . . toward fleeting relationships, whereas
the majority of women only give themselves to a man in the belief and hope
of a lasting, indissoluble shared life.”119 Gertrud Bäumer held that the ideal
of monogamous marriage “has its origins not only in spiritual culture, but
in the biological connection in women between love and motherhood.”120
Quite aside from such anthropological theories, however, these women simply
held that men had laxer moral standards. As Katharina Scheven wrote in

1905, men did not have the “inner discipline of a sense of responsibility”
that prevented freedom from “degenerating into licentiousness.”121 Women
sometimes explicitly drew the obvious conclusion from such ideas: that, as
Pappritz put it in 1904, “a large part of the masculine world does not possess
the moral maturity and the moral seriousness to deal with such matters with the
appropriate measure of dignity,” and that therefore women were “the proper
leaders in this area.”122
A fundamental principle underlay and necessarily proceeded from this
understanding of morality as something that women defended and men trampled on: the principle of female solidarity. The social gulf between bourgeois
women and working-class prostitutes permitted the women’s movement to
support relatively draconian measures – such as those advanced by BieberBöhm and the BDF both before and after 1902. But over time the idea that
prostitution was an affront to all women, that it compromised the interests
and honor of respectable middle-class women no less than those of poor
women actually working in the sex trade, steadily gained ground. Already
in 1881 Gertrud Guillaume-Schack had pointed out that “police regulations
affect all women equally,” because even respectable women had no recourse
against arbitrary police power.123 Almost two decades later, the growing
frequency of cases in which this warning was born out helped to mobilize
women in support of abolitionism. Thus in 1897 Marie Raschke, commenting on one such case in Die Frauenbewegung, observed that “every German
woman . . . must feel herself insulted by the awful treatment of this girl.”124 A
BDF resolution of 1902 declared §361.6 to be “a disgrace for the entirety of
German womankind,” warning that the police “are turned by this paragraph
into a danger for the female half of the nation.”125 The Abolitionist, appealing in 1906 to the “feeling of solidarity” of women, objected that regulation
reflected and enforced “the sexual bondage and denial of rights of the whole
sex.”126
Again, conservative religious women shared a great deal of their male colleagues’ broader moral and political analysis and were less focused on women’s
social disabilities, much less their political rights, than were the abolitionists.
There were exceptions – Bertha Pappenheim in particular published, for example, an influential essay in Die Frau in 1901 on “The Social Origins of Prostitution,” which was foundational to the abolitionists’ social analysis.127 But the
majority in the religious women’s organizations focused on moral, not social,

concerns. It is all the more striking, therefore, that particularly in the second half
of the decade of the 1900s the language of female solidarity cropped up with
growing frequency even among confessional women, especially in the DEF.
Thus in 1906 Countess Münster, reviewing the whole analysis of the social
origins of prostitution, expressed sympathy for the “justified outrage over the
degradation of their sex” that moved some women to the regrettable “passion”
sometimes betrayed by female critics of regulation.128 By 1912 Paula Mueller
appealed to the “sentiment of solidarity” among her colleagues: “As women
we are outraged by the fact that members of our sex, who should be as sisters
to us, are treated as . . . commodities. Their humiliation affects us.”129
In fact within a few years of its formation the DEF was drifting, under the
impact of such sentiments, toward open adoption of the abolitionist position.
By 1904 Paula Mueller made it clear in the DEF’s journal that she, unlike the
leaders of the AKDS, regarded the criminalization of prostitution as “impossible today without leading to the greatest injustice against women, and above
all against poor women.” She explicitly rejected the idea that the state had no
“right to intervene in matters of morality”; but, as she pointed out, the DZIAF’s
commitment to using the state to combat “all manifestations of immorality that
make themselves evident in public life” meant that the two organizations were
largely in agreement.130 In early 1908 the organization’s morality commission
finally voted overwhelmingly in favor of decriminalizing prostitution, with only
one vote in dissent.131
The DEF as an organization did not formally adopt this position before
World War I. But it was increasingly involved in advocating it in practice. The
DEF sent a representative to the 1908 conference of the DZIAF and joined
the BDF in 1908 – against the advice of its spiritual advisors, pastors Weber
and Mätzold of the AKDS. Later that year the BDF reiterated its demand
for the abolition of §361.6, by unanimous vote and without discussion.132
By 1910 Mueller exactly echoed abolitionist language in the journal of the
DEF: “A complete eradication of prostitution through police repression” was
“impracticable,” and in any case “prostitution is a question of . . . personal
morality” and such problems “cannot be solved by the criminal law.”133

The defection of the DEF to abolitionism brought about a fundamental
change in the thinking of conservative Protestant men. Neither the Inner Mission nor the AKDS formally changed their position on prostitution before
World War I. In the last years before the war, however, there were intensive negotiations going on within the conservative Protestant morality movement, as men struggled to come to grips with the thinking of their female
counterparts. By June of 1912 the Inner Mission’s regional conference in the
more liberal southwest of the country adopted the abolitionist position.134 The
national organization thereupon established a special commission to reconsider the matter. Within that commission the representatives of the DEF and
the AKDS argued that the Inner Mission should advocate decriminalization.
More conservative members pointed out that the Central Committee of the
Inner Mission had to be more careful, because it was dependent on the public authorities; as one member put it, “one can’t demand the impossible of
the Central Committee.”135 Within the Central Committee itself, meeting in
November of 1912, more conservative members continued to insist on criminalization; but both Mueller and representatives of the AKDS advocated abolition
without criminalization, because (as Wilhelm Philipps put it) the “Protestant
standpoint” was “redeeming love,” not punishment.136 In the end the Central
Committee itself could not reach a clear decision and referred the question back
to the special commission.137 The issue was not resolved before the outbreak of
the Great War. The writing, however, was clearly on the wall. The presence of
women in the counsels of the Inner Mission had broken what one abolitionist
called the “hermetic isolation” of conservative Protestant men; the certitudes
of “male morality” were beginning to falter under the impact of “women’s
feeling of solidarity.”138
The language of solidarity with prostitutes almost never appeared in the
speeches and publications of the leadership of the JFB or the KDF, and these
organizations did not openly support the abolitionist position before 1914.

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

And yet, it appears that there was a dynamic at work here similar to that
apparent in the DEF. Again, Bertha Pappenheim in particular was one of the
architects of the social analysis of prostitution; and of course the JFB, too,
had joined the BDF in 1907 and apparently accepted the demand for decriminalization without demur.139 The KDF, like the broader Catholic morality
movement, avoided taking a clear stance on prostitution before World War I.
Prostitution appears not to have been a very important issue within the organization, which did not establish its own commission on the morality question
(Sittlichkeitskommission) until 1908.140 As was true among Protestants, the
most vehement resistance to abolitionism came from charity organizations
involved in “rescue” work, which depended heavily on cooperation with the
police. In the Rhineland, where the KFV was most influential, this view prevailed; and indeed the national KDF headquarters there even tried to rule out
discussion of the issue within its chapters. In Munich, in contrast, the local
branch of the KDF insisted on signing a petition of Bavarian women’s organizations in 1908 requesting that the Bavarian government support decriminalization in negotiations between the states over revision of the Criminal Code.141
Faced with such differences, the KDF established its own morality commission
in the same year.142
By 1914, then, the entire women’s movement was converging on a shared
set of ideas. Increasingly, all women involved in the morality movement were
speaking the language of female solidarity and of female moral authority. And
at least within the Protestant morality movement, they were able fundamentally
to change the terms of the debate already by 1912.
IV. Morality and Women’s Roles: The Erosion of Female
Patriarchalism
The claim to moral authority central to women’s engagement with the problem of morality was obviously also a broader claim to a public role, to political authority. This was clearest in the case of the nonconfessional women’s
movement. Here radicals and moderates alike argued fundamentally that – as
Helene Lange had put it in arguing for the vote for women in 1897 – “the

Religion, Women, and Morality

107

masculine state is a fiasco,” and that the influence of women was needed to rescue German society from the pathologies of masculine power.143 Unlike more
conservative Christians, they interpreted women’s essential difference from
men – their “motherliness” – not as disqualifying women from participation in
public life but precisely as the justification for women’s emancipation. Lange
summed up the argument in 1902: “The interest of society in the liberation of
woman derives from the differentiation of the sexes,” specifically from a quality
that “men have never had, nor can have . . . , motherliness.”144 As Bäumer put
it seven years later, the “suffusion of the merely civilizational achievements” (of
men) “with cultural values” (of women) “cannot be achieved through action
at a distance from the security of the home”; it required women’s “responsible,
self-conscious collaboration” in shaping public life – and hence fully equal civil
and social rights for women.145 The program of the nonconfessional women’s
movement included, however, not only a demand for equal access to the public
sphere but also that for the transformation of the private sphere. As Lange put
it in 1908, the women’s movement demanded “that all traces of the sexual
servitude of woman disappear from legal institutions, all provisions of marriage law that concede power to the husband, as husband, over the wife, and
all provisions by which the state itself sanctions the double standard.” There
must be “a transformation of marriage” in the direction of “comradeship” and
“mutual understanding.”146
This was not how the confessional women’s movements understood the matter. In fact the most influential journals of the Christian women’s organizations
quite frequently carried articles by men that explained the proper or legal or
biblical role of women in society and the family; and not surprisingly the views
presented in such pieces were profoundly conservative. In 1903, for example,
the KDF’s journal Die christliche Frau regaled its readers with the good old ideal
of “the man as the head of the marital unit, to its [mutual] advantage (because
community between two complete equals is simply unthinkable), not to his
own advantage.”147 Another essay in the same volume argued that married
women should not work, because they would then “be unable to do full justice
to the more important of her two callings, that of motherhood.” A third was
more ambivalent, holding that “woman has the right to learn everything she
is capable of, insofar as her femininity is not compromised,” demanding equal
pay for equal work, and arguing that girls who could support themselves financially would not have to enter into marriages of convenience or “meal-ticket
143

Helene Lange, Frauenwahlrecht (1899), reprinted in Elke Frederiksen, ed., Die Frauenfrage in
Deutschland 1865–1915 (Stuttgart: Reclam, 1981), pp. 386, 391 (quotations).
144 Helene Lange, “Wissen und sittliche Kultur,” Frau 10 (1902): 199.
145 Baümer, “Die Frauenbewegung und die Zukunft,” p. 524.
146 Lange, Frauenbewegung, pp. 74–75, 76.
147 Gottfried Schmitz, “Das Bürgerliche Gesetzbuch und die Frau,” CF 1 (1902/1903): 314.

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

marriages.” But it also stated flatly that “the man is the head of the family, the
wife is . . . the heart of the family. . . . So it should ever remain; that is natural
law and divine order.”148
The journals of the DFHS and the DEF were, particularly in their earlier
years, not significantly less conservative in outlook. Adolf Stoecker, for example, writing in the DEF’s journal in 1904, stated that there was no reason
why women should not study theology or law in order to work in women’s
religious orders, or with women’s trade unions. On the other hand, women’s
“primary mission” would always be in the family and in helping others – for
example, through work in child welfare; daycare; care for the ill, handicapped,
or needy; and so on. Women, he insisted, should “not offer the man false competition” by going beyond work in such helping professions. And “may God
preserve us from the vote for women!”149 Other men were considerably less
broad minded: one claimed in the DFHS journal in 1903, for example, that
“the modern woman rebels against divine, human and natural order” by championing equality rather than seeing to the vitality of the “roots of the German
nation . . . : fear of God, the Christian home, and chaste, good morals.”150 A
few pages later, the journal’s readers were assured that “God’s Word” required
of wives “humble and yet voluntary dependence and subordination within the
bounds set by God.”151
By about 1905, however, the first rumblings of a shift in perspective were
audible at least among conservative Protestant women. In 1895 the DFHS
journal carried an essay arguing that on simple economic grounds “the emancipatory efforts of women are in many respects completely justified,” but it
immediately countered the essay with another that fulminated against the radical women’s movement because their ideas “bear the mark of naturalism on
their brow” and that denounced the “false concept of freedom and equality”
that had given rise to “so-called ‘women’s emancipation.’” The gender order,
it insisted, was “a part of God’s plan for the world . . . which cannot be bent
or broken.”152 A decade later, in contrast, an increasing number of female
authors who published in the journal argued that some degree of “emancipation” was not a threat to but rather the precondition of sexual morality
and hence social order. Thus by 1906 Marie Martin, an influential and more
liberal figure in the DEF, argued that although “the natural and most honorable calling of any girl is to become a mother” and to be “a helpmeet and

companion to her husband,” actually this meant that women too must have a
Beruf, a calling. If women were forced to simply wait for life to bring them a
husband, they would end up in immoral “meal-ticket marriages” – which were
“in their innermost nature prostitution.” Besides, she suggested, men weren’t
really all that wonderful. They were uninterested in children, because they only
thought about sex; they enjoyed useless and destructive “party conflicts”; and
they had “a tendency to brutal force, to brutal pleasure, to the double standard.” From such people, Martin seemed to suggest, a little more independence
couldn’t hurt.153 As for work depriving children of their mothers, one article of
1910 suggested that serious working women would find ways to spend enough
time with their families. In any case, it was not “we” – the women’s movement –
who drove women into the workforce, but material need; and since they were
working, they might as well be well trained and well paid.154 Such views seem
hardly part of the intellectual world dominant in the same journal only a few
years before. Indeed, in 1912, when the (male) editors of the journal saw fit
to publish in its pages an announcement of the formation of the League for
Combating Women’s Emancipation, the journal received so many angry letters from its readers that in the next issue the editors were obliged to publish
the BDF’s response to the formation of the League – which pointed out that
there were 6.5 million single and 3 million married women in the labor force,
and that therefore it was “completely impossible to limit women’s professional
activity . . . to ‘single women’ in traditionally ‘female professions.’”155
This shift in the views of women in the DFHS undoubtedly reflected, among
other things, the influence of the DEF – which had begun to take on a “feminist
character” (as Katharina Scheven saw it) as early as 1903.156 One article in the
DEF’s journal in 1908, for example, celebrated the growing presence of women
in the legal profession (for example, as legal aid workers) with the observation
that “woman is beginning to conquer a place for herself in all areas of economic
and intellectual life.”157 Conservative Protestant women were clearly drifting
increasingly into confrontation with more traditionalist men in their milieu.
It does not appear that Catholic or Jewish women were – as yet – passing
through a similar transition. What discussion there was of politics and morality
in their organizations was not sufficiently extensive to constitute a renegotiation of the traditional ideal of women’s roles comparable to that occurring in
the Protestant community. Yet the very rapid growth of the KDF and JFB was

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

an important signal; and by 1908 the KDF did establish its own morality commission to discuss prostitution, indicating a new sense of independence. It is
surely not a coincidence that in the same year Die christliche Frau published its
first article supporting women’s suffrage.158 The choice of Hedwig Dransfeld
as leader of the KDF in 1912, too, put a woman with a passionate interest in
morality issues at the head of the organization – one who would, eight years
later, make her views on women’s proper political role clear when she was
elected to the German national parliament. And in some instances Catholic
women also suggested that morality fell under women’s purview and not
men’s – as when one remarked in Die christliche Frau in 1905 that “woman
is called by God to be the protector of domestic morality, the better angel of
her husband. . . . The man embodies physical force, woman moral,” or when
Hedwig Dransfeld remarked that women had always been the “decisive force
in the struggle against vice and its consequences.”159
In that sense, in helping to initiate the formation of the DEF and KDF in
particular, men in the Christian morality movements had, so to speak, let the
genie out of the lamp. Their intention had been to counteract the influence of
liberal Protestant women in the IAF and the BDF; by the 1910s, Protestant men
especially found themselves negotiating the details of their own acceptance of
some of the central principles and demands of those same organizations with
the very women they had helped to draw into public debate.
V. Women, Race, Class, and Power
In some respects, then, the agendas of morally conservative men and women
were very similar and converging, at least specifically with respect to their single
most important concern, prostitution. Equally strikingly, however, in other
respects they remained profoundly different. In particular, morally conservative
women seem simply not to have cared much about a whole range of issues that
were of central concern to their male counterparts. What is most striking here,
however, is not what women said about these issues, but what they did not say.
The most remarkable case is that of socialism. Conservative women did
reject Social Democracy; the DEF in particular in fact opposed women’s suffrage largely because its leadership feared that the SPD, with its ties to the
extensive women’s trade union movement, would be more successful than conservative parties in mobilizing female voters. But again, the connection their
male counterparts saw between socialism and immorality was simply not a
significant theme even in the publications of the DEF leadership; and the KDF
158

Baumann, “Religion und Emanzipation,” p. 109; Eilsabeth Gnauck-Kühne, “Christin und
Staatsbürgerin,” CF 7 (1908): 4–8.
159 Cäcilie Movius, “Die Pflicht der Gebildeten zur Fürsorge für jugendliche Verwahrloste,” and
Hedwig Dransfeld, “Schattenseiten der modernen Frauenbewegung,” both in CF 3 (1905):
189, 375.

111

and JFB, much less the IAF and BDF, were even less interested. Women simply
did not often think in party-political or even in constitutional terms.
Conservative women also appear not to have thought a great deal about
military power. They did not reflect much on the military consequences of a
loss of moral backbone among men (perhaps because they didn’t think men had
much to start with). As concern over the declining birthrate rose, women did
discuss the problem in their speeches and journals; but for the most part they
simply refused to panic. Alice Salomon, for example, observed in 1908 that,
fundamentally, the prevailing demographic trend was positive: fewer births,
more children surviving to adulthood, and hence greater reproductive efficiency and “gain in power for the nation, in particular for economic life.”160
Anna Pappritz, too, argued in favor of a more rational “human economy,”
rejecting both the simple-minded pronatalism of conservatives like Bornträger
and the idea that women had to confine themselves to having lots of healthy
babies.161 Even women in the DEF were sometimes surprisingly ambivalent
regarding contraception. One 1913 report to the DEF’s morality commission,
for example, found that birth control “contradicts nature,” was a “serious
moral danger,” and filled the author with “disgust”; but working-class women
clearly desperately needed a way to control their fertility, and “the state would
be better served by the birth of fewer, but healthy, strong children rather than
a mass of sickly ones.” Ultimately, “in such highly personal matters each must
decide according to his best knowledge and good conscience.”162
Conservative women also did not spend as much time discussing race as did
conservative men. The DEF’s morality commission, for example, did address
the question of mixed-race marriage in the colonies in 1912, when this was a
hot topic of public discussion. It held that such marriages were “a personal and
national humiliation and abasement,” that they should be hindered as much
as possible, and that their legal consequences (“e.g. citizenship and inheritance
rights for the colored woman and children”) should be strictly limited.163 Yet
it rejected an outright ban on moral grounds – because it would simply lead to
still more mixed-race children being born out of wedlock. Katharina Scheven
deplored the “spirit of brutal master-morality” that inspired proposals to create
brothels in German Southwest Africa as a way of reducing the number of such
liaisons, and she dismissed as “bordering on madness” the idea of stealing
mixed-race children as a method of discouraging these relations.164 But these
were marginal concerns for these women.

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

Moreover, neither conservative Christian women nor the mainstream moderates indulged in the sort of coyly offhand anti-Semitism that was common
in the speeches and publications of conservative Protestant men. There were
occasional exceptions among conservative Protestant women, and even within
the nonconfessional women’s movement there were some instances at least of
milder forms of social anti-Semitism.165 But explicitly anti-Semitic ideas were
rare even in conservative Protestant women’s discourse.
Finally, women in the morality movements sometimes addressed the topic of
eugenics or “race hygiene” in quite positive terms; but they were not really very
interested. It is telling, for example, that they very often confused hereditarian
eugenics with the prevention of venereal infection. Anna Pappritz, for example,
argued in an essay of 1906 that “those with hereditary diseases (above all
venereal diseases)” should “voluntarily renounce having progeny.”166 Others
pointed out that the single most important source of “racial degeneration”
was clearly sexually transmitted diseases.167 In 1907 Agnes Bluhm, the only
influential female eugenics advocate in Germany in this period, discussed at
a meeting of the Berlin branch of the DZIAF the idea of a legal prohibition
on marriage for people with “certain constitutional, heritable maladies”; but
significantly, what she was actually addressing was the suggestion that men be
required to submit a medical certificate verifying that they were not suffering
from a venereal disease before being granted a marriage license.168
This is not to say that these women did not support eugenics in principle.
Die Frau in particular carried numerous articles by Bluhm. By 1913, the journal even assured readers that the age of liberal universalism was drawing to a
close, because “the natural sciences, genealogy, the history of civilization . . . are
working hand in hand to create a secure foundation for race-hygiene, for
‘eugenics.’” And yet, it also concluded that the time was not yet ripe for legislation, because a firm scientific foundation for policy was still being built.169
And the specific terms in which most women (Bluhm excepted) discussed the
issue make it clear where their primary concern lay. Pappritz, for example,

113

explicitly pointed out in 1913 that “raising a healthy, numerous, mentally and
morally fit progeny can only be achieved through the work of intellectually and
morally mature, physically healthy mothers conscious of their responsibility”;
and creating the latter was “the foremost goal of the women’s movement.”170
And Gertrud Bäumer, in a highly skeptical article on race hygiene in Die Frau
in 1910, asserted that women understood the importance of race hygiene, but
that it was after all just about bodies, not about the spirit – and therefore “it can
in and of itself never be the ultimate goal of culture – because human society is
after all something different from a stud-farm or a chicken-ranch.”171
In short, what was primary for these women was the life of the spirit and the
job of protecting women’s health from men’s immorality. They were simply
not terribly interested in other issues – issues that were of intense concern to
many more conservative men.
This profound gendered division within the morality movements was all the
more unsettling because these movements, as a whole, faced intense hostility
and opposition from many of their compatriots. The combination of trends was
not auspicious: in the face of what they saw as the rising challenge from secular
and scientific worldviews, socialism, the culture of the big city, and the media
revolution, the morality movements after 1900 were increasingly fragmented
along confessional and gender lines, effectively falling victim to the same proliferation of “isms” that they deplored in their culture more broadly. And yet,
it was also obviously true that growing numbers of Germans were engaging
directly and passionately with the problem of sex and morality. The rather odd
outcome was that the morality campaigners’ perceptions of their society and
culture were increasingly schizophrenic. Although they were convinced that
their society was descending into an ever more frightful moral crisis, they were
also convinced that they were triumphantly on the march against that crisis.
Chapter 5 turns to the emergence of this oddly bifurcated perception.

Isolation and Impact

I. Jeremiah in Germany: Isolation, Ridicule, and Confusion
A large proportion of liberal and progressive public opinion in Germany
regarded the morality campaigners as ignorant, backward, reactionary
troglodytes on a mission to crush everything creative and exciting out of
German public life. Liberal newspapers variously saw them as representatives of “the high-church and extreme reactionary party” on “an offensive
against modern culture”; denounced their “spirit of intolerance and shortsightedness,” their “narrow-minded zealotry,” and their “unspeakably silly
positions”; accused them of wanting to “nail the genius of art to the cross
of prudery”; or deplored the “inquisitorial zeal of their medieval moral
teachings.”1 Social Democrats were even more vehement. In 1899 the flagship
Social Democratic women’s journal, Die Gleichheit, characterized the morality campaigners’ attempts to introduce more stringent censorship as being
motivated by the “blind rage and hate of reactionaries for the free development of intellectual life.”2 The same journal saw in the efforts of BieberBöhm and Christian antiprostitution campaigners mere “childish naiveté” and
“moral dilettantism.”3 And some critics even discerned sexual rather than
political motivations behind the morality campaign. The humorous journal

“Die Apostel der Sittlichkeit,” Leipziger Neueste Nachrichten (14 October 1904); Welt am

Isolation and Impact

115

Simplizissimus, itself a special target of conservative Christian attacks, wrote
in 1911 that the morality movement was “a kind of spiritual venereal disease. . . . The struggle against the sexual is in this case one last opportunity for
sexual experience.”4
The morality movements also faced intense criticism from those whose
economic interests it threatened. This was particularly true of the prostitution industry. One representative of Berlin’s Property Owners’ Association
(Grundbesitzerverein), for example, told the annual conference of the national
Home and Property Owners’ Association in 1905 that Kasernierung “must be
demanded in the name of the well-being of the community, the family, the
church and the schools” as well as “of public health.”5 When one small city
in central Germany decided to abolish its brothels, a local craftsman warned
that many producers and retailers depended on the sex industry to bring cash
and customers to the town’s businesses, and in one small Saxon city this argument was made even in the city council.6 Members of the Berlin City Mission’s
“Midnight Mission” (Mitternachtmission), who patrolled streets, cafés, bars,
and public amusements in order to distribute pamphlets and shame young
men out of hiring prostitutes, complained of “insults in the street,” “scorn and
mockery,” and “curses and abuse” from both prostitutes and their clients; their
counterparts in Dresden reported “physical assaults” and accusations that it
was “immoral” to “deprive of their livelihoods honorable people and the poor
girls who sacrifice themselves for the city.”7
Other industries sometimes defended themselves as well. The trade journal Der Kinematograph (The Cinema) argued shortly before the war, for
example, that the efforts of some schools in Berlin to prevent their pupils
from going to the movies were just a “new example of bureaucratic class
justice.”8 The morality campaigners themselves, of course, were convinced that
those who objected to censorship were merely “a certain sector of the public
who have a business interest in distributing low, obscene works in print and
pictures.”9
Municipal patriotism, too, was sometimes offended by the antiurban tirades
of the morality campaigners. Thus the Berliner Börsenzeitung (Berlin Financial
Times) reported of the BMBU in 1889 that “the way Berlin is portrayed and

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

described in this association borders on slander.”10 Similarly, one speaker at the
AKDS meeting of 1901 in Leipzig protested that “my Leipzig is no Sodom!”11
And a liberal newspaper in Munich complained shortly after the founding of
the interconfessional men’s morality association there that the way the city
had been characterized in speeches at its first annual conference was “severely
damaging to the good name” of the city.12
The resistance faced by female morality campaigners in nonconfessional
women’s organizations differed little from that faced by Christian men and
women. Feminist moral reformers were lampooned as “decency aunties” or
“abstinence aunties” and “fools” who indulged in “puritanical piety.”13 One
medical man wrote in 1910 that feminist activists in this field were simply hysterics or “masturbators” who were “aggressive in making sexual accusations
and creating all sorts of scandal and upset” because they were “morally ruined
by frequent masturbation.”14
Such scurrilous denunciations were no doubt hurtful. Even more disturbing
to the morality campaigners, however, was simply the widespread indifference
of the German public. Over and over again the publications and speeches of
the morality campaigners reported on instances in which their contemporaries
clearly regarded as self-evident propositions that they saw as profoundly
immoral. Whereas an ideal of sexual self-control was central to the identity
of conservative Christian middle-class men in the morality movements, a
large number of middle-class and working-class men subscribed to a very
different conception of masculinity. They accepted that their bodies demanded
sexual satisfaction and assumed that any rational system of morality would
take this irreducible need into account. A ruling of Berlin’s commercial court
(Kaufmannsgericht) argued in 1913 that “the natural satisfaction of unmarried
people’s sexual drives therefore cannot be seen as immoral in and of itself;
that’s true for people both of the female and of the male sex.”15 In the same
year a Berlin newsletter for civil servants remarked that there was no other way
for the lower bureaucrat to preserve his social position than contraception;
and the journal of the liberal trade unions held that birth control was “in
and of itself not an immoral act – rather it is the result of a deep sense of
responsibility toward one’s children.”16

117

What fragmentary evidence there is regarding Germans’ actual sexual practices, moreover, suggests that most Germans inhabited a moral universe that
overlapped very little with that of the Christian morality campaigners. Prostitution is a particularly striking case: despite decades of agitation, it appears
that relatively few working-class people saw it as a moral problem. In 1903,
for example, one doctor in Vienna reported with some bemusement that in his
experience, the working-class prostitute didn’t see prostitution as disgraceful
and “doesn’t understand why people want to prevent her from deciding of
her own free will what she does with her body.” Nor, he observed, did they
suffer any meaningful consequences within their social milieu, “in which sexual honor appears only as an imaginary quantity.”17 As for the clients who
paid for sex, that was widely regarded, apparently in all classes, as a regrettable necessity and ubiquitous fact of life. The journal of the Protestant men’s
morality movement concluded already in 1888 that “in the preponderant part
of the male population of all classes, the view prevails that one can’t really hold
premarital sexual intercourse against a young adult man.”18 That attitude does
not appear to have changed much in succeeding decades. Even in the Bavarian
parliament, for example, one deputy’s remark in 1902 that in the matter of
prostitution “probably all of us men can say together ‘mea culpa’” elicited
“loud amusement.”19
Prostitution was not a unique case. The prominent criminal psychiatrist Paul
Näcke reported in 1913, for example, that about half of all firstborn children
were conceived out of wedlock.20 Both the panic of the morality campaigners
over the growing prevalence of contraception and the falling birthrate suggest
that the idea that sex should serve only the purpose of conception did not occur
to many men – who may well have believed, as one price list mailed out by
a condom manufacturer put it in 1910, that “no rationally thinking person
can deny that the prevention of conception is in countless cases an outright
necessity.”21 The leading sexologist Max Marcuse found in an informal survey
of 100 female patients in 1913 that some two-thirds practiced some form
of contraception, with coitus interruptus “far and away the most common
method.”22 Marcuse also found that for the most part “the women see the fact
of abortion as something self-evident, and see no reason to deny it,” because

they “do not perceive it in the least to be something immoral.”23 In 1915 one
jurist remarked that whereas twenty-five years earlier oral sex “had not yet
attacked the healthy body of the nation, today it is widespread in all social
circles.”24 In 1908 the Allgemeine Rundschau, a journal close to the Catholic
morality movement in Munich, reported that one of the lawyers in a scandal
trial involving homosexual acts by a prominent member of the Imperial court
had remarked, “God yes, it’s sad and certainly highly reprehensible, but isn’t
it actually quite common? Is the youth of any man who has passed through a
cadet-school, a boarding school or something similar free of it?”25 As for the
campaign against immoral texts and images, again, the period around the turn
of the century saw an enormous boom in popular publishing and, after 1900,
in the film industry. That boom was built on popular tastes that were simply
not as restrictive as those of conservative Christians. As the secretary of the
BMBU put it in his annual report of 1898, the simple fact was that “there is a
general predilection for indecency in word and image.”26
It is hardly surprising, then, that the morality movements failed to mobilize
masses of supporters. The morality movements – of all ideological varieties –
probably had no more than 50,000 members by 1913. In contrast, by one
estimate in 1890, 150,000 men paid for sex each year in Berlin alone, and
in one instance in 1915, 3,000 men visited Hamburg’s brothels in one night
alone.27
In fact, for much of their history, the morality associations were a rather
sleepy affair. In 1898, for example, the Korrespondenzblatt’s report on the
annual conference of the BMBU verged on the pathetic. The meeting was “only
weakly attended”; membership had fallen slightly from the year before; the
organization was operating in the red and faced “serious financial problems”;
the authorities at the municipal women’s hospital were not cooperating with
the volunteer sent to them by the Berlin City Mission; and the police department
was uncooperative, for example, in its handling of young prostitutes or film
censorship. The only good news was that the organization had secured a subsidy
of 900 marks annually from the Ministry of Culture.28 In 1902 only 370 men
and women attended the AKDS’s annual conference.29 Other organizations

faced similar problems. In 1910, the DZIAF reported that representatives of
only half of its chapters attended its annual conference in Dresden; that in
particular few men were present; that a well-advertised public meeting on the
second day of the conference was very poorly attended; and that only one of
the 700 invited lawyers and doctors in the city bothered to attend.30 As the
Korrespondenzblatt put it in 1889, “we are in a position similar to that of
Jeremiah.”31
Still more unsettling, however, was the fact that at times the morality
campaigners themselves had difficulty agreeing what was immoral and what
was not. In a discussion at the 1893 conference of the AKDS, for example,
Ludwig Weber used the prominent playwright Hermann Sudermann’s play
Heimat as an example of an indecent theater piece but was contradicted by
another attendee, who suggested that the same playwright’s Sodom’s End was
a much better example. A third speaker then chimed in with the opinion that
Sodom’s End was not indecent either. A fourth discussant added that some people took offence at Richard Wagner’s opera Lohengrin, but that this “surely
goes too far” – to which there was, finally, general assent.32 Even some of the
most bitterly conservative morality campaigners hinted that they, too, thought
that some of their followers might be motivated by suppressed lust, rather
than genuine moral principle. An article of 1902 in the journal of the KDF,
for example, warned “that frequently there lurks beneath prudery a dangerous, perhaps even corrupted imagination, which sees everything as risqué” and
takes offense even “where impartial souls see nothing dirty.”33 Anna Pappritz
warned in 1914 against people “for whom the ‘nude’ is synonymous with ‘indecent,’ a view that can only arise from pathological, hidden lasciviousness.”34
In 1906 Friedrich Bohn of the AKDS denounced the “pathological prudishness” of those who had chopped the offending bits off a public statue of a
naked boy in Kassel. Similar events in Elberfeld five years earlier had led the
Korrespondenzblatt to condemn “nocturnal moral lynch-justice.”35
A decision of the German supreme court (Reichsgericht) in 1899 held that
the question of the decency or indecency of any given publication had to be
decided on the basis of the “normal, shared feeling of modesty and morality in sexual matters.” The morality campaigners often appealed to the same

standard. But the court went on to admit that it was difficult to determine what
the “average” or “common” or “normal degree of modesty and morality” was,
and furthermore that such ideas or feelings were “in no people, and in no age,
absolutely unchanging.”36 In fact there simply was no universal sense of what
was or was not moral and decent. As the prominent painter Hans Thoma put
it in a speech to the parliament of Baden in 1907, “what popular sentiment is,
and who has it, is admittedly difficult to say.”37
II. Failures: Legislation, Administration, and Public Opinion
Given the relative isolation (and occasional confusion) of the morality campaigners, it is not surprising that on many issues they failed rather abjectly to
reshape either the legal environment or public opinion. This was nowhere more
true than in the case of prostitution. Despite a generation of agitation against
the system of regulation, by 1910 its critics – whether they favored criminalization or abolition – seemed no closer to their goal than they had been in
1880. In fact the police and medical experts often seemed to be moving in the
opposite direction. Increasingly they favored the imposition of the barracks
system – which was de facto a step in the direction of the resurrection of the
public brothel. By 1902 the AKDS worried that regulation, long typical only
of larger cities, appeared to be becoming more appealing to municipal administrations in smaller towns as well.38 In 1905 one Prussian minister openly
advocated Kasernierung in the Prussian parliament; in 1906 the annual conference of the AKDS passed a resolution deploring the “growing inclination” of
municipal governments in favor of the barracks system; by 1909 Pastor Ellger
feared that Kasernierung was more and more favored by “public opinion” as
well.39
Another particularly painful example is that of child sexual abuse. Everyone
involved in the morality campaign regarded men’s sexual predation among
minors as a particularly egregious sign of the moral decrepitude of their society,
and they supported an intensification of policing in this area. In fact this crime
was policed with growing intensity, and in that sense the morality movement
may have had an influence on policy. After 1900, however, the rising number
of prosecutions of men for having sex with girls also sparked a backlash and
a growing demand among jurists and doctors that the law be modified so

Isolation and Impact

121

that only men who victimized “innocent” children could be prosecuted. Max
Marcuse is a striking example; in his view, the law should protect only truly
“pure, uncorrupted children,” and not “regular whores” who happened to
be minors.40 Girls and their parents, some argued, were taking advantage
of the law to blackmail men; others held that “mendacity is a professional
characteristic” among prostitutes (including minors), who should therefore be
barred from testifying in the courts; still others believed that false accusations
of sex crimes were being lodged by hysterical women and girls corrupted
by masturbation.41 In some instances, such ideas influenced the courts. In
a particularly egregious case of group abuse of minors in Cologne in 1901,
which eventually involved some sixty men, the court decided that the two
girls in question displayed “extraordinary depravity,” which it counted as a
mitigating circumstance in sentencing.42
It is hardly surprising, in this atmosphere, that the morality movement found
the heated debates over the reform of the Criminal Code in the 1890s – the
lex Heinze – extraordinarily frustrating. The course and outcome of the debate
revealed how limited the appeal of the morality campaigners’ agenda was.
The initial bill pursued two aims. First, it introduced the crime of pimping,
under a new §181a of the Criminal Code and attempted to protect landlords
from prosecution for procuring by introducing a new subparagraph in §180 to
the effect that renting to prostitutes “is not punishable if it occurs in conformity
with police regulations issued to this effect.” Second, it sought to expand the
policing of public indecency under §184. The existing law punished anyone
who “offers for sale, sells, or distributes indecent texts, pictures, or depictions
in places accessible to the public.” The proposed revision added
anyone who produces them for distribution, or possesses them for the purpose of
distribution, or advertises or offers them, or anyone who uses advertising in print
to seek indecent connection, or who displays or posts in public streets or plazas
pictures or portrayals that, without being indecent, are suited to give offense by
grossly insulting the sense of modesty and morality.43

The morality campaigners initially had considerable success in revising this
legislation in committee. They regarded the proposed revision of §180 as an
attempt to introduce “localization” or the barracks system, and it was struck

from the bill. Instead the committee decided that landlords should not be punished for procuring as long as the rental agreement “does not involve any
exploitation of the immoral earnings of the renter” – that is, as long as prostitutes were not charged special, exorbitant rents.44 The committee also raised
the age of consent from sixteen to eighteen; added a new paragraph punishing
employers for using threats or promises “in connection with the employment
relationship” to persuade their female workers to perform or tolerate indecent acts; and added a new subparagraph to §184 (on public indecency) that
punished the public display or advertisement of “objects intended for indecent
use” – that is, primarily, contraceptives. An attempt to introduce stricter theater
censorship was narrowly defeated; but a new paragraph was added punishing
those who had sex while aware that they were infected with a venereal disease.45
After this initial success, however, the morality campaigners’ champions in
the legislature hit a wall of opposition. Over the next eight years, there was a
stubborn, spluttering, and increasingly bitter three-way struggle between the
representatives of the government (who championed, effectively, the interests of
the police and employers), the parliamentary friends of the morality movement,
and the opponents of more restrictive censorship legislation. Debates on the
1892 bill and a new version submitted by the Center Party in 1897 were
not concluded before the end of the respective legislative sessions. In a bitter
culminating battle in 1900, the minority opposed to the bill were able, by
repeatedly absenting themselves so that there was no quorum, to force the
majority to draft a compromise bill that retreated from key clauses of the
original. This bill was then, at last, adopted. In the end, as one history of
the Center Party concluded in 1929, “one could not overlook the fact that
this result represented a severe defeat for the Christian-thinking parties and for
Christian morality.”46
The morality campaigner’s drive to reshape the Criminal Code was frustrated by three problems. The first was that most parliamentarians were completely deaf to all arguments against the regulation of prostitution. In fact even
Catholic representatives of the Center Party who supported the bill were not in
favor of eliminating it (although they did oppose Kasernierung).47 The idea of
striking §361.6 – thereby criminalizing all prostitution – did not even get out of
committee until 1900, when it was defeated by 237 votes to 48.48 For Protestant morality campaigners, this was a devastating defeat; as Ludwig Weber told

the AKDS conference in 1893, “if we lose on this, we’ve lost completely.”49
And outright decriminalization (“abolitionism”) had even less support.
The second problem was that many influential participants in the debate
did not share the morality campaigners’ understanding of what was or was
not immoral – and neither did much of the public. Government representatives, for example, objected to the employer paragraph on the grounds that if
men were punished for “every impure touch” of a female worker or servant,
“very undesirable consequences for marital harmony and for the authority of
fathers over children would eventuate in many families.”50 The assumption
here seems to have been that men would be men, and their authority must not
be compromised by their moral laxity. One parliamentary deputy remarked in
the debate on the law that it was simply part of the “divine order of the world”
that a high degree of civilization brought with it a flourishing sex trade.51 In
committee hearings in 1899, some members argued that landlords or parents
who allowed affianced couples to have sex under their roof should not be
prosecuted for procuring; it would be “unjust and unfair,” as one put it, “if
the law were to treat as ‘indecent’ things that are in wide social circles not
regarded as indecent.”52 And hilarity was so frequent during the debates over
the law that in 1904 Anna Pappritz would recall the “sorry spectacle . . . of the
elected representatives of the people treating so serious a matter as the morality
question . . . as if it were a risqué farce.”53
Third, it was very difficult to reduce moral sensibilities to a clear legal standard. The courts had settled on a reasonably clear definition of what constituted
“indecent” texts or images: those that portrayed or described sexual acts. Once
lawmakers began to consider what might or might not “offend against the sense
of shame and morality,” they entered into a definitional jungle through which
they simply failed to cut a path. The parliamentary committee first settled
on criminalizing display of materials that “are suited because of their lewdness or lasciviousness grossly to offend the sense of modesty or decency”;
a second revision favored punishing the display of materials that “without
being indecent, are suited due to gross indelicacy grossly to offend the sense of
decency or modesty.”54 Opponents denounced such wording as “too vague,
too elastic,” or as “blank-check definitions.” They pointed out that urban and
rural people often had different standards regarding public decency; that moral
standards were different, too, in different social groups even within a given

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

community; that judges’ views varied according to their background; and that
in any case standards of decency actually changed quite rapidly even within
particular social milieus. As one parliamentarian put it, then, “we lack a universally valid norm that defines the sense of modesty.” Another observed bluntly
that what was offensive in word or image was simply “damned difficult to
define.”55
The compromise bill that was eventually passed criminalized pimping; raised
penalties for some morality crimes; and punished the production of indecent
materials, the public display or advertising of “objects intended for indecent
use,” and public advertising for indecent intercourse. It also made it illegal to
sell indecent materials or even materials that merely “grossly insult the sense
of modesty” specifically to those under age sixteen. But it did not raise the age
of consent, introduce stricter standards for the theater, punish knowing transmission of venereal diseases, permit intervention against the display of merely
“shameful” materials or their sale to adults, or criminalize sexual harassment
by employers – or, of course, eliminate the regulation of prostitution.56 Not
all the morality movements, of course, supported all these measures. But most
were bitterly disappointed by one or another aspect of the new law.
What is more, the debate had been followed closely by the educated public,
and a number of important arts associations – including the Royal Academy
of the Arts in Berlin – had worked to mobilize public opinion against the bill.
Ultimately the affair led to the formation of an anticensorship alliance of artists,
writers, art professors, and various prominent figures in German cultural life –
the Goethe Association for the Protection of the Freedom of Art and Science.57
Although not happy with the legislative outcome, participants were relieved
that the damage had been contained. A celebratory meeting held in Berlin on
the day of the compromise bill’s passage drew an audience of 6,000, who were
told that a heroic minority in parliament had defeated the “domineering clerics
of both confessions.”58
The extent of the morality campaigners’ failure to win the public relations
struggle outside parliament was made clear a decade later in the debate over
the reform of the Criminal Code as a whole between 1909 and 1913. The

Isolation and Impact

125

preliminary draft of the new Criminal Code published in 1909 made virtually
no improvements, from the morality campaigners’ point of view, on the lex
Heinze. Section 175, which criminalized sex between men, was to be extended
to homosexual acts between women as well; parents were added to the list
of those punished for committing indecent acts with those in their care (§173
penalized only incestuous sexual intercourse); and new provisions were introduced that made it easier to prosecute “white slavers.” Otherwise, the bill
virtually ignored the agenda of the morality campaigners.59
The morality campaigners were completely taken aback. Paula Mueller
wrote in the DEF journal that the retention of regulated prostitution in the
bill was, “after everything that has been said and written in Germany in the
past decade, scarcely to be believed.” Friedrich Bohn of the AKDS, too, found
the obtuseness of the legislature “completely incomprehensible.”60 Anna Pappritz concluded that the draft was “a great disappointment for us” and an
expression of “unconscious male sexual egotism”; indeed she feared that “our
25 years of work has been for nothing!”61 And the further course of legislation
brought few improvements. Liberal jurists vehemently attacked the bill as out
of touch with modern legal thought, producing their own “counter-draft” in
1911;62 but the draft finally submitted to parliament in 1913 was little changed.
The whole project was abandoned with the outbreak of the war; but as of 1913,
it appeared likely that the new Criminal Code, whenever it might be passed,
would largely ignore the agenda of the morality campaigners.63
Whereas the legislative process was particularly important in revealing to
the morality campaigners the extent of their isolation, numerous judicial and
administrative decisions during the decade before World War I also reinforced
this message. In the last years before the outbreak of the war, for example, it
became clear that the military hierarchy regarded prostitution as a normal and
unavoidable part of life in the armed forces and was interested only in trying to
prevent venereal infection. From about 1905 onward, a number of army corps
set up dispensing machines for prophylactics in barracks – a step the AKDS
regarded as an “outright invitation to debauchery,” and Katharina Scheven

saw as “official training in shamelessness” for young men.64 In the end, the
emperor himself intervened to forbid the practice, and the machines were
removed; but he also ruled that medical officers on army bases could stock
prophylactics, to be given out free of charge to those soldiers who insisted
on endangering themselves.65 In 1912, moreover, it came out that the military authorities had been pressuring the garrison city of Colmar (in Alsace)
to reintroduce regulation, which it had abandoned two decades earlier.66 As
the Korrespondenzblatt put it, “in military circles people are still completely
stuck in the old view of the necessity and indispensability of extramarital
sexual intercourse for young men.”67 But again, as we have seen, a growing
number of municipal governments too favored the adoption of some form of
Kasernierung, or localization of prostitution. A particularly galling case was
that of Hanover, where the DEF had its headquarters.68
The police took a similar view of a number of other issues related to morality. Even in conservative Catholic Bavaria, for example, in 1909 the police in
Munich held that although truly offensive public lectures on sexual matters
clearly had to be proscribed, “a general knowledge of the normal processes
of male and female sex life, and of the dangers of extramarital sexual intercourse” was not entirely a bad thing, “above all in view of conditions in
the metropolis.”69 Munich’s police took a relatively relaxed attitude, as well,
toward the city’s often provocative arts scene; indeed in 1911 one conservative
Catholic paper commented on the police chief’s “well-known recipe of gradually, almost un-noticed, stepping back inch by inch from the boundaries of
morality, good taste, and decency” in order to allow Munich’s art community
to develop “new ‘attractions’” that would draw visitors to the city.70
Even in cases in which the police could be moved to act, moreover, the
courts frequently rejected the notion that there was any objective standard of
decency, taking the behavior of the public – the market – as their measure
instead. In 1897, for example, a Berlin court held that a suggestive performance could not be forbidden because it was “no different in moral terms
from performances that are usual in such theaters, and the public knows what
kind of performances” they would find there.71 In other cases judges chose to

rely on the aesthetic judgments of artists (often professors at art academies)

As early as 1890, for example, Wilhelm Philipps of the AKDS had gone so far
as to describe as a “completely unauthorized usurpation” a ruling of Berlin’s
regional court (Landesgericht) holding Boccaccio’s Decameron to be “in and
of itself offensive” but of such “historical and artistic value” as to be above
censorship.73 Even the Prussian minister of the interior complained to the minister of justice in 1903 that the courts were exercising “striking leniency” in
indecency cases, despite the new legislation of 1900; the Berlin police department called it instead “astonishing leniency.”74
The morality movements appear, then, to have had an extraordinarily difficult time persuading any branch of government – the legislature, the military,
the police, municipal government, or the courts – to support their agenda. It
was particularly demoralizing, too, that in some cases they could not depend
even on their own churches, which occasionally hung them out to dry on
morality issues in order to avoid compromising other vital interests. In 1902,
for example, the Protestant church authorities in Oldenburg decided that they
would not publicly protest their city government’s approval of two new brothels, declaring that “decisions regarding hygienic measures . . . we leave to the
competent authorities.”75
III. Winning the War of Attrition? Morality and the Regulatory State
And yet, we should not exaggerate the extent of the morality campaigners’
failures. In truth the ideas of the morality campaigners seem to have been
widely influential at least among more conservative middle-class Germans.
Although they did fail to abolish the regulation of prostitution, for example,
they were able to make it an important topic of debate – a problem. The code
of silence that had surrounded prostitution in the nineteenth century had been
definitively broken. In some cities the police still attempted to make public
policy by administrative fiat; but it appears that they rarely succeeded in doing
so without sparking intense public debate. Similarly, the morality campaigners
failed to gain everything they wanted in the lex Heinze debate; but of course
some measures they favored were adopted. The army preserved its freedom
to distribute prophylactics, but it was forced to remove dispensing machines
from its barracks. And the policing of crimes against morality did intensify
throughout the prewar years – in fact, the rate of conviction (convictions per

1904), p. 25.

Moral Reform, 1880–1900

1,000 legally responsible adult citizens) for the category of morality offences
rose 62 percent between 1882 and 1913, whereas that for all crime rose by
only 10 percent.76
In short, the morality campaigners appeared around the turn of the century
to be winning the most fundamental struggle of all: the struggle to define
what people will struggle over. The morality movements lost many particular
battles, but by 1910 it would have been difficult for any German to argue that
there was not a “morality question.” As Ludwig Weber put it in 1910, “today
the morality associations have a position in public life that can no longer be
overlooked.”77
In fact, behind the scenes, government agencies often responded favorably
to pressure from the morality movement. In 1908 and 1910, for example, in
response to growing pressure from teachers and parents organized in local antiSchmutz committees, ministries in a number of states (Prussia, Bavaria, and
Württemberg) issued circulars requiring schools to warn pupils and parents
of the dangers of Schmutz and Schund, or even to boycott bookstores that
refused to remove such literature, or indecent images, from public display.78
In some areas (such as the Rhineland) the provincial authorities were already
taking the initiative in this field, for example, by instructing school authorities
to discuss the matter in teachers’ conferences, parent-teacher meetings, and the
like.79 In 1910 the Berlin police established an anti-Schmutz center for all of
Prussia.80 By 1912 Der Volkswart was claiming that total Schmutz sales in
Germany had been reduced from 60 million marks in 1908/1909 to 45 million
in 1910/1911.81
After 1910, moreover, apparently having concluded that they would not
gain much ground in attempts to reform the Criminal Code, the morality
campaigners shifted their strategy, attempting instead to achieve regulatory
changes through piecemeal revisions of the Industrial Code (Gewerbeordnung).
After repeated petitions from various conservative groups in favor of a new
law against Schmutz and Schund, for example, in early 1914 the government
at last introduced a bill revising the Industrial Code to prohibit the display in
public places (such as shop windows or bookstore sales rooms) of images or

texts “suited to give offense by reason of moral endangerment of the youth” –
a bill that opponents referred to as a “new lex Heinze.”82 At the same time,
a bill was introduced that would have imposed on cinemas the same licensing
requirement that governed theaters and other forms of live performance, in the
hope that limiting competition would reduce the pressure to offer spectacular or
racy films.83 A bill using the Industrial Code to further restrict Animierkneipen
was approved by the upper house of parliament in the spring of 1914.84 And
beginning with a first draft in late 1910, repeated attempts were made to pass
a bill allowing the upper house of parliament to issue regulations restricting
or banning the sale of contraceptives and abortifacients.85 The outbreak of the
war put these projects on hold; but there was clearly gathering momentum in
favor of restrictive regulation.
The morality movements had significant success in shaping the policies of
local and state agencies as well. In the early years of the cinema, for example,
there was virtually no control over subject matter except at the local level;
and even there the conditions for police intervention were in practice fairly
restrictive.86 But local and state governments soon introduced stricter controls.
Only two German states actually passed new film censorship laws (Brunswick in
1911 and Württemberg in 1914); in the rest of Germany censorship remained
in the hands of local authorities. The local censorship board established by
the police in Berlin, however, soon came to provide a minimum standard for
most of Prussia and, by 1914, other parts of Germany as well. The practice of
the board closely followed the agenda of the morality campaigners: the greatest
number – about half – of censored scenes depicted violence; about one-eighth
were sexually suggestive. In many cases, furthermore, local authorities ruled
that films could not be shown to minors under the age of sixteen at all, or not
to unchaperoned children; others established special “family” programs for
children. By 1913 school and police authorities in some fifty cities and several

provinces or states had passed laws restricting minors’ access to the movies.
Entertainment taxes were also used locally to impose some restraint on the
cinema business.87
The morality campaigners also did have some successes in the courts. The
supreme court (Reichsgericht) adopted an increasingly strict interpretation of
the new §184.3 of the RStGB as it applied to art and literature, holding, for
example, in 1905 that a text could be banned even if there were no specific passages in it that were indecent, because that did not rule out the possibility that
its “conceptual content” could “offend against the general sense of morality or
modesty of the reading public by exciting lasciviousness.”88 In 1909 a Cologne
court even held that “every accurate depiction of the naked human body in
which the sexual characteristics are clearly evident is . . . suited in and of itself
to excite lasciviousness.”89 Similarly, the Reichsgericht ruled that an object did
not need to be only intended for indecent purposes to be technically indecent,
and that mailing catalogs describing contraceptives to individuals was illegal
even if those individuals had requested such catalogs in response to public
advertisements; indeed, even offering such articles to doctors and apothecaries,
or in medical journals, was indecent.90
In some instances there were surprising victories, even in the case of prostitution. In 1905 a new Prussian law on infectious diseases would at least in theory
have allowed the replacement in that state of police regulation of prostitution
with a purely “hygienic” or medical system. A circular issued by the Prussian
government in 1907 – after the minister of the interior had a personal audience
with Anna Pappritz – instructed local police departments to make sure that free
treatment of or advice concerning STDs were available in their jurisdictions, to
merely require those arrested on suspicion of prostitution for the first time to
submit a doctor’s certification that they were healthy or in treatment, to register women as prostitutes only after a formal court procedure, to work with
rescue associations, not to punish minor infractions against police regulations,
and to charge with assault those who had sex with others while knowing they

the whole topic of regulation in order not to risk alienating government agencies whose cooperation it needed, decided to advocate at least the abolition of
brothels and passed a resolution opposing Kasernierung.92 And in 1910 the
parliament of the liberal southern state of Baden voted in favor of the closure
of all brothels in the state.93
More important, the morality campaigners had some success in preventing
(or rescinding) the introduction of Kasernierung or brothels in individual cities
through careful coalition building across ideological lines, strategic use of civil
suits by property owners concerned for their property values, neighborhood
demonstrations, and even direct action, such as the use of a spotlight and
nightly pickets to disrupt business in red-light districts.94 In 1909, one speaker
at a conference on venereal diseases even complained that the general assault
on brothels in Germany had created such uncertainty that capital invested in
them was no longer secure.95
Similar local efforts by groups concerned with various forms of public indecency resulted in small gains locally in cities around the country. In Strassburg,
for example, a coalition of Catholic, Protestant, and Jewish organizations and
school officials organized a boycott of stores that displayed indecent objects,
texts, or images in their windows or on their shelves; peppered the city government and police with petitions and notifications of illegal activity; organized
“patrols” to keep an eye on shop windows; persuaded the local schools to
boycott noncooperative stores; and moved the city government to force operators of kiosks to eliminate Schund from their offerings.96 Similar efforts had
some success in moving the police to adopt stricter practices as well. In Berlin,
