Moral Reform, 1880–1900

by 1913 there were cases in which policemen were stationed in dance halls to
discourage indecent dances, and the barbers’ guild complained to the city government that members who sold contraceptives were being hauled down to the
police station for questioning.97 In 1909 the journal of the DEF reported with
satisfaction that in some cities the police were prohibiting public addresses by
sex reformers (Aufklärungsvorträge or sex education talks).98 In Munich the
morality movements secured the prohibition in 1907 of Maud Allen’s seminude
“Salomé” dance, and the arrest of Adorée Villany for a similar performance in
1911.99
By about 1908 or 1910, in fact, a new and rather surprising tone began to
appear in the speeches and publications of the morality campaigners: increasingly a note of triumphalism began to surface alongside the more traditional
Jeremiads. Already in 1904, for example, Hermann Roeren believed that “no
one dares any more to deny the frightful decline of morality.” In the following year Ludwig Weber reported that “the whole tendency of the times has
become more favorable to the morality movement and its goals.” Two years
later, Gustav von Rohden claimed that “the cause of the morality associations is
drawing in ever wider social circles. What ten years ago was seen as an unpleasant crotchet of small groups of decency fanatics and pessimists and laughed
at or impatiently dismissed is now talked about by ‘the best people.’”100 By
1910 Der Volkswart detected a “revolution in public opinion” in favor of the
morality movement that had been underway since 1908. The IAF celebrated
the fact, in 1912, that even “outside of the organized abolitionist movement
the conscience of the German people and particularly of German women is
beginning to stir,” and in 1913 Anna Pappritz believed that there had been
a “revolution in opinions” in favor of abolitionism since 1900 and “that we
have every reason to look with joyful courage to the future.”101
And yet, in precisely these years the morality campaign was also confronted
with a new and frightening challenge. For whatever their successes in the
regulatory war of attrition against immorality, from 1902 forward the morality
campaigners also faced a coherent ideological challenge from progressive social
and sexual reformers who were in many cases no less idealistic, no less utopian,

and no less crusading in spirit than they were themselves, but whose ideas were
in many respects diametrically opposed to their own. The Christian morality
campaigners had, by 1905, been denouncing philosophical materialism as the
root of the moral crisis of their times for more than twenty years; but by that
year they were embroiled in an increasingly heated confrontation with a set of
reform movements that championed explicitly and self-consciously scientificmaterialist notions regarding sexual morality.
The morality campaigners, then, had been successful in establishing sexual
morality as a problem in German society and in imposing a broad, ongoing
debate over their moral agenda – in parliament, in the courts, within the regulatory agencies of the state, in municipal councils, and in the public sphere
at large. By 1908, however, it seemed increasingly possible that this victory
would turn out to have been a Pyrrhic one. Increasingly, it appeared possible
that they might lose the debate they had imposed.
This is the subject of Part II.

part ii
SEXUAL RADICALISM, 1900–1914

6
Social Democratic Sexual Ethics

Social Democrats were relatively minor contributors to the discussion of sexual
ethics, measured by the sheer volume of their publications and speeches on
the matter. Nevertheless, socialist thinking on the problem of sexuality and
sexual morality was of central importance in the broader debate, for two
reasons. On the one hand, the role of foundational texts by Friedrich Engels
and particularly August Bebel as starting points for the elaboration of a radical
realist and materialist sexual ethics gave the socialist position an influence
out of proportion to Social Democrats’ direct engagement in the debate. On
the other hand, Social Democrats could cast themselves as spokespeople not
only for a particular theoretical tradition or position but also for an emergent
social reality – the real, existing sexual culture of the working class.1 It may
also have been significant that Social Democratic journals reached a very wide
audience. Even the party’s leading theoretical journals, Die Neue Zeit and
Sozialistische Monatshefte, both of which published intermittently on topics
related to sexuality, had circulations between 3,000 and 10,000 in the decade
before 1914 – two or four times that of the specialty journals of the morality
campaigners. The socialist women’s journal Die Gleichheit, which was both a
key publication for the women’s trade union movement and a major forum for
the articulation of socialist views on sexuality, reached an audience of 85,000
in 1910.2

und Sozialdemokratie (Frankfurt: Fischer, 1981); Christa Uhlig, Reformpädagogik: Rezeption
und Kritik in der Arbeiterbewegung (Frankfurt: Peter Lang, 2006), pp. 160–173.
2 Till Schelz-Brandenburg, “‘Die Neue Zeit,’” available at library.fes.de/nz/nz-intro.html, accessed
12 May 2013; Hubert Woltering, “Die ‘Sozialistische Monatshefte’ (1895/96–1933),” available

137

138

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

Three distinct positions were dominant in Social Democratic thinking on
sexuality. Particularly during the earlier years, first, critiques of the moral corruption of bourgeois society led some Social Democrats to develop an analysis
of the immorality of their times that sounded surprisingly similar to that of
conservative Christians. Thus, for example, in 1892 Heinrich Lux insisted
that prostitution was the product of “the influence of social misery,” but
also of “seduction, bad example, miserable living conditions, deficient education . . . chaotic family conditions, men and women working together in the
same spaces, especially at night, the pleasures of loose living, love of finery
etc.” And the result of widespread prostitution was growing sexual cynicism,
demoralization, and brutalization, such that “the whole of social life takes on
a lascivious tone through constant contact with prostitution.”3 In 1896, similarly, the Social Democratic women’s journal Die Gleichheit deplored the fact
that the “entrepreneurial class unscrupulously sacrifices the virginity of women
workers to the profit motive” and that “starvation wages” forced female “wage
slaves” into prostitution. Employers of domestic servants, factory owners, and
managers preyed on their female employees, making them “pleasure slaves.”
Among workers, poor housing conditions “deaden the sense of sexual delicacy,
awaken and excite sensual desire early, and often lead to its pathological development,” and in any case working-class girls left home long before they were
ready to face the moral challenges of independent living.4 August Bebel, in
the 1887 edition of Woman and Socialism, criticized the “unscrupulous businessmen” who “lure” men into brothels; deplored the “trade in female flesh”
in which white slavers “ply their trade with the same cold-bloodedness as if
they were dealing in any other commodity”; warned that “an excess of sexual
pleasures” could lead to impotence, sterility, nervous disorders, and the need
for “special forms of stimulation” such as homosexual acts or child sexual
abuse; and suggested that the result of all this “vice, debauchery, crimes and
misdemeanors” was that “the whole of society is kept in a state of disquiet.”5
Not only did Bebel sound very much like the morality campaigners, but he
even sometimes quoted directly from the AKDS’s Korrespondenzblatt – for
example, in the parliamentary debate over the lex Heinze.6
Even after the turn of the century, Social Democrats often viewed popular
culture with a skepticism similar to that of conservative Christians. Thus in
1904 Die Gleichheit held that “in the capitalist world the mind of youth is

argued that the cinema – characterized by “ugliness and baseness . . . mendacity
and sensationalism” – distracted proletarians from the struggle for social justice by filling their heads with sexually suggestive and trivial nonsense.8 In the
1910 edition of Woman and Socialism, Bebel deplored the fact that newspapers
and magazines carried advertisements that “encourage unnatural satisfactions
in the most shameless manner,” whereas obscene pictures, suggestive poems,
novels, and modern art made it little wonder that “sexual excesses . . . have
become a social disease.”9 In 1911 Die Gleichheit blamed imperialism, militarism, and the profit motive among the owners of “Tingel-Tangel, variety
theaters, Animierkneipen” for the white slave trade and for spreading “sexual
licentiousness and debauchery throughout the world.”10
Conservative Christians and Social Democrats in fact to some extent shared
an understanding of the moral status of capitalism. Most Social Democrats
argued that prostitutes were, as one put it in 1884, “victims of an all-devouring,
demoralizing money-culture”; as Die Gleichheit argued twenty-eight years
later, prostitution was “only the last and most heinous consequence of an economic system that rests on the exploitation of one human being by another.”11
Socialists frequently argued that the morality campaigners were simply hypocrites; but they were in fundamental agreement on the nature and consequences of “mammonism.” Even the metaphors Social Democrats used were
sometimes the very ones favored by conservative Christians. In 1899 the prominent socialist-feminist journalist Wally Zepler, writing in the flagship journal of revisionism, Sozialistische Monatshefte (Socialist Monthly), referred to
immorality as an “incurable organic sickness of our society.”12 Die Gleichheit
argued in 1912 that only social reform, not “Bible quotations, legal paragraphs
or the police saber,” could “dam up” the “rising waters of prostitution.”13 Such
rhetorical flourishes were hardly as common in Social Democratic as in Christian discourse; but socialists do appear to have treated this as the available
metaphorical vocabulary.
Second, however, many Social Democrats developed an assessment of the
sexual culture of the working classes that directly contradicted that of most
conservative Christians. They argued that, far from being dissolute and corrupt,

140

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

working-class sexual mores both were healthy and pointed to the future of sex.
Particularly striking is an article in Die Gleichheit in 1896, which suggested that
it was perfectly moral for working-class women to “give themselves to the man
who wins their affections, without the blessing of the priest or the formulas
of the county registrar,” marrying only when the first or second child was
born. It was bourgeois marriage that was immoral – effectively itself a form of
prostitution, because middle-class women had no other means of supporting
themselves than to find a husband. In contrast, working-class women had
jobs and were not dependent on men. Die Gleichheit put this case even more
explicitly in an eight-part article on “Marriage and Morality” in 1906, asserting
that “love takes on vitality and substance above all in the marriages of those
who own nothing or little, because among them the power of property has
disappeared.”14
A debate in the pages of the leading orthodox Social Democratic journal Die
Neue Zeit in 1898 neatly sums up the tensions between these two positions. In
the opening salvo Willy Hellpach critiqued prostitution as a feature of the capitalist economic and social order, observing that “any sexual act is contrary to
nature which does not serve the purpose of the survival of the species.” Those
who masturbated, hired prostitutes, or sold sex “defiled” themselves; so did
any woman “who indulges in repeated sexual pleasure while self-consciously
preventing conception.” If the use of contraception became widespread, he
warned, the result would be “indiscriminate and unrestrained” intercourse
and “sexual-psychological degeneration” among women.15 Several responses
took a very different position. One critic insisted that, from a “purely physiological” point of view, sex was not really about reproduction, conception being
merely a “secondary point”; on the other hand, many prostitutes were already
“morally degenerate creatures.”16 A second characterized Hellpach’s article as
“cant” and symptomatic of a disturbing “tendency toward prudery” in the
party. Hellpach was advocating a “purely animalistic existence” in which the
individual was “merely a member of his species,” ignoring both the real imperatives of working-class life and working-class people’s aspirations to material
well-being and intellectual self-improvement. The triumph of socialism would
clear aside such outdated and crabbed moral precepts, bringing about an age
not of sexual “virtue” and abstinence but of sexual self-realization.17
Third, despite such disagreements, two fundamental ideological commitments actually did generate a certain underlying consensus in Social Democratic
thought regarding the family, gender, and sexuality in this period. The first was

Social Democratic Sexual Ethics

141

the commitment to a natural-scientific worldview – to explanations derived
from an understanding of the natural requirements of the human organism.
The second was the commitment to historical materialism, to the understanding that social forms are determined by the fundamental requirements of the
mode of production, and that they accordingly change with it.
The locus classicus for the first position was Bebel’s Woman and Socialism.
It was, Bebel wrote, a requirement of normal development “not to neglect
the exercise of any organ of the body, not to deny any natural drive its satisfaction.” Repression would merely cause “atrophy and injury to the entire
organism,” indeed potentially “madness and miserable death.” The denigration of the body as “lower” and less legitimate than the spirit, he held, was
fundamentally mistaken and harmful: the “so-called animal passions are at no
lower a level than the so-called intellectual ones,” because both were “functions
of the same organism.”18 Sexual desire was the strongest, most vital expression of the “will to life,” and “the strongest force in human nature.” Every
human being, he asserted, “has a right to . . . satisfy those drives . . . which are
intimately connected with his innermost self, that are his self itself [das Sein
selbst].”19 By 1910 Bebel had found a formulation for this point calculated to
enrage conservative Christians: “Human beings do not stand above the laws
of nature; they are, physiologically, the most highly developed animals.”20
Other Social Democrats were explicitly dismissive of Christian conceptions:
one held in the leading revisionist socialist journal in 1896, for example, that
it was useless to discuss whether the sex drive could be repressed, because such
repression was clearly harmful and in any case simply wasn’t going to happen –
and “nothing is accomplished in this matter by ethical-moral preachments and
recriminations.”21
Equally scandalous to conservatives was the fact that Social Democrats also
consistently argued that ideas about sexuality were not immutable and timeless but changeable. As the foremost theorist of socialist revisionism, Eduard
Bernstein, put it in Die Neue Zeit already in 1895, “moral views are historical entities.”22 Henriette Fürth, another leading revisionist, was equally
blunt in 1912: morality, she asserted, is an expression of “economic circumstances and needs”; it was therefore “changeable, fluid, inconstant,” relative,
and debatable.23 Specifically, of course, socialists almost universally argued

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

that the so-called Christian familial order was in fact the product of the emergence of private property and capitalism. As Die Gleichheit (presumably the
journal’s editor, the orthodox Marxist Clara Zetkin) put it in 1906, “the existing bourgeois marriage . . . is not a moral but an economic, a property-law
institution.” The patriarchal structure of the family, originally dictated by the
needs of household production and capital accumulation, was now breaking
down under the impact of industrialization and proletarianization; marriage in
the working class was increasingly a matter of love, not business.24
In this, all these authors were following the argumentation of Friedrich
Engels, whose extremely influential 1884 work, The Origin of the Family, Private Property, and the State, put prevailing legal and moral norms in long-term
historical and ethnographic perspective. The monogamous patriarchal family,
Engels held, was the product of the “world-historical defeat of the female sex,”
itself a corollary of the development of private property. It had in fact “absolutely nothing to do with individual sexual love.” With the disintegration of
capitalism, the extant form of marriage and the strict moral code it imposed –
on women – would cease to have any economic function and would collapse.25
Most socialists shared Bebel’s and Engels’s faith that the revolution would
establish a new and natural sexual culture in which the pathologies of the
repressive bourgeois sexual order would disappear. Biology and love, freed
from artificial constraints imposed by capital, would hold happy sway. In
the meantime, many Social Democrats were willing to define as natural and
therefore unobjectionable an extraordinary range of sexual behaviors that conservative Christians regarded as immoral and pathological. One socialist journalist in Berlin argued in 1893 that Social Democrats had happier marriages
than other workers because they practiced “rational production of children” –
that is, they used contraceptives.26 In 1895 Eduard Bernstein argued for the
decriminalization of homosexual acts between men and held that the personals advertisements that conservative Christians (and some Social Democrats)
found so disgusting were neither surprising nor necessarily immoral. In capitalist society, many young men simply could not get married, for financial reasons;
wanting to have sex anyway did not make one a “libertine.”27 Sozialistische
Monatshefte urged in 1896 that “we don’t need to wait for the collapse of capitalism” to solve the sexual problem, because the use of contraceptives would
allow unmarried couples to meet their sexual needs without having to fear

pregnancy.28 Die Neue Zeit pointed out in 1906 that there were 892,684 more
women than men in Germany (or 103 women per 100 men) and asked “what
they . . . are supposed to do” with their “reproductive organs?” The implication
was obviously that one could really not judge unmarried women for having
children.29 And of course many Social Democrats held that prostitution was
not evidence of individual moral turpitude but rather of the fundamentally
corrupt nature of class society, “a necessary social institution” in bourgeois
society, as Bebel put it, “just like the police, the standing army, the church,
business, and so on.”30
In contrast, many Social Democrats were contemptuous of bourgeois marriage. For Engels, it was clear that so-called monogamous marriage had rested
from its inception on a falsehood, because monogamy was in fact only imposed
on women. The sexual order of capitalism consisted of “monogamy complemented by adultery and prostitution.” And because bourgeois marriages were
at bottom “marriages of convenience” and did not actually rest on mutual love,
they usually created at best “a state of leaden boredom, which we call marital
bliss.”31 The socialist doctor and activist Hope Bridges Adams-Lehman argued
in an article in Die Neue Zeit in 1897 that “at least 90 percent . . . of respectable
bourgeois ladies . . . are engaged in exactly the same trade in their bodies as the
most depraved street-whore, with the sole difference that their cowardice in
the face of life is greater, and they sell their wares more dearly.”32 The radical
sociologist Ladislaus Gumplowicz even argued in 1900 that only “indolence,
cowardice and low hypocrisy” explained the “continued existence of a barbarity long since recognized to be senseless” – namely Christian marriage. Comparing traditional, single-earner marriages to the family life of chimpanzees, he
suggested – playing on the symbolic association between Catholicism and the
color black – that marriage was a “barbarity of the various blacks in Bavaria
and Central Africa.”33
Social Democrats generally believed, in fact, that the future belonged to
“free love,” but in a very specific sense: love under socialism would be freed
from money. As the socialist social policy expert Lily Braun put it, free love
was the freedom to choose a spouse “free from any material considerations,
solely out of love.”34 Under socialism, the party program of 1891 held, men

and women would form relationships, as autonomous equals, on the basis of
mutual regard; both prostitution and “meal-ticket marriages” (Versorgungsehen) would disappear.35 Socialism, in short, would realize the moral ideals that
bourgeois society preached but did not practice. Monogamy, as Engels put it,
would not disappear under socialism; “rather it will be for the first time fully
realized” for both sexes.36
And yet, on the whole Social Democrats had a somewhat unconventional
understanding of what monogamy would be like in socialist society. For many
of them held that the ideal of lifelong marriage was outdated and harmful.
Among the more orthodox Marxist leadership, this belief took the form merely
of a demand for what would today be called no-fault divorce.37 But others went
much further, arguing that under modern social conditions, the dissolution of
a growing number of marriages was in fact to be expected, and even welcomed.
As Die Gleichheit put it in 1898, although modern people expect “that love
and marriage coincide,” fluid, dynamic, modern social conditions generated
“greater mental and moral differentiation of personalities” and made people’s
emotional lives more complex and unpredictable. The natural result would be
that marriages might not last.38 Wally Zepler, too, held that people changed
more over their lifetimes under modern social conditions; and “the more differentiated . . . a person’s construction, the richer his personality, the . . . greater
the possibility that paths that initially ran parallel will widely diverge in the
end.”39 As civilization advanced and both individuals and their ways of loving became more refined, divorce would flourish. That was fine, Gumplowicz
argued, because “the easier it is to dissolve a marriage, the more frequently a
married couple will also be a loving couple.”40
In some cases, Social Democrats even went so far as effectively to argue
for toleration of promiscuity. This was a position implicit in their vehement
adherence to the general principle that people’s private lives were their own
business. August Bebel’s formulation is a good example: “The satisfaction
of the sex-drive,” he argued in Woman under Socialism, “is each individual’s
personal business. . . . Nobody is accountable to anyone else for it.”41 Henriette
Fürth spelled out the potentially radical implications of this doctrine in 1908,
arguing that although marriage based on love was the “only form of sexual
intercourse compatible with human dignity,” it was also true that

in the area of sexual morality, too, there is only one fundamental truth, which is:
be true to yourself, to the requirements and laws of your innermost nature! . . . The
one is by nature monogamous . . . , another is polygamous, a third loves monogamously but temporarily. We have to . . . concede the right to these various forms
of expression. The sexual life of every individual must remain sacrosanct . . . , his
own private business.42

In particular, some Social Democrats believed that marriage was a matter for
mature people, whereas youth had to be free to experiment and to search.
Zepler, for example, held that under socialism people would enter into varied
and changing sexual relationships in youth, and monogamous marriage only
in maturity.43
Again, this preference for tolerance in principle was supported by an important pragmatic consideration: the fact that all these positions largely corresponded with what the working classes already practiced. As Zepler put it in
1899, those who clung to conservative Christian conceptions of sexual propriety “have not even been able to imagine in theory the change in moral
conceptions that is already taking place practically under our very eyes.” One
could already observe in practice the “emergence of a more liberal concept
of sexual morality in the future.”44 Conservative Christians might believe, in
other words, that industrial capitalism was creating sexual disorder and moral
disaster; Social Democrats believed that they could see it creating, under their
very noses, a new, more moral, more democratic, and happier sexual culture.
As revisionism gained influence among German Social Democrats after
about 1905, however, there were growing disagreements about precisely what
that better socialist future would be like in detail. One feature of revisionist
thought in particular led some of its advocates into sometimes embittered conflicts with more orthodox Social Democrats: its openness to biologistic ideas,
and to considering gender no less important than class.45
A striking example is contraception. In an influential essay on “Woman and
Intellectual Life” published in 1902, the socialist journalist Oda Olberg rejected
the arguments of those who saw the use of contraceptives as unhealthy and a
threat to national power. Instead, birth control was “a rational corrective to
degeneracy,” because if people who couldn’t handle modern life didn’t have
children, that was all to the good. But more important, she held that most who
used contraceptives were simply people whose sense of their responsibility as
parents led them to keep the number of their children small, so as to be able to
raise well those they did have. The more intensive care possible in such families

44 Ibid., p. 291.
45 On the debates between orthodox and revisionist women in the SPD, see Quataert, Reluctant
Feminists, pp. 76–82, 97–99, 107–133.

had a “race-hygienic value,” whereas large families too often produced “weak
individuals, marked by constitutional diseases, who have received insufficient
sunshine, air, and love.”46 By 1913 this position was not uncommon among
Social Democrats – and this at the height of the conservative panic over the
birthrate. And it could sometimes be combined with almost messianic hopes
regarding the benefits of using contraceptives to achieve the aims of eugenics,
to prevent the birth of “inferior” or “defective” individuals – as when, for
example, Henriette Fürth observed that “we are mastering death in ever greater
degree” and that “it’s high time that we also master life. That we decide what
should be brought to life, and when.”47
But this kind of optimism stuck in the craw of more orthodox Marxists,
who still expected the revolution to be born of immiseration, not of growing social rationalization. In 1913 the issue of contraception and the birthrate
sparked an intense debate within the party over the “birth strike” – the idea
that deliberately reducing fertility could be a means to alleviate working people’s material suffering and even perhaps to undermine capitalism itself by
depriving capitalists of the reserve army of labor that kept wages low (and
profits high). The orthodox party leadership rejected this position vehemently,
because it smacked of mere meliorism. Clara Zetkin, for example, responded
by denouncing as mere “quackery” the idea that the birth strike was an alternative to “the political struggle for the realization of social reforms”; and
Luise Zietz was “saddened and ashamed” that such reformist views should
be so common in the party.48 Some even argued that the birth strike was
an expression of moral weakness. Olberg, for example, held that a “happy,
healthy optimism” was part of the socialist personality; overuse of birth control would be an expression of “selfishness” and “meager faith in oneself and
in the future.” Like Christian nationalists, in other words, she demanded high
fertility as a proof of loyalty and good character.49 Those who supported the
idea of the birth strike saw in such remarks evidence of a reactionary moralist
spirit within Social Democracy, and that reading seems to have struck a chord
with the rank and file.50 In any case, ultimately the introduction of legislation
to restrict the availability of contraceptives just before World War I moved
socialist women, in particular, to close ranks – because although they might

differ as to the political functions of birth control, they could virtually all agree
that women, as private individuals, had the right to control their own fertility.51
But the gulf between revisionism and orthodoxy on sexual questions was
clear.
The debate over the birth strike, moreover, was only the last of a series
of similar debates within the party reaching back to the turn of the century.
Arguably even more important, for example, was an ongoing discussion of the
problem of women, work, and motherhood. This issue had riled the socialist
women’s journal Die Gleichheit already in 1901, when Clara Zetkin ripped into
Lily Braun for suggesting that collective households could liberate workingclass women from the double burden of housework and paid employment
even before the revolution. Braun, Zetkin suggested, had created merely an
“abstract utopia”; in fact she was one of those “unclear or overly clever social
reformers” who were currently “infiltrating . . . the proletariat” in order to try
to undermine its revolutionary élan.52 In response, Braun compared Zetkin
to narrow-minded Christian defenders of orthodoxy and observed that it was
“pretty comical how customary it has recently become to accuse those people of
utopianism who seek to translate the ideals of Social Democracy from the stage
of preachments to the stage of deeds.”53 As editor of Die Gleichheit, Zetkin
gave herself the last word, calling Braun’s witticisms “cheap and tasteless.”
Thereafter, Braun was systematically excluded from the journal.54 But the
same issue was revisited in the revisionist journal Sozialistische Monatshefte five
years later, when the leading revisionist (and longtime member of the national
parliament) Edmund Fischer argued that the orthodox model, in which women
“liberated” from excessive demands of child care and homemaking could lead
working lives just like men’s, was nonsense, because women didn’t want those
lives. This “old” feminist standpoint, he held, “contradicts feminine nature
and human nature itself” and had been simply “borrowed from the vocabulary
of the bourgeois women’s rights advocates.” In working-class circles, the fact
that men worked in the factories while women did the housework “is regarded
as an equal division of labor”; for nine-tenths of the working class, the “lifegoal of woman, deeply rooted in female nature, is to be mother, and to live
through the care and education of children.” The socialist society of the future
would therefore achieve the “liberation from the evil of capitalism, which forces
women to work in factories.”55
Critics dismissed such ideas as “the familiar petit-bourgeois ideal,” “backwardness,” and “reactionary sentiments,” arguing among other things that
work was a precondition for “personal independence” and hence for “full

humanity,” and that in any case most mothers did not in fact have the “special
understanding for the child’s soul” or any natural talent or training as educators. What was needed in child rearing, as anywhere else, was specialization and
professionalization.56 Clara Zetkin did not spare the rod: she found Fischer’s
views shameful, philistine, wrong headed, banal, frivolous, petit bourgeois,
narrow and shortsighted, and ill informed. Children should be “democratized
and socialized” from earliest childhood in public institutions by the “best pedagogical influences, the most superior pedagogical resources”; that would be
fine with mothers, who had no interest in being reduced to purely reproductive
beings.57 And Wally Zepler even found it “crass absurdity” to confine children to house and school, when what they needed was freedom of movement
and social interaction with other children; being “chained” to parents and
siblings, so far from fostering “peace and happiness,” was very frequently an
“inexhaustible source of suffering and inner unfreedom.”58
There were similar divisions within the party over the problem of prostitution. The orthodox position was that prostitution resulted from the impoverishment of the working classes, the destruction of working-class family life,
alcoholism as a product of misery and desperation, and the moral dangers generated by the capitalist entertainment industry – what Oda Olberg, in 1903,
called “a social environment that over-excites sensuality.”59 Prostitution was
most common in cities of mixed social makeup, where men with purchasing
power encountered women without it.60 The solution, of course, was to destroy
capitalism; and Social Democrats sometimes poked fun at bourgeois abolitionists for their lack of realism and advocacy of mere palliatives.61 Yet in fact
many socialists tacitly or explicitly supported abolitionism. Already in the late
1890s, for example, socialist women played an important role in protests over
arrests of innocent women by the morals police.62
But here too revisionists created a furor by calling both positions into question. Edmund Fischer again penned the most important statement of their
position, arguing in 1906 that “a mentally and morally normal woman is not
turned into a prostitute by any degree of poverty.” Instead, selling sex was “a
mark of degeneration”; women who did so were “morally sick” and “born
prostitutes.”63 “Prostitution,” he argued in 1909, “has nothing to do with

149

class differences.”64 Fischer was not alone in this view; indeed in 1906 Die
Neue Zeit even carried a piece on “Wages and Prostitution” in which Wilhelm
Hammer pointed out that both the men who paid for sex and the women
who sold it were socially diverse groups, so that it could not be material need
that created prostitution.65 Critics responded that Hammer’s own notes on the
young women he had examined showed that they were bitterly poor, even if not
actually starving to death. Poor education, inadequate housing, and inability
to pay for a minimum of “indispensable pleasures” were no less real problems than actual starvation. As the leading venereal disease expert (and Social
Democrat) Alfred Blaschko put it, “human beings simply need a little more to
keep them alive than bread and a spot in the city’s homeless shelter!”66
Not surprisingly, this disagreement extended to the assessment of “race
hygiene,” or eugenics, as well. Henriette Fürth was a particularly vehement
advocate, arguing, for example, in 1911 that the “pathological or incurable
degenerates” could be allowed to have sex if they used contraceptives but
could “never be granted the right to reproduce.”67 In 1913 she argued in favor
of decriminalizing abortion in cases of rape or for the “prevention of degenerate births” and regarded as “incomprehensible” the position of those who
opposed “voluntary or compulsory sterilization” of “defective” people.68 In
contrast, August Bebel himself had ridiculed early eugenic thought as implying that reproduction in the future socialist society would resemble that “in
the [monarchical] state’s stud farms.”69 In 1910, the social policy expert, ethnologist, and race hygiene theorist Hans Fehlinger held in the Sozialistische
Monatshefte that “any legislative regulation of reproductive life” would deliver
a “terrifying instrument of power” into the hands of “officialdom,” while also
being “detrimental to the community in question” because the breeding preferences of bureaucrats would tend toward the suppression of “independence
and individuality.” The real eugenic threat, in any case, was the inheritance of
private property, because it gave some people material advantages they did not
biologically deserve.70
At bottom the central issues in each of these controversies were the same.
After the turn of the century revisionists inched away from the economistic
and revolutionary materialism of orthodox Marxist theory, seeking instead

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

to develop a meliorative program defined and guided by biologistic ideas.
The two sides still had much in common, obviously; but specifically with
regard to sexuality, Social Democracy was increasingly divided after about
1905. Revisionists accused the orthodox of simple-minded adherence to a onedimensional version of Marxist social theory that was both increasingly clearly
wrong and overly influenced by bourgeois moralism; the orthodox accused
revisionists of being bourgeois social reformers whose obsession with biology
was leading them politically and ideologically astray.71
There was a good deal of truth to this last accusation, for these conflicts
within Social Democracy were to a large extent the product of the growing interpenetration between revisionist Social Democracy and the sex-reform
movement. Revisionists played important roles in the radical sex-reform movement; and much of the élan of that movement derived precisely from the near
euphoria that resulted from the convergence, in many sex reformers’ thinking, between the economic teleology of Marxist historical materialism and
the biological teleology (as they understood it) of Darwinian evolutionary
thought. Again, Social Democrats generally were less intensely interested in
sex and morality than either conservative religious men and women in the various morality organizations or the liberal Protestant and Jewish women in the
nonconfessional women’s movement. There was no Social Democratic journal devoted to issues of sexual morality and public decency comparable to Der
Volkswart, the Korrespondenzblatt, or the Abolitionist; and Social Democratic
journals like Die Gleichheit, Die Neue Zeit, and the Sozialistische Monatshefte
did not publish on these issues with the frequency that – for example – Die
Frau, Die Frauenbewegung, or the journal of the BDF did.72 Nevertheless,
revisionist Social Democrats in particular made a critical contribution to the
thinking of the radical sex-reform movement after the turn of the century.
The reasons for this are obvious. The basic postulates of socialist thought
offered an alternative to Christian moral discourse that appeared both to be
realistic and to promise transformative improvement. Social Democracy offered
a vision of moral purification every bit as righteous and as ambitious as that of
conservative Christians, but on the foundation of a natural- or social-scientific
worldview. What was more, whereas Christians saw modern society as fundamentally corrupt, pathological, and dangerous, Social Democrats argued that
the pathologies of the present were merely side effects of positive and progressive developments – the birth pangs of a new, more moral, and more rational
society. Sex reformers saw themselves as deliberately championing just that
development.
It is worth considering finally, however, just how frightful that socialist optimism seemed to conservative Christians. For religious moralists, marriage was
a sacrament, not an agreement between two people, to be dissolved when it
71
72

On this point, see Niggemann, Zwischen Sozialismus, p. 252.
See Wischermann, Frauenbewegungen, pp. 65–70.

Social Democratic Sexual Ethics

151

no longer served their purposes. The vision of a future in which people formed
and then dissolved marriages at will was for them a vision of a world in which
marriage was spiritually and morally meaningless. The idea that young people
might engage in a period of experimentation and exploration with sexual and
emotional ties was equally alarming – because, as we have seen, conservative
Christians viewed sexuality as a potentially destructive force that could easily
come to dominate the moral personality altogether. A period of promiscuity or
even of serial monogamy in early adulthood would therefore be the worst imaginable preparation for responsible sexual adulthood, or indeed for the capacity
for moral responsibility of any kind. The communal child-rearing practices
that some socialists envisioned as enabling their moral utopia were anathema
to conservative Christians, who regarded life in the nuclear family as the only
soil in which the moral personality, capable of self-denial in the interests of
others, could thrive. Most fundamentally, finally, the philosophical materialism foundational to both Social Democratic positions on sexual morality –
orthodox and revisionist – was simply not a viable foundation for any kind of
morality at all. For Christians, morality was rooted in man’s spiritual nature;
neither cupidity nor greed and neither biology nor political economy could be
so organized as to be the source of morality.
In that sense conservative Christians actually were right about the relationship between socialism and immorality: the ideas of Social Democrats did form
a key theoretical justification for what conservative Christians saw as sexual
disorder. It therefore cannot have surprised conservative Christians that Social
Democrats played leading roles in two movements that, in their view, defended
sexual behaviors that were exceptionally immoral and corrosive: the homosexual emancipation movement and the medical campaign against venereal
diseases.
Chapters 7 and 8 treat these movements.

7
Homosexual Rights

I. Brain Science and Morality
Nothing better illustrated the profound implications of the philosophical materialism underlying socialist perspectives on sexuality than the emergence of the
homosexual rights movement in Germany at the turn of the century. The prejudice against homosexuality was so intense among educated Germans in this
period that the mere existence of an organized movement against the criminalization of homosexual acts potentially called every other sexual taboo into
question as well. If this issue was debatable, then so was everything. At the
same time, the arguments advanced against §175 of the Criminal Code, which
punished sex between men, represented so profound a revision of prevailing
conceptions of sexuality that they had implications far beyond this one issue.
A concatenation of developments contributed to the emergence of the homosexual emancipation movement. The most important of these lay in the development of psychiatry and of the theory of heredity. The foundation of psychiatry
was the understanding that human consciousness is the product of organic
processes in the brain – that mind, or spirit, is material. This belief led psychiatrists to assume that all kinds of behaviors, attitudes, and character traits
were rooted in the organic structures of the brain. At the same time, it also led
them to believe that these same behaviors, attitudes, and traits were shaped by
heredity.
The central ideas of the German homosexual emancipation movement of
the early twentieth century can be traced to the publications of Karl Heinrich
Ulrichs in the 1860s. Because all human beings, Ulrichs argued, are the product
of a union between a man and a woman, it follows logically from hereditarian
principles that all human beings are fundamentally hermaphrodites (Zwitter) –
a fact reflected in the undifferentiated sexuality of human embryos in the early

152

Homosexual Rights

153

months of their development. Homosexuality was a product not of immorality or willful perversity but of a rare variant or expression of this fundamental hermaphrodism. Homosexuals were people who had developed male
bodies, but female souls, or brains; homosexuality was a biological anomaly,
not a moral failing. The criminalization of homosexual acts was therefore, in
Ulrichs’s view, “a direct violation of human rights.”1
When Ulrichs attempted to present his ideas before an important congress
of natural scientists in 1867, he was literally shouted down; he eventually
immigrated to Italy and died in obscurity. Nevertheless, his ideas were picked
up almost immediately by the new science of psychiatry, and particularly by a
number of influential figures in that discipline who in the 1880s and 1890s laid
the foundations for sexual science (Sexualwissenschaft), or sexology.2 By the
late 1880s and early 1890s, psychiatry was sufficiently developed to produce
a growing number of studies specifically of the psychiatry of sex. The most
influential of these works not only concluded that homosexuality was a product
of an organic defect but also explicitly concluded that §175 was – therefore –
both pointless and unjust.
A particularly important case was that of Richard von Krafft-Ebing, a
German psychiatrist resident in Vienna. In his Textbook of Forensic Psychopathology, published in 1875, Krafft-Ebing concluded that although homosexual acts were rooted “for the most part in moral depravity,” actually there
were cases in which homosexual desires were the product of “a primary and
instinctively perverse sex drive,” which was in turn produced by a pathology of
the brain.3 He associated homosexuality with pederasty and held that homosexuals were characterized by “perversity and monstrosity . . . , imprudence . . . ,
cruelty” and “perverse lusts and selfish impulses”; they were “a severe menace
to society as long as they live” and “should be kept under lock and key for
life.” Nevertheless, they should not be “branded as criminals,” because they
were in fact “unfortunates who deserve pity.”4

154

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

Twelve years later, however, Krafft-Ebing’s views had substantially changed.
He prefaced his influential Psychopathia sexualis of 1886 with a kind of confession of faith in conservative Christian sexual ethics, arguing that Christianity had done more than anything else to make sexual relationships more
ethical and warning that despite its teachings people were permanently “in
danger of sinking from the luminous heights of pure and chaste love into the
swamp of low lust.” The human spirit was the site of an “unremitting struggle
between . . . sensuality and morality,” always threatening to bring about “the
collapse of the state and material, moral and political ruin.”5 And he still held
that homosexuals were suffering from an “abnormal psychosexual character”
or “hereditary neuropathic taint,” indeed that they were so degenerate that
“many even lack a consciousness of the pathology of their condition.”6 And
yet, Krafft-Ebing now also argued in effect that there were no cases of acquired
homosexuality. This conclusion derived from a newly clarified understanding
of sexuality itself, which he held to be defined by feelings rather than acts.
Homosexuality was a “feeling toward one’s own sex,” not “sexual acts with”
them; it was a perversion, not perversity. In fact, Krafft-Ebing argued that
sexuality was so deeply rooted in selfhood that it could not be changed by
any behavior. The “sexual personality” was among the “most firm constitutive
elements of self-consciousness”; it was inextricably bound up with the “whole
personality and even the physical mode of feeling” of the individual. When genuine homosexuality appeared later in life, therefore, it could do so only on the
basis of a “pre-existing disposition,” of “latent homo- or at least bisexuality.”
Men who turned to homosexual sex as a result of excessive masturbation or
libertinage were, therefore, actually merely perverted heterosexuals.7 In short,
Krafft-Ebing now regarded genuine homosexuality as an authentic form of
sexual subjectivity, or selfhood – as Bebel had put it, “self itself.”
Accordingly, sexuality was not a permanent threat to decency, the family,
and the state but rather the source of almost everything good in human life.
Sex was closely related to religious feeling and to aesthetic sensitivity; it could
inspire heroism, manly self-confidence, and statesmanship. It was an essential
and productive component not only of individual personhood but of human
culture as well. In fact, Krafft-Ebing believed he was engaged in the “rescue of
the honor of humanity,” because his work revealed that so much that “insults
the ethical and aesthetic sensibilities” was rooted not in normal but in pathological sexuality.8
This was his goal specifically with respect to homosexuality as well. He
argued that in cases of “originary” homosexuality, “the anomaly is limited to

the vita sexualis alone,” without corrupting the “character and entire spiritual
personality.” Accordingly, “the vita sexualis is among homosexuals . . . exactly
the same as in normal heterosexual love.” Anal intercourse was practiced
“only rarely and clearly only among morally defective . . . individuals”; most
homosexuals practiced merely mutual masturbation, and for many “a mere
embrace is sufficient to bring about ejaculation.” And unlike “depraved libertines,” genuine homosexuals were attracted not to boys but to adult men.9
Homosexuals did have an abnormally strong sex drive; but that merely further
excused their actions, because suppressing it would make them neurasthenic
and depressive.10 Krafft-Ebing still believed that most homosexual acts were
the product of libertinism; but in cases of genuine homosexuality, sex between
men should not be illegal. The genuine homosexual was, in fact, “a mentally ill
person” and hence “not legally responsible,” not a criminal; he was suffering
from “pathological perversion” and not a “moral deviance (perversity).”11 In
an essay on “The Homosexual in Criminal Court” published in 1894, KrafftEbing further elaborated on the implications of his findings. He still argued
that homosexuals “suffered” from a disorder that “is quite incomprehensible
to the normal person and fills him with horror.” But §175 was simply “unjust
and cruel,” because it punished “unfortunate people” who were merely following their “pathological . . . natural urges.” It “is based on false assumptions, is incompatible with the findings of scientific research, has done a great
deal of harm by driving useful and respectable citizens into scandal, distress
and death,” and must be abolished “in the interests of truth, justice, and
humanity.”12
A number of other researchers followed Krafft-Ebing’s lead in the 1890s. The
most influential was Albert Moll, who would become the leading sexologist of
his day by the turn of the century. Moll’s study of Die konträre Sexualempfindung (contrary sexual feeling), published in 1891, found that homosexuality was
an authentic sexual identity – “a pathological instinct that permeates the individual.” In consequence “we who study the question objectively really cannot
find in the homosexual instinct as such anything depraved.”13 The “unsavory
and often contemptible personal characteristics” of homosexuals, their (as he
saw it) tendency to be liars, their moodiness, their love of gossip, and their
vanity and envy, were in fact not signs of moral corruption but merely proof
that the “character” of the homosexual man displayed “more similarity with

that of the woman than that of the man.” Homosexual men were not corrupt, but merely womanish. But the negative image of the homosexual man
was also a product of the fact that it was only the most histrionic types who
were recognizable as homosexuals at all. Many homosexuals were actually
of “irreproachable character,” and some even “outstanding men of culture
and upright character.”14 As for the idea that homosexual sex was disgusting,
Moll simply observed that “normal intercourse with a woman surely has little
that is aesthetic about it” either.15 He therefore rejected the criminalization
of homosexual acts between men out of hand. Section 175 was unjust, it did
not deter homosexual men, punishment did not cure them, abstinence would
merely make them sick or neurotic, and because it was impossible to convert
a heterosexual into a homosexual, the law could not serve any public health
purpose.16
The arguments of Moll and Krafft-Ebing were certainly not universally
accepted. Some psychiatrists believed homosexuality was the product of chance
influences such as example, seduction, exposure to indecent pictures or texts,
mutual masturbation among boys, or, as the forensic psychiatry professor
Gustav Aschaffenburg argued, even the “flood of literature about sex” of recent
years.17 Most argued that some homosexuality was inborn and some acquired,
although they differed as to the proportions, the absolute number of homosexuals, and so on.18 Nevertheless, the historian Florian Mildenberger has
concluded both that most psychiatrists agreed on the inborn nature at least of
some homosexuality and that there was “substantial consensus . . . regarding
the senselessness of §175.”19
In the course of the mid-1890s, a number of factors helped to bring this
emerging psychiatric perspective on homosexuality to the attention of a broader
public. One was the trial of Oscar Wilde in London in 1895, which in
Germany as elsewhere in Europe created an opportunity for sexual radicals
to put their views forward.20 Public policy toward homosexuality was also one

more issue Social Democrats could use to point to the hypocrisy of bourgeois
sexual mores, and to elaborate their own naturalist alternative. The leading
revisionist Social Democrat Eduard Bernstein, for example, did precisely that
in his reporting for German audiences on the Wilde case in London (where
he was living as a journalist).21 The debate over the lex Heinze gave Social
Democrats an opportunity to raise the issue in Parliament; and August Bebel
sought out Magnus Hirschfeld, the leader of the most influential homosexual
rights organization, in the summer of 1897 and volunteered to support his petition against §175 in parliament, perhaps as a way to poke the advocates of the
lex Heinze in the eye.22 And more broadly, finally, the growth and consolidation of a homosexual subculture particularly in Berlin played an important role
in changing attitudes, particularly after 1900 – including among psychologists
and criminologists (a topic we will return to subsequently).23
In 1896 and 1897 this concatenation of factors produced the two initiatives in Berlin that would dominate the homosexual emancipation movement
for the next two decades. One was the loose coteries of radical activists and
literati around the journal Der Eigene, started in 1896 by Adolf Brand; from
1903 this group called itself the Community of the Peculiar (Gemeinschaft der
Eigenen [GE]). Its members largely eschewed scientific claims, ignoring developments in psychiatry and sexology in favor of more libertarian, rights-based,
Nietzschean-aesthetic argumentation.24 The Scientific-Humanitarian Committee (Wissenschaftlich-humanitäre Komitee [WHK]), founded in 1897 under
the leadership of Magnus Hirschfeld, was more influential; it cast its advocacy for the repeal of §175 – the central focus of its activities – explicitly in
medical-scientific terms.
Hirschfeld first laid out his ideas in 1896 in a pamphlet titled Sappho and
Socrates. Here he staked out the central message of all his later publications on
homosexuality over the next four decades: that human sexuality was not fixed
in two or a few immutable categories or oppositions (man/woman, male/female,

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

hetero/homo, etc.) but rather was a continuum of countless individual variants, and that within this “immeasurable variety” of love, all sexualities were
morally equal. Reviving Ulrichs’s argument, Hirschfeld reasoned that “in their
basic heredity all people are physically and spiritually hermaphrodites.” Remnants of masculinity were present in all women, and of femininity in all men –
and in varying, entirely individual degrees. The “qualitative differences”
between apparently distinct sexualities were in fact only of “quantitative
nature.” Homosexuals, bisexuals, and heterosexuals were thus all the same
in kind, although not in degree. Deviations from “the normal instinct” were
equivalent to “a congenital deformity,” a “birth defect” or a “developmental disorder” similar, say, to cleft palate. Homosexuality was not a pathology
but “a deeply rooted constitutional natural instinct.”25 A further implication,
obviously, was that there was actually no such thing as acquired homosexuality. What was not there at least in latent form could not be developed by any
external influences. It was possible to “awaken slumbering instincts” through
education, example, seduction, or suggestion; but in such cases “‘acquisition’
is just manifestation.”26 Accordingly, §175 was completely senseless – it was
in fact “a judicial crime” ( Justizverbrechen); and homosexuals could demand
legalization “not as a favor, but as their right.”27
Hirschfeld would return again and again in subsequent years to three central
themes set out in Sappho und Sokrates. The first was the authenticity and irreducibility of sexual identity – that sexual preferences were rooted in “the entire
personality” of the individual, were “inborn and unchanging characteristics.”28
He was particularly vehement in his prewar magnum opus on “Homosexuality
in Men and Women” (1914), going to enormous length to identify sexuality
as discernible in the entire physical and psychic personality of the individual –
from temperament to taste in furniture to facial expressions, gait, or the way
people sat. In sum, sexuality was “fused most intimately with the entire essence
of the personality.”29
Second, the fundamental hermaphrodism of all people similarly appeared
over and over in Hirschfeld’s work. In 1905 he would go so far as to assert
baldly that “seen from a very strictly scientific standpoint one can . . . not
really speak of men and women, but rather only of people who are primarily

Homosexual Rights

159

masculine or primarily feminine.”30 By 1912, in “Natural Laws of Love,”
Hirschfeld would even suggest that “it is in no sense clear yet what is masculine and what is feminine,” and that in any case there were many characteristics
of any individual “which one cannot label . . . with the adjective ‘masculine’ or
‘feminine’ at all.”31
Finally, Hirschfeld also recurred over and over to the theme of the “endless
variety” (1906) or “almost limitless” diversity (1910) of sexual variants. In
“Homosexuality in Men and Women” (1914), he actually did calculate the
number of possible variant sexualities: 43,046,721. But the logic of Hirschfeld’s
ideas was driving him toward the conclusion that actually there were just
people, each and every one of whom effectively constituted a sexual type or
category – that “love is as varied as people are.”32
Just as radical as these ideas were two fundamental assumptions related to
them. The first was that the only legitimate foundation of social order was
individual rights. He elaborated on this position particularly in his study of
“The Nature of Love” (1906), pointing out that because “the modern state
protects the individual, his life, his property, and his honor . . . interfering in
the sexual life of adults, the invasion of the bedroom,” was “an attack on
individual rights” – and hence should itself be punished.33 In 1906 he compared
the homosexual rights movement to the movement for the abolition of slavery
in the United States; in 1908 he even ridiculed §175 as “state regulation of
ejaculation.”34
This assumption rested, ultimately, on a second: that only science could
provide a legitimate and viable foundation for morality. As it became apparent that the clergy could not be won over, and as attacks from the Christian
morality movement mounted, Hirschfeld gradually grew more frank about
this view; and he put his cards fully on the table in “Natural Laws of Love”
in 1912. The title itself was a good indication of his intention here; but for
good measure Hirschfeld dedicated the book to Ernst Haeckel, the central figure in the German monist movement. Hirschfeld characterized love as a set of
automatic reactions of the “soul, brain and nervous system” to stimuli from
the senses. The upward spiral of the stimulus-response cycle culminated in
the “automatism” of the later stages of sexual intercourse, which Hirschfeld

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

went so far as to compare to the “mechanical” responses biologists had studied in animals whose brains had been removed.35 By the end of the book,
the antireligious thrust of this mode of thinking was explicit. Europeans had,
he explained, been “in the grip of anti-hedonist exaggerations for two thousand years,” thereby committing psychic “self-mutilation.” Christianity was
essentially sadomasochistic, delighting in the pain of ascetic self-denial. Not
surprisingly, among Christians the “excesses of abstinence” frequently gave
way to “excesses of debauchery”; thus Christian asceticism was the root of
the sexual misery and sexual anarchy of his times. Fortunately, humanity was
progressing toward a sexual culture that made more sense; morality was being
“liberated from prejudices” and rebuilt on “that natural foundation . . . , upon
which alone moral codes can be constructed.”36 In short, Christianity was
repressive and destructive ignorance and superstition; science was liberating
truth.37
Most involved in the homosexual rights movement agreed at least in principle with these fundamental elements of Hirschfeld’s perspective. The terminology of rights and of liberation in particular was virtually universal, appearing
frequently both in the WHK’s journal (the Jahrbuch für sexuelle Zwischenstufen [ JSZ]) and in the publications of those closer to the GE. The leading
intellectual figure in the radical wing of the movement, Benedict Friedländer,
would, for example, make much the same argument in the JSZ 1906, pointing
out that “criminal law is not the guardian of virtue, but rather has the aim of
punishing injuries,” and concluding that §175 was “a codified crime against
individual liberty.”38
It is more difficult to find evidence that others in the movement embraced
Hirschfeld’s project of developing a post-Christian scientific morality, his
understanding of the authentic originary sexual identity of the homosexual,
or his understanding of the endless variety of sexuality. But such views were
often at least implicitly present in texts by others. Thus, for example, the Dutch
student of homosexuality Lucien Römer developed a classificatory system for
describing homosexuals that was even more elaborate than Hirschfeld’s own,
including 423 basic types (each described by a Latin neologism).39 One author

Homosexual Rights

in Brand’s Der Eigene described himself and his circle as having “won through
to the free, sunny world-view of modern science.”40 Friedländer was even convinced that Christian sexual morality had originated in a plot on the part of the
priests to convince poor, suffering humanity that they were sinful and in need of
clerical guidance – it was a “trick” and a “monstrous fraud of world-historical
proportions . . . , for the purpose of usurping power.”41
The level of prejudice against homosexuality was massive and devastating,
and both wings of the movement were rather secretive. The WHK was not
a legal entity, in part because legal incorporation as an association (Verein)
would have involved submitting a list of members; the GE was even more
loosely organized. Many of those who published in the journals of either group
did not publish under their own names; they used initials or pseudonyms.42 In
1904 Benedict Friedländer observed that many respectable men did not even
dare to attend meetings of the WHK, “so great is the odium that is still associated with the matter.”43 When some well-to-do supporters of the WHK offered
a prize for the best educational essay on homosexuality in 1906, they did so
anonymously; and the winning entry was published under a pseudonym.44
Even so, some key figures did fall foul of the law. In 1902 the police in Berlin
forbade the open sale of the WHK’s educational pamphlets (for example, in
newspaper kiosks) as likely to give moral offense.45 In 1904 Hirschfeld was prevented by the police from speaking in Leipzig, on the grounds that his message
might persuade some in his audience to commit immoral acts “or at least to
consider them entirely unobjectionable.”46 In the same year, the WHK mailed
a questionnaire on sexual preferences to 3,000 students at the Charlottenburg
polytechnical institute (Technische Hochschule). Apparently at the instigation
of Wilhelm Philipps of the AKDS, six of them brought suit against him for libel
(Beleidigung, or insult), on the grounds that asking them whether they were
attracted to men implied that they might be. Hirschfeld was convicted and paid
a heavy fine.47 Adolf Brand’s deliberate provocations brought him a total of
two and a half years in jail for libel and assault; he was repeatedly charged
with distributing indecent materials; he and two colleagues faced hefty fines in

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

1900 and 1903 (along with two months in jail and confiscation of issues of
Der Eigene); and there were further legal cases in 1905 and 1906.48
Not surprisingly, then, the homosexual emancipation movement remained
small. The WHK reported in its newsletter in late 1906 that it had 450 members
or contributors; the Brand circle was probably considerably smaller.49 Both
organizations were focused in Berlin; there appear to have been branches of
the WHK in southwest and south Germany (Munich and Frankfurt) and in
the Rhineland, but they were small and low profile.50 The historian James
D. Steakley estimated that the organization had more than 1,000 members by
1914.51 In 1905 the WHK sent out 1,800 copies of its monthly newsletter to
members and sympathizers; that number rose to 3,000 in late 1907.52 In 1905,
at an early high point in the WHK’s development, 300 attended its annual
conference.53 Der Eigene appeared only sporadically; circulation numbers do
not appear to be available, although at least one issue had a print run of
1,000.54 All in all, it appears likely that the number of active supporters of the
two organizations together was probably around 3,000.
In the absence of membership lists, a useful indicator of who these people
were is the list of 830 signatories to the WHK’s petition for the repeal of
§175 in 1899. Just more than a third were employed in the arts, music, the
theater, publishing, and journalism, and a further 5 or 6 percent were employed
in museums, archives, and libraries or were academics; a third were doctors;
and about 9 percent were in the legal professions. Just more than 1 percent
were members of the clergy.55 The twenty-eight officers (Obmänner) of the
WHK in 1907 had a similar social profile: ten were doctors (plus one dentist),
four lawyers, three businessmen, three writers, two members of the nobility,
one a theologian, one an engineer, one a druggist (and two not identified by
profession).56 The WHK was dominated, in short, by doctors, lawyers, and
members of the white-collar middle class in what we might call the culture
industry. The professions dominant in the morality movements were virtually
absent.
An early focus for the activity of the WHK was the publication and circulation of its petition against §175, which was first submitted in 1897 with

200 signatures; it was resubmitted in 1899, 1904, and 1907, in the latter year
with 6,000 signatures.57 The petition itself gave mostly medical grounds for the
decriminalization of sex between men, concluding that §175 was “incompatible
with advanced scientific knowledge”; from 1899 onward it was accompanied
by a supplement that gave primarily juristic grounds, arguing that §175 was
“in contradiction with the principles of the constitutional state, which must
only punish where rights are injured.”58 From 1899 the JSZ brought scholarly
and informational articles. From 1902 the WHK also put out informational or
agitatorial pamphlets – about 100,000 copies by 1914.59 In 1898 Hirschfeld
published a new edition of the works of Karl Heinrich Ulrichs; other members
of the WHK published translations of novels with homosexual themes, and
works of Oscar Wilde.60 Hirschfeld’s 1904 study of the homosexual subculture
of Berlin (“Berlin’s Third Sex,” a term commonly in use at the time), published
in a popular series on Germany’s big cities, sold some 28,000 copies.61
Meetings of the WHK in Berlin appear to have been relatively frequent,
although small; the meetings of the Gemeinschaft der Eigenen were sporadic
and even smaller – one source reported meetings of fifteen or eighteen people
in 1904. From 1905, Hirschfeld and others addressed public and medical and
scientific meetings in major provincial centers around Germany.62 Probably
more significant in influencing public opinion in the long run was the WHK’s
survey among students in Charlottenburg and another sent to metalworkers in
Berlin. These yielded what was for the time an astonishing result: something
like 2 percent of men were attracted only or primarily to men, and another 3
or 4 percent to both women and men. Previous estimates had been far lower:
Ulrichs and the leading sexologists Iwan Bloch and Albert Moll believed that
perhaps 1 in 2,000 men were homosexual, and Krafft-Ebing estimated perhaps
1 in 1,000. As Hirschfeld pointed out, these survey numbers suggested that
there were some 1.2 million homosexuals in Germany, and 56,000 in Berlin

alone.63 These figures suggested how unrealistic was the idea (or ideal) of

Particularly in the years before 1907, these activities enabled the homosexual rights movement to generate a lively discussion of their agenda. As the
annual report of the WHK pointed out in 1906, as late as 1895 there had
been about a half dozen substantive publications in Germany on the subject of
homosexuality annually; by 1905 there were some 320.64 In Hirschfeld’s view,
this in itself was “no small thing: the period of silencing, of ignoring, is over,
definitively past. . . . Public opinion, which before fearfully avoided anything
even related to the topic, now concerns itself intensively with homosexuality.
It is, so to speak, on the public agenda.”65
The movement was also able to achieve some rather remarkable successes
in winning over psychiatrists and sexual scientists. A particularly striking case
is that of Iwan Bloch. In a 1902 study of the etiology of sexual disorders,
Bloch insisted that “‘inborn’ cases of homosexuality probably don’t exist at
all”; the whole idea was a product of the lies of homosexuals (“Priapus is a
god of lies”). Instead, homosexuality and other perversions were caused by the
natural or “physiological” need for sexual variety or by “external influences”
like suggestion or association.66 In fact, he feared that perversions could be
sparked by any form of deviation from a rational and respectable bourgeois
mode of life – sexual overindulgence, idleness among the wealthy, the influence of servants (who were from the lower classes and hence were primitive
and more likely to be perverts), the perversions common in brothels, mutual
masturbation among boys, indecent literature, pornography, nude statuary,
the ballet, variety-theater acts, circus acts, and so on and so forth.67 In the
case of women, he mentioned the role of the women’s movement, which gave
women masculine sensibilities and built solidarity among them. But the “primary etiological factor” was, for Bloch, “homosexuals themselves.” For “most
homosexuals are satisfied only by sexual intercourse with sexually normal people, whom they try to seduce for this purpose” – and it was a “sad truth” that
many homosexuals were particularly attracted to young boys. A repeal of §175
would be a “potent encouragement of the ruination of youth” and the consequence would be “inevitably a progressive moral and physical degeneration

of the human race.” Homosexuals should therefore be confined to “special
institutions” where “all therapeutic methods for the real extirpation of this

By the time of the publication of his very influential study, “The Sexual Life
of Our Times,” in 1907, Bloch had performed a complete about-face. He now
distinguished between genuine homosexuality and “pseudohomosexuality,”
the latter denoting primarily homosexual acts among heterosexuals in singlesex institutional settings. But the former was the norm and was not a pathology
or sickness at all. Instead, “genuine homosexuality like heterosexuality has the
character of an instinct rooted in the essential nature of the individual.” Having
called Hirschfeld’s estimates of the number of homosexuals “pure nonsense”
in 1902, Bloch now accepted the “approximate correctness” of Hirschfeld’s
numbers and observed that they meant that homosexuals had to be viewed as
“a curious anthropological variation on the genus Homo.” As for §175, it was
no longer the shield of youth but a “codified injustice,” even a “sacrilege.”69
One key reason for Bloch’s change of perspective appears to have been
that Hirschfeld introduced him to actual, live homosexuals in Berlin; his earlier
work, apparently, was entirely theoretical, based on secondhand information.70
Nor was this a unique case. The psychiatrist Paul Näcke, for example, regarded
homosexuality as a pathology in his early publications, but after visiting Berlin’s
homosexual scene in the company of Hirschfeld in 1904, he reported that he
was now “very much inclined to see homosexuality as a normal, infrequent
variation of the sex drive.”71 In other words, Hirschfeld’s knowledge of and
access to the thriving homosexual subculture of Berlin was an important factor
in reshaping medical opinion.
In contrast, the legislative response to the WHK’s petition against §175
might have been taken as rather discouraging: it was killed in committee twice
and debated in the plenum twice but on both occasions rejected (in 1898
and 1905).72 Hirschfeld, however, regarded the mere fact that parliament discussed the question in 1898 as a sign of progress – indeed, it was enough to
convince him that “truth is on the march.”73 By 1905, the debate was much
more heated. In that session the Social Democratic spokesman adopted most
of the arguments of the homosexual emancipation movement – for example,
that the treatment of homosexuals was the modern equivalent of the persecution of witches in the Middle Ages; that science had discovered that there
were not only men and women but “a great number of intermediary steps”;

and that homosexuality was not even a disease and, in any case, was not

again judged the debate “an important step for our movement; this is the first
time that the German parliament, perhaps the first time that any parliament
has discussed the well-being and woes of homosexuals in open session.”75 It
may have seemed significant, too, that Hirschfeld in particular was able to
make himself a resource, serving as an expert witness for individuals suffering
from the nasty effects of §175. Without citing figures, Hirschfeld had claimed
already in 1901 that “in a whole series of cases” he had been able to convince
the courts that the defendant did not have free will “with respect to the sexual
instinct,” thereby securing acquittal (by reason of diminished responsibility) or
even dismissal.76
Finally, particularly after 1905, the homosexual rights movement was able to
build alliances with a growing number of organizations pursuing related goals.
The WHK had a particularly close relationship, for example, with the leading
sex-reform organization in Germany, the League for the Protection of Motherhood (BfM), which was formed in 1905; a number of leading figures in the
WHK were early members.77 Both organizations had ties to the German Monist
League (Deutscher Monistenbund [DMB]). Hirschfeld was one of the signatories to the public invitation to join the DMB at its founding in 1906, as was
Helene Stöcker, the key personality in the BfM.78 Leading members of all three
groups were close to the SPD as well. Hirschfeld himself became a Social Democrat while at university, and one historian has suggested that he was effectively
“the great retailer of Social Democratic sexology.”79 The WHK and Hirschfeld
in particular also cultivated ties to the emerging psychoanalytic movement; and
Hirschfeld was among the founding members of the Berlin Psychoanalytic Association in 1908.80 Sigmund Freud himself held that homosexuality should not

be classified as a disease, and at least before 1910 he argued that it must have
some foundation in the constitution of the individual.81 Finally, Hirschfeld
was also able to build ties to the broader emerging discipline of sexology,
among other things by cofounding the short-lived Journal of Sexual Science
in 1908, and then the successful Medical Society for Sexual Science (Ärztliche
Gesellschaft für Sexualwissenschaft und Eugenik [ÄGSE]) in 1913, in collaboration with Iwan Bloch and the prominent sexologist Albert Eulenburg.82
In short, increasingly after 1905 the homosexual emancipation movement
appeared to be part of a rapidly expanding and ramifying spectrum of reform
movements explicitly and self-consciously founded on a shared commitment to
a scientific worldview, and particularly to a social and sexual ethics based on
natural science. The formation in 1907/1909 of the Weimar Cartel, a coalition
of organizations committed to a secular and libertarian worldview (including
the BfM, the DMB, the Society for Ethical Culture, the League for Secular
Schools, and several other organizations), helped to foster the sense that what
supporters considered modernity – the scientific view of the world, individual
rights, and some form of democratic and socialist politics – was on the march.83
II. Hypervirilism, Scandal, and the Emergent Monist Reform Milieu
As it turned out, however, the march of progress was anything but smooth. The
entire period from 1906 to 1910 was, in fact, one of painful reversals. The first
of these was a split within the WHK itself. Differences between Hirschfeld’s
relatively moderate WHK and the more radical grouping around Adolf Brand
and Der Eigene had divided the movement from its inception; and in 1906
the influential radical Benedict Friedländer led a self-styled “secession from the
WHK.” The WHK’s reliance on medical and above all psychiatric authority,
he argued, had produced “a certain one-sidedness” in the movement, encouraging the view that homosexual desire was primarily a sexual pathology.84
In fact, however, sexual orientation and sexual activity were not problematic
for the normal homosexual or bisexual; and such people did not need medical
experts to speak for them. “In a matter in which the subjective feelings play
a key role,” he pointed out, “it is obvious that only those can be counted
as experts who know that subjective feeling from their own experience.” The
