Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

people best able to represent the interests and analyze the feelings of homosexuals and bisexuals were not “crazy-doctors” (Irrenärzte) but homosexuals and
bisexuals themselves.85 And the proper basis for the homosexual emancipation
movement was not natural science but natural law; it was primarily a question
of the “axiomatic principle of personal freedom,” not of medicine.86
Friedländer associated his own, primarily political argumentation with
manliness, claiming to speak for those with “virile” character – not for the
“Urnings” (Ulrichs’s term), those with a woman’s soul in a man’s body. Real
men would not “beg for pity” by characterizing themselves as suffering from
a “disease” or a “deformity” or even an “anomaly.”87 The time was ripe,
instead, for principled opposition. The movement had now grown so large and
influential that it could “probably no longer be held back by any power.”88
And it was only one part of the “whole modern movement for sexual freedom”
(Friedländer mentioned particularly the BfM) against the “fraud,” the “ascetic
delusion,” of “the Christian priests of the Middle Ages” who had labeled
“everything sexual as suspect and sexual pleasure as such . . . as sinful.”89 In
concrete terms, Friedländer supported the idea of a mass self-outing of homosexual men – a strategy discussed but rejected at the 1905 meeting of the
WHK.90
Friedländer’s advocacy of this “manly” approach was rooted in an alternative understanding of the nature of homosexuality. In his Renaissance des
Eros Uranios of 1904, Friedländer reasoned that human beings were higher
primates, animals with social instincts; and those instincts had “‘carnal’ or
physiological” foundations, “physiological forces of attraction . . . independent
of sexual difference.” In contrast, sexual attraction between males and females
had nothing to do with the higher functions of sociality; it was merely the
foundation of reproduction, a “primitive” urge humans shared with all
animals.91 The indiscriminate physiological attraction binding social animals
together, in contrast, was the foundation of everything higher – for example,
love of friends, patriotism, and humanitarianism. Same-sex attraction was “a
special, inborn, specifically human affect sui generis,” and it was what made
human beings civilized.92
The boundary between sexual attraction and “physiological friendship”
(as he called the bonds created by men’s social instincts) was, Friedländer

conceded, “more or less fluid”; men sensually attracted to each other would of
course sometimes slip over into sexual acts. That was unfortunate; but there
were of course endless instances of “cruder instincts” and “animalistic passion”
in heterosexual relations as well. The whole matter was in any case “really not
such a frightful affair.”93 Fundamentally the situation was that “two people
who like each other give each other pleasurable sensations” without injury to
each other or anyone else; the idea that the state should get involved in that
scenario was “as absurd as any taboo of primitive peoples.”94
The persecution of homosexual men in fact rested on absurd superstition,
foisted on humanity by priests and women. The prevailing Christian code of
morality consisted of “remnants of a cunning clerical fraud and sinister delusion,” designed to make men believe that they needed priests to intercede for
their sinfulness.95 But its primary supporters were actually “females” (Weiber),
for the simple reason that women were inferior and slavish creatures. As the
“lesser sex,” the “mentally inferior half of humanity,” women needed something to stifle men’s superior energy, intellect, and creativity.96 The unholy
alliance of the “woman-worshipping tradition of the priest-ridden Middle
Ages” and “modern, misdirected revolutionary egalitarian fanaticism” subjected men to “permanent female surveillance,” which “prevents any real, even
merely intellectual, much less physical intimacy among men from arising.” With
solidarity among men sabotaged, the “social tyranny of women, supported by
custom and priests” was crippling the whole of European culture. Love was
one of the main sources of joy in human life, and joy lent people “energy and
inclination to think, above all to independent scientific or artistic . . . thought.”
Small wonder, then, that the Greeks, who had not denied men the better, more
spiritual half of their opportunities for love, were so creative, whereas modern
Europeans were merely “materialistic and commercial.”97 What was more,
men were by nature characterized by “independence, freedom and productive
work,” and friendship between them was thus a “source of strength and the
sense of self-reliance” and a “bulwark of individual and in particular masculine
freedom.” Women, in contrast, were characterized by “dependence and obedience.” The “tyranny” of women was therefore the great obstacle to democratic
political progress.98 This was also why Social Democracy – as an “authoritarian
Marxist distortion” of real socialism – supported women’s rights.99
Hirschfeld would later (in 1914) dismiss Friedländer’s secession as an
“extremist side-show.”100 But the roots of the split in the WHK were actually

quite deep.101 The concept of the “supervirile” homosexual, who was so manly
that he was “the highest flower of humanity,” intellectually, spiritually, and
physically superior (and attractive) to other men, had been advanced already
by the zoologist and Darwin-popularizer Gustav Jäger in 1880.102 And ideas
similar to Friedländer’s had been standard in Der Eigene’s circle for a decade by
1906. In 1898 the poet and anarchist John Henry MacKay echoed Friedländer’s
later rejection of medical authority, remarking that “I will not let others prescribe . . . the target of my feelings.”103 Elisar von Kupffer, poet and editor of
an anthology of homosexual literature published in 1900, denounced his times
as “unmanly,” calling for the “emancipation of men” and the “revival of masculine culture.”104 In 1902 the ethnologist Heinrich Schurtz published a study
of “Age-Groups and Male Associations” around the world, establishing that
men had a “purely social instinct” that bound them to other men and made
them the “bearers of almost all higher social development.”105 And in concrete
terms Friedländer was apparently able to attract a number of major WHK
donors, thereby cutting painfully into the organization’s financial base (at least
until his death in 1908).106
The timing of Friedländer’s initiative, however, could scarcely have been
more unfortunate. For in 1907 the movement was overtaken by a snowballing
series of homosexual scandal trials involving high government officials, and
by the wave of public anger they inspired. In late 1906 the editor of the liberal journal Die Zukunft, Maximilian Harden, published a series of articles
attacking the court intrigues of a close associate of the emperor, Prince Philipp
zu Eulenburg, and his friends; in particular he suggested that Eulenburg was
homosexual, and that this explained his preference for a conciliatory approach

in foreign relations. Two members of this same grouping were accused of
homosexual activities at the same time, and an unofficial investigation suggested that scores of prominent aristocrats were homosexual.107 Adolf Brand
made a particularly ill-advised attempt to “out” the chancellor, Bernhard von
Bülow, who took him to court for libel, and Kuno von Moltke – a prominent figure at court – sued Harden. The resulting court cases dragged out over
two years, complete with surprise witnesses, overturned convictions, perjury
charges, and a courtroom heart attack; in the end one key trial was indefinitely
postponed for health reasons, and the government paid the cost of a settlement
to make the other go away.108
As this whole affair dragged on and on, a growing number of opinion makers
appear to have concluded that the whole business was a farce, had embarrassed
the nation before the international public, and was – somehow – the fault of
homosexuals. The liberal press, which had previously seemed to support repeal
of §175, turned sharply against the homosexual rights movement.109 Some
academic sexologists, too, now turned against the movement. Albert Moll,
although still supporting the repeal of §175, argued that the trials proved that
it was a terrible mistake to combine agitation with science, as Hirschfeld and
his colleagues did.110 And the scandal provided an opportunity for reactionary
figures to return to well-worn arguments that homosexuality was a “communicable disease” (in the words of Friedrich Wachenheim) or the product of
excessive masturbation (as Otto Ammon saw it).111
This complex of events had a profound impact on the homosexual rights
movement.112 Already in May 1908, the AKDS was celebrating the fact that
public opinion had turned against the WHK and its ideas, a development it
saw as evidence that “God the Father still rules the world.”113 Hirschfeld,
shocked at the vehemence of homophobia in the press and public, spoke of a
“collapse” and blamed Brand and Friedländer for alienating the public. The
WHK’s income fell by two-thirds, and the number of contributors by half.

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

The JSZ was not published at all in 1907 and from 1908 appeared only in
slimmed-down format as a quarterly report. The GE virtually disappeared, as
did Friedländer’s secession.114
It was particularly unfortunate that this crisis came just as the government and parliament were beginning deliberations on a reform of the Criminal
Code. When the national parliament’s committee on petitions discussed the
WHK petition once again in late 1907, rather than considering legalization,
it recommended new and more severe penalties for male prostitution and for
those who used positions of authority to secure homosexual favors.115 A first,
informal “pre-draft” (Vorentwurf ) of the new Criminal Code, published in
October 1909, adopted these suggestions, explaining that homosexuality was
a “danger to the state, since it is suited to damage men most severely in their
character and in their civil existence, to wreck family life, and to corrupt male
youth” and would “seldom remain without influence on the whole moral personality of these deviants.” It even extended the prohibition on homosexual
acts to women, as well as men.116
And yet, the crisis was relatively short lived. By 1909, it appears that the
public was beginning to grow tired of the whole matter. Albert Eulenburg,
commenting on the belief of the authors of the pre-draft that popular opinion demanded punishment of homosexual acts, held that “in truth public
opinion . . . is very little concerned with the matter” and asked, “Why all the
fuss?”117 In late 1911 the journal of the WHK claimed that increasingly “people
sense the absurdity, the injustice, in part even the ridiculousness of” §175.118
The attempt to extend §175 to women, in particular, backfired; much public
commentary found the idea at best laughable, and at worst outrageous. In late
1909, for example, one conservative newspaper commented that
in an age in which behind the scenes the fate of Europe, the well-being and
destiny of peoples is being negotiated . . . , the parliament of the German empire is
solemnly debating whether one boarding-school girl is allowed to slip into the bed
of another, whether they are allowed to kiss each other on the lips, and whether

further caresses are to be permitted by the state, and if so then which, and if not

In fact, one effect of the proposed extension was to rally women’s organizations openly to the cause of the WHK. The women’s movement was divided
by the issue. Marie Stritt, chair of the BDF until 1910, expressed “horror” at
male homosexuality, and the organization’s legal committee, rather perversely,
even welcomed the extension of criminalization to women as a step toward
equality before the law. But others saw that step as proof of male hypocrisy,
voicing their “disgust at what thousands of men call ‘normal’ feelings” even as
they continued to visit brothels.120 In simple, practical terms, however, because
many single women lived together (to save money on housing and to preserve
their sexual honor), extending the law to cover sex acts between women would
expose a large number to potential blackmail, false accusations, and police
harassment. Organized women were therefore often vehement in their opposition even when they found homosexuality morally or aesthetically objectionable. Katharina Scheven of the IAF, for example, feared that homosexuality
was an “infectious mania” but argued that the DZIAF “cannot limit itself, so
far as it takes a position on the question of homosexuality at all, to demanding
that female homosexuality remain unpunished; rather, it must . . . demand the
abolition of §175 full stop” (although she did support a higher age of consent
than for heterosexual acts). The fundamental principle held here too: “The
state is not the guardian . . . of individual morality.” Anna Pappritz described
homosexuality as “reprehensible, repulsive and disgusting,” but she too held
that “private relationships between adults are not subject to the criminal law.”
And the BDF adopted a resolution holding that “sexual aberrations without
injury to legal rights of third persons must remain unpunished (§175).”121
Legal academics were equally skeptical. In 1911 a number of prominent
jurists published their own “counter-draft” to the government’s initial draft of
the Criminal Code revision, arguing that consensual sex between adults posed
no threat to society and therefore was not grounds for punishment. Sex between
men should only be punished when one was under age twenty-one, when
the younger was in a position of dependence (for example, a student, ward,

apprentice, etc.), or when one was motivated by the “profit motive.”122 This

Despite such dissent, the legislative process ground toward adoption of a
more repressive approach before World War I. The official commission convened by the government in 1911 abandoned the idea of criminalizing sex
between women and adopted a more restrictive definition of homosexual acts
between men (“intercourse-like acts” rather than, say, mutual masturbation).
But it suggested that men should be punished even for merely offering sex
for pay, as well as for actually performing sexual acts for material reward.
In parliamentary committee, by 1913, further provisions were added setting
very severe penalties for male prostitution, for homosexual acts with minors,
or even for merely offering homosexual sex. The reform of the Criminal Code
was dropped with the outbreak of World War I; but supporters of homosexual
rights had no reason to be optimistic about the legal future.124
Nevertheless, the WHK in particular made a rapid recovery. By 1910
Hirschfeld reported that the WHK had “resumed its activities in full measure since before the beginning of the year.”125 Some opponents agreed: Der
Volkswart carried one report in 1910 that agitation against §175 “is being
pursued with undiminished energy.”126 Hirschfeld himself produced arguably
his most impressive and radical work to date with “Natural Laws of Love”
in 1912 and “Homosexuality in Men and Women” in 1914. And the WHK’s
journal did not give the impression of being the mouthpiece of a chastened
organization after 1910; instead, it appeared to seek a rapprochement with
the radical wing of the movement. Thus, for example, in October of 1911 it
carried an article defending the adult male homosexual’s love for “the youth
between about 14 (15) and 23 (24) years of age” as comparable to a heterosexual male’s attraction to teenage girls, and suggesting that “physical friendship”
with an older, “respectable homosexual” was healthier for male youths than
the alternatives.127 In 1913 the journal went further still, publishing an update
(in three parts) of the ideas of Friedländer and other radicals by the youthmovement activist, philosopher, and psychologist Hans Blüher, who held that

Equally important, both Hirschfeld and the WHK were more active than
ever in building alliances within the broader progressive reform milieu. Two
leading members of the BfM, for example, became officers of the WHK: the
organization’s most influential activist, Helene Stöcker, in 1912 and the early
lesbian feminist Johanna Elberskirchen in 1914.130 Ties between the DMB and
the WHK also became closer after 1910, with Ernst Haeckel himself contributing a lead article to the JSZ in 1913, and Hirschfeld speaking before the DMB
on the errors of the “theological sex-dictators” and the evil effects of their
“system of sexual coercion.”131 Hirschfeld was one of the three founders and
chairmen, with Iwan Bloch and Albert Eulenburg, of the Medical Society for
Sexual Science and Eugenics (ÄGSE) formed in 1913.132 After 1910 relations
between the homosexual rights movement and psychoanalysis were disrupted,
with leading psychoanalysts arguing that homosexuality was merely a neurotic
compulsion and was hence curable if only the sufferer were truly willing.133
Freud himself, however, continued to deny that homosexuality should be classified as a disease, and to regard homosexuality effectively as an object choice
comparable to that underlying heterosexuality.134 And both he and a number
of other prominent psychoanalysts were members of the ÄGSE – as were, for

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

example, Helene Stöcker and the leading SPD expert on public health and
eugenics, Alfred Grotjahn.135 After faltering briefly during the scandal trials,
the Social Democratic periodical press too continued to support the WHK and
its petition in the years before the war.136 The WHK, in other words, was
not only increasingly radical but also increasingly well connected in the years
following the scandal trials.
Beyond such organizational efforts, however, more fundamentally, by 1914
the movement had played a crucial role in definitively establishing a new model
of authentic sexual identity. As Blüher put it, whereas the “old school fixed the
concept [of sexuality] to the direct activity of the genitals and called an action
‘sexual’ only if it intended a pleasurable excitation of the sexual organs,” the
new model was that “sexual acts” in this sense were “special cases . . . of a
broader and lastingly influential field of action” – one that was central to
individuality as such, and to social life as well. Indeed, Blüher argued, “it can
indeed no longer be doubted that sexuality is the most powerful motive force
on the road to greater refinement” of civilization; sexuality underlay all cultural
achievement, all social order, the existence of the state, and in short everything
that conservative Christians thought it threatened.137
In an odd sense, in fact, the situation of the homosexual rights movement
by about 1910 appears to parallel that of the Christian morality movement.
Building on intellectual roots that reached back at least to the 1860s and
1870s, in the 1890s and 1900s new organizations had been able to generate
a vibrant public discussion of their conceptual, social, and even legal agendas.
But they were not able subsequently to control that discussion – neither in the
broader public nor even internally within their own circles. Obviously, this
latter problem was one that also paralleled the division between orthodox and
revisionist Social Democratic views on sex.
The evolution of the medical campaign against venereal disease is a fourth
example of the same pattern. At its outset, that campaign attempted to gather
together all those concerned with the sexual health of German society – from
conservative Christians through to abolitionists. By the years before the war,
it had alienated its conservative allies, done much to spark the emergence of
the sex-reform movement, and was increasingly being pulled in two different
ideological directions: toward Social Democracy on the left and toward radical
authoritarian race theory on the right.
That process is the subject of Chapter 8.

Syphilis and Salvation

By the early twentieth century, important advances in medical science revealed
the extraordinary extent of venereal infection in German society and the prevalence of long-term and secondary consequences of sexually transmitted diseases
(such as infertility or paralysis). Partly as a result of and partly in response
to criticisms of regulation from the various morality movements, shortly after
1900 medical men made a concerted organizational effort to gain control of the
issue of prostitution. The organizational vehicle for this effort was the National
Society for the Combating of Venereal Diseases (Deutsche Gesellschaft zur
Bekämpfung der Geschlechtskrankheiten [DGBG]), which was formed by dermatologists and venereologists in 1902 and held its first conference in 1903.1
It was immediately successful in attracting a great deal of attention in the
press, and it grew very rapidly. Already by the end of 1904, it had twenty-four
local chapters; by the outbreak of the war it had thirty-seven. Membership
climbed to 4,000 by early 1905 and then planed off, reaching 5,000 by 1912.2
The organization saw its primary task as to spread basic knowledge about
venereal diseases in the population at large, and its activities were above all
informational. From 1904 onward it distributed pamphlets and leaflets in large
numbers and for various audiences, often in cooperation with the public health
insurance system; by 1906, 3 million such informational documents had been
distributed.3 Local chapters offered evening lectures for parents, young men,

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

workers, domestic servants, and students; cooperated with societies for popular
education and charity organizations; lobbied in favor of sex education classes
(although with limited success); and offered seminars for teachers. In the last
years before the war, a traveling exhibition on STDs visited numerous German
cities and was uniformly well attended – in Munich and Hamburg in 1913
by more than 30,000 in each city.4 Public readings of a play dramatizing the
dangers of venereal infection were also well attended.5
It was not immediately apparent that the DGBG would be a competitor
and opponent, rather than an ally, of the morality movements. At the outset
the organizers of the DGBG appeared to be determined to create a genuinely
comprehensive organization for people concerned with the issue. More than
half of the members of the committee convened to found the organization
were doctors (and one-fifth were professors of medicine), and the three leading venereal diseases experts of the day were chosen as chairman, general
secretary, and vice-chair. But the initial organizing committee also included
Ludwig Weber of the AKDS; Otto von Leixner; the leading liberal Protestant
theology professor in Germany, Adolf von Harnack; leading academics in the
social sciences; and the liberal jurist and criminologist Franz von Liszt. Other
members included the sexologist Albert Eulenburg; Kurt Eisner, editor of the
Social Democratic newspaper Vorwärts; Alfred Grotjahn, the SPD’s leading
public health expert; and Max Taube, a key pioneer in child welfare in Leipzig.
Only 12 of the 157 members of the organizing committee were women; but
they included both Katharina Scheven and Anna Pappritz (DZIAF), Hanna
Bieber-Böhm (VJS), Marie Stritt (BDF), Lida Heymann (VFF), and the Social
Democrats Wally Zepler and Hope Bridges Adams-Lehmann. Thirty-seven city
governments joined.6
The membership of the organization itself was less diverse, however. Some
two-thirds of the initial general membership were medical doctors or medical academics; about a sixth were in business or the law (lawyers and some
judges); some 10 percent were women (including a few doctors); 5 or 6 percent
were in journalism, the arts, or non-medical academic fields; and some 6 percent were in city, state, or national government. Civil servants, the clergy, the
military, and the nobility – dominant in the morality organizations – together

made up well under one-tenth of DGBG membership.7 There were, furthermore, a dozen socialists in the organizing committee; and Alfred Blaschko,
its general secretary, was a longtime sympathizer and would join the party in
1919.8
The organizers of the DGBG nevertheless attempted to build consensus
around the public health issue of venereal diseases, in particular by arguing
that the spread of STDs was a crisis that affected the nation as a whole.
At the same time, they attempted to reassure the morality movements. The
organization’s new chairman, Albert Neisser, perhaps the country’s leading
venereal disease expert (who, among other accomplishments, had identified
the gonorrhea bacillus in 1879), was extremely careful in this regard in his
speech to its first meeting. Neisser argued that because STDs were primarily
spread through sex outside marriage, “we cannot shy away from taking up
this struggle too, the struggle against extramarital sex as such . . . we cannot
neglect the moral-ethical side.” What was more, “we will make it our business
as well to eradicate or reduce those phenomena in our social life that are suited
to have a sexually inflaming effect.” And “comprehensive progressive social
reform” to raise the “material and thereby moral condition of the female
population” was needed to cut off recruitment into the sex trade. Clearly the
message was effectively that the DGBG could be everyone’s friend.9 And in fact
a number of leading medical men in the organization were even sympathetic
to the abolitionist position.10 Alfred Blaschko rejected both the abolitionists’
opposition to compulsory medical measures and the moralism of the “pious
abolitionists” (that is, conservative Christians). But he also offered a blistering
condemnation of regulation as “discriminatory legislation” and as worse than
useless from a medical perspective.11 In an address to the annual conference
of the VFF in 1903, he argued that the best form of prophylaxis would be
“to improve the economic condition of women” – which would be possible
only “in a genuinely free, democratic state . . . in which the well-being of all
is the goal, and equal participation the means.”12 And Albert Neisser, the

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

DGBG’s chairman, largely agreed that regulation was in practice a failure, and
in particular that it was medically ineffective.13
Controversy broke out already at the end of the founding meeting in October
1902, however, when one doctor objected to the election of Anna Pappritz
to the organization’s executive board on the grounds that “we are not here
to found a morality association.”14 At the DGBG’s first formal conference
in March 1903, it became clear that this was actually the majority view in
the organization. Albert Neisser’s keynote speech laid out the problem in a
nutshell. Neisser advocated social reforms such as public housing policy, child
welfare laws, vocational education, temperance, and so forth and suggested
that unless the system of regulation were drastically overhauled “it would be
better to drop the whole system.”15 What Neisser proposed to put in its place,
however, was neither criminalization nor abolition but Kasernierung. Modern
medical science, he held, made it possible to cure both syphilis and gonorrhea;
and it was therefore theoretically possible, if all prostitutes could be subject
to adequate medical examinations and then required to undergo treatment,
virtually to eliminate STDs among prostitutes. Something approaching this
ideal state could be accomplished through a number of reforms. Regulation
should be put in the hands not of the police but of a new “sanitary commission”
housed not at police headquarters but in a hospital. The police would play only
a secondary role in this reformed, sanitary/medical system, by finding women
who tried to avoid treatment. But they would also have a crucial role outside
the system; for they would be used to “drive prostitution . . . so far as possible
from the streets.”16 It was not true, Neisser held, that demand from men
created prostitution; the “decisive factor for the dimensions of prostitution at
any given time” was the “seduction to engage in sexual intercourse beyond any
natural need, which proceeds from the female side.” Prostitutes were not only
socially underprivileged and economically vulnerable women but were “antisocial elements . . . , aggressive, provocative”; clearing them from the streets
was necessary to protect men and public decency.17
Logically, if prostitutes were driven from the streets, “brothels . . . should
be permitted under law.” Neisser argued that confining prostitutes to brothels would have substantial hygienic benefits, because it would permit more
regular medical examinations and more closely supervised treatment; in fact,
he suggested daily examinations. In effect, then, Neisser advocated creating a
giant system of compulsory confinement – although he assured his audience
that close public supervision would prevent the kind of egregious exploitation

to which women in existing brothels were subject.18 Anticipating objections
to this plan from the women’s movements, Neisser suggested simply that if
doctors should ever “be in the position to exercise ‘tyranny’ in the interests of
eliminating infection and disease, that would only prove the necessity of such
a new tyrannical organization.”19 He apparently did not regard his own proposal as an instance of such tyranny; but clearly he was effectively proposing
an immense expansion of the level of coercion and control to which women
working in the sex trade were subjected.
Neisser’s model was well received by the medical men in the DGBG. A
number of those who spoke during the discussion after his presentation argued
that municipal or state-run brothels should be established, contending, for
example, that people should be less concerned with the rights of women and
more with the rights of the “young men who are seduced and infected by
women,” or that prostitutes were “often morally and psychologically inferior,
half-idiots, ‘born’ prostitutes.”20
Such plans were by no means uncontested within the DGBG. In fact,
Neisser’s address was followed by a rebuttal by Anna Pappritz, who warned
that the “sanitary commissions” he envisioned would be no different from the
existing vice police; predicted that any such scheme would “require an army of
bureaucrats”; and pointed out that in Berlin alone introducing Kasernierung
would effectively require the creation of an entire “brothel-city” with some
10,000 inhabitants. The whole idea was, she held, not only laughable but also
a “monstrous injustice.”21 In the discussion Katharina Scheven accused Neisser
of trying to recreate “medieval conditions.”22 Blaschko argued that because in
practice most women in the sex trade escaped all efforts by the authorities to
find and control them, the question of whether or not to try to confine them to
brothels was “completely irrelevant.”23
These were not the views of the majority, however, who clearly favored
Neisser’s neoregulationism – or were happy with the system of regulation as
currently practiced.24 As the journal of the BDF put it in its report, the “nature
of the discussion among some men of medicine proves once again that men still
cannot get used to the idea of seeing women as having equal rights.” Katharina
Scheven concluded that “reactionary tendencies” were dominant within the
medical profession; Anna Pappritz considered the “realism” of the doctors,
who thought they could render prostitution hygienic, to be utopian hubris;
Marianne Weber referred darkly to the “ethically disoriented part of our male

population, above all some medical men completely lacking in sexual-ethical
sensibility.”25 Women in particular continued to raise objections at the second
and third conferences of the DGBG, in 1905 and 1907.26
Nevertheless, it is clear that the idea of Kasernierung was steadily gaining
ground within the medical profession. Developments in medical knowledge
encouraged this trend – in particular the discovery of the spirochete bacterium
in 1905, the development of the Wassermann test for chronic syphilis in 1907,
and the introduction of Salvarsan as the first (minimally) effective treatment for
syphilis in 1910.27 The balance of opinion was clearly shifting, for example,
within the National Health Bureau, in which by 1908 six of thirteen members
of a special committee on epidemic diseases favored Kasernierung. In that year,
in fact, even the prime minister spoke in favor of legalizing brothels.28
Doctors’ desire for an intensification of state intervention in the sex industry
was underlain, furthermore, by a very particular understanding of the moral
status of sexuality. Most medical men were indifferent to the ethical concerns
of the morality campaigners, and in particular to their fears regarding the disruptive social potential of sexuality as a demonic, animalistic force. Instead,
they held simply that people wanted to have sex; that there was nothing particularly wrong with that; and that in any case there was nothing that one could
do about it.
This position became explicit in the course of a debate within the DGBG over
the precise wording of its first leaflet for mass distribution, in 1903 and 1904.
The first paragraph of the first published draft of that leaflet warned the reader
that “there are no really reliably effective prophylactics against infection with
venereal disease; all extramarital sexual intercourse can, even if precautionary
measures are taken, be dangerous. Nevertheless it is advisable . . . to make use
of such devices.” The DZIAF submitted a protest to the DGBG, arguing that
this last sentence “has . . . a dulling effect on the sense of personal responsibility and is a direct advertisement for sex with prostitutes.”29 But the IAF’s

preferred, more negative version received only one of twenty votes within the
organization’s governing board.30 In the end the pamphlet was only slightly
revised, warning that the risk of infection could be “substantially reduced,
but not completely eliminated” by using prophylactics.31 Yet even this slight
change infuriated others in the DGBG membership, who argued that because
condoms were in fact effective, it was their duty as medical men to recommend
them explicitly. Even Max von Gruber, who was among the most conservative voices in the DGBG, argued in 1907 that knowledge of prophylactics
“must . . . be spread as widely as possible among the populace, without regard
to whether illegitimate intercourse might at first perhaps be encouraged” by
doing so.32 By 1910 the influential medical sexologist Max Marcuse in particular was so incensed by the willingness of the DGBG leadership to compromise
with the morality campaigners that he suggested that the organization would
have to change its name to “Society for Combating Extra-Marital Sex.”33
Blaschko made himself spokesman for this view in an article in the DGBG
newsletter in 1904. It was all very well to appeal to people’s sense of moral
responsibility, he argued; but it was well known that “in thousands of cases
this sense fails” to change behavior; and as doctors “we have to reckon with
the facts.” It was understandable that “a sensitive woman, who is unfamiliar
with real life,” would shrink from recommending the use of prophylactics; but
doctors familiar with “raw reality” could not be guided by such sentiments.
As for the Christian morality campaigners, he observed that the teaching that
extramarital sex was immoral and forbidden “has been the prevalent one for
millennia” but that history showed that it “takes no account either of the natural characteristics of humanity, nor of real life” and that “the mass of average
people have never known how to resist the vagaries of sensual desire.” In short,
the idea of “converting Germany’s male youth to chastity” was “madness.”34
The radical moral relativism underlying this pragmatic stance was made
clear in an exchange in the DGBG newsletter between Albert Neisser and
Gustav von Rohden, a rising young voice in the Inner Mission, in 1904. Von
Rohden had published an open letter in the newsletter in which he critiqued
a speech Neisser had delivered in Düsseldorf, again in support of regulation
and Kasernierung. The majority of those present, von Rohden believed, “took
home with them from what they heard quite powerful support for excusing their
dissolute way of living.”35 Neisser’s response was blunt. Sober and objective
observation, he suggested, showed that it was unrealistic to think that humanity

“will or even can live up to the demands of an idealistic sexual morality.”36
As for von Rohden’s commitment to Christian sexual ethics, Neisser held that
“from a purely scientific standpoint” there was no indication that there were
actually any “universally valid principles in the area of sexual morality at all.”
And he (Neisser) could “not simply without qualification and in every case
regard extramarital sexual intercourse as something reprehensible,” because
for “countless people it is and has been the source of the highest and purest
happiness and the foundation of their greatest creativity.”37 In fact, Neisser was
also an early signatory to the WHK’s petition for the legalization of sex between
men, apparently believing that sex was good for people in whatever form.38 In
purely pragmatic terms, finally, Neisser had argued already at the first DGBG
conference that prostitution was at bottom simply a market transaction. The
moralistic approach ignored the fact that prostitutes’ clients were simply seizing
on a “coincidental opportunity to pacify their sensual excitation,” whereas the
women involved were either “girls who occasionally have sex and happily
and gladly give themselves to a man, following their own sensual desires” in
return for some form of gift, or “genuine prostitutes” in it for the money. The
whole exchange was either mutual enjoyment or “pure business”; in either
case it was “completely legitimate,” and the moral pathos of the Christian
morality campaigners was irrelevant.39 Neisser was equally dismissive of the
abolitionists. Like Blaschko, he was actually quite friendly toward the women’s
movement; in fact, his sense of gender justice was acute enough to lead him to
observe that “from the standpoint of justice I have to agree . . . with the demand
that women too have the right to satisfy their sex drive before marriage.”40
But as for the rights of the individual over her own body, Neisser dismissed
the idea with the comment that “I cannot acknowledge the justification for a
right to be sick and to injure others through one’s sickness.” As much as he
would like to agree with the abolitionists, he understood only too well that the
“faults and vices of humanity” made it impossible to realize their “in and of
themselves correct ‘principles.’”41
Neisser was particularly brutal in his relativism – indeed, he appears to have
been proud of the fact, remarking that he was “certainly ‘brutal’ enough to take
brutal facts and brutal people for what they are.”42 But others within the DGBG
expressed similar views. The prominent Frankfurt gynecologist Max Flesch, for
example, remarked in the discussion of Neisser’s 1903 speech that the existence
of prostitution “proves . . . , that the uniquely legalized and licensed form of

can, under prevailing social conditions . . . , not remain chaste until marriage.”45
Over time exchanges on sexual morality at the DGBG’s conferences became
increasingly heated. At the second conference in 1905, for example, Katharina
Scheven remarked that “naturally it’s much more convenient to lock defenseless
girls in brothels than to take up the struggle against a pack of brutal and crafty
types” like the men who hired them. Friedrich Bohn of the AKDS observed that
“a lot is said about the protection of the sex-hungry man – this flower of our
nation – but little about the protection of girls,” whom the “brutal man” and
the “brutal state” conscripted for men’s pleasure.46 In contrast, the advocates
of Kasernierung were clearly in no mood to entertain kibitzing from people
they regarded as amateurs. One speaker even congratulated the conference on
the fact “that it is not really necessary to speak to doctors . . . of the usefulness
of regulation.”47 Wilhelm Hammer was equally blunt, arguing that “a point of
view that seeks to feed us pious wishes – e.g. elevation of the moral level
of humanity etc. – is useless.”48 Max von Gruber dissented, arguing that if
everyone were guided by this brand of realism “we’d still be at the level of
pithecanthropus erectus.”49 But he was clearly in the minority.
By the third conference in 1907, Blaschko in particular was clearly not in
a conciliatory mood. In an introductory address to the session devoted to sex
education, he conceded that “we may never go so far in our hygienic efforts
that we grossly insult the ethical sentiments of our fellow citizens.” He also,
however, remarked that “whoever . . . wants to make us believe that there is
one true sexual morality” should simply be “referred to the lessons of history
and ethnology”; whatever moral conservatives might think, “the demands of
nature are as unambiguous and constant as sexual-moral concepts are changeable, and we should be guided only by the former.”50 Others were equally
impatient. In the same session Henriette Fürth dismissed Friedrich Wilhelm
Foerster’s reflections on sexuality and spiritual life out of hand, remarking

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

that “Christian-religious dogma has dominated our culture for two thousand
years. . . . And what’s the result? . . . An unprecedented moral impoverishment.”
The Berlin sexologist and birth control advocate Julian Marcuse too stated
bluntly, in the discussion period, that “in the matter of sexual ethics religion
has, since the very beginning, completely failed.” The sex reformer Maria Lischnewska argued simply that “only that can be moral which is in accord with
the laws of nature.”51
The debate within the DGBG over the use of prophylactics is a good illustration of the emerging principled pragmatism of many doctors. The tone was
set at the DGBG’s 1905 conference in an address on §184.3 of the Criminal Code (which after the passage of the lex Heinze in 1900 punished the
advertising of “objects intended for indecent use”) advocating “universal use
of condoms . . . , if necessary through free or very cheap distribution . . . with
simultaneous instructions for use” as likely to lead “almost to the eradication
of venereal diseases.” The belief that “moral preachments” could achieve the
same end, the speaker insisted, was based on “utopian sentiments” and a “failure to accept reality.”52 Despite some dissent, the majority in the organization
clearly favored this view; and in a petition to parliament in 1910, the DGBG
called legislation introduced that year that would ban advertising for contraceptives “extraordinarily dangerous . . . a serious endangerment of the health of
our own nation.”53 By 1913 Blaschko – the organization’s general secretary –
even recommended the “ruthless recommendation of prophylactics until the
whole population is fully informed from the onset of puberty.”54
Even more revealing was a discussion within the DGBG over the dangers or
benefits to individual health of sexual abstinence. The majority regarded abstinence as a harmless and effective method of avoiding venereal infection; but
in the years before World War I, a growing number of doctors began to argue
that long-term celibacy could have serious and even fatal consequences, particularly for men.55 The centerpiece of the debate was a kind of one-man crusade
against celibacy by Max Marcuse, who in an extended essay in the DGBG’s
journal in 1910 argued that the idea that abstinence was harmless was merely
a “brazen assertion” advanced by conservatives. In fact, long-term abstinence
could cause a whole panoply of ills ranging from insomnia, distraction, and

moodiness to hysteria, depression, hallucinations, paranoia, and perversions of
all kinds (e.g., homosexuality, masochism, sadism, fetishism, and pedophilia).
The good news was that sexual intercourse could cure these ills almost immediately; the bad news was that “if sexual abstinence has gone on too long and
if the malady is too far advanced, then this cure too can come too late.”56
Marcuse was extreme, but many in the DGBG appear to have sympathized
with his views; and in 1911 the organization devoted half of its annual conference to the question. The keynote speaker on this issue, the sexologist Albert
Eulenburg, was decidedly moderate, regarding temporary celibacy as harmless
but considering longer-term celibacy as at best abnormal and an “undesirable,
inappropriate risk” and definitely dangerous for those with irregular sexual
dispositions.57 But a paper by the Swedish doctor Anton Nyström offered a
radically opposed perspective. Nyström delivered a blistering attack on Christian “abstinence fanatics” and “ignorant” doctors who, despite sexual abuse
scandals in the Church and mounting empirical evidence of the harmfulness of
not having sex, continued to peddle the “conventional lie” of the harmlessness
of abstinence and the myth that sex was a “low instinct.” Abstinence was an
“evil contrary to nature” that involved “serious dangers for body and spirit,”
whereas having regular sex made people more capable of leading a “useful and
noble life” by giving them “happiness and joy, health and energy for work.”
It was high time that a “natural morality” replaced the prevailing nonsensical
“spiritualistic morality.”58
The discussion following these papers was inconclusive. What is significant
about the debate, however, is not who won or lost but rather what it was
about. The DGBG had initially defined its brief very narrowly: it was concerned with venereal diseases, and how to control them. The first conference
in 1903 had focused primarily on two legal questions: whether the knowing transmission of venereal diseases should be criminalized and whether or
how prostitution should be regulated. The organization’s second conference,
in 1905, had been devoted to regulation, Kasernierung, and brothels, and to
the question of whether the principle of confidentiality in the doctor-patient
relationship should be modified in the case of venereal diseases. Thereafter, the
focus drifted. The third conference, in 1907, was devoted to sexual pedagogy
and sexual ethics, with Friedrich Wilhelm Foerster and Alfred Blaschko delivering the key addresses.59 By 1911, the organization had returned in part to the

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

question of venereal disease, in that the debate over the legal status of prophylactics did address public health issues; but the centerpiece of the conference
was the discussion of the harmfulness or otherwise of abstinence. This debate
was carried out in purely medical terms.
By 1911, then, the DGBG had moved into new territory in two senses.
First, those who did not share the views of the doctors who dominated the
organization had largely stopped participating in its deliberations. Foerster’s
1907 paper on sexual pedagogy had been a kind of parting shot (although
debate in some local chapters continued).60 The organization did not entirely
abandon its early attempt to provide a broad forum for discussion and debate,
and a special commission it established in late 1912 to try to develop concrete
proposals for the reform of the law on prostitution included not only Neisser,
Blaschko, and other doctors but also abolitionists (Scheven and Pappritz) and
even conservative Christians (Pastor Mätzold of the AKDS and Mueller of the
DEF). But by that time relations between these groups had thoroughly soured.61
Second, the organization had drifted ever further from its original focus on
venereal disease and prostitution and was increasingly debating broader issues
of sexuality and sexual health. The DGBG was clearly contributing not only
to the popularization among medical men of a new strategy for the control of
venereal diseases but also to the elaboration of an alternative code of sexual
ethics more broadly – one that was explicitly naturalistic and pragmatic, rather
than religious and idealist.
In part, this development was driven by Social Democrats – for example,
Alfred Blaschko. But a growing minority of medical men were actually drifting
toward a radically biologistic, eugenic, ethnic-chauvinist völkisch, and often
racist sexual ethics. Thus, for example, in 1908 the DGBG journal published
a radically naturalistic, anti-Christian, and völkisch rebuttal to Friedrich Wilhelm Foerster’s 1907 address by the Munich doctor, monist, and race theorist
Friedrich Siebert. Siebert argued that “Christian abstinence-fanaticism” with
its “onanistic cult of virginity” was creating a pathological “condition of sexual over-excitation” with terrible consequences. The answer must come from
a radical embrace of the theory of evolution and of the ethical value of the
biological nation – that “higher whole” that “will come after the individual,
and stands above the individual.” In Siebert’s radically biologistic code of sexual ethics, “sin” lay “therein, that the soul has sought to elevate itself above
nature”; sex was clearly there “for the sake of the child to be conceived”; the
state was “in the final analysis nothing more than a contrivance of nature for
the care of the progeny of a species”; and the purpose of marriage was “care of
the young” rather than mutual appreciation of each others’ “precious individuality.” And of course the ultimate goal of national-biological life was military

61

See, e.g., “Ortsgruppe München,” MDGBG 12 (1914): 66, 67.
“Sachverständigenkommission der Deutschen Gesellschaft zur Bekämpfung der Geschlechtskrankheiten,” ADF, DEF, no. 7a.

189

power. Pointing to the recent war in German Southwest Africa, Siebert asked
rhetorically “whether our soldiers there need asceticism.” What they needed,
instead, was “a taste for manly deeds.”62
Siebert’s ideas, obviously, were not likely to charm Christians – who believed
that developing a capacity for self-denial was the precondition for performing manly deeds, and who had vehemently criticized the lack of sexual selfdiscipline among German soldiers in colonial wars. In fact, Siebert’s essay was
followed by a brief rebuttal by the leading neo-Malthusian Hans Ferdy, who
observed that “the relationship between the German doctors and ethics as a
science does not offer us a hopeful prospect” and recommended that his medical colleagues “at least remain silent where they are unwilling to learn.” But as
Ferdy remarked, “Dr. Siebert does not stand alone among his colleagues with
his dilettantish ethical efforts.”63 As we will see in Chapter 11, similar ideas
were increasingly influential among medical men interested in sexuality more
broadly.
And yet, again, this drift to the radical nationalist and racist right was not
the only possible outcome of the engagement with eugenic and race-hygienic
ideas. In fact, the debate within the DGBG catalyzed the emergence of a far
different, and far more influential, alternative: democratic and socialist sexual radicalism. In part as a consequence of the debate over the DGBG’s first
pamphlet in 1903/1904, the abolitionist movement split in 1904. Whereas
Pappritz and Scheven remained committed to a conservative sexual ethic, some
spokeswomen – Helene Stöcker, Maria Lischnewska, Lida Gustava Heymann,
and others – adopted the “realist” position that, under prevailing social conditions, extramarital sex was going to happen, and that the risks had to be
contained.64 In 1905, these women would found their own sex-reform organization, the League for the Protection of Motherhood (Bund für Mutterschutz [BfM]). Thereafter, although the DGBG remained influential in policy
debates, the articulation specifically of a radical naturalist sexual ethics within
the DGBG became a mere sideshow. The main event in that respect was now
the sex-reform movement, and the intense debate over sexual ethics that it
generated.
Chapter 9 turns to that development.

Sex Reform

I. The Roots of Sex Reform
The sex-reform movement built on two major currents in late nineteenthcentury thought: the Romantic cult of the individual and monism – the belief
that matter and spirit are a unitary whole, that spirit is merely an expression
of man’s physical being. Helene Stöcker, longtime leader of the League for the
Protection of Motherhood (Bund für Mutterschutz [BfM]), pursued doctoral
and postdoctoral research on eighteenth-century aesthetics and on the great
Protestant theologian and theorist of romantic love Friedrich Schleiermacher;
and both she and her critics frequently pointed out the debt sex reform owed
to the Romantics. She found in the thought of Friedrich Nietzsche the “continuation and fulfillment of Romantic longing”; but she was also one of the
founding members of the DMB in 1906 (as was Magnus Hirschfeld) and would
later write that Ernst Haeckel had been “one of the most courageous, bold,
decisive and path-breaking leaders” in the “cultural struggle for the liberation of the individual” from outmoded social and moral constraints.1 Iwan
Bloch, a longtime member and officer in the BfM, held both that modern love
was “individualized” love and that “anyone who has scientifically researched,
philosophically explored, and really experienced love . . . must become a convinced monist and reject the dualist separation between the physical and the
1

Gertrud Bäumer, “Die neue Ethik vor hundert Jahren,” Frau 14 (1907): 452; Gustav von Rohden,
“Die sexuelle Frage im Protestantismus,” SP 6 (1910); Heinrich Meyer-Benfey, “Lucinde,”
NG 2 (1906): 172–179; Helene Stöcker, “Ehe und Sexualreform” (1911), in Resolutionen des
Deutschen Bundes für Mutterschutz, 1905–1916, ed. Helene Stöcker (Berlin: BfM, n.d.), p. 55;
Marielouise Janssen-Jurreit, “Nationalbiologie, Sexualreform und Geburtenrückgang,” in Die
Überwindung der Sprachlosigkeit, ed. Gabriele Dietze (Darmstadt: Luchterhand, 1979), p. 143;
Helene Stöcker, in Was wir Ernst Haeckel verdanken, vol. 2, ed. Heinrich Schmidt (Leipzig:
Unesma, 1914), pp. 328, 327.

Sex Reform

191

spiritual as artificial.”2 This combination – Romanticism, Nietzscheanism, and
monism – can be found throughout the sex-reform movement.
As radical materialists, many sex reformers were also attracted to Social
Democracy; and in fact most of the ideas central to the sex-reform agenda
had been articulated in much less detail in Bebel’s Woman Under Socialism
at the end of the 1870s, or in the Social Democratic press as early as the
1880s.3 The BfM was never formally a socialist organization, and a number
of important figures in the movement rejected socialist ideas. But most of the
leading figures in sex reform were either Social Democrats or were attracted
to far left, semianarchist socialism. Some leading members of the SPD were
also members of the BfM – including the influential revisionist parliamentarian
Eduard David and August Bebel himself.4
Finally, sex reform was also a product of the broader and intensifying concern with social reform after about 1900, and in particular of the growing
interest in the birthrate, population policy, and infant mortality.5 Although the
leadership was primarily concerned with the effort to reform sexual morality,
many members of the organization’s local chapters were primarily interested
in welfare work with single mothers, and with agitation in favor of maternity
insurance (Mutterschaftsversicherung).
The BfM was founded in Berlin in January 1905 by sexual radicals who had
parted ways with more conservative abolitionists in 1904, partly as a result
of the debate over prophylactics within the DGBG and partly because Stöcker
in particular had antagonized leading moderates in the movement – among
other things by publishing, as editor of the feminist journal Frauenrundschau,
a laudatory review of the English sex reformer Edward Carpenter’s radical
sexual-libertarian views. When the VFF leadership refused to take up the cause
of sex reform (probably for fear of alienating more sexually conservative abolitionists), Stöcker and Maria Lischnewska joined with others in and outside
the women’s movement to form the BfM.6 Those initially involved included
Ruth Bré, who had been independently agitating for the formation of rural
colonies for unmarried mothers; the sexologist Max Marcuse; Walther Borgius,

anarchist pedagogue and general secretary of an influential free-trade lobby
group; Alfred Blaschko; the feminist theorist and novelist Hedwig Dohm; the
medical doctor Agnes Hacker; the sociologist Werner Sombart; Adele Schreiber,
a leading socialist social policy advocate, and several others.7 In February
this group held a public meeting in Berlin to announce the formation of the
BfM; speakers included Stöcker, Marcuse, Lischnewska, Schreiber, Lily Braun
(another important figure in Social Democratic social policy), Iwan Bloch,
Bruno Meyer, the Swedish social and sexual philosopher Ellen Key, and the
prominent Berlin trial lawyer and jurist Erich Sello.8
As these lists suggest, the BfM was initially conceived as a very broad-based,
catchall organization, and early on it had remarkable success in recruiting members from a quite broad spectrum on the political and cultural left. Early supporters included leading revisionist Social Democrats (Heinrich Braun, Eduard
David, and Hugo Boettger); influential left-liberals (Friedrich Naumann, intellectual godfather of left-liberalism; Anton Erkelenz, leader of the liberal trade
union movement; and the influential sociologist Max Weber); welfare advocates (Frieda Duensing, soon to be director of the private National Center
for Child Welfare, established in 1907); medical men (Alfred Blaschko, Albert
Neisser, and Max Flesch); sexologists (Albert Moll, Iwan Bloch, and Albert
Eulenburg); eugenics experts (Alfred Ploetz and Ludwig Woltmann, editors
respectively of the two leading eugenics journals in Central Europe); the philosophy professor and theorist of sex and race Christian von Ehrenfels in
Prague; the Swiss entomologist, temperance campaigner, moral reformer, and
sexual theorist August Forel; the penal reformer Franz von Liszt; and a panoply
of feminist activists and female doctors, including the chair of the BDF, Marie
Stritt. About one-third of members appear to have been men; so were half
the members of its governing board (which comprised usually seven or eight
members total) and almost two-thirds of its broader executive committee in
1905. Of the fifty-three members of the executive committee, twenty-two were
medical doctors (eight of these professors of medicine); seven had doctorates
in the humanities, social sciences, or theology; seven were jurists and judges;
and four were members of the national parliament (eleven were not identified
by profession, and two were a count and countess).9

193

The BfM initially grew rapidly and had some 4,000 members in nine local
chapters by 1909. These chapters operated nine information centers, which
helped single mothers find work and gave advice on contraception, pregnancy,
sexual problems, and so forth; they also founded eight shelters (“mothers’
homes”) with some 110 beds for single mothers and their children. Its journal,
titled Mutterschutz through 1907 and thereafter Die Neue Generation, quickly
became the most important sex-reform journal of the period. The organization
published and distributed some twenty pamphlets and petitions to various legislative bodies, on topics such as the training of midwives, motherhood insurance, public support for breast-feeding, venereal diseases, sexual abstinence,
sex education, and the radical New Ethic championed by the organization’s
leadership. In 1907 and 1908, the organization’s speakers offered fifty-two
public addresses in cities around Germany.10
The diversity of the BfM’s membership soon resulted in a raft of defections.
Ruth Bré felt the leadership was insufficiently focused on social work and left
almost immediately.11 Some eugenics enthusiasts also left soon after the BfM’s
formation, with Alfred Ploetz arguing, for example, that it “can . . . for the time
being not claim to have any race-hygienic value” because it seemed to him to
be unwilling to adopt strict eugenic criteria for assistance to single mothers.12
A whole phalanx of men defected in 1907 and 1908, as it became clear that the
organization would be dominated by radical women. A particularly important
instance was that of Max Marcuse, who left in late 1907 to pursue a more

scientific program in contradistinction to Helene Stöcker’s utopian Nietzschean
humanism.13 Anton Erkelenz left after Helene Stöcker refused to, as he put
it, “pursue her Nietzscheanism outside the League.”14 After bitter personal
conflicts with Stöcker in 1908 and 1909, finally, a number of socialist women
also left – including Lily Braun, Henriette Fürth, and Adele Schreiber.15
Despite these fissures, the BfM continued to constitute the organizational
core of the spectrum of sex reform in the period before World War I. Many
who left the organization – in particular, socialist women such as Schreiber
and Fürth – continued to support and agitate for ideas very similar to those
championed by the BfM. And even some sex reformers not formally associated
with the BfM referenced its work and echoed its message very closely.16 Sex
reformers never achieved a degree of doctrinal unity comparable to that of their
Christian counterparts in the AKDS, the Catholic morality movement, or the
confessional women’s organizations. But there was a remarkable degree of
consensus among them both on fundamental postulates and on practical aims.
The guidelines adopted by the executive council of the BfM in 1910 are
a good summary of the practical measures on which almost all sex reformers agreed. They called for equal rights for children born out of wedlock;
the abandonment of the double standard of sexual morality; equal rights for
women within marriage; sex education in the schools; full legalization of the
production, advertising, and sale of contraceptives; the legalization of unmarried cohabitation; the liberalization of divorce law and legislation on public
decency; the abolition of the system of police regulation of prostitution; and
the creation of a public system of maternity insurance. Although opinions were
divided within the organization regarding abortion, key figures also supported
legalization, and in 1909 the organization as a whole declared the “current
form of §218” (which criminalized abortion) “not viable,” calling for milder
penalties.17 Almost all sex reformers were also agreed on two fundamental
philosophical postulates underlying such demands. First, sexual relationships
should be judged in moral terms not by their outward forms but by their
emotional content. Second, individual sexual relationships were important to
the wider community primarily because of the relationship between sex and
reproduction; in every other respect, sex was a private matter not subject to
outside interference. The fundamentals of the sex-reform program, then, can

be summed up quite simply: sex reformers demanded the liberation from legal
restrictions of the individual as a sexual subject; and they favored the social

variously as society, the nation, the “race,” or the human species).
II. Sexual Repression, Sexual Perversion, and Sexual Exploitation: Sex
Reform’s Critique of Christian Morality
There was a very considerable overlap between the demands of the BfM and
those of radical and even moderate feminists, regarding, for example, family
and divorce law, access to education and the professions, and political rights;
and a number of women prominent in sex reform were active also in the
women’s suffrage movement in particular. Strikingly, however, in some ways
the sex reformers’ critique of their society’s sexual culture was very reminiscent
of conservative Christian views. Johanna Elberskirchen, for example, argued
in 1897 that “our entire civilization, our whole social order is infected with
priapism” and “sexual anarchy”; in 1904 she even wrote of the “swamp”
created by the “bestiality” and “animalization” of sexual life.18 In its petition
in favor of the introduction of sex education in the schools in 1906, the BfM
complained of the general “degeneration and depravity of sexual life.”19 Adele
Schreiber described the BfM in 1907 as a “protest association . . . against the
vulgarity, baseness and licentiousness that in fact prevail in the sexual life of
our times.”20 Ruth Bré believed her society was characterized by “whoredom
and whorish spirit wherever one looks.”21 The sex reformers, too, regarded
prostitution and venereal disease as – as Iwan Bloch put it – “the real heart,
the central problem of the sexual question.”22 They, too, saw prostitution
specifically as the product of men’s sexual brutalism and privilege – their “onesided domination” (as Hedwig Dohm put it), their double standard, and their
“sexual mendacity” (in the words of the Austrian writer and philosopher Grete
Meisel-Hess).23
The sex reformers also shared a sense that the moral crisis of their society was
very broad – that its symptoms included sexual abuse, the sexual precocity of

hat der Mann aus Weib, Kind und sich gemacht? Revolution und Erlösung des Weibes (Leipzig:
Magazin, 1904), pp. 96, 87, 104, 99.

school children and youths, the traffic in white slaves, the deplorable character
of popular film, the dangers of trashy popular literature, and so forth.24 Anita
Augspurg, for example, urged in 1911 that those cultural forms that directed
people’s attention to “the ecstasy of erotic relationships” (such as trashy literature and film) “have to disappear . . . from the field of view of . . . youth”; in
the same volume, Käthe Schirmacher deplored the current “cult of the sexual,
the erotic” in mass culture.25 In 1905 Maria Lischnewska held that “trashy
literature and vulgar entertainments exploit the whole field of sexual life to turn
people into beasts.”26 And Iwan Bloch delivered a denunciation of sexual disorder in 1907 that would have made any conservative Christian morality campaigner proud, deploring sexual anarchy, the “compulsive need for the greatest
possible sensation,” the universal desire for mere “entertainment,” all the various institutions of urban nightlife, the modern “relationship,” pornography,
Schmutz and Schund, and so on and so forth as the “cancer of our society.”27
Nor was it unheard of, finally, for sex reformers to voice opinions regarding
the place of sexuality in human life and psychology that were strikingly similar
to Christian and abolitionist views on the “dominion of the spirit over the
flesh.” The liberal Protestant pastor Ernst Baars, who was active in the BfM,
argued in Die Neue Generation in 1908 that the first commandment of a new
sexual ethic must be “thou shalt . . . bend your sensuality and all your drives
to thy will and thereby ennoble them.”28 Helene Stöcker cited approvingly
the belief of the Austrian painter, novelist, and women’s rights activist Rosa
Mayreder that “the origin and vehicle of all spiritual life lies in the conquest of
an instinct that can subjugate individuality.”29 And the BfM itself adopted, at
its second convention in 1909, the principle that truly ethical relations between
men and women depended – among other things – on “habituation to selfdiscipline and control of the sensual drives by both sexes.”30
Despite such similarities, however, the starting point of sex-reform thought
was actually a radical attack on what the sex reformers saw as the crabbed,

Sex Reform

197

cramped, and unnatural asceticism and prudishness of Christian sexual theory.
In the words of Helene Stöcker’s programmatic introduction to the first issue
of Die Neue Generation in 1905, the sex reformers rejected “the old morality,
which saw . . . the human being as a disobedient sinner and the sex drive as evil
incarnate,” an ethic of “renunciation and denial of life” that “brands the most
elemental vital urge after hunger as something evil.” As monists committed to
the essential unity of body and spirit, the sex reformers must “restore to the sex
drive its original innocence,” must “unite and blend it . . . ever more with our
entire mental and spiritual life.” The aim, as she had put it already in 1897,
was not the absolute rule of the spirit over the body but “harmony between
the intellectual and sensual natures of man . . . man and woman – reason and
sensuality.”31
Stöcker was particularly vehement in this respect; but this view of the unnatural, unhealthy, and destructive character of Christian “dualism” (as opposed
to monism) was common throughout the sex-reform community.32 As the
movement’s most influential philosopher, Ellen Key, argued in 1909, “‘to be
fully human’ does not mean . . . that the spirit suppresses sex, or sex the spirit”;
rather, it requires harmony and balance between the two.33
But Christian sexual morality was not merely crabbed and ascetic; it was
also misogynistic. The denigration of sexuality in Christian thought was, the
sex reformers argued, intimately associated with the denigration, oppression,
and exploitation of women. Christianity identified women with reproduction,
sex, the body, and nature, and thus with sin – which must be controlled,
contained, and repressed. Thus Helene Stöcker wrote in 1905 that whereas “the
great significance of woman for humanity lies in motherhood,” Christianity
had “marked motherhood with a stigma from the start” with the concept of
original sin.34 Iwan Bloch, too, argued in 1907 that “the real origin of modern
misogyny is Christianity, the Christian teaching of the originally evil, sinful,
demonic nature of woman.”35
At the heart of the sex-reform message, then, was an understanding of
the nature and potentials of sexuality, and of the place of sexuality in the
structure of the subject, of the person, that was diametrically opposed to that

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

underlying the morality movements. For conservative Christians, as we have
seen, the authentic subject was the moral subject; morality was the dominion
of the spirit over the anarchic, asocial, selfish, and indeed demonic flesh. In
contrast, the sex reformers held that sexuality was an integral element in the
human personality, and thus that the authentic subject was a sexual subject.
Sexuality, and specifically women’s sexuality, therefore had to be acknowledged as a legitimate and positive force in individual and social life. Sex was
not a dangerous and fundamentally destructive, antisocial force but rather a
creative, erotic force; it generated energy and built social bonds, rather than
dissipating energy and rupturing social bonds. Like any other human faculty,
it could be misused; but its normal exercise was necessary, beneficial, and thus
objectively good. Health, happiness, and individual and social well-being was
not a product of self-discipline and self-denial, of the suppression of anarchic,
egoistic, or destructive vital energies; rather, it was a product of the release and
engagement of creative vital energies – including sexual energies.
The sex reformers therefore saw the pursuit of sexual pleasure as a legitimate
goal in its own right, independent of procreation. In fact, quite frequently the
sex reformers defined sexual pleasure literally as a right. Thus in the third
pamphlet published by the BfM, Walther Borgius declared “sexual activity to
be a natural and self-evident right of every adult man and woman.”36 Henriette
Fürth was highly skeptical of this formulation (and left the BfM in part because
it seemed too unconditional); but she too called sexual desire a “right,” holding
that “in sexual matters too” a woman must “demand her rights.”37 Iwan Bloch
held in 1907 that “human beings have a natural, inborn right to satisfaction of
the sex drive,” within the bounds of social and individual responsibility.38 In
1912 Die Neue Generation defined the “right to sexual intercourse, love and
motherhood” as “one of the most elementary human rights.”39 The logic was
simple: sex is a need; therefore sex is a right.
But beyond the conception of sex as a legitimate need, as a precondition of
mere health, the sex reformers were fascinated by the dynamic, creative potentials of sexuality as the source of the vital energy that underlay human creativity
in every field of endeavor. Adele Schreiber wrote in 1907, for example, that
sexuality and the passions that it created were the “origin of crimes and vulgarities” but also “the inexhaustible wellspring of inspiration . . . , the roots
of art, the creative force behind great deeds!” In 1908 Ernst Baars called the
sex drive the “most powerful, essential creative drive in man” and observed
that sexuality was the root of “madness, cruelty, and brutality” but also of

199

“the most noble activities of intellectual life – religion, art, charity, humanity,
courage, the creative drive etc.” Helene Stöcker believed that “the sex drive
has the tendency to blend with all human abilities, to be sublimated. . . . The
Christian contempt for eroticism is so fateful precisely because the erotic plays
a role in everything human.”40 And in 1915 Leopold von Wiese, chair of a BfM
chapter in Düsseldorf, would argue that the suppression of sexuality amounted
to the suppression of “the best material for the construction of the social body,”
because “feeling, will, thought and action draw their energy from the blood,
from the rhythm of our primary and secondary sexuality.” The suppression of
instinctual drives, he believed, made people unhappy; and “happy people are
at the same time useful people; they are in harmony with their surroundings,
they are friends and willing builders of society.”41
Obviously, this vision of the centrality of sex to literally everything human
rested on the same conception of the authentic sexual self that was central
to the Social Democratic conception of sexual ethics and to the homosexual
rights movement. In 1912, for example, Helene Stöcker argued that “sexuality
is in our view something so inextricably bound up with our entire psychic and
physical being that it cannot ever be separated from our lives.”42 Iwan Bloch
similarly held that sexuality was the “heart and axis of all social life,” “the
inmost, the core of the individual,” the “main factor in human progress,” and
the “genesis” of the “metaphysical, religious, and artistic” elements in human
life.43
Ultimately, in fact, the sex reformers held that sexuality was the highest
expression of the deeper “affirmation of life” itself (Lebensbejahung) – a central concept in their thinking. It was the creative force, the essence of creativity, of “the eternal becoming, the creative and industrious force everywhere
in nature.”44 This idea had been formulated at the turn of the century by
Wilhelm Bölsche, an influential popularizer of Darwinism whose three-volume
study, Love-Life in Nature (1898–1901), had a major influence on the sexreform program. Bölsche detected in nature an “eternal law of love” driving
the evolution of ever greater complexity, sophistication, beauty, and harmony.
For Bölsche, sex was everywhere, a universal, joyful, benevolent fecundity at
the heart of nature, of being; in short, “everything is love.”45 The sex reformers

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

were usually less ecstatic in their appreciation of sex than this; but the influence
of this notion was clear in their discourse. And it was central to their rejection
of what they saw as the ascetic negativity of Christianity – what Helene Stöcker
called its “denial of life.”46
Not surprisingly, the sex reformers were convinced both of the impracticability and of the undesirability of sexual abstinence for unmarried people –
both men and women. As Adele Schreiber wrote in 1907, “all those . . . who
think it is enough simply to assert the commandment of self-discipline have not
recognized . . . the elemental power of instinctive and emotional life in its thousand variations”; in 1912 she would assert bluntly that “prohibition and judgment, moralizing and preachments have no effect.”47 In fact, the sex reformers
believed that the moral crisis of their times was a product precisely of the
unrealistic and harmful moral code to which Christians adhered, and the institutional and legal forms founded on it. Prostitution, venereal disease, sexual
crimes, pornography, and widespread immorality in all its many forms was
for them evidence not of a falling away from right thinking and discipline but
rather precisely of the influence of those teachings in frustrating and diverting
normal, healthy, irrepressible sexual energies.
Men in the sex-reform movement in particular argued, for example, that
the restrictive moral code compromised sexual and mental health – that abstinence caused “anemic passivity and tired decadence in male youth” and “hysteria” in women (according to Kurt Hiller), “impairment of mental capacity, even . . . real maladies in both men and women” (in Max Flesch’s view),
“neurasthenia,” lowered resistance to “infectious diseases like tuberculosis and
typhus,” or even “outright insanity” (as the Dutch birth control and eugenics
advocate Johannes Rutgers claimed).48 Less dramatically, Leopold von Wiese
asserted that it made “morose out of laughing people, ugly out of beautiful,
cowards out of brave men,” and society as a whole “falls into ever greater boredom, dullness, and lack of inspiration.”49 And restrictive sexual mores were at
the root of the prevailing sexual disorder. Bruno Meyer, for example, held that
“wherever the natural satisfaction of a powerful instinct is forcefully hindered,
surrogates are sought and found.”50 Iwan Bloch blamed Christian prudery for
having “fed the lusts of the flesh in the first place,” arguing that “the real league
against immorality is the league against prudery.”51 Walther Borgius believed
