201

that “the abuse of children is merely a . . . sad surrogate for the satisfaction of an
exuberant sex drive, in the satisfaction of which the guilty party has been frustrated by our sexual morality and our economic conditions.”52 Rutgers even
believed that sexual self-denial explained child sexual abuse by priests and
teachers, regarding abstinence therefore as “an outright menace to society.”53
Women shared such views at least in some degree. Helene Stöcker, for example, baldly asserted in 1908 that one of the “fateful consequences” of Christian
morality had been “depraved debauchery as a reaction against the unnatural
shackling of the sex drive.”54 Adele Schreiber believed that even if abstinence
did not cause physical infirmities, the repression of “the strongest craving of
nature” required an immense “expenditure of emotional and physical energy,
thought and joie de vivre” and could “turn an industrious and happy person
into one tired of living, a titan into a limp, ill-humored shadow, a bright and
sunny nature into a moody, morose” one. Ellen Key, too, deplored the waste of
“all the energy that is lost to every nation because the majority have to fritter
it away day by day and year by year in dull endurance of the inhibition of their
erotic life, or in secret struggle against it.”55
More broadly, however, the sex reformers argued specifically that the central institution of the Christian sexual and social order, monogamous marriage, was at the root of the sexual misery surrounding them. The rigid form
of marriage, imposed by civil law, social convention, and poor access to contraception, made it impossible for a very large proportion of adult, sexually
mature men and women to marry. Given the long period of education and
training and apprenticeship through which many had to pass to gain entry, for
example, into the professions, the civil service, or the skilled trades, workingclass men typically married sometime in their mid-twenties, and middle-class
men between their late twenties and middle thirties. As a result, a remarkable
proportion of young adults were not married: as early pamphlets circulated by
the BfM in 1905 pointed out, more than three-quarters of men aged eighteen to
thirty were single, as were almost half of men aged eighteen to forty, four-fifths
of women aged eighteen to twenty-five, and more than a third of women aged
eighteen to forty.56 It was hardly surprising, therefore, that so many people
sought sexual gratification outside of marriage. As Walther Borgius put it in

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

1905, the “prevailing form of marriage . . . is not even remotely able any more
to encompass the whole of sexual life” in German society.57 The assumption
that women would and should be married helped keep their wages low, which
in turn drove many working-class women into prostitution. Single motherhood
plunged women and their children into poverty – and often, again, into prostitution. Moral prejudice and legal discrimination made illegitimate children
particularly vulnerable – as Frida Stéenhof put it, the institution of “marriage
harbors a . . . grave danger for the child: it risks being born illegitimate.”58
In the eyes of the sex reformers, therefore, prostitution was the necessary and
unavoidable complement of the legal institution of marriage; the two together
constituted the de facto sexual order of society. Prostitution existed not in spite
of marriage but “alongside it, with it, as its terrible complement.” It was in fact
the “frightful flip-side of our patriarchal marriage” (in the words of Helene
Stöcker).59
Even within marriage, moreover, many sex reformers – like Social Democrats
and the radical faction in the women’s movement – believed that the financial dependency of women often made the wife’s role not essentially different
from prostitution. The chairman of the BfM’s Breslau chapter, Max Rosenthal,
remarked, for example, that “a woman who sells herself to a rich man without
loving him is trafficking in her flesh just as much as a whore is.”60 Henriette
Fürth argued in 1911 that often the only difference between marriage and prostitution was that one was “sale for life, the other sale for an hour.”61 Bruno
Meyer deplored the fact that men’s financial and legal power forced women to
tolerate their husbands’ sexual whims, turning marriage into a “free haven for
lewdness!”62
Even if marriage were not motivated by base material considerations, moreover, many sex reformers rejected the patriarchal family as undesirable, indeed
corrupting, by its very nature. For example, Anita Augspurg published an
open letter in Die Frauenbewegung in 1905 that characterized marriage as,
for a woman, the “renunciation of her legal existence . . . , complete pecuniary
dependence and . . . complete abrogation of rights over her children”; “for a
woman with self-respect,” she concluded, “it is in my opinion impossible to
contract a legitimate marriage.”63 Henriette Fürth referred to bourgeois marriage simply as “life-long galley slavery,” and Ruth Bré held that marriage
under existing law turned women’s sexuality into the “obligatory tribute of a

captive.”64 The inevitable moral effect on women of living in such an institution was, of course, disastrous. Hedwig Dohm, writing in 1911, believed
that “the complete power of the husband” under existing family law “ruins
the character of both sexes,” because power “brutalizes . . . his instincts, stifles
justice and self-knowledge in him” and forces wives to use the “weapons of the
oppressed: cunning, lies, hypocrisy.”65 And the BfM as a whole, at its 1909
congress, adopted the principle that “marriage is” – that is, should be – “a voluntary union of independent and equal individuals. Any subjection in principle
of one party under the other . . . is contrary to its moral essence.”66 The clear
implication was that marriage, as codified in German family law, was immoral.
In short, as Bruno Meyer wrote in 1905, Christian morality “has become a
cause of immorality through and through”; and in the following year Helene
Stöcker denounced the “whole grotesque cruelty” and the “giant bankruptcy”
of conservative Christian morality.67
The sex reformers took a somewhat ambivalent position with regard to mass
culture. On the one hand, they too saw suggestive and indecent entertainments
as morally deplorable. On the other, they also believed that the popular taste
for smut was a product of the denial and repression of sexuality. It might be
distasteful, therefore; but it was not threatening. It was, so to speak, a toxic
byproduct of the pathological workings of Christian morality and the patriarchal, repressive moral and social order, rather than itself a moral toxin. And
repression might merely make the problem worse – it might create “much more
harmful and dangerous diversions” of “excess energies of sexual origin,” as
Bloch put it.68 Bruno Meyer even held that pornography, as a relatively harmless diversion of repressed sexual energies, was “almost to be welcomed.”69
More important, a commitment to the sanctity of individual rights was
absolutely central to sex-reform thought. “We live,” as Johannes Rutgers put
it in Die Neue Generation in 1908, “precisely in an age . . . , in which the
right of the individual to be an autonomous personality is winning ever greater
acceptance.” Henriette Fürth, similarly (and in the same year) believed that
the “individualizing tendency . . . has given our time its stamp.” And Helene
Stöcker regarded Christian asceticism as an offense against the “natural right
of every adult person to healthy exercise of all his energies and functions.”70
Censorship, obviously, was not compatible with this position.

204

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

This commitment to individual rights was part of a broader commitment
to the superiority of a democratic social and political order – one that was
articulated with growing clarity in the last years before World War I. In 1908
Helene Stöcker, for example, denounced the patriarchal familial social “order”
as “nothing but an act of violence by the dominant and owning classes and sex
against those who own nothing and are dominated.”71 In 1911, in an essay
decrying the proposed criminalization of lesbian sex, she observed that “in the
realm of sexual morality backward absolutism and intolerance still rule . . . we
cannot speak of a free political life . . . until we have achieved alongside legal
and social freedom [and] freedom of religion also the freedom of the individual in her most private of private life, in love-life.”72 In 1912 Frida Stéenhof
deplored the fact that, under current law, marriage was a “property-law relationship, where the man and father is the owner.” The current sexual order
was incompatible with “genuine justice and democratic freedom,” she held; the
“current barbarity of sexual life” must give way to a “democratic social order.”
Democracy was “the highest goal and aim of the times”; current family law
was a relic of “patriarchal and aristocratic ages of civilization,” contrary to the
“principle of moral freedom” and to the “constitutive principles” of the new
social order, “individuality and solidarity.”73 In an essay of 1914 on “Love
and Suffrage,” Gabriele Reuter suggested that at best the old form of (marital)
love was comparable to “the love of a ruler for his people – the king for his
subjects.” In contrast, the “true, highest, real love” would be selfless; it would
be achieved only through a “struggle up from darkness to the . . . highest light”;
and “we women see in the achievement of suffrage a stage in this struggle.”74
But already at its 1909 general conference, the BfM as a whole adopted – as
one of five suggested reforms that would help to eliminate prostitution – the
broader “transformation of our police state into a state of free citizens.”75
Obviously, there was an explicitly anticapitalist as well as antiauthoritarian
slant to this analysis. Most of the sex reformers regarded the existing sexual
order as a product of and natural complement to capitalism – and capitalism,
therefore, as the ultimate source of sexual disorder. Grete Meisel-Hess explicitly
argued, for example, that women would be liberated only with the “liberation
of economic values from capitalism.” Henriette Fürth observed that the existing
marital order rested on a “foundation of property law” that was no longer valid
for the great majority of the population.76 Iwan Bloch was particularly explicit,
writing in 1907 that “free love is simply love liberated from the dominance

of the state and capital. It is therefore realizable only through an economic
transformation that will end the economic struggle for existence. . . . Economic
reform is the only way to a higher love.”77
This is not to say that all the sex reformers were Social Democrats; nationalist
liberals played a secondary but nevertheless significant role in the movement. A
particularly important example was Maria Lischnewska, who paired the antiCatholicism common in the movement with a more unusual antisocialism, class
bias, and ethnic-national chauvinism. And yet, her argument was precisely that
a “decisive energetic nationalism” would welcome the political participation of
women, “one half of the nation,” and would resurrect “the ancient Germanic
ideal of comradeship between the sexes” as a logical consequence of the political imperatives of the modern age, in which the state “depends . . . on the
participation, devotion, and sacrifice of every citizen.” Lischnewska’s chauvinism, in other words, was the chauvinism of liberal nationalists, not of authoritarians.78
It should be obvious that the sex reformers’ understanding of the connection between authoritarian politics and repressive sexuality – and between sex
reform and democracy – was actually rather similar to the political theory of
conservative Christians. The latter argued that the repression of sexual drives
was the necessary foundation for the ability to be obedient to one’s social
betters and political rulers, and hence the foundation of the existing political
order; and they feared that sexual disorder would feed the democratic spirit,
and specifically the Social Democratic revolution. The sex reformers made precisely the same argument – but, obviously, they regarded the collapse of the
authoritarian familial and political order and the creation of a new, democratic
one as a desirable outcome.
III. Freedom and Responsibility: The Positive Program of Sex Reform
The sex reformers regarded equality of the sexes within marriage and above
all the financial and social independence of women as one of the most important preconditions for this transformation. Helene Stöcker was particularly
eloquent on this point. Already in the 1890s, she had argued that “pecuniary
independence” was “the first precondition for every kind of freedom,” and
that without such independence love could never be pure – women could not
choose freely, according to the commands of their hearts, and men would not
be forced to treat them with respect.79 Only the “economic and intellectual
liberation of woman,” she wrote in 1904, “can make sexual relations between
77

Bloch, Das Sexualleben, p. 278.
Maria Lischnewska, Warum muss die Frau Politik treiben? (Munich: Nationalverein, 1910),
pp. 18, 22, 39, 1.
79 Helene Stöcker, “Die moderne Frau” (1893) and “Die Selbstbestimmung des Weibes” (n.d.),
in Helene Stöcker, Die Liebe und die Frauen, second edition (Minden: J. C. C. Bruns, 1908),
pp. 20, 63.
78

206

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

men and women more worthy and more beneficial to society.”80 But others
in the BfM were no less explicit regarding this issue. The consensus was, as
one author summed it up in Die Neue Generation in 1909, that “the economic
independence of woman is the primary requirement for a healthy sexual life.”81
The BfM’s second general conference in 1909 adopted this position explicitly –
that “the foundation of all personal autonomy is economic independence,”
which therefore “has to be demanded for woman as well” if sexual relations
were to be purified.82
In this, of course, the demands of the sex reformers coincided quite closely
with those of the abolitionists and the mainstream feminist movement as a
whole. In fact, the BfM supported a panoply of reforms advocated in this same
period by the mainstream BDF (and sometimes even by more conservative
women): a special maternity insurance system (Mutterschaftsversicherung) for
new mothers, liberalization of marriage and divorce law, legal equality within
marriage, coeducation, equal access to higher education and to all professions,
reform of illegitimacy law, the expansion of the public child welfare system,
and so on.
What distinguished the sex reformers from the mainstream or moderate
feminists (as well as from conservative Christian moralists) was their understanding particularly of the nature of women’s sexuality. Whereas both the
secular feminist mainstream and conservative Christians held that men must
be educated up to the level of women’s morality, the sex reformers denied that
there was any difference between men’s and women’s sex drives.
Johanna Elberskirchen stated this view with unusual force in an essay on
“Sexual Feeling in Woman and Man” (1903). The sex drive in men and women
derived, she argued, from precisely the same physiological source, and both
“hungered” for sex equally. This sexual drive was not in itself evil or destructive; what explained the sexual and social misery of the day was the fact that
men had used their social and financial power to reduce women to a state
of “sexual slavery” and to establish themselves as “for the woman, in the
realm of sex, the capitalist,” the exploiter. As a result, “the sexual needs of the
man exceeded the physiologically necessary,” whereas those of some women –
those who were not, as prostitutes, required to service this “pathological, hysterical . . . sexual feeling in men” – were repressed. The solution was to return
both sexes to a normal or “physiological” level of sexual activity.83
Elberskirchen’s argument was particularly explicit but in its essentials typical. Ida Boy-Ed, a prolific author of women’s novels, for example, demanded

the development of a healthy and natural understanding of female sexuality and suggested that child rearing, instruction, and literature should abandon prurience and repressive silence and “awaken in woman the courage to
be sensual!”84 Henriette Fürth too believed that women must demand their
“right” to be sexual creatures, while also braking men’s “hypertrophied sexuality” and returning men to a “healthy” degree of sexuality “that is in accord
with the aims of nature.”85 Stöcker even argued that women were more sexual
than men – that woman was “in fact born to love with all the fibers of her
being, with mind, heart and senses – with all her nerves – for she is in the
noblest sense . . . much more sexually needy than the man.”86 Ellen Key, too,
believed that “the sexual life of woman – if it has remained strong and healthy –
governs her . . . much more profoundly than it does the man.”87
Not surprisingly, therefore, the sex reformers contested men’s authority to
define sexuality and policy toward it. Like homosexual men, they rejected the
authority of one sexual population in matters pertaining to the feelings of
another. Already in the 1890s, Gisela von Streitberg (a pseudonym for the
radical Countess Bülow von Dennewitz) had argued that women should rely
on observation of “her own nature” rather than the “productions of belletristic
literature, or all the physiological, gynecological, ethnological, anthropological,
philosophical and social writings, which are authored mostly by and for men
and read by them.”88 In 1896 Johanna Elberskirchen delivered an impassioned
defense of the legitimacy of her own viewpoint, telling her male readers that
“your morality is not my morality. . . . I do not belong to the so-called objective
[ones]. In the final analysis objectivity has to admit everything, even vermin,
even swine, even – your morality . . . ! But not subjectivity – not I!”89 Again,
these views were particularly explicit, but not unusual. Stöcker summed up
the point in 1903, asserting simply that whatever male doctors might say,
“regarding what women feel, women will presumably best be able to judge for
themselves.”90
Whereas abolitionists and conservative Christians demanded that both
women and men practice self-restraint and self-denial, then, and whereas the
champions of regulated prostitution essentially defended sexual libertinism
for men only, the sex reformers championed instead the New Ethic of sexual liberation and sexual responsibility – a new regime of sexual freedom
for all.

208

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

The sex reformers did not reject the ideal of monogamy as such; in fact they
repeatedly insisted that they regarded it as the highest and most desirable form
of relationship between a man and a woman. Helene Stöcker even insisted that
the “Holy Trinity of father, mother and children will always remain the highest
ideal,” whereas Iwan Bloch explained that the sex-reform movement favored
not “free sex” but “free love” – which, of course, would create its own bonds
of commitment and responsibility.91 At its conference in 1909, the BfM as a
whole adopted a similar statement, holding that “the ideal for marriage is a
physical and spiritual communion between husband and wife that is intended to
be permanent” – particularly because “the family founded on moral marriage,
the home and the intimately shared life of parents and children offers the best
conditions for the spiritual development of children.”92
As a matter of simple social reality, however, the BfM’s 1909 statement of
principles also argued that “in addition to this ideal, and in light of economic
conditions, other forms of sexual relationship should also be recognized as
morally justified . . . , on the condition that they are founded on spiritual communion of two people and fulfill [the parents’] duties toward [their] children.”93
A very large proportion of the sexually mature population was not married,
largely for various financial reasons; and most members of the BfM assumed –
as did, for example, doctors in the DGBG – that it was unrealistic to expect
them to remain celibate. As Max Flesch had argued in the fourth pamphlet
published by the BfM, it was an irreducible fact of life that “by far the majority
of men participate in extramarital sexual intercourse at least for a part of their
lives,” and that “furthermore very many women – aside from prostitution –
also practice extramarital sexual intercourse.”94
The sex-reform position was not merely that extramarital sexual relationships were unavoidable, however; many sex reformers also argued that they
were, in some senses, desirable. At the very least, some believed that greater
acceptance of nonmarital sexual relationships would form a more moral
(and healthy) alternative to prostitution. Helene Stöcker, for example, held
in 1905 that informal sexual relationships “would be a lesser evil than the
commercial sex that today poisons our entire sexual life.”95 Bré concurred:
“Free marriage according to matriarchal law,” she believed, would “drive
the prostitute from the field.”96 And in any case, as Stöcker remarked in
1905, a sexual relationship that grew out of friendship and was based on
“mutual respect,” “reverence,” and “equality” was superior to “the current

209

exploitative condition” in marriage; indeed “anything else would be better
than the current brutal power relations.”97
More positively, then, the sex reformers’ position was that the older, formalistic conception of sexual morality must give way to the “moral judgment
of sexual life according to its spiritual content,” as Heinrich Meyer-Benfey put
it.98 The BfM guidelines of 1910 declared that the organizations’ efforts were
“directed toward internalization of the concept of morality, to make it dependent not on a mere formality, but on the consciousness of responsibility and
on actual fulfillment of one’s duties.”99
In fact, the sex reformers universally assumed that real sexual morality
would only blossom on the basis of sexual freedom. Thus, Ernst Baars suggested that sex reformers “want freedom, because greater freedom raises the
consciousness of duty and the sense of responsibility.”100 Adele Schreiber hoped
that “the end of compulsory marriage will be the beginning of a new, higher,
more moral communion between man and woman.”101 Iwan Bloch, too,
believed that a new, less restrictive structure of sexual relations would result
in a lower rate of divorce, because “freedom is the source of constancy.”102 In
Ellen Key’s formulation, “the energies liberated by freedom themselves work
against the dangerous consequences of freedom!”103
The sex reformers differed regarding the precise nature of the legal and institutional reforms that might create the new sexual order. In some few cases, in
fact, they delivered what more conservative contemporaries would have considered outright paeans to sexual disorder. Henriette Fürth is a particularly
striking instance. In 1903 she had already gone so far as to celebrate the “small
community of strong, self-confident individuals,” the “path-breakers of a new
moral law” who, rejecting the moral authority of priests and bureaucrats,
embraced “responsible affirmation of life with all of its consequences.” Sexual
life, she argued, was “holy ground, on which every one has to come to terms
with himself,” and “neither society nor the law can intervene with their clumsy
hand.” By 1908 she argued that sex was every individual’s “private affair” and
neither state nor society could stand in judgment over it – even if that meant tolerating serial monogamy or polygamy.104 Her assumption was simple: because
sexuality was inseparable from selfhood, any expression of authentic desire

was morally legitimate. Others clearly shared this perspective. Ruth Bré, for
example, suggested that “monogamous free marriage” might not necessarily
last a lifetime; in fact, it might survive only “a couple of years, perhaps a couple
months – or weeks. For some women perhaps only one night.”105 Iwan Bloch,
writing in 1907, argued that the “immensely varied mental differentiation of
modern civilized man” justified not only serial monogamy but in fact “simultaneous double love,” because one person might have erotic needs and desires
that could only be satisfied by two other people.106 Adele Schreiber held, in
1912, that given the “heterogeneity of human beings,” it was obvious that
“no degree of latitude can be big enough, with respect to love and marriage,
to do justice to the individual’s peculiarities”; the “straight-jacket of ‘one true
morality’” of any kind was therefore unacceptable.107 Helene Stöcker summed
it up in 1904: the ideal society needed moral “room for a thousand different
kinds of love.”108
About one form of sexual desire – homosexuality – the sex reformers were
strikingly reticent. The issue barely registered at all in the internal discussions
within the BfM at any time; and the organization’s journal did not publish
any substantial discussion of homosexuality until the summer of 1908, when
Stöcker finally presented her perspective on the scandal trials rocking the homosexual rights movement. Thereafter, the journal once again fell more or less
silent on the issue, until the discussion of the attempt to extend §175 to women
in 1911. And there was a certain ambivalence even to what was said within
the BfM regarding the moral status of homosexuality. The rhetorical core of
Stöcker’s first essay on the topic in 1908, for example, was that homosexual
“seduction” did far less damage to individual and society than did men’s heterosexual predations; thus the “moral outrage’” of homophobes was simply
hypocritical.109 In the same year, Die Neue Generation carried a strikingly
homophobic article by Bruno Meyer, who asserted that homosexuality was the
product of either celibacy or sexual excess.110 Even as late as 1914, Stöcker
remarked somewhat ambiguously that “aesthetic aversion” should never “go
so far as to make us treat those who think and feel differently with cruelty and
injustice.” But she also hoped that Freudian theory would yield therapies that
would enable doctors to “lead them back in many cases to a normal mode of
feeling.”111

Still, Stöcker at least was quite vehement in her rejection of §175, which
she called an example of “the darkest Middle Ages” in sexual ethics and
an “artifact from the times of darkest absolutism, the most foolish police
power . . . crudeness and barbarism” comparable to “cannibalism and witchburning.”112 In 1911 she even looked forward to the day when such interference
in people’s private lives would be regarded as “‘perverse.’”113 And although the
sex reformers were almost completely silent regarding female homosexuality,
there was at least one member of the BfM, Johanna Elberskirchen, who was
one of the only openly homosexual women in German public life. In 1904 she
had responded to accusations that leading members of the women’s movement
were lesbians by remarking that “we have good reason to be.”114 Elberskirchen
kept a low profile in the BfM and beyond this one essay does not appear to
have made an issue of her sexual orientation; and the BfM generally acted,
effectively, as if lesbianism were a nonissue. But in some cases the sex reformers offered explicit justifications of lesbian relationships. Stöcker herself, for
example, held that “tender friendship with women” was often a surrogate for
a relationship with a man, particularly among female civil servants who had
to remain both unmarried and childless to keep their jobs.115 Käthe Schirmacher too argued that sexual relationships between women had to be judged
tolerantly, given that women’s opportunities for sexual gratification were so
constrained.116 Cautiously, perhaps even reluctantly, but nevertheless clearly,
the sex reformers applied their radical moral individualism even to this most
taboo of sexual topics.
What precisely this radically nominalist and individualist position implied
in legal terms was not entirely clear; but it was universally agreed that, as Grete
Meisel-Hess put it in 1909, existing marriage law “assumes the miraculous as
a universal human destiny” and was therefore nonviable.117 Some suggested
instead the introduction of some form of temporary marriage particularly for
young people. Others advocated replacing existing marriage law with a regime
of individual contracts. The official position of the BfM was less clear. The
first general assembly of the BfM passed a resolution that merely demanded
“completely equal rights for man and woman” within marriage; the “legal
recognition of free marriage”; legal equality for illegitimate children; and the

expansion of child welfare services.118 In 1909, the organization’s second conference laid out the basic principles of equality, financial independence, mutual
exclusivity, and shared responsibility that would characterize a truly moral
marriage law.119 Max Rosenthal’s guidelines for the organization, accepted by
its governing board in 1910, called for the “moral and legal recognition of any
relationship characterized by consciousness of responsibility for the duties arising from it and the will to fulfill them as in truth ‘marital’ – even in cases where
the legal formalities are not observed.”120 Beyond that, the sex reformers seldom made specific practical demands; for of course the logic of their position
regarding the benefits of individual freedom was, as Heinrich Meyer-Benfey
put it in 1908, that “a morally healthy humanity, developing in freedom, will
always create for itself the forms it needs.”121
The sex reformers did not reject all order, nor even all legal order in sexual
matters. They did reject any binding, universal morality based on revelation,
on Christian tradition. But they were fully committed to natural science as
the source of authority in moral matters, and as their guide in constructing
a new set of social and personal relationships between men and women; and
they sometimes drew quite sweeping conclusions from that commitment. As
Ellen Key held in 1905, what was above all necessary was to “bring legal
concepts into harmony with well-researched nature”; or, as Lischnewska put
it in 1907, “only that which is in accordance with the laws of nature can be
moral.”122 But the sex reformers did not conceive of the bonds of natural law
as onerous, because their view was that anything natural was healthy – as
Bré put it, “natural” sexual desire must necessarily be “good,” because “in
nature everything is moral. Her intentions are always pure.”123 And again,
most sex reformers assumed that only the individual could know what was
natural for him or her. What was more, the program of creating a scientific or
natural morality necessarily implied creating a morality that was in constant
flux, one that could probably never be codified. For as good Darwinists, the sex
reformers believed that nature itself was always evolving, and science always
advancing. Accordingly, insistence on the idea of the historicity of all morality
was universal among the sex reformers.
The problem of Christian morality was precisely that it was outdated –
the product of “an age of civilization,” as Stöcker put it, “that has otherwise
been overcome,” a living cultural fossil.124 Walther Borgius, similarly, argued
that “the inherited clerical-ascetic moral teaching” was incompatible with the

“modern conception of life resting on scientific-sociological foundations” and
must be discarded.125 But the deeper point was that any moral code was necessarily historical and would in the fullness of time become outdated. Henriette
Fürth made this implication explicit in an essay of 1905, arguing that any
moral concepts were “only pertinent and justified under particular conditions
and for a particular age.”126 There was, then, as Hedwig Dohm put it, “always
only a moral du jour.”127 This perspective was enshrined in the BfM’s guidelines of 1910, which asserted that “morality too is subject to the condition of
progressive evolution.”128
The extraordinary optimism at the root of this evolutionary view of moral
development is self-evident. Whereas Christians regarded the apparent wave of
immorality of their times as part of a more general falling away from Christianity, many sex reformers viewed the whole discussion of sexuality and morality
as an inspiring development – evidence of the moral evolution of mankind in
their own times. Maria Lischnewska, for example, argued in 1905 that, until
the present, society had merely “forcibly and carefully covered up” its dark
side; but “our whole modern life is characterized – and this is one of its best
aspects – by openness.” The “swamp” of immorality had now been uncovered and could now be drained; and so “a new age has begun.”129 Helene
Stöcker, writing in the same year, held that “we live in an age of hope” comparable to the age of the Reformation, an age of liberation in which the dead
weight of the past was being replaced by “warm authentic life.”130 Iwan Bloch
even held that “there has never been an age that thought more purely and more
healthily than ours with respect to moral impulses,” and that the growth of
scientific knowledge of sexuality would allow the creation of “more natural,
free, noble conditions.”131
Many of the sex reformers, particularly socialists, believed that there was
very specific, concrete evidence in favor of this optimism. For they believed that
the proletariat was already on its way to creating a more rational, flexible, and
natural sexual ethic, in which premarital sexual relationships were common,
single mothers were not stigmatized, there was an implicit understanding that
unmarried fathers must help to provide for their illegitimate children, and
women were moving toward economic independence. As Bloch put it (citing
Alfred Blaschko), “in the proletariat the ideal of free love has long since been

realized,” particularly among people aged eighteen to twenty-five.132 Grete
Meisel-Hess, too, believed that the working class “has long since accepted
concubinage (which in nine out of ten cases leads to marriage) as a fully
adequate substitute for marriage, and makes use of prostitution in far lesser
degree.” This pattern was, she held, a “transitional arrangement” on the way
to a “new sexual order.”133
And yet, class was obviously not the central term in the sex-reform discourse;
and the optimism at the heart of sex-reform thought was not optimism about
the evolution of the mode of production. Instead, at the heart of the sex-reform
program there was a celebration and veneration of biology that verged on
the religious – and that in fact was conceived of by many sex reformers, with
increasing frequency after about 1908, literally as a new religion. And although
they were convinced that time was on their side, they were also becoming less
willing simply to wait for evolution to take its course; it was time, they argued,
for humanity to take its own biological development into its own hands. As
Max Rosenthal put it in 1911, “humanity wants to be not only an object, but
also a subject of natural evolution.”134 In the last years before World War I,
in short, sex reform was increasingly understood to be a eugenic program, and
indeed a eugenic religion.
Chapter 10 turns to this development.

Religion of Love

I. Prophet: Ellen Key
The single most influential intellectual figure in German sex reform was Ellen
Key, a Swedish philosopher and feminist who, in a series of major publications
after 1900, elaborated a quasi-religious sexual-ethical creed, which she variously called “evolutionism,” the “religion of life,” or the “happiness-teaching”
(Glückslehre). Key had close intellectual ties to Germany; she appeared there
often in her capacity as a public speaker (for example, at the first public meeting
of the BfM); her works were translated almost immediately into German; and
they were of fundamental importance in shaping the basic terms and assumptions of the German sex reformers’ view of the world.
All life, Key held, was subject to a ceaseless process of change and upward
development, driven by the will to live, by Nietzsche’s “will to power.”1 This
evolutionary process was in fact the aim of life, the deeper purpose of life:
“Life itself,” as she put it, was “the meaning of life.”2 Key meant this in literal,
biological terms: the purpose of life was the evolution of life. This should
therefore be the aim of human society as well – “to improve and ennoble the
material of humanity.”3 What made people thrive, what made them vital and
strong, was morally good. And because happiness was simply the experience of
optimal conditions for life, it was both the measure and the product of morality;
in Spinoza’s formulation, “joy is perfection.”4 The individual’s desire to thrive
and be happy in this sense, which conservative Christians condemned as animal
egotism and as the sign and substance of man’s sinful will, was for Key the
1

Ellen Key, Der Lebensglaube: Betrachtungen über Gott, Welt, und Seele (Berlin: Fischer, 1906),
pp. 98, 26.
2 Ellen Key, Über Liebe und Ehe (Berlin: S. Fischer, 1911), p. 181.
3 Key, Über Liebe und Ehe, pp. 54, 55.
4 Spinoza, quoted in ibid., p. 59.

215

216

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

primary source of the increasing perfection of the species, hence the essence
of mankind’s capacity for goodness, as she defined it. “Self-preservation,” she
held, was “an expression of the divine power at work in everything,” which
was driving all life toward greater perfection, toward divinity. “Growth” was
“only another word for self-preservation, which is itself only a deeper word
for freedom.” Thus, there was in truth “no other freedom than the necessity of
following our own nature.”5
What the body desired, then, was morally right, because it was biologically
beneficial. Obviously, this new creed “sees in the sensual and the spiritual the
two forms of the Divine,” and in it body and spirit would be reconciled.6
So too would the individual and society; for the “conditions for our own
self-preservation” included the well-being of others and the preservation of
harmonious relations with them. As she put it, “nothing is more useful to
man than man”; those ideas and actions that fostered the health, freedom, and
vitality of all people were also most in the self-interest of the individual.7
Thus, for Key, “morality arises . . . from the conditions of life imposed by
our nature.”8 The marvelous logic of humanity’s situation was that morally
good intentions are effortlessly achieved. In fact, Key explicitly argued that
happiness – achieved through “intensification of life” – is “the only duty for
those who see life as the purpose of life.”9 In Key’s eyes, Christianity was a
source of suffering and immorality precisely because it regarded the achievement of moral goodness as the product of a bitter struggle to control one’s egotistical urges – a struggle of duty against desire. This was, of course, hopelessly
unrealistic: human beings, as living things, would naturally seek the pleasure
that derives from the enhancement of life. As Key put it, “only when moral law
has become natural is its dominion ensured.”10 Only then would people truly
be forced – through “congruity [Übereinstimmung] with themselves” – to be
free, to be moral.11
For Key, sexuality, as the origin of life, was therefore also the source of the
sacred. It was the motor of evolution; its purpose was the purpose of life itself –
to create more life; it was the fundamental life force, the generative, creative
force, “the nourishing and fruitful soil” from which everything else grew. Every
form of “endeavor for the common good” and creativity “draws upon and uses
the erotic energies in transposed form”; and therefore “everything is connected
to sexual love, the deepest foundation of life. . . . It stands in deep reciprocal
relationship with art . . . , with literature, with the law, work, religion” and
was “the instinct by which humanity is ever increasingly bound together and

217

ennobled.”12 Key’s goal, therefore, was to make love “what it once was, when
the peoples still stood reverently before life: a religion.”13 “Fertility, the power
of conception in all its forms,” she remarked, was “the divine in man. . . . The
altars that were erected in the past to the gods of fertility must be built up
again.”14
Concretely, Key argued that the emotion of love served a direct biological
purpose, because love between parents was the best guarantee of adequate care
for children.15 But the emotion of authentic love was also an expression of the
will of nature for the reproductive pairing of two people, for the purpose of
breeding better humans – it was a product of that same “mysterious longing for
perfection itself, which in the course of evolution has raised instinct to passion,
and passion to love.”16 It was for this reason, for example, that opposites
attract – to create more balanced, more harmonious, more highly evolved
offspring. Love was “that form of selection that most improves the species.”17
Hence, “the more perfect humanity will be, in the fullest sense of the word,
loved forth.”18
The crucial moral imperative with respect to sexuality, therefore, was that
marriage and reproduction be made contingent on love, on mutual desire. The
“unity of love” must be the “guiding moral principle” in sexual matters – the
principle that all, and only, “those who love each other are man and wife.”19
The central practical task of the hour, then, was clear: “Society must make
it possible for the erotic happiness of the individual to serve the improvement
of the species.”20 But there was really no difficulty here at all, because love –
“the erotic happiness of the individual” – was a tool of evolution.21 Society
merely had to step out of the way of the achievement of happiness through
love. The problem of sexual morality was essentially a nonproblem.22 And this
nonproblem, in Key’s view, was the key to human existence – it was “the vital
question, the question of the happiness of society, in comparison with which
all others appear insignificant,” because it was the key to the “elevation of the
human species.”23
Before this simple, transcendental calculus of happiness could operate unimpeded, humanity had to be liberated from the bonds of the “old morality,”

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

of Christianity and the institutional forms it had created. In locating the
“foundation of sexual morality in a transcendent reality,” Christianity denied
the true purpose of sexuality – life, here on earth. As a consequence, as a
purely practical matter it was a failure from day one; it had merely created the
hypocrisy, misery, and illness that characterized sexual life.24
The task of the moment, therefore, was to invent, in concrete institutional
and social terms, a practical “erotic monism” – a morality that coupled desire
with love. This would be achieved not by establishing a new set of moral or
legal rules and commandments but by creating greater freedom and flexibility.
Freedom would allow experimentation, so that new standards could grow
out of real needs – as Key put it, “evolutionism can regard only continual
experience as revelation.”25 But more fundamentally, no single moral standard
could ever be appropriate for all people, because part of the richness, vitality,
and creative potential of life was precisely that people were so very different
in their needs. Those who understood this knew “that humanity cannot be
homogenized by a single faith, a single morality, a single ideal, because they see
in the variety of life a great part of its value.”26 Because people were different,
“the concepts of good and evil must also be different for each individual.”27
Laws and norms appropriate for those who were naturally monogamous, for
example, must not be imposed on those who were by nature “many-loving.”28
The new morality demanded “the individual right to serve the commonweal
with his love according to his own choice, and to exercise the freedom of his
love under his own responsibility.”29
And yet, for Key, freedom was not an end in itself but merely a means to
the end of the improvement of the species. There was therefore an odd tension
running through her works between boundlessly optimistic erotic anarchism
on the one hand and a stern code of eugenic responsibility and discipline on
the other. Mankind had a moral duty to enter into a conscious “struggle to
consolidate its position as humanity and its elevation to super-humanity.”30
Where freedom served this purpose, it should be secured; but where it did
not, it must be constrained. The new religion of life must invent “forms that,
whether they increase or decrease freedom of action, encourage a use of erotic
energies that intensify life for the individual and for humanity.”31 Science
would discover natural “laws regarding the conditions for the improvement of
the race”; and those discoveries would yield both new moral imperatives and
“new legal norms.”32

What precisely these new norms might be was unclear; but hints were scattered throughout Key’s writings. In a collection of essays titled Über Liebe und
Ehe (On Love and Marriage, 1905), for example, she suggested on the one
hand a whole range of social reforms – public housing, equal property rights
for wives, liberalized divorce law, remuneration for women’s domestic work,
an eight-hour day and minimum wage laws, equal pay, and so on.33 On the
other hand, she also proposed a prohibition on marriage before the age of
twenty-one; mandatory classes for girls in hygiene, care for the ill, and child
development; and legal “limitation, not of the freedom to love, but certainly of
the freedom to beget children.” Key even suggested that parents had a moral
duty not only to have no more children than they could provide for and raise
well but also to have no fewer children than they could provide for, because
that would be “anti-social.”34 Similarly, in Der Lebensglaube (The Religion
of Life), published in German in 1906, she observed that vast sums of money,
immense productive energies, and even the “highest ideals of the nation” were
routinely sacrificed for the maintenance of great-power status and “economicterritorial expansion in the interest of a group of power-holders” and suggested
that “the state . . . itself could live with doubled intensity” if “the intensification
of the lives of its own society’s members were the aim of the reason of state.”
But she also remarked that it was probable that in the future “parenthood
will be legally forbidden to the degenerate,” and even that “it is possible that
in future society will in greater degree than at present extinguish lives that
can never be intensified – the lives of moral, intellectual and physical freaks
[Missgeburten].” Christianity, she admitted, had achieved something fine and
useful by expanding humanity’s capacity for empathy; but “not every life is
sacred. What is sacred is the upward evolution of life.”35 Even the religion of
life, it seems, might require human sacrifice.
Fundamentally, then, Key’s religion of love and life was a religion of reproduction and eugenic health. She stated the overall goal of this program in
astonishingly crass terms: “Ever more valuable human material, capable of
evolution – that’s what we must create above all.”36
In this religion, women had a special place, because they were – Key
thought – more important in and more concerned with the reproductive process than men. Because woman’s “whole being is eroticism,” women were by
nature closer to the God of Key’s religion. Their love was “purer,” “higher,”
“deeper,” and more “unshakeable” than that of men. In women, she felt,
“‘the milk of human kindness’ flows more richly than in most men.” They
were “less hindered by religious and social dogmas, but filled with greater
piety and deeper public spirit than are men.”37 In particular, “in motherhood,
33

Key, Über Liebe und Ehe, pp. 149, 302–303, 406–407, 41, 416, 420, 422, 425, 436–450.
Ibid., pp. 152, 162, 168–169, 407, 451, 219–220, 246–247.

37 Key, Über Liebe und Ehe, pp. 138, 198, 283, 288–289.

220

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

humanity has attained its most perfect form of life.”38 Motherhood was that
transcendental value that would replace, in the new age, the Christian concept
of salvation as the center of Western religious life. As she argued already in
Misused Woman-Power (Missbrauchte Frauenkraft), published in German in
1898, “when the power of motherhood appears on earth in its full glory, then
it . . . will give birth to the salvation of the world.”39
Key adopted a very ambivalent position with respect to the feminist movement of her own time, however. She supported virtually the entire range of
feminist demands for equal rights for women, because she believed that full
equality would better enable them to perform their essential function of motherhood, and because she believed that women’s motherliness was a necessary
corrective to the dominance of male values and characteristics in social and
political life.40 And yet fundamentally Key believed that woman’s proper function was to be an object of sexual desire for men, a bearer and educator of
children, the cultivator of feeling rather than reason, and a homemaker. She
stated this position vehemently in Misused Woman-Power, arguing that the
women’s movements’ focus (as she saw it) on developing masculine virtues in
women was a great mistake. It was silly for women to try to excel in “masculine fields of work” like science, industry, or politics, because the “true,
inmost nature of woman” made it impossible for her to match men in those
spheres. For the “true woman,” the “highest goal in life” was “motherhood
though love” and all the essentially emotional tasks she thought it entailed –
making a comfortable home, attention to domestic detail, and raising children to be decent, happy people and good, peace-loving patriots.41 Radical
feminism, then, was “hubris”; in it “the female sex sins against humanity.”42
Against this “old” feminism the champions of the religion of life now had to
struggle. Women must abandon the “man-hating” of early feminism and contribute to building “a society in which the well-being of the next generation is
the focal point”– and in which the members of each sex made that particular
contribution to it to which their nature suited them.43
II. Eugenics, Race, and Power
Few German sex reformers shared this contempt for the “old” feminism. In
some cases, in fact, they echoed rather precisely the views of moderates in
the women’s movement, even regarding sexuality, suggesting that the more

221

important priority was not sexual liberation but the sexual civilization specifically of men. Thus Grete Meisel-Hess wrote in 1909 that “the unwillingness
and incapacity for love of today’s men is the tragedy of today’s women.”44
Gabriele Reuter summed up the same position in the title of an article in the
BfM’s journal in 1910: “The Education of Man by Woman.”45 Others clearly
implied – as did the moderates – that men were not quite as sacred as women,
because their desires were by nature animalistic and brutal. A quite striking case
is that of Johanna Loewenherz, who in 1895 had asserted that the “principle of
preservation” was “embodied by woman,” whereas the “principle of destruction” was “embodied by man. Woman is affirmation, man denial of life.”46
Even Helene Stöcker, who believed that “the problem of love, of marriage, of
parenthood can only be solved by both sexes together,” sometimes fell into
these cadences. “The future must come from woman,” she wrote in 1897, a
future characterized by “harmony between the spiritual and the sensual nature
of mankind.”47 And in 1903 she even asked whether “that which constitutes
the inmost essence of woman – love, goodness, culture – will triumph, or at
least hold its own alongside that which characterizes man: violence.”48 These
women clearly agreed that motherhood was sacred – that, as Henriette Fürth
put it, motherhood was “the principle of eternity underlying all that is,” and
that “women have always been not only the element that preserves the species
but also the element that drives its development forward.”49 But the struggle for
gender equality was for them necessary to achieve that forward development,
to achieve the victory of love over violence. Stöcker, for example, explicitly
regarded Key’s “hatred” for women’s rights advocates as an “error.”50
And yet, most of the sex reformers were clearly adherents of something
very much like Key’s religion of love; and in consequence they also sometimes
distanced themselves from the “old” feminism. Stöcker is a striking case. She
too had written in the late 1890s of the “oddly one-sided . . . views” of feminists,
of their lack of “warm pulsing youthful blood,” and of their rush to embrace
“only that which has been denied them up to now: reason, knowledge” and to
abandon “communion with a man.”51 She consistently stressed that her goal

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

was to end the “separation and alienation between the sexes,” to “liberate
woman from her bitterness toward man, man from his disdain for woman,”
because “only man and woman together can make real the higher love of the
future that we long for.”52 Stöcker did warn that “we must not make a dogma
of the ‘profession of motherhood’ that would hinder the free development
of the personality of the individual woman”; but she also argued that the
emancipation of women was desirable in large part precisely because it would
allow her to “become a mother in an ever higher, ever more comprehensive
sense.”53 A “richer development of female individuality,” she believed, would
create a “deeper motherliness.”54 Women’s emancipation, in other words, was
for her primarily a means to the end of making women better at what they had
always done: motherhood.
Although Stöcker was primarily an activist rather than a philosopher, in
fact, in her numerous speeches and essays she did clearly advocate a coherent
creed that, while more heavily inflected by Nietzschean and Romantic vocabularies, was strikingly similar to Key’s – one she too explicitly referred to as the
“religion of life” and of joy. Sexual love, as “logically the highest expression
of the love of life,” was the central symbol and sacrament of this faith. The
notion of original sin was “a crime against life, the real sin against the Holy
Spirit of life.”55 Christianity, she conceded, “had its good side,” because it
had led to a necessary “spiritualization” of man; but in stigmatizing and denigrating corporeality and sexuality, it had sabotaged people’s capacity to be
“good,” or more precisely full of life – to be joyful and creative.56 This mistake
she proposed to correct. Stöcker explicitly rejected “commonplace materialist
eudaimonism . . . , primitive pleasure, mere joy in the senses.”57 Instead, love
for Stöcker meant not only sexual union but also spiritual and emotional communion – “Eros,” not “Sexus.” For this reason, Stöcker argued “that in our
view there is no such thing as ‘free love,’” because “love is an inner bond
with other people, it means feeling responsible for their happiness.” The first
commandment of her new religion, she held in 1911, was precisely “individual responsibility.”58 But by this she meant above all responsibility to children, to the products of sexual union – and through them to the “race,” to
humanity in general. For her as for Key, the religion of joy, love, and life was

therefore necessarily a eugenic religion, a religion of human physical improvement. The worship of “eternal life, the eternal return of life . . . the triumphant
‘Yes’ to life . . . true life as the collective continuation of life through conception, through the mysteries of sexuality,” was for her the “best foundation
for religion and ethics.”59 And her new religion was therefore in some senses
“stricter and more exclusive” than Christianity, because it demanded “renunciation of parenthood” for persons who could not contribute to the creation of
a better generation of children.60 Already at the public meeting announcing the
formation of the BfM in 1905, she held that “we will have to find a means of
preventing the hopelessly ill or degenerate from reproducing.”61 She continued
to advocate this position for the next decade – remarking in 1914, for example,
that “inferior people” were “a threat and a hindrance for the state,” and that
preventing their birth, “by all means known to science, is not only our right
but our duty.”62
The great majority of the sex reformers clearly shared this commitment to
the transcendent value of life, sex, evolution, and eugenic health. Thus Ruth
Bré held that reproduction was “holy.”63 Gabriele Reuter imagined a society
of the future “in which reverence prevails not for the laws that human beings
made and human beings can change and destroy, but more, much more for
the eternal powers of divine Mother Nature.”64 Ernst Baars held in 1908 that
“our responsibility to the commonweal and to the next generation” was a
“more valuable substitute” for “heaven and hell”; the “desire for salvation
finds gratification in the doctrine of evolution,” and the “belief in the capacity
for evolution in all life” was “our religion.”65 And Adele Schreiber called
parenthood “the one form of immortality that an age of scientific knowledge
makes the focus of new religious feelings.”66
Even short of such explicitly religious conceptions of sexuality and evolution, however, a large number of the sex reformers clearly identified sex as
fundamental to the very meaning of life. Ernst Kromayer stated with striking
nonchalance that “sexual matters are the most important in life”; Walther
Borgius wrote of the “sanctity and beauty of sexual life”; Leopold von Wiese
remarked in Die Neue Generation in early 1914 that it was obvious that

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

“the existence of the individual and of us all stands under the dominion of
the sex drive.” Stöcker spoke for most of the sex-reform community when she
pronounced love to be “the core of our personal life as well as of the life of our
species.” So did Grete Meisel-Hess, in remarking that sex and sexual love was
the “most central zone” of life, “happiness pure and simple,” and the “focal
point of existence . . . the heart of any human life.” Henriette Fürth spoke in
1903 of sexuality as “the central power of life” and of sexuality as “the best
and highest in man.”67
There was consensus, too, on the sanctity specifically of the evolution of the
human species. Thus Max Rosenthal argued in 1903 that “the upward evolution of humanity” must be recognized “as a higher standard for our moral
action.”68 At the VFF conference of that year, Anita Augspurg characterized
women’s “innate calling” as “the improvement of the race.”69 In the same year
Ruth Bré also argued that the sexual order must provide not only “opportunities for individual happiness for every person” but also opportunities for the
creation of “higher forms of humanity through selective breeding.”70 Adele
Schreiber, speaking to the meeting at which the formation of the BfM was publicly announced in 1905, complained that too few in the women’s movement
understood “the high meaning of love-life . . . as the foundation of improvement of the race.”71 Similar passages dot the writings of the sex reformers
with increasing frequency in the years following the formation of the BfM. By
1911 the opening lines of the public invitation to the first international conference on sex reform in Dresden summed this credo up neatly: “To live means to
develop,” and “making the sexual life of man serve the well-being of the living
and the ascent of the species is the highest task of advancing civilization.”72
By that year the biological and eugenic obsessions of the sex reformers had
become quite vivid. An essay by Anita Augspurg, published in a collection
of essays by leading sex reformers in 1911, is a striking example. Augspurg
argued that in nature males competed with one another for every female they

225

encountered, whereas females chose the strongest and most successful competitors as their mates. The existing sexual order stood this natural order on its
head. The “institutions of the masculine state” were virtually all designed, she
believed, “to sabotage . . . precisely this selective instinct of woman.” The result
was the double standard, “massive sexual debauchery,” prostitution, mercenary marriages, and degeneration, a “visible increase in the loathsomeness of
humanity. . . . A stroll through lively streets, a ride on a Sunday afternoon excursion train shows us as a rule dull, ordinary, stupid physiognomies. . . . Ugliness
is the norm, beauty, sympathetic features are the striking exception.” The only
solution was to open up educational and professional opportunities for girls
and to pay mothers to raise their children, so that women did not face the alternative of hunger or marriage – perhaps to an ugly, selfish, greedy, antisocial
but therefore rich man.73
Augspurg may have derived her analysis from that of Grete Meisel-Hess,
whose massive tome, The Sexual Crisis, published in 1909, made a very similar argument at imposing length. Looking around one, Meisel-Hess observed,
one was gripped with “despair at this profusion of ugliness and dullness,”
by “what shines, or rather doesn’t shine,” from the eyes of one’s fellow citizens. The average punter, she believed, barely reached the level of “the normal
human being,” much less the “superman.” The simple reason was that the
existing sexual order was unnatural and ensured a “de-selective breeding” of
humanity, because it sabotaged women’s “freedom of choice” in reproduction.
The biological salvation of humanity depended on the “liberation of the female
womb” from capitalism and patriarchy. And a spiritual revolution was a necessary part of that revolution; for “reverence for procreation is the religion of
the future.”74
Women were not alone in presenting such ideas. The Social Democratic
member of parliament and BfM member Eduard David, for example, offered
a blunt statement of the eugenic vision of sex reform in two essays in the BfM
journal in 1910. Denouncing Christianity for having pursued a “degradation of
the body to a mere transitory vessel of sin,” he championed instead the “ideal of
the organic fitness and higher breeding of the generations.” Arguing that modern welfare programs created the very real danger of “degeneration through
the artificial preservation of organically inferior progeny,” he suggested that
society had “a solemn duty” to make sure that “physically or mentally inferior
human seed” did not “come to life at all.”75 The answer would be provided by
women’s liberation and modern contraception. The “economic independence
of woman” would enable a “more rational selection of spouses” in place of
the current “capitalistically corrupted business of spousal selection,” in which
73

Anita Augspurg, “Reformgedanken zur sexuellen Moral,” in Dohm et al., eds., Ehe? pp. 22,
23, 25, 28, 29, 33, 34.
74 Meisel-Hess, Die sexuelle Krise, pp. 20, 287, 7, 6, 324–325, 290.
75 Eduard David, “Säuglingsfürsorge und Rassenhygiene,” NG 6 (1910): 3, 5, 6, 8.

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

marriage was “in 90 out of 100 cases a question of money, of class, of career”
rather than of “organic hereditary qualities of the highest social value, such
as strong altruistic inclination.” Birth control would enable a “more rational
selection of seed” instead of the natural “selection of individuals” in the struggle for the survival of the fittest; it would permit “the exclusion of the bad
seed-corn from the garden of humanity” in humane and rational fashion.76
Particularly after 1910, organizational ties between the BfM and the broader
eugenics movement grew increasingly dense, and the organization’s journal
published extreme eugenic ideas with growing frequency. In 1910, for example, it carried without critical comment the leading eugenic theorist Wilhelm
Schallmeyer’s anxious reflections on the “steady self-extermination of the
gifted” through lower fertility.77 In 1911 it printed the prominent sexologist Hermann Rohleder’s argument that those who received poor-relief
“have . . . forfeited the right to reproduction (nota bene not the right to sexual pleasure).”78 In the same year, it reported, again without critical comment,
on the growing number of eugenic laws passed by various states in the United
States.79 Two years later it reprinted a pamphlet put out by the Berlin chapter
of the DMB that held that “only physically and mentally healthy people have
the right to reproduce.”80
Many sex reformers clearly hoped that genetically “inferior” people could
be persuaded, as Eduard David put it, “voluntarily to forgo having children”;
and the sex reformers were vehement in their advocacy of free access to contraceptives not only as a means to defend women’s economic independence and
the culture of erotic love free of reproductive risk but also for their potential
eugenic benefit. But most also agreed with David that “society must have the
right to exclude individuals burdened with serious heritable illnesses and disabilities, if not from marriage, then at least from reproduction.” Whatever the
implications for individual rights might be, ultimately “everything that serves
the higher evolution of the species is morally good.”81 Again, Helene Stöcker
was particularly insistent on this point. Henriette Fürth, too, advocated not only
“strengthening of the moral sense of responsibility” in eugenic matters but also
“as ultima ratio compulsory castration or sterilization.”82 Adele Schreiber was
more explicit still, suggesting that “reproduction by alcoholics, the mentally

disabled, and abnormal people, who can never be given the energy of will necessary for contraception, should be prevented by means of legal sterilization,
as it has been implemented in parts of the United States.”83
Almost no one in the sex-reform movement went as far as Ellen Key, who
advocated murdering “inferior” children. But some came close. Schreiber, for
example, advocated eugenic abortion at the discretion of a “panel of race
hygienists” – although she admitted that such “suggestions” at first sounded
“monstrous” or “very off-putting.”84 Grete Meisel-Hess supported the same
idea.85 Others followed the logic of “evolutionism” to less frightening, but still
quite odd conclusions – as when the sociologist Matilda Vaerting argued, in the
BfM journal in 1914, that women should reproduce much later in their life cycle
than men, because experience with house pets showed that this produced better
offspring.86 This, at last, was too much for Bruno Meyer, who denounced the
crude “stud-farm perspective” adopted by some of his colleagues.87 But a high
proportion of the organization’s intellectual leadership clearly agreed with the
Frankfurt doctor who, in an article in Die Neue Generation in 1912, remarked
that “we live in the age of racial hygiene.”88
The BfM as a whole was relatively circumspect. But it did formally adopt
vague resolutions in favor of restrictive eugenic legislation, including “legal
prohibition of marriage for the sick and inferior” at its first conference in
1907 and “race-hygienic measures to limit the procreation of inferior elements”
at its second conference in 1909.89
There was, then, a startling self-contradiction at the heart of sex-reform
thought. It was a prime article of faith among the sex reformers that freedom would generate its own order, and that the state had no business interfering in the sexual lives of its citizens. Most appear to have assumed that
the state could regulate reproduction without regulating sex; as Key put it,
“love will . . . become more and more a private concern,” but “children on the
other hand ever more a vital question for society.”90 Some sex reformers were
troubled by the fact – as Albert Eulenburg pointed out at the BfM’s 1911
conference – that some proposed eugenic measures might “contradict or be

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

disquieting to modern individualism.”91 But the terms in which the sex reformers conceived of sexuality and sexual morality simply militated against the
recognition that there could be a conflict between their libertarian sexual
agenda and their calls for restrictive eugenic legislation. A resolution passed by
the Berlin chapter of the BfM in protest against pending legislation restricting
access to contraceptives in 1911 is a telling example. Such a law, the resolution
pronounced, would be
an ineffective and immoral measure that would compromise the free, morally
responsible decision to become a parent and introduce compulsory child-bearing
by means of police power. The consequences of indiscriminate population growth
would be not ascent but decline of the race, an increase in venereal disease and
prostitution – whereas in contrast the sick and mentally, morally and physically
inferior people should be excluded from reproduction in the interests of society!92

The group simply did not see any contradiction between objecting to “compulsory child-bearing” and advocating compulsory sterility.
It is of course precisely the biologistic postulates underlying the sex-reform
program that explain this self-contradiction. The sex reformers demanded freedom of sexual expression because it would serve the upward evolution of
the race. Sexuality was sacred, and individual sexual autonomy inviolable,
for that reason. Where sexuality did not serve evolution, it was not sacred and
inviolable and should not be free. For them, evolution was the sole measure
of moral good; those who did not serve it were morally irrelevant, morally
invisible.93
From this perspective, there was a certain logic to the sex reformers’ position on reproductive freedom – a logic diametrically opposed to that of the
male morality campaigners who were increasingly concerned with the decline
in the birthrate. In some cases, it is true, the sex reformers did not scruple to
play on the appeal of nationalist pronatalism as a means of advocating for
change, particularly with respect to the welfare of single mothers and their
children. The first pamphlet put out by the BfM in 1905, for example, referred
to the high mortality rate among illegitimate infants as a waste of a “powerful source of our national strength” and deplored the fact that many of
those who survived became “criminals, whores, and vagrants,” and few were

“fit for military duty.”94 Maria Lischnewska suggested that maternity insurance would “secure healthy and strong recruits” to maintain “Germany’s world
power.”95 In 1906 the BfM’s journal reprinted, without critical comment, an
excerpt from the work of Friedrich Naumann in which he argued that “men
forge weapons, but soldiers rest in the arms of mothers. . . . Only nations with
capable mothers impose their will. Mothers are the conquering element.”96
And yet, in fact it was much more common for the sex reformers to reject
the pronatalist position; and as conservative concern about the issue grew more
vocal, they became ever more insistent on the right of women to control their
own reproductivity, and this issue became more and more central to their conception of the necessary connection between sexual and political liberty. Most
probably agreed fundamentally with the political perspective of the socialist
philosopher and political commentator Theodor Lessing, who asked in Die
Neue Generation in 1909 whether “anyone still really believes that the people
of a particular territory are the property of the state or even of their ruler,
pecus inane, cannon fodder, which must be ‘delivered’ in the greatest possible
quantities for the good of the political map?”97 Women, the sex reformers
insisted, could not be reduced (as Stöcker put it in 1911) to mere “things, to
baby-factories” for the militarist and authoritarian state.98 Stöcker reacted with
horrified disdain to Bornträger’s yearning for a leader with “sufficient conviction and force” to impose the kinds of intervention he considered necessary to
halt the fall in the birthrate; she regarded him as a “high-priest of ignorance and
darkness.” Such “police-clerical chicanery, denunciation, spying, prohibitions
of intellectual freedom” as he proposed, she believed, could never be effective
as long as people like him “cannot construct a national community in which
every man and every woman is, every minute of every day and night, under a
police supervision which watches over every impulse, every movement in his
life and love” – a notion she clearly found abhorrent.99
Even when they admitted to concern about the birthrate, moreover, the
sex reformers often insisted that conservatives were going about addressing
it from the wrong direction. The BfM proposed instead of police measures
a palette of positive measures to encourage fertility – motherhood insurance
or payment of a child allowance, welfare measures for illegitimate children,

better training for midwives, free obstetric care, public housing programs,
lower taxes on consumption, and an end to the requirement that female civil
servants give up their jobs on marriage.100 Pointing to the causal connection
between high fertility on the one hand and impoverishment, exhaustion, and
high infant mortality on the other, they suggested that a lower fertility rate,
combined with a lower mortality rate, made both human and economic sense.
Stöcker, for example, welcomed the falling birthrate as evidence of an ongoing
“rationalization of the process of reproduction,” such that fewer children were
born, but more of them grew to healthy adulthood (a position common, as we
have seen, also among the abolitionists).101 And the guidelines adopted by the
BfM’s steering committee in 1910 argued for rational population management
“in the race-hygienic and economic interests of the nation.”102
Interestingly, however, this prioritization of biological quality over quantity
did not translate into an affinity for ethnic racism. Again, in some instances a
strikingly racist note did creep into sex-reform discussions. Ellen Key warned,
for example, that “a race cannot sustain itself without healthy and moral
mothers” and that continued low fertility among Europeans would “in the end
amount to the problem of the future of the Euro-American peoples.”103 Ruth
Bré was concerned that the Germans might be overrun by the fast-breeding
Slavs, and then by the Chinese, in a century or two.104 Grete Meisel-Hess
suggested in 1911 that “it is unquestionably important that the biological race
that is the bearer of the highest civilization, that is the white race, spread
over the earth as far as possible and not let itself be displaced by the colored
races.”105 Maria Lischnewska in particular was a rabid ethnic and cultural
chauvinist.106
And yet in most of those scattered instances in which ethnic racism was
mentioned at all in sex-reform writings, it was actually explicitly rejected –
and in fact this was increasingly common in the years just before World War I,
even as the sex reformers turned more decidedly toward eugenics. Thus in 1912
Die Neue Generation reported with approval Eduard David’s suggestion, in
parliamentary debate, that some whites “could perhaps not degrade but rather
improve their progeny” through intermarriage with the indigenous Samoan

population. In 1914 it carried an article arguing that, given the historical mixing
of populations, the idea of a “pure” race was a fantasy, and that “there are no
races that are . . . more primitive or more advanced than others. Every race is in
certain characteristics superior to others, in other characteristics inferior.”107
And in the same year, before the DMB’s annual conference, Stöcker observed
that “the ‘Yellow Peril’ belongs in the realm of fable,” derided the “fanaticism
for large birth numbers,” and insisted that what was important was that people
have “children who raise the level of the species.”108
It is worth noting, furthermore, that a relatively high proportion of participants in the sex-reform movement were secular Jews or the children of Jewish
converts to Christianity – including, for example, Schreiber, Bloch, Fürth,
Meisel-Hess, Rosenthal, Dohm, Kurt Hiller, Benedict Friedländer, Magnus
Hirschfeld, and the DGBG’s Albert Neisser, who was also a longtime member of the BfM.109 The phenomenon of the self-hating Jew was of course well
known at the time; but with very few exceptions anti-Semitism played no role at
all in the collective thinking of the sex-reform movement. This was arguably a
more important test issue than the so-called yellow peril or anti-African racism,
both of which were almost entirely abstract for most Germans.
This is an odd combination of convictions – enthusiasm for eugenic categories of human “quality,” but rejection of ethnic-racial ones, and enthusiasm for coercive measures aimed at securing high-quality people, but rejection
of coercive measures aimed at securing quantities of people. One explanation for it is that sex reform was quite close to Social Democracy, which
was at once the most powerful prodemocratic and antiracist political force
in Germany at the time and highly attracted both to economistic reasoning (such as Ellen Key’s question, “What could be more immoral than to
ask the strong and healthy members of society to burden themselves with
increasingly heavy taxes in order to support the vicious human offscum?”) and
to natural scientific perspectives.110 Again, eugenic thinking was particularly
attractive to revisionist Social Democrats, some of whom played important
roles in sex reform. But the deeper point here is that the sex reformers were
democrats not in spite of their biological obsessions but because of them –
because they believed that democracy and individualism were biologically beneficial. The same is true of their commitment specifically to feminism. Women’s
