Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

liberation did not actually come first for them; as Grete Meisel-Hess put it in
the BfM journal in 1911, the women’s movement was “only a means to an
end,” the improvement of the race.111 This should not call their sincerity into
question – the sex reformers were, in their great majority, vehement champions both of democratic political rights and of complete political, legal, social,
and sexual equality for women. But in most cases, biology was central to their
conception of democracy; indeed, for many it seems democracy and evolution
were one thing, that they were not complementary but identical. This connection implied rather frightening limitations on their commitment to individual
rights; but it also made their commitment to democracy literally, as they put it,
religious.
In this sense, too, their ideas were the mirror opposite of those of their
opponents. Most conservative Christians regarded contraception as immoral
and eugenics as at best a merely material concern; and most had a literally
religious commitment to the authoritarian state.
III. Fission: Gender, Politics, and Personality in Sex Reform
On these central elements of the sex-reform program, virtually all sex reformers were in agreement. Nevertheless, the sex-reform movement, and the BfM
in particular, erupted in 1908–1909 in an internal battle even more dramatic
and damaging than that suffered by the WHK in 1906–1907. This was a
complex split along multiple fault lines within the movement. One central
problem for the organization was that Stöcker had a tendency to regard
the BfM as her personal project and property. The organization’s journal,
Die Neue Generation, had actually been her initiative. It was formally adopted
as the BfM’s organ when the organization was created; but Stöcker continued to
edit it, and it was fundamentally her journal. A number of early conflicts within
the organization appear to have been generated by Stöcker’s high-handed (as
at least some seem to have felt) editorial practices.112 She was also apparently a
rather poor administrator – possibly precisely because she did regard the BfM
as in some sense her personal affair. Separate accounts were apparently not
kept for the BfM’s Berlin chapter and for the national organization, for example, and a new administrator brought in to help sort out the mess described the
organization’s office in December 1909 as being in chaos.113

Religion of Love

233

Adele Schreiber, aware of the organization’s financial problems, appears
to have decided in late 1908 that only hiring a competent, full-time administrator (by diverting to this new employee Stöcker’s salary of 1,500 marks
per year) would solve them – and curb Stöcker’s “autocratic, purely arbitrary
leadership.”114 Stöcker was uncomprehending; as she put it, “it is a little odd
that the leader of a spiritual movement should be judged in the first place on
whether she understands double-entry book-keeping.” Her solution, instead,
was to become the organization’s general secretary herself (with Lischnewska,
briefly in 1909–1910, as new chairman), double her salary, and move the
organization’s office to her private apartment.115
A deeper issue, however, was that it was actually very difficult even for the
sexual radicals in the BfM to escape the power of conventional views and taboos
specifically regarding female sexuality. As the debate over organizational issues
escalated, cracks began to appear in the sexual radicalism of the participants. At
a meeting of the Berlin chapter in January 1910, Stöcker’s opponents pointed
out that Bruno Springer, one of her strongest supporters on the BfM board, was
actually her lover. Springer in turn accused Schreiber of having a “past” herself,
and of having tried to seduce him – generating the first of, ultimately, no fewer
than five libel cases occasioned by the conflict.116 After some weeks of further
accusations and counteraccusations and a failed attempt to get to the bottom of
the matter by a special investigative committee within the Berlin chapter, other
members of the organization, and particularly many of the men involved, seem
to have been torn between despair, disgust, and amusement. One, for example,
drew laughter from the attendees at the BfM’s general meeting at the end of
February 1910 by proposing “to investigate, right here and now, the sexual
relationships of all those present.”117
The problem, however, was a serious one. In principle, within the BfM
the sexual behavior of the women involved should have been nobody’s business; but in practice, for women specifically, accusations of sexual laxity
were apparently still the moral equivalent of (as Stöcker put it) a “war of

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

annihilation.”118 At least some men in the organization apparently found the
whole episode incomprehensible, however, and defaulted to gendered stereotypes to explain it all. As the Berlin chapter’s investigator put it, the problem was that both Schreiber and Stöcker had “allowed themselves . . . to be
carried away by their temperament” and were “overly gifted at writing and
talking” – a comment that naturally drew “vigorous cries of protest” from
women members.119
This element of gender tension also played a role in a second important split
within the sex-reform movement. For, simultaneously with the break between
Stöcker and Schreiber (and their respective supporters), a whole phalanx of
male doctors – led by Max Marcuse, one of the founding members – left the
organization in 1907–1908, establishing their own journal and the organizational nucleus for the new medical discipline of sexology. This development
is treated in the next chapter; for now it is important to note that the sense
that the radical women who dominated the BfM were typically irrational and
unstable females played a role in motivating Marcuse and his colleagues to
leave the organization, and it was clearly apparent in the rhetorical terms they
used to distance themselves from it.
The role of sexual accusations and gender stereotypes was not the only form
of tension between theory and practice at play in the BfM, however. For an
important faction within the organization, particularly in its local chapters, was
in fact more committed to social work with single mothers and their children
than to the ethical revolution espoused by many in the Berlin leadership. The
members of this group feared that propaganda for the New Ethic would merely
alienate many people who would otherwise be inclined to support their efforts.
Sex-reform organizations formed in Munich and in Hanover confined their
activities to practical social work and did not join the national organization;
local chapters in Stuttgart, Frankfurt, and Hamburg joined but resisted the
Berlin leadership’s agenda.120 And a number of important figures in the national
organization too – particularly men – continued to object to the whole idea of
adopting an explicit program of ethical reform, arguing that such a step would
only lead to endless disagreements and wrangling.121
The costs of these conflicts were considerable. Max Marcuse, Adele
Schreiber, Henriette Fürth, the venereal disease experts Max Flesch and Ernst

Kromayer, the demographer Paul Mayet, and Lily Braun, all prominent in the

in the far east of Germany, where the moral climate was more conservative,
also seceded, whereas a fourth declared that it would remain in the BfM but
engage in social work only. The BfM’s budget in 1910 was one-third what
it had been in 1909.122 Schreiber, Mayet, and Fürth continued to denounce
Stöcker’s “arbitrariness and injustice” and her “sexual-ethical radicalism” (in
the words of Fürth); Schreiber formed the competing Society for Mothers’ and
Children’s Rights, which was not very successful but did have at least one
local chapter by 1912.123 And the airing of the organization’s dirty laundry
cannot have done much for the sex reformers’ cause; indeed one conservative Protestant crowed in early 1910 over the “collapse” and “fundamental
bankruptcy” of the BfM; and a Social Democratic observer held in 1912 that
the BfM was “at present more ash than fire” as a result of these internal
conflicts.124
This concatenation of difficulties and conflicts ultimately led to a fundamental reorganization of the BfM. Already in 1908 the governing board of the
organization had been expanded to include one representative of each of the
group’s local chapters, as well as seven from the Berlin leadership.125 In 1910 it
was decided to rotate the chairmanship and headquarters among the provincial
chapters (by election), rather than fixing them in Berlin; the executive board of
the national organization was now to consist of the board of whatever local
chapter currently led the group, plus one member from each other chapter.126
The BfM’s general assembly voted in favor of Breslau as the new headquarters;
and the chairmanship was taken over by the head of Breslau’s local chapter,
Max Rosenthal. Stöcker remained editor of Die Neue Generation and chair of
the Berlin chapter; but the dominance of the Berlin leadership was, at least in
principle, broken.127

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

The assumption of the chairmanship of the national organization by Rosenthal had important implications for the ideological posture of the organization
as a whole. Rosenthal was extremely skeptical regarding the thinking of many
of his female colleagues in the movement, and particularly of Stöcker herself.
He openly regarded Nietzscheanism with deep distaste, as a symptom of what
he saw as the rampant egoism of the age; and he had argued that this same prevailing egoism made socialism more or less a dangerous pipe dream. Tensions
soon developed between him and the Berlin leadership; in late 1907, Stöcker
had even complained to the board of the BfM that Rosenthal was excluding
women from the leadership of the Breslau chapter, and that he “is in theory
a feminist, but in practice doesn’t think much of it.” And in fact in 1908 the
Breslau chapter was the only one in which male members outnumbered female
members.128 The subsequent development of Rosenthal’s thinking did nothing
to smooth relations. By 1912, in a study entitled “Love: Its Nature and Value,”
Rosenthal would offer a biting assessment of his fellow sex reformers, whom
he felt to be indulging in “an enormous over-estimation of love as a cultural
factor.” Women in particular, he found, were “over the top” in their estimation
of the importance of love. Actually, he held, love was not altruistic but almost
wholly egoistic, indeed antisocial, because it absorbed energies that might otherwise have been directed toward socially useful ends. It was often based on
self-delusion and generated endless dramas and upsets. All in all, “nowhere
else is so much energy uselessly squandered as in love.” The only thing that
made love useful, he reasoned, was that it encouraged monogamy, which was
conducive to what was, as he saw it, the real “goal” of human sexuality: “the
production and education of healthy progeny” and hence “human evolution.”
As for morality, what made sex moral was simply “duty” – the commitment
to front up to the responsibilities one took on by getting married and having
children.129
This realism may have recommended him to those in the BfM who sought
to create a counterbalance to Stöcker’s influence; and his more sober and pragmatic approach to eugenics and evolution, stripped of Nietzschean romanticism
and paeans to happiness, may have seemed an opportunity to shift emphasis to
what appeared to be more concrete and scientific ground that would be more
likely to build consensus. The organizational transformation of the BfM, in
other words, reflected the drift toward a more explicitly eugenic and “evolutionist” approach to sexual ethics.
This organizational and intellectual transition was highly successful. In particular, the BfM’s practical social work did in fact blossom. In 1909 the BfM

237

had had twelve local chapters but only three shelters for single mothers; in
1910 and 1911 it added five more shelters – despite losing local chapters.130
The group still had some 3,500 members and eight provincial chapters – down
from its peak of around 4,000 members and eleven chapters, but not drastically
so. In 1913 three new local chapters and a separate group for academics were
formed; and by that time the total membership of the organization had most
probably regained the level of 1909.131 In 1911 the BfM was able to initiate the
formation of an international sex-reform organization, the Internationale Bund
für Mutterschutz und Sexualreform (IBMS), and to convene its first conference
in Dresden. And the list of some 130 signatories on the public invitation to join
the IBMS was imposing, including major luminaries from sex reform, sexology, Social Democracy, the women’s movement, the homosexual emancipation
movement, eugenics, the arts, the DGBG, and psychoanalysis.132 Much smaller
national sister organizations had, by 1912, been formed in Holland, Sweden,
and Austria, and in 1913 they met concurrently with the regular biennial BfM
conference.133
Like the homosexual rights movement, then, by 1913 the BfM had little or
nothing concrete to show for its efforts to shape legislation or even administrative practice; yet the organization was clearly not demoralized or chastened, and
its leadership in fact appears to have had a clear sense that they were gaining
ground culturally, if not in practical politics.134 Obviously, the sex reformers’
analysis of the evolution of social and gender relations implied that time was
on their side. At least some in the movement felt that developments were confirming this prognosis. As Stöcker put it in 1913, “everywhere . . . new, deeper
expectations for people’s behavior in love and friendship are arising out of
the new knowledge of humankind. . . . Secretly, almost invisibly . . . everywhere
today new inner laws are developing.” Frida Stéenhof, writing in the previous
year, had regarded the spread in all classes of a new form of informal sexual
“relationship” between men and women as a crucial example.135 And the sex
reformers also believed that they were gaining purchase on opinion among the
political classes. Even Adele Schreiber concluded by 1912 that the BfM was
reaching a growing audience; as she put it, “what yesterday seemed so subversive and revolutionary has today been popularized in wide social circles.”136
Max Rosenthal argued – also in 1912 – that the “undeniable achievement of

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

the League is that it has brought discussion of the sexual problem into motion
and directed universal attention to it.”137 In short, the sex-reform leadership
believed that although it had not – yet – been able to shape outcomes, it
was increasingly successful in setting the agenda of public debate. This was,
of course, precisely the conviction of the leadership of the homosexual rights
movement, the abolitionists, and the Christian morality campaigners in the
same period.
The BfM too was, moreover, forming an increasing number of important
organizational alliances within the expanding progressive monist milieu – what
Stöcker called the “cultural alliance of all emancipatory reform efforts.” In
1911 and 1912, representatives of the BfM joined or addressed conferences of
the WHK, the neo-Malthusian movement, the DMB, and the Weimar Cartel.
Stöcker had presented her ideas in the journal of the DMB in 1907; she
addressed the annual DMB conferences of 1911, 1912, and 1913, describing sex reform as “purely monistic”; and the DMB’s annual conference of
1912 essentially endorsed the BfM’s New Ethic as embodying monist views
on sexuality and reproduction.138 And the BfM intensified its international
engagements and raised its international profile by initiating the creation of the
IBMS.
Despite tension between Stöcker and Social Democratic women such as
Schreiber, Fürth, and Lily Braun, the BfM’s relationship with Social Democracy was also increasingly cordial. Individual Social Democrats – like Eduard
David – played an important role in the organization; and the Social Democratic
press reported on the BfM with increasing interest and approval after 1910.
In the late 1890s, orthodox socialists had been deeply skeptical of the ideas of
bourgeois sexual radicals; and the more orthodox in the party still sometimes
argued after the turn of the century in effect that sex reform should not have
an autonomous existence outside the Social Democratic movement, because
the economic and sexual emancipation of women could only happen under
socialism.139 But revisionists were more sympathetic. By 1911, Hope AdamsLehman was praising the BfM in the Sozialistische Monatshefte as one of those
“subsidiary streams” of the great army of liberation represented by Social

Democracy, to be “greeted in cheerful and comradely” spirit and admired for
the “clarity and boldness of its demands” and for the practical work it did.140
The prominent Social Democrats Eduard David, Eduard Bernstein, Ludwig
Frank, and Oda Olberg all signed the public invitation to the IBMS conference
of that year.
The sex reformers were also able to build bridges to the psychoanalytic
movement. Helene Stöcker was associated with the Berlin Psychoanalytic Society from its foundation in 1908; and important figures in it joined the BfM
and/or published in its journal. Heinrich Koerber – a founding member of the
Psychoanalytic Society and chairman of the DMB in 1908 and 1909 – published an essay in the BfM journal in 1910, for example, that was sympathetic
to both the homosexual rights movement and sex reform.141 In a 1913 article in
Die Neue Generation, Wilhelm Stekel, a leading figure in the psychoanalytic
movement, was highly sympathetic, reiterating the sex reformers’ conviction
that sexual desire was ubiquitous in human affairs and that its repression
caused all sorts of moral, physical, and mental hardships, and even agreeing that
“our sexuality is our share of immortality.”142 In 1913, on Freud’s invitation,
Helene Stöcker attended a meeting of the Vienna Psychoanalytic Society; and
Freud himself supported both the IBMS and the Austrian branch of the BfM.143
No less important, the sex reformers were also able to form alliances to the
burgeoning world of social welfare reform, and particularly to the movement
for the amelioration of infant mortality rates. The leadership of the infant
welfare movement appears to have been either indifferent or, in some cases,
hostile to the philosophical musings of the sex reformers; but they were acutely
concerned about the health of illegitimate children (who suffered markedly
higher mortality rates than children born to married couples). They therefore
contributed to the growth of a climate of opinion that regarded the plight of
single mothers and their children not as a moral but as a social issue. The
BfM journal reported from its inception on the key institutional innovation
in the fight against illegitimate infant mortality – professional public legal
guardianship – regarding it as a useful instrument in combating both social
hardship and social prejudices.144 Both sex reformers and welfare advocates

Sexual Radicalism, 1900–1914

faced animosity from moral conservatives who felt that the poverty of single
mothers was a good deterrent against sexual laxity. In some cases that common
interest was evident in surprisingly concrete developments – as when, in 1911,
the BfM’s journal reported on a municipal motherhood insurance scheme that
had been adopted in the face precisely of the argument that helping single
mothers would encourage nonmarital sexual unions.145
Despite conflicts between the BfM leadership and male sexologists, moreover, a number of the most influential German and international sexologists
continued actively to support and/or participate in the BfM after 1910. By
1913 a number of these male medical men formed a small but potentially
important organization, the Medical Society for Sexual Science and Eugenics
(Ärztliche Gesellschaft für Sexualwissenschaft und Eugenik [ÄGSE]). Although
it adopted a more studiedly “scientific” posture than the BfM, this group was
clearly closely allied to the sex-reform movement. Its chairman was Albert
Eulenberg, a very early (1898) supporter of homosexual rights who was also
sympathetic to sex reform; its first meeting opened with the reading of a telegram from the godfather of monism, Ernst Haeckel, and then heard addresses
by founding members Iwan Bloch and Magnus Hirschfeld.146
As we have seen, finally, at least some doctors in the DGBG were drifting
toward common ground with the BfM on some issues – for example, on the
importance of free access to contraceptives or prophylactics, or on the potential harmfulness of sexual abstinence. Its leader, Albert Neisser, was a longtime
supporter of the BfM – an odd fact, given his views regarding prostitution,
but also a revealing instance of the importance of the shared monist/scientistic
underpinnings of medical and sex reform. An important example of the common ground between the two movements is their intensely critical reaction to
the attempt to legislate against contraceptives in 1914.
Ultimately, then, the development of the BfM was strikingly similar to that
of the WHK in the same years. It too had its origins in early intellectual
innovations in the 1890s; passed through a period of rapid expansion and
intense optimism immediately after its foundation; experienced severe internal
conflicts that appeared devastating at the time but turned out not substantially
to have compromised its growth or vitality; and, in the years before the war,
was able to build important organizational relationships with an emerging
network of like-minded activists across the spectrum of left-modernist reform
both within Germany and internationally.
Also like the WHK, however, the BfM proved unable to control the discussion of sexuality that it had done much to initiate in its early years. Particularly
in the five years before the outbreak of World War I, it found itself only the
most prominent of a growing number of organizations participating in a rapidly
widening debate concerning sexuality, eugenics, gender roles, and the nature
145
146

of an ethical perspective founded in natural science and specifically biology.
Some of these organizations supported much or even most of the sex-reform
program. But the most influential, the emergent scientific discipline of sexology or sexual science (Sexualwissenschaft), was in many cases directly opposed
to the central postulates and demands supported by most of the BfM leadership. In particular, the majority of its exponents were bitterly antifeminist and
homophobic – and became increasingly so as the women’s movements and the
WHK gained traction on public opinion.
Chapter 11 turns to the emergence of this competing movement.

part iii
CONFLICT, 1908–1914

11
Men, Sex, and Science

I. Diversity, Unity, and Polarization
Whereas sex reform had an institutional focus in the BfM, the discipline of
sexology as it took shape after 1900 remained diffuse and divided. Most of
its exponents were medical academics or doctors in private practice; they had
little institutional motivation to agree with one another. The discipline cast
its intellectual net widely and was pulled in multiple contradictory directions,
often by the interventions of relative outsiders who were able to grab headlines
with provocative claims and proposals. Until 1913 it did not generate its own
autonomous organizational focus. The two key journals for the development
of sexological ideas reflected the diversity of interests in the field. The more
important of the two was Max Marcuse’s Sexual-Probleme, founded when he
left the BfM in 1908. Marcuse deliberately defined sexology broadly to include
multiple disciplines (biology, race theory, sociology, anthropology, psychology,
etc.) and pursued a very open editorial policy, publishing contributions from
across the spectrum of the debate on sexual morality. The first two volumes,
for example, included articles not only by men who had left the BfM, like
Marcuse and Christian von Ehrenfels, but also by Anna Pappritz of the IAF;
Bruno Meyer and Hermann Rohleder, both of whom contributed also to Die
Neue Generation; Sigmund Freud; the birth control advocate Hans Ferdy; the
Swedish sex reformer and venereal disease expert Anton Nyström; Paul Näcke;
and Kurt Hiller. The other important journal was Geschlecht und Gesellschaft
(Sex and Society), published from 1906 by the Berlin artistic and publishing
entrepreneur Karl Vanselow. Vanselow was editor of the controversial lifereform journal Die Schönheit (Beauty), which advocated for nudism, vegetarianism, and associated ideas and was illustrated with – among other things –
conventional photographic nudes. The two journals were among Vanselow’s
many commercial ventures, which included publications related to nudism and
245

246

Conflict, 1908–1914

life reform, the sale of photographic nudes, nude and semi-nude dance performances, and even a nudist hotel on the Baltic island of Rügen.1 Geschlecht und
Gesellschaft offered a colorful mix of articles on the arts and literature, ethnology, venereology, sex reform, nudism, and reproduction, among many other
things. Contributors ranged from Helene Stöcker to the conservative theology
professor Reinhold Seeberg and included, for example, Max Rosenthal, Anton
Nyström, the psychoanalyst Otto Adler, and the right-wing völkisch radical
Friedrich Siebert, as well as academic medical sexologists.
Sexological ideas were also elaborated and debated in numerous other
venues. The leading eugenics and race-theory journals of the period – the
journal of the German Society for Race Hygiene, Archiv für Rassen- und
Gesellschaftsbiologie, and the Politisch-Anthropologische Revue, the leading
venue for theorists of Aryan or Nordic racial superiority – carried influential discussions of particular issues. The importance of forensic psychiatry in
the study of sexual “perversions” made criminological journals (particularly
the Archiv für Kriminal-Anthropologie und Kriminalistik) yet another relevant
venue. And the leading medical journals, too, carried numerous articles on
sexuality.2
Sexology nevertheless did have a certain degree of implicit coherence, for
several reasons. First, it was consistently focused on three loose thematic complexes: sexual pathology, normal sexuality and its management, and reproduction. Relatively defined and focused debates shaped the discussion of each.
Second, sexology defined itself – to an increasing degree – as masculine, rational,
and scientific, in contradistinction to sex reform, which it defined as feminine,
emotive, and speculative. The sexologists were virtually without exception men.
Both Geschlecht und Gesellschaft and Sexual-Probleme did publish essays and
reviews by women, including a handful of women doctors; but the perspective
of sexology was overwhelmingly and self-consciously male. Third, sexology
was decidedly self-referential – quite literally, in the sense that a large proportion of major publications in the field were compendia of quotations about sex,

and often about women, drawn from a wide range of religious, literary, philosophical, medical, anthropological, and aesthetic works, overwhelmingly by
men. And the sexologists constantly recycled key passages from one another’s
works. By 1909, in fact, this pattern had become so glaringly obvious that
Albert Moll observed with obvious annoyance that the actual advance of sexological knowledge “stands . . . in gross disproportion” to the massive outpouring of books on sexual problems, for the simple reason that “most authors
repeat what others have said in similar or the same words, or publish synthetic
books on sexual life” that merely summarized what was already known.3
In fact, one of the most striking characteristics of sexology was the extent
to which it was unscientific, in the specific sense that it had little basis in experimentation or measurement. It was not an exact science but a Wissenschaft in
the sense defined, for example, by the economist and demographer Julius Wolf
in 1913: “Wissenschaft in the strict sense is sifted, systematized knowledge.”4
In practice the sexologists relied almost exclusively on two sources of knowledge: case studies from their own practice and the authority of other authors.
Of these, in most cases, the latter predominated. Even when cases from medical
practice were cited, there was almost never any attempt to render them in any
other than anecdotal form. Cases were, for example, almost never subjected
to statistical analysis; and studies of control groups were never used.5 As Paul
Näcke had remarked already in 1899, sexology as a field was “unsystematic,
more or less anecdotal” – and for the most part it remained so.6
Many sexologists were therefore extremely excited by the work of Eugen
Steinach, who shortly before World War I experimented with transgendering
small mammals by transplanting testes and ovaries. This seemed to be the start
of an actual experimental and medically useful science of sex. But Steinach’s
work appeared quite late, with the key text published in 1912; and by World
War I he had not actually isolated the hormones in question. For the time
being, therefore, Steinach’s work simply made embarrassingly clear just how
vanishingly little was actually known about the physiology of sexuality.7
The anecdotal quality of sexology made Sigmund Freud’s theorization of
sex appealing to some sexologists as well. In Three Essays on the Theory of
Sexuality, published in 1905, Freud pointed out that the key terms in prevailing models of perversion had no actual content. The idea that perversions
were acquired effectively meant that people fell into the habit of behaving
one way and not another. There was no mechanism – no disease vector, no
3

248

Conflict, 1908–1914

trauma, nothing actually identifiable as the process by which a perversion was
acquired. Similarly, the notion that sexual orientation was inborn was simply a
metaphor, and no one had any idea what organic mechanism it described.8 In
fact, what was most radical in Freud’s theory was that he essentially denied the
existence both of an authentic sexual self and of sexual normalcy. Like almost
all sexologists, he was sure that sexuality was rooted deep in the organism, in
“inner-somatic stimuli.”9 But his understanding of the enormous flexibility of
sexuality sabotaged the idea of an irreducible, stable, “normal” sexual selfhood.
What sexual objects the individual fixed on as the source of sexual gratification was a product of multiple environmental variables, and individual choices
were accordingly diverse. In light of that fact, Freud regarded the prevalence
of heterosexuality as a problem that needed explaining; and he concluded that
everyone was in one degree or another “perverse.” The perversions were rooted
in “something inborn . . . but something that is inborn in all people”; and the
differences between “so-called normal sexual life” and perversion were differences of quantity, not quality. There were no clear boundaries between normal
(“physiological”) sexuality and pathological sexuality.10
Rather than normalizing perversion, in short, Freud abnormalized sexual
normalcy; and in doing so he stressed over and over that most of what sexologists thought they knew about sexuality was simply unfounded speculation. No
one really knew what sexuality was – it was “something,” but precisely what
something was a matter of guesswork. The final line of the book concluded
“that we know far too little about the biological processes that constitute the
essence of sexuality to be able to develop, from our isolated insights, a theory
adequate for comprehension of either the normal or the pathological” in sexual
life.11
And yet, Freud himself had nothing better to offer. His theory was founded
on anecdotal case studies – “a large number of psychoanalyses that has been
growing for twenty years,” which he had conducted. In short he claimed authority based on his personal experience – just like every other sexologist.12 Older
sexologists were not swept off their feet. Albert Eulenburg found “a lot in
Freud . . . hardly to be taken seriously” and deplored the “excess doctrinal and
theoretical ballast” that, in his view, kept psychoanalysts from simply observing
psychological facts. Paul Näcke wrote similarly of the “colossal exaggeration,
the subjective and fantastical in the whole of psychoanalysis.”13 Wilhelm Stern

Men, Sex, and Science

249

found that Freud’s theories regarding infantile sexuality fell “entirely in the
realm of the absurd.”14 Before World War I the influence of psychoanalysis
in sexology as a whole was quite limited; psychoanalysts played an important
role on the sexological left, and a very minor role in sex-reform thought; but
that was all.
In the absence of any experimental or statistical mode of falsification, disagreements among the sexologists could almost never be resolved. As Magnus
Hirschfeld put it in a discussion of abstinence in 1908, a simple fact explained
what made the diametrically opposed positions of various sexologists plausible: “that this like so many other sexual problems has . . . simply not yet been
systematically studied on the basis of exact observation.”15 The discipline was
characterized, then, by unresolved and often wildly speculative arguments right
down to 1914. It was also, however, highly vulnerable to purely political forces.
In fact sexology became increasingly polarized along political lines. On the one
hand, socialist and left-liberal sex reformers or reform-oriented doctors continued to champion the ideas dominant in the BfM and the WHK. On the other
hand, an opposing trend among a loose grouping of more conservative men
steadily gathered momentum. Some of these men were drawn to the radical
Right; many of them were at least skeptical of democratic politics; and almost
all of them were vehemently antifeminist.
By 1913, this development was institutionalized in the formation of not
one but two competing sexological organizations. In February of that year, a
small circle of male medical men in or sympathetic to the BfM and WHK
established the ÄGSE, which was essentially a medical wing of the sexreform movement. Members of its governing board included Iwan Bloch and
Magnus Hirschfeld; the socialist medical expert Alfred Grotjahn; Hermann
Rohleder and Albert Eulenburg (as chairman), both influential sexologists
sympathetic to sex reform; and a number influential figures in the psychoanalytic movement.16 Although only medical doctors could become regular
members, others could be co-opted as “extraordinary members”; the first of
these, co-opted at its first meeting, was Helene Stöcker. By the beginning of
1914, the ÄGSE’s membership had climbed to 102, and it was able to revive the
Zeitschrift für Sexualwissenschaft (ZSW), which had appeared for one year in
1908.17

Conflict, 1908–1914

Sexologists hostile to the sex-reform movements responded almost contemptuously. Max Marcuse, commenting on the “extraordinarily extensive overlap
between the founders . . . and the leadership and influential members” of the
BfM and WHK, warned that the new organization would have “a dilettantish
stamp from day one.” He himself had been invited to its constitutive meeting
but refused to join.18
Instead, in November 1913, Marcuse and other more intellectually conservative sexologists (the term is used here and later in the chapter in its purely
comparative intellectual sense; politically most of the men in question were
liberals) formed their own, competing organization, the International Society
for Sex Research (Internationale Gesellschaft für Sexualforschung [IGS]). In
addition to Marcuse himself, its governing board included, among others, the
economist and demographer Julius Wolf; Albert Moll; Albert Freiherr von
Schrenck-Notzing, a psychiatric opponent of the theory that sexual orientation
was inborn; Hugo Sellheim, author of works attempting to define feminine
beauty in scientific terms; Eugen Steinach; and, significantly, the Berlin theology professor Reinhold Seeberg, an influential figure in the Protestant morality
movement. At its constitutive meeting, Moll announced the group’s intention to
pursue “purely scientific” work, not agitation for reform; and Julius Wolf criticized the “metaphysical tendency” of competing organizations, which presumably was a swipe at sex reform’s focus on sexual ethics.19 Later in 1914, Wolf
would reinforce the message, underlining at the organization’s first membership meeting that “what we seek is simply knowledge . . . what we don’t want
is in any way to pursue politics in this realm. . . . We are interested only in the
facts.”20
The division between these two organizations is well illustrated by their
divergent response to early research into the physiology of sex. Iwan Bloch
admitted in the introduction to the first volume of the (revived) ZSW in
1914 that “we have not yet gone beyond the earliest beginnings,” but he was
certain that the discoveries of Steinach and other medical researchers would
generate an “extraordinary broadening” of the “concepts ‘sexuality’ and ‘sexual.’” The discoveries of “sex-chemistry,” the fact that the entire human body
was suffused with “inner secretions” or “so-called hormones,” proved that
there was an “intimate connection between sexuality and the nervous system
and mental life” and confirmed the “enormous importance of the sexual for the
individual” and “as a powerful cultural principle.” In other words, the existence of the authentic sexual self and the centrality of sexuality to all human life
had now been established as concrete, physical facts. Yet Steinach himself was
a member of the IGS, and conservative sexologists were not at all troubled by
18

M. M., “Aus Vereinen, Versammlungen, Vorträgen,” SP 9 (1913): 354–355.
“Aus Vereinen, Versammlungen, Vorträgen,” SP 9 (1913): 871–874; “Aus Vereinen, Versammlungen, Vorträgen,” SP 10 (1914): 83–88 (text of Wolf’s address).

Men, Sex, and Science

251

his findings. Instead, they took his work as proof that sexual perversions were
in fact physiological pathologies and hence could and must be cured. Bloch’s
hope that the nascent science of hormones would carry sexology beyond the
“conflicts of the political or religious parties” was, in short, immediately proven
illusory.21
II. Sexology and Sex Reform, 1900–1908
Curiously enough, before the critical years between 1905 and 1908, it had not
been at all clear that this would be the case. As good monists and progressive
men of science, many sexologists were quite sympathetic to or even actively
involved in sex reform; and some would remain so throughout the prewar
years. The line between the two groups was in fact quite indistinct.
A particularly striking case was that of the Swiss psychiatrist, entomologist,
and temperance, morality, and Esperanto activist August Forel, whose The Sexual Question of 1904 was widely read and influential in Germany. In that and
lesser works published in the ensuing few years, Forel laid out a perspective that
was in most respects identical to that of the BfM. Like the sex reformers, Forel
argued that sex was the “root of life,” and the health of individual and race
was the “most sacred thing in humanity.”22 After concluding that “morality
is . . . relative” because all morality is historically, socially, and even situationally determined, he rejected the “old heritage of mysticism, dogma, fashion
and tradition,” the futility of which was proven by “our disgustingly hypocritical morality” and the “total bankruptcy of orthodox religious ethics.”23
In its place, he put a new and, he believed, scientific foundation: “Everything
sexual . . . that is qualitatively beneficial to the individual, society, and above all
the race (our offspring) is ethically positive; everything that harms it is ethically
negative; everything that neither serves nor harms it is ethically neutral.”24
Therefore, “the satisfaction of man’s sexual drive belongs among his natural
rights. Science forces us to establish this principle.”25 Forel’s views on eugenics
were as radical as those of the most extreme of the sex reformers. He favored
compulsory sterilization of the eugenically inferior and in fact even suggested
that it was “terrible that the law forces us to keep alive . . . embryos that will be
born as cretins, idiots, hydrocephalics, microcephalics and suchlike”; in future
at least parents should be allowed to direct a doctor to kill such infants “with
a gentle narcosis.”26

252

Conflict, 1908–1914

In more practical terms, Forel advocated effectively the elimination of marriage law, because “outward coercion here produces only hypocrisy, conflict
and fraud”; women must be made financially independent through the separation of assets and payment for women’s domestic labor; there should be no legal
distinction between children born in and out of wedlock; and the “social and
legal equality of women” was a “first demand” to be made on the way to creating a healthy society. Needless to say, Forel also favored votes for women.27
And he saw birth control as a way to “separate love and the satisfaction of
the sex drive from reproduction” – which would serve both eugenic and social
purposes.28 Forel thought prostitutes were mostly “pathological creatures,”
but he was an abolitionist on the grounds that “the state cannot prohibit an
adult and mentally competent person from making use of his own body” as he
saw fit.29 Homosexuality Forel found “absurd,” and he thought most homosexuals were “severe psychopaths”; but homosexuality had nothing to do with
“depravity or wickedness” and was “pretty harmless” – certainly less so than
prostitution.30
Finally, Forel’s political principles also matched those of his counterparts
in Germany. He was, he wrote in 1908 in the Sozialistische Monatshefte,
“a whole-hearted socialist,” detested German “feudalism and the militarism
and megalomania” and the dysgenic effects of war, and believed that “all
the peoples of Europe and even of the earth” should be “united in one great
nation.”31
Iwan Bloch is, in some ways, an even more telling example of the overlap
between sex reform and sexology. We have discussed the sudden shift in his
views on homosexuality in Chapter 7. Bloch made an equally radical change of
direction with respect to the women’s movement. In his two-volume study of
the sexual perversions, published in 1902–1903, Bloch had written dismissively
of “the so-called ‘women’s emancipation’” movement, which he believed made
“impossible” demands; and he had held that “the functions of the sexual apparatus attendant upon childbirth and motherhood . . . compromise any intensive
mental activity severely, indeed make it impossible” for women.32 Abolition he
considered “nichtig,” or a nullity, and merely a product of English “hypocrisy”

and the denial of the realities of sexual life; he himself advocated a state-run
system of Kasernierung.33
In The Sexual Life of Our Times (1907), in contrast, Bloch devoted sixteen
pages to an uncritical summary of Ellen Key’s ideas, which he now called
“the gospel for all those who are determined to bring love into harmony with
all the changes and advances of cultural life” in the past century. Rejecting
the “Jeremiads of the blind apostles of morality,” he believed instead that a
“radical perfection of love” was imminent; everywhere the “beginnings of a
new, more noble, more perfect configuration of sexual life” could be seen.
The “whole mendacity and infamy” of Christian morality still created much
“sexual misery.”34 But all that would be corrected by the “introduction of
free love and the new sexual morality associated with it, which sees man and
woman as two free, equal, but also mutually responsible personalities.”35 Not
surprisingly, he also embraced virtually all of the concrete proposals of the sex
reformers, with respect to family law, divorce, abolition, and so on.
Other sexologists had actually long been quite open to the ideas and aims of
the women’s and homosexual rights movements. Albert Eulenburg, for example, observed of resistance to the demands of the women’s movement that
“barbarism . . . is deeply rooted.”36 Hermann Rohleder, too, shared the sex
reformers’ belief that sexuality was the “origin of every form of progress in
all realms”; that every sexually mature person had a “right . . . to satisfaction
of his sex drive, to the exercise of his sexual individuality”; and that sex was
“an action that is of interest only to the two participants, an internal, private
matter, a priori no concern of the law.” He supported the abolition of §175,
holding that homosexuality was inborn, ineradicable, and neither pathological
nor degenerate but merely “a variety, a caprice of nature.”37 Both he and Bloch
were actively involved in the WHK.38 And the role of Richard von Krafft-Ebing
and Albert Moll in laying the conceptual foundations for the homosexual rights
movement has been examined in Chapter 7.
In fact, even some of those who would emerge later as conservative critics,
opponents, and competitors of sex reform had actually, in the years before
about 1908, been quite positive toward it. Max Marcuse was one of the
founders of the BfM; at its first meeting he had deplored the “incomprehension

and indifference with which men still today look upon the sacred struggle of
woman for her just rights.”39 Even after becoming a bitter critic of the BfM,
he continued to champion some of its central ideas – for example, that sexual
morality evolved and changed with changing times and contexts.40 Albert Moll
signed the WHK’s petition and argued already in 1897 that women should be
granted equal access to higher education and the professions as a matter of
“justice for women and with regard to the commonweal.”41 He continued to
praise the BfM and the protection of single mothers as late as 1912.42
The tone and content of the early volumes of the two leading sexological
journals reflected this sympathy. The first pages of the journal Geschlecht und
Gesellschaft in 1906 amounted virtually to a sex-reform manifesto. The editors
argued that “every social instinct and every form of sociability is built on the
biology of sex,” denounced Christian prudery and hypocrisy, and held that
the “development of the sense of individual freedom and the consciousness
of personal responsibility” in modern society meant that “tutelage in intimate
matters that concern only the individual” was no longer viable. A later article
deplored the “hatred and frenzy of persecution of some ‘apostles of decency’”
when faced with “pure, chaste nudity” (such as that of the dancer Isadora
Duncan). A third repeated Hirschfeld’s arguments regarding the fundamental
bisexuality of all people. A fourth supported coeducation as a path to “a much
more serious morality in relations between the sexes.” A fifth recommended
contraception as a way to enable early marriage, and hence avoid prostitution
and venereal disease. A sixth held that the informal premarital “relationship”
common in working-class communities both derived from “ancient Germanic
custom” and was a model for the future. A seventh argued that equal education for boys and girls would help to improve marriage, reduce immorality,
elevate the arts, and advance science, religion, international understanding,
and the global economy, asking “how much useful energy must be denied” to
social progress “because female humanity is artificially held at a low level of
knowledge?” An eighth offered a paean to sex reform as a “sacred longing for
renewal and purification.” A ninth repeated the argument that the “mysterious magnetic force that draws lovers to each other” in a true “love-match”
expressed “unconsciously the reproductive aim for the creation of ever better
crossings” and hence was superior in a eugenic or evolutionary sense.43

The sex-reform perspective continued to be well represented in later issues
as well. The third volume, in 1908, carried another manifesto for sex reform,
repeating all the usual postulates and calling for a “crusade . . . for the liberation
of love.”44 Even as late as 1914, the journal carried articles by Helene Stöcker
arguing against §175, by Rosa Mayreder observing that the existing legal
form of marriage seemed by all the evidence to be no longer “adequate to the
conditions of modern life,” and by Isaak Spier-Irving arguing that “it can no
longer be denied that the natural rights of woman in sexual life are equal to
those of the man.”45
Sexual-Probleme too was initially quite sympathetic to sex reform. Marcuse’s introductory essay in the first volume in 1908 sought to seize the
intellectual high ground by arguing that only science could solve the sexual
problem and by promising to avoid “abstract theoretical speculations” – a
thinly veiled swipe at his erstwhile colleagues in the BfM. But he went on to
offer the classic activist sex-reform agenda for the journal: to
pave the way for liberation from sexual misery and danger; refine relations
between the sexes both in and outside of marriage – help to make them happier, healthier and more honest; contribute to the reform of economic and social
defects in consequence of which asceticism, prostitution, venereal disease, perversions and other signs of degeneration must arise; help to . . . protect state and society from a further increase in the mass of anti-social and unfit individuals. . . . We
want to pursue sexual Realpolitik.46

The first substantive article in that volume announced “that any legal stipulation that hinders or constrains natural instincts . . . must be despised as a hopeless effort” and argued for the decriminalization of prostitution and unmarried
cohabitation, liberalized divorce law, and improved wages for women.47 In the
next article, reform-friendly gynecologist Max Hirsch deplored the “martyrdom with which human society in our time burdens the unmarried mother”;
advocated the “liberation of woman from physical and economic dependence,”
the use of contraception to rationalize reproduction, the legalization of abortion, and separation of property within marriage; and held that alcoholics and
the mentally ill were “unfit for reproduction.”48
Again, such arguments did not entirely disappear from the journal’s pages
in later years. In 1911, for example, Marcuse himself published a very long
Brönner, “Ehe und Entwicklungslehre,” all in GG 1 (1906): 3–4, 6, 18, 27, 74, 88–90, 100,

article in the journal opposing legislation that would further inhibit the sale
of contraceptives, on the grounds that Germany’s population was growing by
800,000–900,000 per year and that in any case the welfare of the nation was
dependent “not on the quantity but on the quality of [its] progeny.” Instead,
the state should work to reduce infant mortality among the working class,
fund better prenatal care, and introduce a system of motherhood insurance.49
Even in 1914, the journal carried an extended article that, while poking fun
at the “dilettantism” and “disputable theoretical constructions” of the BfM
leadership, nevertheless exactly replicated much of sex-reform thought and
welcomed the fact that “inherited traditions and authorities have largely lost
their guiding and persuasive power in broad social classes,” who were drifting
toward a “new faith, a new religion.”50
III. The Science of Difference: Biological Foundations of Gender Roles
Such fundamental sympathies did not, however, rule out quite bitter rhetorical
attacks. The introduction to the first volume of Sexual-Probleme, for example, implicitly labeled the BfM leadership “immature and unqualified” and
“do-gooders and naive ideologues” and announced that it would adopt “a
policy in which not feelings but experience and knowledge are decisive.”51
In the second issue, Marcuse complained that the BfM had developed into a
“special sect of the women’s movement . . . , in which the ladies talk only to
each other.”52 By 1909, he was waxing rabid, declaring that both the BfM
and the “orthodox indecency-sniffers” suffered from “thoughtless dogmatism
and arrogant narrow-mindedness,” and that Stöcker’s position was a “sexualpolitical menace to society.”53 Hirschfeld came in for a drubbing as well; he
suffered from “strong emotional affect” and was incapable of “calm objective
research and reporting.”54 The sex reformers (male and female), in short, were
irrational, emotional, unrealistic, illogical, and essentially silly. This was a view
that some others were willing to express more bluntly. Christian von Ehrenfels, for example, held the female sex reformers to be “womanish and weak,
illogical . . . mired . . . up to their ears in the moonshine romanticism of anemic

girls.”55 Of Ruth Bré in particular he found “something’s not quite right in her
upper story”; she produced merely a “jumble of errors, nonsense and manic
emotional outbursts” in a “nagging woman’s voice.”56 Alfred Klaar explained
that Ellen Key’s ideas were a “childish bit of fantasy.”57 Others writing in
Sexual-Probleme denounced female sex reformers as “spiritual prostitutes of
the lowest sort,” or as “truly womanish, that is, without any sense for logic.”58
Such comments may have reflected personal animosities generated by the
split within the BfM; and in fact there were almost no denunciations of sex
reform in Geschlecht und Gesellschaft similar to those in Sexual-Probleme.
Nevertheless, it too was not immune to the temptation to denigrate female
sex reformers’ ability to reason. In the introductory article in the first issue,
for example, the editors were careful to distance themselves from “delirium
of modern exuberance in the realm of sexuality” and from the “Amazons”
who led the sex-reform movement.59 And in 1912 the journal offered an essay
in which Bruno Meyer, a professor of art history, author of richly illustrated
coffee-table books on the female nude, and early activist in the sex-reform
movement, suggested that women really had nothing worthwhile to say about
sex; for although “men make science, and naturally know what they experience in sexual intercourse . . . [o]n the female side there is an almost complete
absence of comparable . . . experiences and observation. Women lack the practice in exercising their understanding necessary to give . . . an account of their
experience . . . in the form of a sober, truthful and exhaustive description.”60
And even men close to sex reform sometimes used a similar tone – as when Max
Rosenthal, for example, remarked on Ellen Key’s “flights of fancy” concerning
the social usefulness of love.61
Obviously, gender stereotypes played an important role in shaping such
views. The term “stereotype,” however, is not quite adequate; for such ideas
rested atop a massive edifice of theorization of the profound, pervasive, and
essential sexual differences between men and women. Fundamental to sexology
as a body of knowledge was the postulate that men’s and women’s sexuality
were radically different, and radically at odds.

258

Conflict, 1908–1914

The locus classicus for this view was Richard von Krafft-Ebing’s Psychopathia sexualis of 1886. “Without doubt,” Krafft-Ebing asserted, “the
man has a more lively sexual need than the woman. . . . Following the powerful urgings of nature, he is more aggressive and tempestuous in his wooing. . . . It’s otherwise with the woman. If she is mentally normally developed
and well-raised, her sensual desire is minimal. . . . She behaves passively.” Furthermore, the “emotional tendency of woman is monogamous, while the man
leans toward polygamy.” For men, finally, sex was an episodic interest, because
“if his desire is fulfilled, his love recedes temporarily behind other vital and
social interests.” In contrast, “the realm of sexuality has greater influence on
the consciousness of woman than on that of man. The need for love is stronger
in the former than in the latter, continuous, not episodic; but her love is more
spiritual than sensual.”62
Sexologists would repeat these four central themes – that men’s sexual drive
was stronger than women’s; that men were aggressive and women passive;
that men were polygamous and women monogamous; and that sex was a
brief episode for men but filled women’s whole lives – over and over again
for the next thirty years. Thus the prominent gynecologist Alfred Hegar, in
his 1894 study, “The Sex Drive” (“Der Geschlechtstrieb”), would argue that
the sexual instinct had two components: the drive to have intercourse (Begattungstrieb) and the drive to reproduce (Fortpflanzungstrieb), with the former
more important to male and the latter more important to female sexuality.63
Albert Moll, in 1898, divided the sexual drive into the specifically genital
drive for Detumeszenz or release (predominant in men) and the more generalized drive for Kontrektation or touch (women).64 Hugo Sellheim argued
in 1908 that men’s desire “soon takes on a particular form. He sets his eyes
on the goal, has at it directly, and takes the obstacles by storm.” Women, in
contrast, had no “primary understanding” of “male charms,” but rather only
“adaptability” – the ability to accommodate men’s sexual desires for the sake of
emotional closeness. Although once they did, “love occupies all their thoughts
and aspirations” – whereas “the man’s love recedes into the background as
soon as his thoughts are engaged with his profession.”65 Max Marcuse denied
that this difference was natural, insisting that women had, only under pressure from men, “very gradually learned to feel monogamously”; but because
he believed “men have never been forced in the same degree to emancipate
themselves from their polygamous instincts,” the outcome was the same.66

Men, Sex, and Science

259

Even men quite close to the BfM shared most of these views. August Forel
believed that men’s sex drive was “more imperative, more tempestuous and
more irresistible than that of normal women.” In contrast, “among a very
large number of women the Libido sexualis is completely absent,” although
normal women did have a “need to give themselves passively, to play the role
of the defeated, the coerced, the dominated.” And “on average woman is much
more monogamously inclined than man,” who had a “polygamous instinct.”67
Iwan Bloch contrasted the “impetuous, aggressive character of the masculine
sex drive” to woman’s “greater outward passivity” and believed nevertheless
that “woman is much more sexual than man”; indeed he wrote of her “saturation . . . with sexuality.”68 Max Rosenthal too held that the “extraordinary
difference in the . . . purely physical character of the genital systems” of men
and women “points to a difference in kind between male and female sexual feelings.”69 Even Sigmund Freud wrote in Sexual-Probleme in 1908 that
women were the “true bearers of the sexual interests of humanity.”70
Some men who occupied the gray zone between sexology and sex reform
did make one concession to their female colleagues: they conceded, as Forel
put it, that once a woman’s sexuality was awakened by a man, “it is not at all
rare that in the course of many years of marriage the relationship is reversed,
and the woman becomes more desirous than the man.”71 Bloch too believed
that women’s sexuality “develops in its full strength only after the onset of
regular sexual intercourse.” Marcuse argued that the “greater self-mastery
that women . . . are obliged . . . to exercise” was not evidence “that they have
nothing to master.” This view seems to have been growing more influential in
the years before World War I; but it was still a minority position.72
Many sexologists believed, moreover, that the sexual drives or natures of
men and women were not only different but incompatible. In fact, the image of
the struggle or even war between the sexes was ubiquitous in sexological discourse. Thus, for example, one author observed in the opening line of an essay
published in Geschlecht und Gesellschaft in 1907 that “since the beginning of
the world man and woman have been at war. . . . The sexes are incomprehensible to each other.” Hans Adner held that this conflict was only an apparent one,
because actually it only built up the “drive to combine and resolve the antithesis in love.”73 Others were not so optimistic. Christian von Ehrenfels believed
that the instincts of men and women “necessarily clash with one another.

Conflict, 1908–1914

Reconciliation is unthinkable.”74 The Munich bohemian and dandy, antiSemite, misogynist, and popular novelist Oscar A. H. Schmitz remarked in
1910 that “I know that I speak here as a man, with all the one-sidedness of a
man . . . but womb and brain” – by which he meant woman and man – “are
enemies . . . peace and compromise are impossible. . . . There can only be domination of the one by the other.”75 Iwan Bloch too remarked on the “basic,
deeply rooted antipathy between the sexes that grows out of their deep heterogeneity, out of the impossibility of really understanding each other.”76 Max
Rosenthal was more straightforward: “Love is . . . war . . . , stubborn, dogged,
bitter and embittering.”77
The male sexologists and sex reformers therefore tended to see sexual intercourse as a fundamentally hostile act, an act of violence committed by men
against women. In its most benign form, this was expressed in an almost playful
use of metaphors – as when, for example, one author compared sperm entering
the womb to “bold conquerors,” “brazen conquerors,” or even a “conquering
people.” Others asserted that both men and women found the game of sexual domination and surrender exciting.78 Other views were more ambivalent.
Max Rosenthal observed in 1904 that “love and its preliminaries often take
on, in jest or in earnest, the forms of warfare.”79 One article in Geschlecht und
Gesellschaft in 1908 argued that sexual intercourse was a “combat between
man and woman, even if only play-acted combat.”80 Robert Michels reported
in 1911 that it was often difficult for a man to tell “whether the resistance
that the girl opposes to his desire is genuine or fake”; the “boundary between
the legitimate exploitation of a situation and a criminal action” was hazy.81
And one south German police doctor argued in 1908 that most women’s lack
of interest in sex was merely feigned, and that husbands should not “take the
resistance and whimpering of newly married women too seriously” but rather
proceed to “enjoy the right of domination, which the apparently recalcitrant
woman [actually] gladly grants him.”82
Still more negative views were quite common. Albert Eulenburg, for example, stated bluntly that “sexual satisfaction through intercourse is bound up

with cruelty.”83 And many sexologists were particularly fascinated with what
they imagined as the violence of “the wedding night,” as they commonly called
it – women’s first experience of sexual intercourse. Thus the gynecologist Enoch
Kisch, author of the massive tome The Sexual Life of Woman (1904), held that
“brutality” was “more or less inherent” in the act of “defloration” and that the
ignorance of men regarding women’s sexuality was so great that in many cases
“one can speak of the rape” on the wedding night. Essays in Geschlecht und
Gesellschaft in 1907 and 1908 argued that defloration was often a “violent
act” that destroyed the sexual foundation of marriage at its outset, or that
most cases of female “frigidity” could be traced back to the “brutal violence
of the man” on that night.84
In all three of these latter cases, the authors were arguing for greater sensitivity among men to the different sexual rhythms and needs of women; one in
fact argued that between 10 and 40 percent of women never reached orgasm
and that they had “a right to a change in this situation,” which would require
only adequate sex education and a little bit of “adaptability in the man.”85
More frequently, however, the sexologists argued that their discovery of the
nature of the sexual differences between men and women provided a scientific foundation for the double standard of sexual morality. Thus Richard von
Krafft-Ebing argued that “natural drive and social position bring the man easily to fall, while the woman is granted much protection,” and that adultery
by women was therefore “endlessly more morally serious.”86 And Hermann
Rohleder argued in 1907 that women had a duty to be more disciplined in
sexual matters because “the fetus is entrusted to the woman alone” – or, as
Rohleder put it, “nature itself” (and not “men’s brutality”) had given her
greater sexual responsibility.87
Such views were not universal among the sexologists. Paul Näcke in fact
explicitly and vehemently rejected the double standard, arguing that girls
should be forgiven their “missteps” just as easily as were boys.88 Albert Moll
rejected the double standard equally clearly, as a product of “men’s lust for
domination.”89
Yet defenses of the double standard and of prostitution in the sexological
journals were sometimes strikingly explicit. The first volume of Geschlecht und

Gesellschaft in 1906, for example, carried an essay arguing that, given the facts
of sexual difference, prostitution was necessary “in order to occupy the young
men whose income is not yet sufficient” to support a family. As for the married
man, “why shouldn’t he . . . have a little bit of freedom to do what he will
with what his wife can’t use?”90 Bruno Meyer argued in the 1912 volume
of the same journal that it was right to judge prostitutes and their clients by
different standards, because men were primarily “professional beings,” whereas
in women “the sexual being stands very clearly at the forefront,” and that it was
“contrary to reason” to judge men and women who committed adultery by the
same standard, because only the wife could bring an “heir of foreign descent
into the marital union.”91 And numerous contributions to both Geschlecht und
Gesellschaft and Sexual-Probleme simply offered the theory that prostitutes
were morally or mentally defective and “born whores.”92
The debate over the dangers of abstinence played an important role in such
defenses of the double standard. Opinion among sexologists was divided. Moll,
Hegar, Eulenburg, Näcke, and others thought that abstinence was both possible and harmless. Marcuse was the most fervent advocate of the opposing
view, but he was supported by many others – including, for example, Hermann
Rohleder, who believed prolonged abstinence could cause sexual neurasthenia,
hysteria, or satyriasis, and Anton Nyström, who reported cases in which abstinence caused nervousness and lack of energy, impotence and atrophy of the
testes, hypochondria, and other disorders.93 One contributor to Geschlecht und
Gesellschaft in 1906 even reported (of course on the basis of unspecified “experience”) that abstinence led to “feminization” of men and “masculinization”
of women, and ultimately to homosexuality.94
The discussion of abstinence was closely bound up with that on the dangers of masturbation. Here again opinion was divided. August Forel was
unusually sanguine, arguing that the dangers of “moderate” masturbation
had been “unbelievably exaggerated”; and Eulenburg and Näcke more or
less concurred.95 But the foremost expert, Hermann Rohleder, believed that
masturbation could be terribly harmful. It demanded “colossal labor of the
imagination” and so delivered a “shock to the whole nervous system”; it could

weaken the memory and undermine the ability to work and was conducive to
feelings of shame and remorse, depression, melancholy, cramps, convulsions,
hysteria, palpitations, diarrhea, twitching eyelids, sensitivity to light, hypochondria, panic attacks, dishonesty, hypocrisy, weakness of will, unemployment,

even epilepsy and mental illness. In short, masturbation was a threat to the

that although moderate masturbation was harmless, excess could generate all
the ills Rohleder listed plus egoism, hard-heartedness, poor eyesight, frigidity
in women, and sexual perversions, including “pseudo-homosexuality.”97
Whatever the precise details of these debates and whatever the nuances of
the positions taken in them, the implicit message of a sizable grouping of the
medical sexologists was clear: that men needed to have sexual intercourse, and
therefore their access to women’s bodies had to be preserved.
The most striking instance of this project was the discussion in sexological
and sex-reform circles of the idea that Europeans needed to abandon their
(superficially) monogamous sexual order and embrace some institutionalized
form of polygamy – or rather polygyny – instead. The most influential advocate
of this idea was Christian von Ehrenfels, a professor of philosophy in Prague
who made the case for polygyny in a barrage of articles and books published
between 1902 and 1910. Von Ehrenfels was actually a rather sensitive soul
who was thoroughly disgusted with the prevailing sexual culture among men
and appreciative of the cultural benefits of monogamy. But he held that this
cultural advance had come at a high, and no longer sustainable, biological
cost. By ensuring that most men – hence also inferior ones – reproduced, it was
eroding the biological quality of the European population.98 It also lowered the
birthrate, and so put Europe at a numerical disadvantage in the coming global
geopolitical and economic conflict with the polygamous Chinese. Von Ehrenfels
feared particularly the prospect of a Japanese conquest of China, which would
create an unstoppable juggernaut – “400 million healthy, clever, wily coolies –
virtuosi of reproduction – under the leadership of a military power of the first
order.” But even short of that, the success of Chinese workers in the global
labor market would eventually bring about “the complete Mongolization of
the whole population.”99

Conflict, 1908–1914

In short, the “biological indispensability of a sexual morality differentiated
by sex” was clear. Women should continue to be monogamous; men should be
polygynous. This would guarantee “virile selection,” by making it possible to
limit reproductive rights to only the most courageous, smartest, and strongest
men; and it would also guarantee adequate numbers, by making use of the
reproductive capacities of a maximum number of women.100
Von Ehrenfels argued, however, that such a system would have innumerable
more immediate benefits as well. The “demand for a ‘unitary morality’ for both
sexes” was a “fateful misconception,” because the whole “‘raison d’être’ of the
masculine sex per se” was to serve evolution by competing to impregnate as
many women as possible.101 Monogamy was in fact “that variety of sexual life
that . . . takes the needs and capacities of woman one-sidedly into account, at
the expense of those of the man”; its institutionalization was an “abnormal
state,” unnatural and unsustainable in the long term.102 Concretely, it had
obliged European men to create the double standard, prostitution, and all the
attendant evils, because “the polygynous instincts of the man cannot be decreed
away by any moral commandment.”103 It explained, too, why “in marriage
the man demands the subordination of the woman under his will” – as a form
of compensation for the violence he was doing to his own sexual selfhood.
And all of these ills had given rise to the understandable but unreasonable
demands of feminists.104 The “property-fanaticism” of many men and the
predatory excesses of capitalism were also expressions of men’s “unsatisfied
sex drive.” And because men in the monogamous family naturally focused on
their own children and wanted to pass on their wealth to them, monogamy
underlay the distribution of wealth according to privilege rather than merit –
which, inevitably, gave rise to revolutionary socialism as a very foolish but
understandable reaction.105
Von Ehrenfels developed a concrete set of proposals on the basis of these
ideas. European society must first of all exclude a large proportion of men from
reproduction – those who were not financially successful and thus could not
afford to support children, and/or those who were not found fit for military service. Because these men could not simply be forced to endure lifelong celibacy,
however, it would also be necessary to create a recognized and respected caste
of “courtesans” to serve their sexual needs. These women would live in communal, all-female households.106 For those men who were deemed worthy of

Men, Sex, and Science

265

reproduction and the women who bore their children, von Ehrenfels proposed
the creation of a new form of sexual relationship, the “reproductive marriage”
or “matriarchal marriage.” The women in these marriages, too, would live in
all-female communal households with their children – because one did not want
to create an “intimate, individual bond of love” between fathers and their children that would tempt the former to limit the number of their progeny in order
that each should have a larger inheritance.107 By dividing domestic labor among
a large number of women, moreover, these communal households would also
achieve much greater efficiency than the monogamous nuclear family.108 This in
turn would permit perhaps half of all women, including mothers, to undertake
professional careers, creating a massive new economic and cultural potential
while at the same time providing enormous opportunities for personal development and satisfaction for women.109 Husbands would visit their wives from
time to time, make child support payments, and have a right to make collaborative decisions in and to “oversee” the raising of their children. Wives would be
bound to sexual fidelity to these husbands, whereas men would be free to form
as many such marriages as they could afford; but regardless of the duration of
the marriage, men would remain financially responsible for all their children
until they reached adulthood.110
Von Ehrenfels’s plan was not the loopiest on the intellectual market at the
time. It was at least rivaled by Willibald Hentschel’s project for the creation
of “breeding-grounds for a heroic humanity.” Hentschel believed that “lifelong monogamous marriage has proven to be an ineffective method of racial
higher breeding”; that the “Germanic-Aryan” race was degenerating; and that
“Christian marriage has to go if we still want to think seriously about saving
our nation.” His answer was to create rural colonies whose initial population
would consist of 100 men and 1,000 women each. Here the men would live in
collective households and the women in individual huts, and the two would be
joined only in temporary marriages, which would end “with the sure beginning
of pregnancy” so that the husband could get on with impregnating his next
wife.111

Conflict, 1908–1914

Both von Ehrenfels and Hentschel published first in journals devoted to race
hygiene and Nordic racial theory – the Archiv für Rassen- und Gesellschaftsbiologie (ARGB) and the Politisch-Anthropologische Revue (PAR). But the
proposition that men were actually by nature polygamous was virtually ubiquitous in sexological discourse. It should therefore not be surprising that Marcuse granted von Ehrenfels plenty of space in Sexual-Probleme – including five
essays in the first volume of the journal, almost one-eighth of its total length.
He also published a blistering response in which Bruno Meyer excoriated von
Ehrenfels as a “breeding-fanatic” and a “race-fear freak”; but clearly Marcuse
himself did not regard von Ehrenfels’s ideas as indiscussable.112 Nor was he
alone; in fact, von Ehrenfels was widely respected, and his ideas were widely
discussed. Sigmund Freud began his own essay in the 1908 volume of SexualProbleme with a reference to an “important train of thought” in von Ehrenfels’s
1907 book on “sexual ethics” and invited him to speak to the Vienna Psychoanalytic Society.113 One contributor to the journal in 1910 precisely replicated
von Ehrenfels’s argument in favor of recognizing the value of the “polygamous
instinct in men.”114 Another, in 1913, regarded monogamy as “the consequence of blackmail committed by women exploiting a temporary condition
of diminished responsibility in the man” in the early stages of heterosexual
love.115 In the first volume of Geschlecht und Gesellschaft, Friedrich Erhard
observed that “nature shows clearly enough that . . . the man requires more
than one woman,” because men were more sexually excitable and because
women “definitively cease at about the age of 45 years to be desirable and a
sexual creature . . . the man, in contrast, twenty years later.”116 Another essay
in the same year found that the tribes of ancient Germany and Scandinavia had
practiced polygamy and argued for a “return to ancestral virtues.”117 Isaak
Spier-Irving held up instead the ancient Hebrew practice of polygyny as the
model for modern Germans.118 And even some men close to the BfM were
sympathetic. Iwan Bloch conceded in 1907 that “racial biology, if it really
wants to achieve ‘breeding successes,’” would have to follow von Ehrenfels in
“declaring polygamy desirable in certain cases.”119 August Forel supported the
notion that men were “driven to have sex with as many women as possible and
to beget as many children as possible.”120
