IV. Women, Sex, and Horror
Fantasies like those of von Ehrenfels and Hentschel, in which men got to reproduce without having to live with women, can be seen as part of a powerful
current of outright misogyny in sexological thought. In this of course they
merely echoed developments in Central European culture more broadly; for
the period around the turn of the century saw the publication of a number of virulently misogynistic – and quite widely read – works, most of
which purported to be based on modern biomedical science. The message
of all the misogynist texts of the period was fundamentally the same: that
woman’s sole purpose is reproduction, and that therefore she is contemptible.
The most emblematic of these texts was Paul Möbius’s rant, On the Physiological Feeble-Mindedness of Woman (1900), which argued that women
were “intermediate between a child and a man,” with smaller and less welldeveloped brains, driven by instincts that made them “animal-like, dependent,
confident and cheerful,” suggestible, impulsive, and gossipy. All these characteristics, Möbius believed, derived from women’s role in reproduction: bearing
and then caring for children was stultifying work, and therefore “female feeblemindedness is not only present, but necessary.”121 Sex reform was good evidence: Ellen Key was “without doubt a very competent woman in her way, and
look what ghastly things she’s scribbled about love and marriage.” As for her
colleagues, they indulged in “Darwinist enthusiasms” and waxed lyrical about
“communion of souls and other silliness.”122 Otto Weininger’s Sex and Character, published in 1903, recycled most of what Möbius had already said.123
Woman, Weininger believed, is not a subject but an object; women have no
self, no “I,” no Eigenwert (value in and of themselves), no soul. Accordingly,
they have no capacity for logic, morality, honor, genius, honesty, or action, no
free will, no love, and no shame.124 They exist only as sexual objects; women
are “nothing but sexuality” or, more simply still, “nothing.” Their only purpose and aim is “coitus” (or “procuring” coitus). They are given meaning,
identity, indeed existence only by sex, by a man, in fact by “the phallus.”125
“Only when the man becomes sexual does woman come into existence”; or,
in other words, “only when Something becomes Nothing can Nothing become

pp. V, 8, 9, 10, 14.
122 Ibid., pp. 14, 17, VII, 11.
123 For Möbius’s quite contemptuous response, see Paul Möbius, Geschlecht und Unbescheidenheit (Halle: Marhold, 1904). See Susan C. Anderson, “Otto Weininger’s Masculine
Utopia,” German Studies Review 19 (1996) or Matthias Wolfes, “Otto Weininger: ‘Geschlecht
und Charakter’: Das Werk und seine Wirkung,” Historische Mitteilungen 13 (2000):
76–93.
124 Otto Weininger, Geschlecht und Charakter: Eine prinzipielle Untersuchung (Vienna: Wilhelm
Braumüller, 1925), pp. 234, 253, 248.
125 Ibid., pp. 108, 393, 340, 332, 396.

268

Conflict, 1908–1914

Something.” Thus, woman was “man’s guilt become flesh”; woman is “sin, as
a possibility in the man.”126
Mainstream sexologists were less extreme; but many of them shared the
assumption that women were by nature and of necessity intellectually inferior
to men. Again, even many female sex reformers – such as Ellen Key – thought
of women primarily as mothers and creatures of feeling rather than intellect.
But they thought motherhood to be of transcendent importance, and hence
sacred. Many of the sexologists were content merely to point out, as Albert
Moll did in 1912, that “great new achievements in the realms of science, art
and technology are almost all exclusively thanks to the masculine sex,” and
that where that was not the case, the women in question were generally so masculine that “one can say without further ado that she was not a woman.”127
Iwan Bloch believed that men and women were “different, but equally valuable”; but his discussion of what women were really like consisted almost
entirely of unfavorable comparisons with men. Women were suggestible, emotive, excitable, tired easily, and tended toward religion rather than rationality;
they were “more monotone and conservative” rather than “variable and progressive” and were “much more . . . sexual than the man.”128 The problem of
woman’s emancipation was this: “How can the development and perfection of
her higher nature be achieved without too much compromising and obscuring
her peculiar character as a sexual being?”129 For Bloch, in other words, what
was specific to women as sexual beings was not “high.” Implicitly, “high”
meant “male.” Max Rosenthal too believed that men “are able to think more
critically and deeply,” whereas women were “more ‘emotive’”; women were
“not only more stubbornly conservative, reactionary if you will; they are also
less imaginative.”130 Hermann Rohleder remarked in passing that only “people
who think more deeply” had a well-developed moral sense, “which explains
why the man, mentally superior to woman, has a higher morality.”131
The sexological journals sometimes printed rather crass versions of such
arguments. One review in Geschlecht und Gesellschaft in 1910, for example,
critiqued a work that argued that women were subhuman, concluding that
the fact “that the physical and mental capacities of the man in general exceed
those of the woman probably no one will dispute” but that this was no reason to deny women’s “membership in the human race.”132 And in 1913 the
journal carried an article that held that the influence of the “sexual glands” on
126

269

“mental processes” was stronger in women than in man, that women’s brains
were starved of blood by the demands of their reproductive apparatus, and that
as a result women had only mimetic intelligence and remained “their whole
lives long big children.”133
Obviously, then, contempt for women was quite widespread among male
sexologists. Fear of women’s sexuality, however, was certainly no less common. This fear was expressed in various forms. Among the most common was
that women would exploit sexual difference to gain power over men. Thus
Bruno Meyer believed “that women misuse their better capacity for life without sexual intercourse to keep men ‘dangling’ and to bring them into shameful
subjection.”134 Another author observed in Geschlecht und Gesellschaft in
1913 that woman’s “passivity” was “the best and most successful weapon
with which to make the man submissive to her wishes.”135 Both merely echoed
Krafft-Ebing, who had remarked that “the weakness of the man with respect
to the woman lies in the power of his sexual needs.”136
On the other hand, many men also feared that women were too sexual. Max
Marcuse, for example, believed that “so-called frigid women” could actually
achieve sexual satisfaction “in coitus arbitrarily drawn out by the man – to the
great ‘delight’ of his wife and with great injury to his own nervous system.”137
Max Rosenthal found that extramarital sex was the result of men’s “stronger
sexual nature” and their “brutality” regarding sex; but “if we ask who is to
blame for it,” the answer was “the obliging cooperation and the easy venality
of the female sex in general.”138 Bruno Meyer fantasized about the heartless
woman who “submits to the foreign conqueror” and “laughs with her subjugator” about her “cuckolded dummy” of a husband. Others ground their
teeth over the sexual curiosity of young German women about visitors to
Germany from Africa, the Middle East, or Asia. Max Marcuse believed that
it was a “fact of experience . . . that members of an alien, particularly often
precisely an . . . ‘inferior’ race exercise an extraordinarily strong influence on
women.”139
Such fears became increasingly intense in the last years before World War I.
A striking instance is Isaak Spier-Irving’s discussion in Sexual-Probleme in
1913 of the character of Lulu in Frank Wedekind’s play Erdgeist and a number
of similar female figures in drama and the daily press. These “Lulu-figures,”
he observed, illustrated the “sinister influence of the purely animal-feminine

on the man.” A woman could subvert a man’s intelligence, humiliate him,
“wear him down, diminish him, make out of a spiritual hero a miserable,
whimpering weakling and knave. . . . She has been given by nature the power
to be desirable, and this weapon is stronger than all reason and all the mental
superiority of men.” Such characters could be found throughout literature and
history; there were “Lulu-characters everywhere the eye roves.” Education and
tradition, he believed, forced most women to hide their sexual desire; “‘Lulu’
may be pathological, but a bit of pathology lurks in the feminine soul.”140
Another author warned in Geschlecht und Gesellschaft in the same year that
“no woman . . . stands so high that she does not carry within her a faint, even
if imperceptible taint of the whore.”141 Max Marcuse believed that “woman
is by nature an exhibitionist.”142 Oscar A. H. Schmitz, in 1914, even found
that “if not contained, women’s sexual nature” was “a raging torrent, which,
without firm banks, floods everything.”143
A particularly odd instance of such fears was the discussion of children’s testimony in sexual abuse cases. For although they classified attraction to children
as a form of perversion, there was a very clear preference among the sexologists
for seeing the children involved in such cases not as victims but as perpetrators.
Albert Moll, for example, believed that men almost never escaped conviction
in such cases but were mostly innocent.144 Otto Adler believed one could only
understand the problem of child sexual abuse if one knew “what a gift for lying
sensually precocious children already have and how well they know how to
act.”145 And in addressing the arrest of a large ring of pederasts in Breslau in
1913, Sexual-Probleme quoted a newspaper report to the effect that “not the
girls but the men were the victims.”146 Such assertions were commonplace in
sexology.
And yet, it was not only women’s sexuality that seemed dangerous to the
sexologists; for they regarded sexuality per se as dangerous. Discussion of the
potential dangers of masturbation is one example. But one sexologist or another
found almost any sexual practice to be dangerous and disturbing. Alfred Hegar
warned that “frequent copulation” could “not be borne . . . in the long run without injury.”147 Albert Moll wrote of “how powerful the organic shock” of the
“process of detumescence” was; he reported that “particularly in men . . . death
has been . . . observed to be a direct consequence of intercourse” and that “not

seldom the onset of epilepsy has been reported” (although he went on to admit
that such disasters were “exceptions”).148 Max von Gruber, a professor of
hygiene in Munich, reported that “the man’s nervous system suffers with particular frequency” due to “sexual intemperance.”149 Christian von Ehrenfels
believed that “quite a few” men planted “the seeds of their death” through
sexual excess during their honeymoons.150 Hermann Rohleder believed
that sexual excess caused pathologies such as masturbation, pederasty, obsessive sexual daydreaming, inability to concentrate, and job loss.151 Contraception – particularly coitus interruptus, but also the use of condoms – was made
responsible for all kinds of ills, too, including phrenocardia (imaginary chest
pains), neurasthenia, hysteria, phobias, panic attacks, erectile dysfunction, back
pain, moodiness, obsessional thinking, melancholy, paranoia, headaches, memory loss, asthmatic complaints, premature aging, and death.152
Occasionally it was clear in fact that many of the sexologists found their
own sexual drives puzzling and disturbing. Christian von Ehrenfels’s whole
elaborate vision of a sex-segregated reproductive order was a response to his
discovery of the crudity and animalism of men’s (and it appears his own) sexual
culture. Within even “relatively sensitive men,” he found, there lurked a “different, lower, animalistic personality.”153 Iwan Bloch believed that men hired
prostitutes because of a secret desire “to renounce and abase oneself through
submission to an inferior creature.”154 Rohleder was “ashamed” to confess
that most people had the urge only to have sex, not to make babies; and he
found it troubling that even “the greatest genius, the most important personality comes down from the heights in sexual pleasure and is in that moment like
an . . . animal.”155 Bruno Meyer believed that the “unparalleled sensations of
pleasure” of intercourse were there to help people overcome the “undeniable
nastiness of the sex act,” which was fundamentally an “uncomfortable, disgusting, shameless business.”156 And Albert Eulenburg felt that after sex it was
natural for a man to feel “disgust” and “revulsion” and a desire to be cruel to
his partner, because he “experiences it . . . as a form of shame and humiliation
that he has let himself be overwhelmed by sexual pressure in this way.”157

Conflict, 1908–1914

As the language of these passages often makes clear, however, even where
men subjected themselves to such self-examination, it was clear who was
ultimately to blame for their unease. This is not surprising, because, again,
almost all the sexologists to one degree or another defined women as sex,
and men as intellect. The sexologists’ distaste for and fear of sexuality in
general, then, cannot really be separated from their distaste for and fear of
women.
V. The Women’s Movement and Sexological Reaction, 1909–1914
The sexological discussion of all these issues was complex, fragmented, and
diverse; on each of them multiple divergent and often conflicting positions
can be found in the periodical and monographic literature. The sexologists’
discourse ranged from the relatively mild and nuanced (Iwan Bloch and
Hermann Rohleder) to the extraordinarily crass (Bruno Meyer and Christian
von Ehrenfels). And the foregoing pages will have made clear that the distinction between sexology and sex reform is to some extent artificial, because a
number of influential men were important participants in both discussions. In
aggregate, however, it is difficult not to see a simple message in the thinking of
most of these men: they didn’t like women much but wanted to have sex with
whatever females they could get their hands on, often in a manner just shy of
brutal; they didn’t want to have to deal with a lot of feelings and emotional
folderol about it; and they found the whole subject rather unpleasant. Nothing
could be further from Helene Stöcker’s dream of heterosexual love as “the
wonderfully harmonious union of all physical and mental energies” and “the
crown of life.”158
As the role of the women’s movements in public discussions of sexuality
grew in the decade before World War I, this contrast grew ever more radical.
Backed further and further into a political and intellectual corner, the sexologists collectively became increasingly crude in their denigration and fear of
women. The response of sexology to the women’s movement more broadly is
revealing in this respect and helps to put the discussion of sexual difference
in context. For as women made growing (if still very modest) gains, overall
the responses of sexologists grew increasingly sour. From about 1909 or 1910,
both major sexological journals began to carry a growing number of articles
skeptical of women’s emancipation.
Vanselow’s Geschlecht und Gesellschaft was relatively circumspect and
never devoted a great deal of space to explicit denunciations of women’s
emancipation. By 1910, however, a reactionary note began to creep into its
pages. In that year, for example, the journal’s supplement dismissed feminist
views on the question of whether women teachers who got married should

be fired, because those who complained were “women who feel just as masculine as they outwardly appear.”159 In 1911 and 1912, the journal carried
multiple articles defending the double standard and implicitly critiquing, for
example, the IAF. In the 1913 volume Robert Hessen, author of numerous popular pamphlets championing a “natural” sexual order, characterized feminists
as suffering from “systematic mendacity”; their “ugliness and petty egotism”
were a “painful warning sign of national decline.”160 Another author in the
same volume found the “problematic woman” to be “torture on the nerves”;
and he defined as problematic “the modern woman as such, so far as she participates in . . . ‘women’s emancipation.’” Women “have at bottom no mental
life, rather they are merely a complex of passions and feelings”; feminists were
all suffering from “anomalies in the area of their sexual life . . . , repressed or
excessive sexuality.”161 Isaak Spier-Irving found that the English suffragettes
were “women without inhibitions” whose “tricks” had “to be explained as
diverted sexuality” that produced “fanatical hatred” for men; for “otherwise
the actions of the suffragettes simply cannot be understood.”162
Sexual-Probleme was even more vehement. In the early years, its critiques
of women’s emancipation were relatively moderate, often presented in “yes,
but” form – yes, there should be “economic, social and political equality for
women,” for example, but education for girls should not train “competitors
for men in all areas of endeavor” and “stunt the psychical-physical peculiarity of feminine nature.”163 By 1913 and 1914, in contrast, Sexual-Probleme
devoted a substantial proportion of its pages to openly vituperative attacks
on the women’s movement. Two themes dominated these attacks: that the
women’s movement sought to dominate men, not emancipate women, and
that it was un-German. Max Marcuse held, for example, that “it is everywhere evident that the goal of the feminist struggle, which has nothing against
discrimination against men, is not the achievement of equal rights but of privileges for women.”164 Hans Fehlinger found that the new forms of women’s
work attracted “a striking number of virile types” who were more typical of
British than German women.165 Another author urged German men not to
engage in “self-castration” by permitting “subversive elements” to introduce
English-style marital cruelty and divorce laws into their country. August Hallermeyer warned that the “weaknesses of the female psyche,” conditioned by
menstruation and pregnancy, “could become the ruin of the nation” and that

the “tyranny of women in America demonstrates this danger with frightful
clarity. . . . The flip-side of the emancipation of woman is the enslavement of
man.”166
Shared fear of and contempt for feminism did not reconcile sexology with
the morality campaigners in these years. In fact, many sexologists regarded
Christians and their repressive sexual morality as the real authors of the sexual misery of their times. Max Marcuse believed in 1909, for example, that
there was an “intimate relationship between piety and sexual debauchery”;
and Isaak Spier-Irving warned in Geschlecht und Gesellschaft in 1910 that
“secretiveness” in sexual matters merely steered children “onto the path of the
forbidden and prohibited.”167 Nevertheless, in the last years before the war, a
broader sense of moral crisis similar to that prevalent among the morality campaigners did creep into sexological discourse. Thus in 1910, Sexual-Probleme
carried an article in which the race theorist Heinrich Driesmans claimed that
“the ‘crimes against morality’ of ancient times were childish games compared
to the cynically refined indulgences of our day.”168 In the same journal in
1912, the social reformer and cultural critic Victor Noack warned that “a
sadism packaged in sentimental excess . . . speaks ever more brutally” in popular film, and that “in most of the awful ‘blockbusters’ violence against women
is exploited for thrills.” In the following year, Bruno Meyer deplored the “cinema plague” as a “social danger.”169 In 1913, Geschlecht und Gesellschaft
carried an extraordinary rant explaining that capitalism’s commodification of
absolutely everything was at bottom sexual, and that the modern department
store was the “most poetic . . . revelation of modern eroticism” because most
salesgirls sold sex on the side and the masses of women who shopped there
were motivated by “sexual covetousness.”170
In fact, some sexologists began to suggest that public discussion of sexuality was itself fundamentally objectionable. Thus, for example, Otto Adler
found in 1909 that although the development of sexual science was imperative, “the sexual question is . . . discussed a little bit too much in the general
public.”171 In the same year Paul Näcke deplored the fact that Iwan Bloch’s
Sexual Life of Our Times had sold 15,000 copies in one year, a figure that he
believed showed that the book was serving not “real thirst for knowledge” but
“common salaciousness.”172 One skeptic even complained in Sexual-Probleme

Men, Sex, and Science

275

in 1910 that discussion of sexual problems was increasingly dominated by “the
sensation-seeking cultural rabble.”173
One important feature of this broader backlash, finally, was of course a
marked turn toward homophobia among some sexologists in the wake of the
scandal trials of 1907–1909. Albert Moll, for example, after being in the 1890s
one of the architects of the theory that homosexuality was inborn and should
not be punished, argued by 1908 that many heterosexual acts were legally suppressed too, and that there was no reason why “qualitatively abnormal” desires
should be treated differently.174 Isaak Spier-Irving, writing in Geschlecht und
Gesellschaft in 1912, reported that “a lesbian high tide has set in over Germany
and indeed all of civilized Europe” and was threatening to “sweep aside natural
activities with irresistible force.” In this crisis, all intimate female friendships
were “highly suspect.”175 Bruno Meyer argued in Geschlecht und Gesellschaft
in 1909 (while still advocating the repeal of §175) that homosexuality was
“always the result of a sexual life in which either abstinence or excess have
dulled or over-excited natural feelings and thereby led to un-natural lusts.”176
In 1911 he suggested that lesbians were responsible for the “sexual misery of
men,” the “growth of prostitution” and venereal disease, and the decline in the
birthrate.177
The connection between these two trends is obvious. Male sex scientists were
driven by the successes of the women’s movements more and more to emphasize
sexual difference rooted in physiology or anatomy, and hence to argue that it
was essential and unchangeable. There was, therefore, less and less room in their
conceptual world for people whose desires jumped the (to them) unbridgeable
gap between male and female. Men could not desire men because, if they did,
they would be like women. Homosexuality was impermissible because men
and women could not possibly understand each other.
VI. Race and Death in Sexology
Commitment to the unalterable importance of sexual difference was not the
only respect in which sexologists denied the unity of the human species, however. Racism too played an important and growing role in sexological discussions.
A kind of offhand racial prejudice was certainly present in some earlier sexology texts. Thus, for example, Alfred Hegar believed that Africans, Asians,

173

Erich Liliethal, “Das Sexualproblem beim Fünfuhrtee,” SP 6 (1910): 802, 804.

Conflict, 1908–1914

and workers had stronger libidos than did white people; Iwan Bloch, in his
earlier writings on sexual perversions, was convinced that the Middle East
was the “worst breeding-ground” of homosexuality.178 And August Forel was
comprehensively and vulgarly racist, asserting at various points in The Sexual Question that Jews were oversexed, commercial, and therefore deeply
involved in the sex trade; that Africans were characterized by “mental inferiority . . . unbridled sexual passion” and “cruel barbarism”; and that the aim
of future racial breeding programs must be to give contraceptive knowledge
to “the sick, the incompetent, the idiots, the bad, the inferior races” while
teaching superior people to breed generously.179
On this issue, too, however, sexology was quite divided. Albert Eulenburg,
for example, warned already in 1896 against “delusional and useless play”
at “prophecies of the end of the world” regarding the “Slavic or Mongolian
racial high tide” or “American Yankeedom.”180 Max Marcuse, although he
was very interested in Christian von Ehrenfels’s ideas about polygyny, distanced himself from the latter’s obsession with the “Yellow Peril.”181 In 1912,
Marcuse devoted almost sixty pages of his journal to rebutting anti-Semitic
beliefs regarding marriages between Jewish and non-Jewish Germans; along
the way he comprehensively demolished contemporary racial theory, concluding that it “has nothing in common with science.”182 And in the following
year, in the context of a heated public debate over sexual relations in Germany’s
colonies, Sexual-Probleme carried articles poking fun at the idea of racial purity
as a product of extraordinary historical ignorance; deploring the misogynistic
outpourings of one race theorist as “grotesque distortions”; and citing approvingly the view of a leading anthropologist that Africans, Asians, and Europeans constituted together “a complete and self-contained unity, the human
species.”183
Nevertheless, sexologists defined their discipline primarily as a biological
science; and sexology therefore did engage actively with racist theory, and vice
versa. The most obvious example, again, is Marcuse’s decision to publish the
views of Christian von Ehrenfels, whose earlier articles appeared in ARGB and
PAR. Although primarily focused on other issues, those journals did regularly
publish discussions of sexuality; and in that intellectual context von Ehrenfels’s
ideas were certainly not outlandish. In 1909, for example, the PAR carried an
article by the French race theorist Georges Vacher de Lapouge that rehearsed

many of the same arguments von Ehrenfels had made.184 Willibald Hentschel’s
ideas, too, were made available to the broader public primarily in the PAR and
the ARGB.185
Nor were von Ehrenfels’s essays in Sexual-Probleme the only or last example of slippage in the other direction. In 1913, for example, Sexual-Probleme
carried an article in which August Hallermeyer, who was active on the radical right-wing anti-Semitic fringe in Munich, warned that Europeans were
degenerating due to “indiscriminate mixing with inferior races,” wars, the
welfare state, the humanitarian ideal of Christianity, democracy, “pleasureseeking,” the “over-valuing of personal comfort,” and capitalism. Hallermeyer
warned that soon the “coolies” would “be firmly established in all four quarters of the globe and given their limitless reproduction soon overrun all other
races,” including “the most highly developed, the Aryan race.” He recommended “selective-breeding measures on a large scale” that would make the
Aryans so superior that it would be “easy to dominate the earth and hold the
other races in check.” Hallermeyer also recommended the abolition of parliamentary government and the formation of a new eugenic religion.186 In a
follow-up article early in 1914, Hallermeyer pointed out the “indispensability
of war as the final decider in questions of race”; racial questions, he explained,
were “pure questions of power,” and “we demand that the earth belong to the
fittest.”187 In 1906, similarly, Geschlecht und Gesellschaft had carried an essay
on reproductive ethics that concluded that “the sexual crime of psychic and
physical abortion will degrade our master-race into slaves of Asiatic despots
or American parvenus” unless men and women ended their “unhappy struggle
for hegemony” and started producing more babies.188 In 1914 it published an
essay suggesting that the European peoples had to band together – and have
more babies – to face the “Slavic or the Yellow Peril.”189 Such radical visions of
global racial conflict were not predominant in sexological discourse; but they
are evidence of how porous the boundary between sexual and racial science
was.

In contrast to the sex reformers involved in the BfM, however, sexologists
were rather skeptical of eugenics. Those closer to sex reform were exceptions.
August Forel is the most striking example; his enthusiasm for eugenics was
even more radical than that of most in the BfM. Iwan Bloch paid relatively
little attention to eugenics but agreed “that only healthy people, or at least
those burdened with only such abnormalities or diseases as are not physically
or mentally detrimental to their offspring, should mate.”190 Paul Näcke established an extensive catalog of people who should be sterilized (sexual offenders,
habitual criminals, epileptics, alcoholics, the mentally ill, and hysterics); and
Sexual-Probleme carried an article in 1910 that favored not only that proposal
but also castration for sex offenders.191
Most conservative sexologists, however, were either uninterested in eugenics
or explicitly skeptical. Thus Alfred Hegar, already in 1894, had warned against
passing eugenic laws, which would create “very substantial limitation of individual freedom,” particularly because “a great deal in heredity is still obscure,
unexplained and not clear enough to formulate legal precepts.”192 Eighteen
years later, Albert Moll would make the same argument, noting that “for the
most part we’re still feeling around in the dark” when it came to heredity.
Noting that some states in the United States had adopted such measures, Moll
hoped that “these proposals will not be converted into action in Germany, and
that our race-improvers don’t gain too much influence over legislation.”193
Max von Gruber conceded in 1905 that it was morally a “crime” to have
children if one knew they “will be stunted, crippled, sick, or burdened with a
serious predisposition to sickness”; but as for actual legislation, he wondered
where one would find “the wise authority that would be able to give the right
guidelines for selection and then proceed objectively and reliably” to enforce
them. As for ideas about selective breeding, he urged his colleagues “not to
indulge in fantasies.”194 In the context of rising interest in American eugenic
legislation, Sexual-Probleme carried an article in 1914 suggesting that “the
exclusively prejudicial nature of qualities that the eugenists want to extirpate
from the genetic material is not established with sufficient scientific certainty”
to justify “playing around” with them, and deploring the “trite utilitarianism”
of eugenics advocates.195 Max Marcuse summed up the views of many sexologists: “On the whole I take no real joy in all these radical race-hygienic
proposals; their justification is inadequate, their usefulness doubtful, not to

speak of the loss of human material that is perhaps constitutionally inferior,
but may be culturally very valuable.”196 And Christian von Ehrenfels dismissed
eugenics almost as laconically as he did the “farce” of anti-Semitism: it was
inhumane, authoritarian, and impracticable.197
Sexology, then, was relatively skeptical of eugenics, and relatively open
to racism; sex reform was relatively indifferent to racism, but obsessed with
eugenics. The reason for this divergence is simple: in the conceptual world of the
female sex reformers, evolution was the product of love, and more specifically of
women’s work of selecting mates and bearing and raising children. In the conceptual world of a large proportion of (but not all) sexologists, evolution was
driven primarily by men, struggle, and death – men competing for women, conquering women, and vanquishing racial aliens.198 Max von Gruber put it this
way in a monograph on the declining birthrate in 1914: “Aggression and appropriation are a necessary part of life. Life is struggle. . . . Life is necessarily full of
bitter tragedy.”199 In von Ehrenfels’s formulation, evolution was driven by the
“forces that lead to struggle, and through it to selection.”200 The vision of sex
reform was fundamentally ecstatic; that of sexology was fundamentally tragic.
This difference also extended to politics. A majority of the sex reformers were democratic socialists, and hence believers in cooperation. Sexologists
were more often sympathetic to left-liberalism (Moll, Marcuse, Eulenburg, and
Rohleder), and antisocialism and antidemocracy were not infrequent among
them. Alfred Hegar’s early (1894) work on the sex drive was conceived as a
rebuttal to August Bebel’s views on sex in Woman Under Socialism; twenty
years later, in 1914, Oskar A. H. Schmitz would argue in Sexual-Probleme that
the demands of the women’s movement – which he detested – “stem . . . from
the same source as socialism, indeed all of democracy: from the delusional pursuit of equality.”201 Friedrich Siebert, similarly, wrote in Sexual-Probleme in
1909 that “leveling and democratic individualism . . . the dogma of the equality
of all people . . . the empty phrases of the French Revolution . . . the proletarian tendencies of Christianity” were all contributing to the biological wreck
of humanity.202 Sex reform, then, accommodated a broad spectrum of political views relatively open to the radical socialist Left and relatively closed

Conflict, 1908–1914

to the conservative Right; sexology was relatively open to the radical racist,
antidemocratic Right and relatively closed to the socialist Left.
A final important distinction between the sexologists and the sex reformers
is that whereas a rising triumphalism can be distinguished among the latter in
the years before World War I, among the former a sense of crisis and catastrophe was clearly deepening. Some feared that the women’s movements would
enslave men or render their entire culture effeminate; some feared demographic
collapse; some saw racial Armageddon looming; and some feared a flood of
lesbianism. Whatever the issue, the sense of looming apocalypse appears to
have been virtually ubiquitous.
It is not completely clear why this should be. Most of the sexologists were
doctors, and hence members of a rapidly growing and increasingly influential
profession – and one apparently on the verge, with developments in endocrinology and psychoanalysis, of major scientific and therapeutic advances. One
would expect them to have a sense of growing momentum, of optimism. It
is of course tempting to see in the mounting fears of the sexologists precisely
what Freud diagnosed as “masculine hysteria” generated by the repression of
homosexual desire.203 Their distaste for and fear of women and sex might
fit that pattern. Yet a more straightforward explanation seems more plausible. Sexology began to take shape as a discipline in the years between about
1905 and 1910; but by that time the notion that sexology as a discourse of
scientific expertise would be able to dominate or guide public discussion of
sexuality and reproduction would have sounded laughable. Krafft-Ebing in
1886, Hegar in 1894, Moll in 1898, Rohleder in 1899, or even perhaps Iwan
Bloch in 1902 might have been able to believe that they would achieve that
role; by 1908 the public discussion had reached such dimensions, and such
diversity, that any such aspiration must have seemed clearly delusional. What
was happening, instead, was that the intensity and tone of the debate among
the multiple parties to the discussion was escalating rapidly and virulently.
Between 1908 and 1914, it resembled a brawl – intense, unpredictable, and
often bruising. To use another metaphor, the sexologists could see a new continent of authority, prestige, and professional opportunity opening up before
them; but they could also see that, in the developing free-for-all land grab, they
weren’t going to get much of it.
The final chapter of this study will briefly examine some of the hardest
punches thrown in that fight.

203

Freud, Drei Abhandlungen, p. 31.

12
Confrontations, 1908–1914

I. Fault Lines
The foregoing chapters have shown that there were two diametrically opposed
anthropologies of sex in play in the debate over sexuality in early twentiethcentury Germany. One understood sexuality as a demonic, antisocial, dangerous force that must be controlled, both within the individual and in society, by
authoritative moral forces – whether moral principles and the moral will, or
social authorities (the church, the state, or the law). In this Christian anthropology, the authentic self was the moral self; the true “I” was ethical will,
moral reason, and the higher principle embodied in man’s mind and spirit.
This was what made humankind human, defined the individual, and made
people happy, productive, social beings. Sexuality, in contrast, was rooted in
the body, in humanity’s animal, merely material self, and threatened constantly
to overwhelm the mind and the individual identity that it embodied, generating
pathology, disorder, and suffering in society. Conservative moralists saw the
evidence of this struggle all around them; what they understood as the sexual
pathology of their times was for them the product of the rising tide of naturalism and materialism, which was liberating the beast within and threatened to
drown the social order in a “flood” of sex.
The other prevailing view regarded sexuality as the engine of human creativity and of human social cohesion, the fundamental life energy that drove
everything good and noble in humanity and that must be liberated if the individual, society, and indeed the human species were to thrive. In this monist
anthropology, the authentic self was the sexual self; individual desire defined
humanity and made people productive, happy, social beings. Repressing this
creative life force in the service of some unnatural spiritualist/dualist fantasy or
superstition could only lead to psychological suffering, social pathology, and
biological degeneration. The monists saw evidence of this struggle all around
281

282

Conflict, 1908–1914

them; what they understood as the sexual pathology of their time was for them
the product of the long nightmare of Christianity. That unnatural, impoverishing, life-denying doctrine had tortured individuals and sabotaged the progress
of evolution for more than a millennium and must now, at long last, be demolished so that the life energy of sex could flow freely through society and through
the biological substance of humanity.
The other most intense division in the debate over sexuality was that between
men and women. For the women’s morality movements – confessional and nonconfessional alike – women were the real, natural, and best representatives of
the moral principle, the truly human principle, and men were representatives
of the destructive and animalistic and sexual principle in human life. On the
journey to the Kingdom of God on earth, women drove the bus. For women in
the sex-reform movement, women were the real, natural, and best representatives of the life principle and of honest and natural and uncorrupted sexuality;
as mothers, women were the representatives of the interests of life. Men were
the champions at perverting or sabotaging the life force and indeed at killing.
On the journey to evolutionary transcendence, women drove the bus. Men
in the morality movements fundamentally agreed with their female counterparts that men were the greatest problem, the champions in sexual disorder
and animalism; but they clearly did not think women should be driving anything – fundamentally they should be at home with the kids, cultivating moral
selfhood, while men did everything else. Heaven, for men in the morality movement, was a patriarchy. For the male monists in sexology, women were clearly
both biologically inferior and biologically passive; it was men who (in a natural
order) made the reproductive choices that drove evolution – women were too
stupid to do that.
This is a complex picture, and as we have seen, the lines between these groupings were not always clear cut. Nevertheless, the fundamental divisions were
obvious to everyone. The hostilities and the debates were intense, sustained,
and played out across multiple arenas – local politics, state and national legislatures, and the media. And these hostilities and debates were also clearly escalating. Particularly between 1907 or 1908 and the outbreak of World War I,
the heat and aggression of the rhetorical confrontations between and among
these groups ratcheted up to a new level.
The reasons for this development are obvious. The organizations and groupings involved were steadily expanding, maturing, articulating their ideas, and
increasing their profile in the public sphere – in the media, in policy making,
and in legislative initiatives. As a result, they were increasingly rubbing up
against one another. This was a process that can be observed in many areas
of German life in the period – the growing organization and media saturation
of German society made all kinds of cultural, political, and economic conflicts
more evident, more explicit, and more pervasive. At the same time, both the
gradual coalescence of the monist reform milieu (the growing ties and interconnections among the DMB, the BfM, the WHK, the SPD, the neo-Malthusians,

Confrontations, 1908–1914

283

and so forth) and the increasing cooperation among confessional groups –
Catholic, liberal and conservative Protestant, and Jewish – in the morality
movements gave the contending parties a deepening sense that they had to overcome an organized and malevolent opposition. Similarly, the growing success
of the women’s movements generated rising tension between men and women
across the ideological spectrum (although moral conservatives managed them
far more effectively). And limited legislative successes for most groupings raised
the stakes on all sides as well.
The rising urgency of these conflicts reshaped the ideas of the contending
parties in important ways. We have seen one example in Chapter 11: the
growing importance of the women’s movements (not least the BfM) generated
an intense intellectual backlash among sexologists, feeding their commitment to
the concept of gender difference and perhaps also of racial difference. A similar
process appears to have been at work in the DGBG, in which debate with
Christian conservatives and with the IAF in 1903–1905 helped to consolidate
commitment to an explicitly pragmatic and naturalist approach among doctors.
As this chapter shows, the same sort of process was under way among moral
conservatives and among the sex reformers. As each grouping mobilized to
face the challenge of its opponents, its ideas evolved in subtle but important
ways.
II. The Authentic Moral Self
The quantum step up in the intensity of debate after about 1908 was probably
least clear in the case of the hostility between conservative Christianity and sex
reform, for the simple reason that it was difficult for these groups to trump
their own early efforts in despising and denouncing each other. Conservative
Christians reviled the sex reformers from the foundation of the BfM, indeed
even before 1905. There were, it is true, sympathetic voices among Christians.
The BfM’s journal was even able to cite, for example, the opinion of one liberal Catholic priest, who wrote that its efforts were characterized by “truly
humane spirit, true Christian love.” One Protestant pastor, too, at least conceded that he respected the “great pure idea” of the BMS; and some liberal
Protestant clergy played important roles in the organization.1 Across most of
the spectrum of Christian opinion, however, the response was overwhelmingly
contemptuous and dismissive. Already in 1904, for example, Hermann Roeren
regarded the emergence of sex reform as “indicative of the low state of our
morality.”2 One Protestant pastor referred to the BfM in 1905 as the Mutterschmutz (mother-filth) movement; another thought the leaders were “apostles
1

Cited in “Zur Kritik der sexuellen Reformbewegung,” NG 2 (1906): 31, and in Helene Stöcker,
“Zehn Jahre Mutterschutz,” NG 11 (1915): 115.
2 Hermann Roeren, Die öffentliche Unsittlichkeit und ihre Bekämpfung (Cologne: J. P. Bachem,

of Satan.”3 Friedrich Bohn, leader of the AKDS, accused Helene Stöcker in
1907 of attempting to make respectable the “shameless spirit of whoredom”
and “unadorned hedonism.”4
And yet, after about 1908 some conservative Christians became even more
vehement. In 1908, for example, Friedrich Paulsen deplored the feminist sex
reformers as “raving females” and “incoherent poets.”5 One speaker at the
Inner Mission’s 1909 conference concluded that the sex-reform ideal resembled
“an organized rabbit-hutch!”; another called sex reform “a glorious gospel for
all dissolute spirits”; and an AKDS pamphlet of 1914 accused Ellen Key of
having “more or less the mental horizons of a Herero or Hottentot” (referring
to natives of southern Africa) and of offering only “barren utopianism.”6
The escalation of rhetoric among Catholic observers was similar. In
1908 Armin Kausen, one of the leaders of the Catholic morality movement
in Munich, accused Ellen Key of spreading “methodical propaganda for sexual
license”; another essay in his journal that year denounced August Forel’s public
addresses as aiming at the “broad-gauge extirpation of all sense of shame.”7
Der Volkswart denounced the “New Ethic” as “sexual communism” or “ethical anarchism.”8 By 1914 Joseph Mausbach concluded that sex reform “is leading us into heathen immorality . . . , disparaging the value of the personality of
woman, endangering and murdering infant life, slowly but surely undermining
piety and faith.”9
Although such scurrilous attacks made good press, however, more important
was the fact that after 1907/1908 a number of leading conservative Christian
intellectuals launched a vigorous defense of the “old” morality. The single most
important of these was Friedrich Wilhelm Foerster’s influential address to the
DGBG in 1907 on sexual ethics and sexual pedagogy, which was subsequently
published as an extended essay and became one of the most widely discussed
publications on sexual morality in the prewar period. Foerster was uniquely
placed to reach a broad audience: an influential member of the Society for

Ethical Culture, a small circle of mostly liberal Protestant and agnostic intellectuals centered primarily in Berlin, he later converted to an idiosyncratic personal
brand of nonsectarian Christianity and achieved wide recognition as an unusually eloquent champion of a deeply conservative but also deeply humane brand
of Christian moral thought accessible to a wide public. Foerster was highly
sympathetic to Catholicism (and in fact was often thought to have converted
to that faith); but his thinking was shaped also by liberal Protestantism and
humanism.10
The core of Foerster’s essay was a vehement rejection of the most important
foundation of sex-reform thought, the idea of the authentic sexual self, in favor
of the Christian notion of the authentic moral self. As radical individualists, the
sex reformers held that authentic and genuinely binding moral judgments had
to originate in the voice of individual conscience. Foerster insisted instead that
the essence of any practically meaningful moral sense “consists precisely in the
fact that here something impersonal can speak in our inmost interior, correcting
our subjective bias” and setting limits for our “whims” or arbitrary caprices.
Conscience had to be guided and stiffened by “a sacred tradition of the real and
the true.”11 This was particularly true with respect to sexuality, because in this
area the “human drives, desires and passions” were so strong that most people
were thoroughly ruled by them, rather than by rational thought.12 Subjection
to such an authoritative tradition did not, as the sex reformers believed, constitute “an unbearable renunciation of one’s own life and thought”; for “only
through faith in a higher wisdom is one liberated from the prison of one’s own
experience and knowledge.”13 The “old ethic” and the “absolute prohibition
of all extra-marital sexual connections” were designed to remind people of
the ethical “unity of human individuality even in our sexual actions.” Its clear
commandments were “not created to make us slaves, but in the deepest sense
to maintain our freedom” from our own subjectivity and desire.14 Thus, “the
firm and exclusively monogamous form of sexual relationship” was “the real
bulwark of moral freedom” and the “representation of the solid and lasting
self as opposed to the merely sensual self.” Its purpose was to permit people
to “act from the depths of their essential selves,” not out of “sensual drives”
and their “whims, illusions, and passions.”15 The sex-reform program, in practical terms, must lead to an “absolute dictatorship of Eros” and reduce “the
individual to a helpless slave of his erotic urges.”16
10

See Maria Hoschek, Friedrich Wilhelm Foerster (1869–1966) (Frankfurt a.M.: Lang, 2002),
esp. pp. 43–50, 57.
11 Friedrich Wilhelm Foerster, Sexualethik und Sexualpädagogik (Munich: Josef Kösel, 1907),
p. 8.

13 Ibid., p. 9.

Conflict, 1908–1914

Nor was the old ethic patriarchal and oppressive to women. Instead, the
rigidity of Christian morality was a response to the simple fact that men suffered
from “vagabondish tendencies” and were likely to abandon the mothers of their
children unless reminded of their duty by “inviolable rules” and institutional
forms – it was an “only too deeply justified vote of no confidence in the
reliability and chivalry of male feeling.” The only effective “Mutterschutz,” he
held, was “that institution . . . which obliges and educates the man to protect
the mother” – Christian marriage.17 As for contraceptives, they would merely
“rob us of the last remaining beneficial constraints and encourage the sensual
excesses of men to the utmost.”18
Fundamentally, then, Foerster held that the sex reformers completely misjudged the nature of nature. Their deification of nature and specifically of
sexuality was enough to make one think that “God reveals himself no longer
in our conscience, but rather in our reproductive organs.” But the demand
that humankind obey the laws of nature was fundamentally mistaken, because
it neglected the simple fact “that nature is less than human . . . , that nature
does not bear within itself . . . its own proper boundaries, but rather receives
them from the spirit, and that wherever nature escapes from the dominion of
the spirit” it degenerated into “unnaturalness, indeed perversity.” Nature, he
held, was “not divine,” not orderly, not lawful; it was disorderly, incalculable,
ungoverned.19 Freeing it from the spirit would only create pathology.
As for eugenics, “people with weak bodies” but “fine and strong spiritual
qualities do much more in the final analysis for the health and vital energy
of the race than robust healthy people, who often, precisely due to a lack of
spirituality and conscience, become a source of moral and thereby also of physical degeneration.” Thus, the “enhancement and consolidation of the dominion
of the spirit over the flesh,” and not “the greatest possible production of meat,”
was “the foundation of all racial health.”20
Again, Foerster’s essay was particularly important among Catholics; but it
was by no means the only alternative for them. Leading Catholic intellectuals
were also publishing major works on ethics and morality, virtually simultaneously with Foerster’s essay. Joseph Mausbach and Augustin Rösler, for
example, published important works addressing sex reform and the women’s
movement more broadly in 1907 and 1908; Victor Cathrein wrote a detailed
analysis of Social Democratic thinking on the family and sexuality. None
matched Foerster’s clarity and rhetorical force; but all adopted a moderate
and authoritative tone that may have been well received within the narrower
conservative Catholic milieu.21

287

There was a similar raft of publications from conservative Protestant
thinkers; indeed here the role of sex reform in generating a renaissance of
conservative ethical thought was even clearer than among Catholics. Friedrich
Mahling admitted, in the first major Protestant response to sex reform in 1907,
that sex reform was forcing him and his colleagues to articulate more clearly
an explicitly “Protestant perspective” on sexuality.22 Specifically, he held that
in Protestant thought – unlike, he believed, Catholic thought – “sexual life is
something absolutely sacred and divine, it is an expression of a drive implanted
in our nature by God himself, and we have no reason to be ashamed of its
urgings.” A colleague similarly held at the Inner Mission’s 1909 conference
that “the whole medieval monkish conception of sexual life” had been falsely
“attributed . . . to us,” but that it was “not Christian morality as we in the
Protestant Church understand it.”23
Ultimately, however, many Protestants too came to conclusions rather similar to those drawn by Foerster. Thus Mahling held that man “stands . . . as a
creature of both body and spirit between God and animal and has the task of
ruling over the body, in all its manifestations and drives, with the spirit.” This
was what it meant to be moral; but it was also what it meant to be free, because
“conscience is . . . the innermost core of our spiritual life,” the true expression of
human selfhood.24 Friedrich Paulsen, too, held in 1908 that humanity had only
two choices: “subjection to the sensual drives” and ultimately “degradation of
the human beneath the animal” or “dominion of the spiritual self.”25 In the
same year, Johannes Jansen wrote of the permanent “tragic conflict . . . between
the demands of our lower, sensual nature and the goals of our higher, spiritual nature,” and said that “only in the struggle against the lower, sensual self
and all its whims and passions is the higher spiritual self, truly free spiritual
individuality, born.”26
The single most influential Protestant response to sex reform, however, was
Gustav von Rohden’s essay, “Marriage and Free Love,” of 1911. Von Rohden
saw much to praise in sex reform – for example, its commitment to spiritualized love, responsibility, and monogamy; and (quoting Schleiermacher) he
emphasized the common ground between sex reform and Protestant sexual
ethics.27 But he, like Foerster, insisted that the sex reformers’ commitment to

individual sexual freedom was desperately naive. For men, he believed, sex was
“an episode,” but for women it was “the meaning of life”; “for the true woman
love is life itself.” And because true women “see their own personal happiness
in life and in love inseparably bound up with the well-being of their children,”
their primary aim must be to create “the strongest possible guarantees and protections for the healthy development of their ‘other self’” – of which, of course,
“the existing rules and form of marriage” were among the most important.28
Far from marriage having been created to hold women in subjection, then, “the
history of marriage is the history of the development, assertion and recognition of female individuality.”29 That people suffered under the institution, he
believed, was evidence only of their own “immaturity, unhealthiness, incapacity for the ideal,” and lack of love.30
Activists in the confessional women’s organizations engaged less intensively
with sex reform and the New Ethic; but they did echo their male colleagues.
The DEF’s Paula Mueller, for example, held that the New Ethic was immoral,
socially irresponsible, and bad for women; the case was that simple. In her
first essay on the BfM in 1905, she insisted that Christian women should be
guided by the “simple notions of pure morality and the sanctity of monogamous marriage,” the “simple, eternally valid moral commandments as our Lord
Jesus Christ taught and lived them.” It was true that single mothers should be
helped, she conceded; but “the concepts of guilt and sin, remorse and atonement can not be blurred, cannot be extinguished.” The realization of the principles of the BfM would “put a premium on the rule of whim, of momentary,
unconstrained emotion, of caprice, weaken the sense of moral responsibility,
and thereby encourage immorality.”31 Countess Selma von der Gröben, Paula
Mueller’s deputy in the DEF, accused the sex reformers of preaching “freedom
at any price”; sex reform amounted for her merely to “protection of frivolous
men and women.”32 The Countess of Münster, also prominent in the DEF,
believed the realization of the BfM program would create “complete anarchy,”
in which “predatory instincts” would prevail.33 The DEF journal thought the
New Ethic amounted to advocacy of “sexual self-indulgence” and “exaggerated individualism.”34

Catholic and Jewish women were less active in opposing the BfM but used
similar terms. Hedwig Dransfeld believed the New Ethic was simply Bebel’s
materialist sexual morality and therefore a step on the path to “moral anarchy”;
it was a “toxic rot and a sure sign of decline.” Love and charity toward single
mothers and their children must “not confuse our moral views. Those who
put themselves outside the moral order . . . must bear the consequences.” And
the worth and dignity of women could not be measured only by their role as
mothers, since “their individuality stands above their nature as sexual beings.”
As for individual freedom, Dransfeld defended “that moral compulsion that
outwardly binds and inwardly liberates.”35 The JFB’s Bertha Pappenheim simply asserted, in 1907, that eventually “women’s suffrage will make the ‘New
Ethic’ superfluous” by paving the way for laws that would realize the virtues
of “the one, true, ancient, unchanging ethic.”36
III. The Tragedy of Erotic Life: The Mainstream Women’s Movement
and Sex Reform
In short, then, despite confessional and gender differences between the various
religious morality movements, there was a high degree of unanimity in their
response to sex reform. Strikingly, the reaction of the “moderate” mainstream
women’s movement was also quite similar. As we have seen, the impetus for the
formation of the BfM came in part from a split within the IAF; and a number of
leading figures in the moderate women’s movement acted very quickly, between
1903 and 1905, to distance themselves from sex reform. Anna Pappritz, for
example, argued already in 1903 that sex-reform ideas (in this case Edward
Carpenter’s) were “mortal poison” and “would lead to moral and cultural
chaos.”37 In particular, she held that the sex reformers fundamentally failed
to understand men, who did not want love but only to have sex with lots
of women. If the existing legal barriers – however fragile – to their doing so
were removed, “this indiscipline would be immeasurably heightened.”38 Helene
Lange, the grande dame of the moderate faction within the BDF, precisely
echoed Pappritz’s position in 1905. Because women represented the spirit, and
men the body, she held, women who supported sex reform “undermine the
foundations of their own house.”39 Christian marriage was actually “a victory

Conflict, 1908–1914

of woman over the polygamous instincts of man,” because women simply
“stand biologically closer to the ideal of the limitation of sexual intercourse
to monogamous marriage.”40 Gertrud Bäumer too held that monogamous
marriage was rooted “not only in our spiritual culture, but also in the biological
connection between love and motherhood in woman” – whereas men just
wanted sex. In effect, sex reform, which saw “the goal of all social institutions in
the satisfaction of the erotic instincts,” was a masculine program, which could
only produce abuse and misery for women.41 Katharina Scheven was much
more sympathetic to sex reform; but she also held that true freedom could only
exist on the basis of “inward constraint through the sense of responsibility”
and that “men are still a long way from this freedom, and therefore they have
to be educated to it.” The whole sex-reform project, she found, breathed “a
masculine spirit.”42
On a number of specific practical issues, many moderates in fact agreed
with the sex reformers. Marianne Weber, for example, conceded that “a considerable proportion of our legal marriages stand, in their motives, no higher
than prostitution.”43 Helene Lange saw the legal condition of unwed mothers
and their children as “remnants of the sexual servitude of woman and the
master-morality of man.”44 And of course the two groups had in common the
whole canon of contemporary feminist demands – equality within marriage,
full civil rights for women, equal access to the professions, the abolition of
particular disabilities for women, and so forth. As Helene Lange put it, “with
respect to the problems that we call the ‘marriage question’ or the ‘sexual question’ our paths part”; but the two movements “agree on all other questions of
principle.”45
And yet, as the sex reformers’ ideas became more and more clearly articulated after 1905, the rhetorical tone of mainstream responses gradually escalated. An intense debate within the BDF over the issue of abortion in 1908
played an important role in this process. Again, most of the leadership of the
BfM supported legalization of abortion, on the grounds that a woman had
the right to control her own body. Opinion within the mainstream women’s

291

movement was more divided. Many in the moderate leadership argued that
legalization was ethically indefensible and a threat to national power. But the
BDF’s legal commission actually favored legalization in its recommendations
regarding reform of the Criminal Code. The commission’s report conceded that
“modern science teaches that the embryo is alive already from the moment of
conception.” But it went on to argue that it was “an indissoluble part of
[a woman’s] own body” and that punishing a woman for doing whatever she
wanted with her own body was “an unjustified infringement of the right of
self-determination.” Whatever the scientists said, “woman must . . . be, as a
free individual, master of her own body.” What was more, given the “unhappy
family conditions” in which many women lived, alcoholism among men, and
the suffering of single mothers as moral pariahs, abortion was in many cases
ethically justifiable in its own right.46 At the BDF’s national conference in 1908,
this recommendation sparked a heated seven-hour debate, one that helped to
cement a new alliance between the moderates and religious women in the DEF
and the JFB.
A number of leading figures in the BfM supported the legal commission’s
view that criminalizing abortion was “an unjustified assault on the right to
dispose of one’s own body – that is, on the freedom of the individual”; and
they argued also against population-policy concerns.47 Adele Schreiber, for
example, argued that “a healthy and moral populace is not attained through
use of the criminal law,” and that the proper approach would be “to stop up the
sources of abortion” by securing the welfare of all children. Käthe Schirmacher
defended “the right of self-determination,” rejecting the idea that male experts
should have the right to “decide regarding the most sacred and intimate” affairs
of women. Helene Stöcker suggested that one must not “view children already
in the mother’s womb as property of the state.”48
The arguments of the opposing side were strongly influenced by eugenic
ideas. Agnes Bluhm had been chosen to rebut the legal commission’s recommendation, presumably because she was a doctor and abortion was in part a
medical issue. Bluhm was a provocative choice, as she was the one prominent
female race hygiene expert in the country. She did not disappoint, arguing,
for example, that “granting room and board” for nine months “cannot earn
one the right to decide over life and death”; that abortion should not be legalized in cases of rape because “in this matter pregnant women lie in downright

hair-raising fashion”; and that in general women sought abortions for “trivial,
indeed frivolous reasons.” What was more, “the number of heads is not a matter of indifference . . . for a people in maintaining its place among the civilized
nations.” And it would be the more intelligent and rational women who would
get abortions if they were legalized, whereas the stupid and improvident would
continue to multiply; so the quality of the population would decline, too.49 The
BfM’s Maria Lischnewska delivered a still more extraordinary tirade, holding
that Germany was “a rising nation” that “has the mission to become the foremost civilized power on earth by conquering new economic and intellectual
territory,” and that this meant that “we need in the first instance people, and
in fact a lot of people” – as workers, as thinkers, as soldiers and sailors, and
as settlers in the colonies. One need only look to France and white America
to see what became of peoples that didn’t punish abortion: the French were
“a dying, sinking nation,” whereas in the United States “in a few decades the
Blacks . . . will decide” affairs in the country. And at the same time, however,
“we are being run into the ground by the mass of completely degenerate elements who are getting brought into the world,” and “one can not demand
of us, as healthy, hard-working people, that we throw away our taxes and
our productive energies in continuing to keep these inferiors alive.” Abortion
therefore had to be legalized in the case of rape, or when the father was an
alcoholic, syphilitic, or “mentally or physically ill” – but only when approved
by a panel of doctors.50
The ultimate outcome of the debate reflected these concerns. The assembly
voted to retain paragraph 218 (with milder penalties for women), but to allow
abortion – subject to approval by a medical panel – in cases in which childbirth
threatened the mother’s life or health, in case of rape, or “if it is to be expected
that the child will enter into life bearing a severe hereditary physical or mental
taint.”51
In practical terms (of votes), however, the key objections to legalization
voiced in the course of the debate were moral, not medical or military. Gertrud
Bäumer did discuss biology but concluded simply by remarking that “unprejudiced popular opinion” saw “abortion as something that should not happen.”52
Paula Mueller of the DEF observed with equal simplicity that “it is surely selfevident that anyone who takes the standpoint of Christian faith cannot support
the striking of this paragraph” (§218).53 Agnes Neuhaus of the KFV remarked
that she could not address questions of principle “because I am too rooted in
the Catholic conception of the sanctity of marriage.”54 Anna Pappritz equated

abortion with “murder” and insisted that it “has to be regarded as a crime.”55
And Bertha Pappenheim observed “that reverence for life is a fundamental
characteristic of Jewish ethics.”56
In short, the radical challenge from sex reform highlighted the JudeoChristian foundation that the moderates in the mainstream women’s movement
shared with their counterparts in the confessional women’s organizations. This
pattern was evident too in a number of important publications in the years
1907–1909, including, for example, Marianne Weber’s influential address to
the Protestant Social Congress in 1907, Helene Lange’s 1908 history of the
women’s movement, and an important volume of essays critiquing the New
Ethic published by the leading figures in the moderate faction in the BDF in
1909. Many of these essays rehearsed familiar arguments – in particular, as
Weber put it, that women “are considered by the mass of men primarily as
sexual beings,” so that any “unleashing of the sexual drives would lead to a
brutalization of emotional life,” and “it would be woman who would have to
bear the costs of [this] brutality.”57
There were, however, two new notes in the essays of these years. On the
one hand, many of them were more explicitly critical specifically of the radical
individualism of sex-reform thought. Marianne Weber was particularly insistent on this point. Even the “most loveless average marriage,” she believed, “if
it is at least a marriage of respect, testifies to the willingness of the spouses to
take on their full responsibility, that is to the subordination of their personal
lives to the idea of duty.”58 Helene Lange accused the BfM of putting “in place
of ethical individualism . . . individualism full stop, in the sense of a right to
self-realization.”59 Obviously such condemnations precisely echoed those from
conservative Christians.
A second shift in emphasis revealed a still greater affinity with conservative
Christian views, specifically with respect to the proper definition of freedom.
Marianne Weber’s 1907 address is perhaps the most striking example; for she
argued that the harmony between morality and nature that monism aimed to
achieve was simply an impossibility. The “titanic and painful conflict between
what is and what should be in our sensual-spiritual nature” was not a “problem” or a “crisis,” as the sex reformers argued; it was not something to be
reformed out of the world. Instead, it was “obviously an inescapable fate,
an explicit mark of our ‘human dignity’ in contrast to animality, and one
of the very most important means of our spiritual refinement.”60 But Helene
Lange spelled out the same perspective even more clearly in 1908 and 1909,

remarking that “growing individualization means growing subordination of
animal instincts to the spiritual” and that “the individual as a whole has to
fight out a struggle against one part” (that is, the “animal” part).61 In these
texts, the moderates were explicitly making the central argument of many
conservative Christians: that real freedom was to be found not through the
emancipation of the flesh but through the dominion of the spirit, not through
the liberation of the authentic sexual self but through the empowerment
of the authentic moral self. And in fact explicit traces of the conversation among
these figures can be found in the texts they published – as when Helene Lange,
for example, quoted directly from Friedrich Wilhelm Foerster; when Gustav
von Rohden quoted from Alice Salomon; or when Paula Mueller published a
highly complimentary review of the 1909 collection of essays by the moderate
leadership.62
IV. Eugenic Responsibility and “Individualistic Anarchy”
Not surprisingly, the sex reformers responded to the more scurrilous and unfair
attacks of their critics with equal vehemence. In 1905 and 1906 Helene Stöcker
deplored their “unbelievable conceptual confusion,” “objective mendacity
and . . . carelessness,” and “prudery and fearfulness.”63 Kurt Hiller denounced
conservative Christians as champions of “hypocrisy,” “fertility-happiness and
a rabbit-ethos,” and the “mendacity of our official system of morality.”64
Die Neue Generation described Paula Mueller’s behavior, in 1912, as “not
only rude but un-Christian.”65 By 1914 Stöcker was so frustrated by Helene
Lange’s utterances that she accused her of “gross distortions and misrepresentations of our goals” and observed that moderate women’s “aversion to men”
suggested that they “belong to the homosexual orientation.”66
Yet the shock of confrontation also elicited a more positive response: a
progressive shift from Nietzschean individualism and Romantic individualism
toward biological or evolutionary ethics. As we have seen, within the BfM and
sex reform as a whole, eugenic and evolutionary thought played an increasingly important role, particularly precisely from 1909/1910 onward – in fact,

295

Stöcker signaled this change explicitly in an editorial note introducing the first
issue of Die Neue Generation in 1910.67 Again, this may have been in part an
attempt to downplay divisions within the movement; and it also fit well with the
organizational strategy of building ties with other groups in the broader monist
reform milieu. But in emphasizing biology, the sex reformers collectively were
also responding specifically to criticisms that stressed the irresponsible and
exaggerated individualism of sex-reform thought. The emphasis on responsibility to the “race” was in part a response to the intensification of criticisms
that stressed the social function of sexual ethics.
Stöcker herself explicitly adopted precisely this rhetorical strategy in some
texts published just before World War I. She remarked in 1914, for example,
that “it will be . . . eugenics that . . . will be the religion of the future, that will
save us from destroying ourselves through individualistic anarchy, that will
make us self-conscious architects . . . of the future.”68 Henriette Fürth had taken
a similar position already in 1911, arguing that in advocating contraception
she was not “preaching sexual anarchy,” because in fact she was in favor of a
new degree of “responsibility. . . . We are now liable not only for the number
but also for the quality of our progeny. We owe our children . . . every form of
security that flows from the mastery of humanity over itself and over all the
expressions of its life.”69 And as we have seen, the transfer of organizational
leadership from Stöcker to Max Rosenthal may have been in part a move away
from radical Nietzschean individualism toward a more sober biological ethic
of responsibility.
V. “Moral Ruin Through Medicine”
As an organization explicitly committed to undermining the Christian sexual
order, the BfM was the focus of conservative Christian ire. But Christians did
not ignore their intellectual opponents in the sexology movement, the DGBG,
or the WHK. Indeed, given the range of medical practitioners who preached
tolerance of or understanding for sexual needs (“normal” and/or “perverse”),
it is hardly surprising that many conservative Christians were convinced, as one
Catholic commentator put it in 1909, that “precisely the doctors are abetting
moral ruin in fateful manner.”70
Of particular importance in this respect was the alienation of moral conservatives from the DGBG, as doctors who were committed to using whatever
means available to combat venereal disease drifted more and more explicitly toward acceptance of extramarital sex as an irreducible quantity. Thus
67

Helene Stöcker, “An unsere Leser,” NG 6 (1910): 1–2.
Helene Stöcker, “Eine Soziologie der Liebe und Ehe,” NG 10 (1914): 331.
69 Henriette Fürth, “Der Neomalthusiasnismus und die Soziologie,” SM 17 (1911): 1671.
70 Cato, “Sittenruin aus der Medizin,” Volkswart 2 (1909): 98–99.

296

Conflict, 1908–1914

Der Volkswart, in an article of 1911, condemned the DGBG’s “pessimistic
standpoint that we cannot turn back morally” and insisted instead that “sin
remains sin” and must be resisted.71 One Dr. Hans Brennecke, having warned
already at the AKDS’s conference in 1905 that the DGBG’s position on prophylactics was an example of “morally vacuous naturalism,” in 1913 accused
doctors of “abusing science in the service of Eros and performing morally subversive work of the most questionable sort under the mantle of hygiene” (and
of representing the “spirit of a foreign race,” that is, of being Jews).72 By 1910,
Katharina Scheven took for granted the fact of antagonism between women
and doctors; relations between them in fact constituted a “struggle between
two world-views . . . , one utilitarian-materialistic and the other transcendentalidealistic”; and in 1913 the IAF’s representative at the DGBG’s annual conference deplored that organization’s exclusion of women’s voices and its “purely
masculine standpoint.”73 In 1910 Hanna Bieber-Böhm reported in remarks
at the DGBG conference that, under the “barracks” system (Kasernierung),
women in the sex trade felt “justified in their recognized trade” and had
lost “any feeling for right and wrong, and all consciousness of their own
reprehensibility.”74 The solution the doctors favored, in other words, merely
encouraged shamelessness.
In contrast, as we have seen, a growing number of doctors argued simply that
morality had nothing to do with the matter. Doctors who opposed this view
were increasingly at odds with the DGBG leadership. In 1911, for example,
the DGBG newsletter carried a bitter exchange between the editors of the
journal and Max von Gruber concerning the latter’s lectures to young people
on venereal diseases. Unhappy with Gruber’s insistence that condoms posed
an “enormous race-hygienic danger” and therefore should not be advertised
openly, the editors accused him of being on the side of “clerical zealots and
immorality-sniffers . . . informers and provocateurs.”75
Moral conservatives found plenty to object to in sexology as well; for they
explicitly rejected the idea that people in general needed to know more about
sex, or that science was ethically relevant. One Catholic critic warned in 1908,

for example, that Forel’s “one-sidedly naturalistic standpoint misleads youth
into thinking all too indulgently about excesses and aberrations of the allegedly
strongest human instinct,” while Ellen Key’s works did the same among young
women.76 Another had held in 1906 that the works of sexologists had “done
more harm than good” because they gave people too much information about
sex.77 The KDF’s Ellen Ammann found even merely the table of contents of
Iwan Bloch’s Sexual Life of Our Times to be “fateful” for young people.78
And Der Volkswart held in 1909 that the works of Krafft-Ebing were a “poisonous” and “morally ruinous influence” because they encouraged people to
believe that homosexuality was a product of “‘sickness,’ ‘degeneration,’ ‘hereditary taint,’ ‘need’” rather than a crime and a sin. The “moderate scientific
tones,” the “overly free language,” and the “completely pointless piling up”
of cases of “sexual crimes of the most disgusting nature” made his work a
threat to moral health.79 A particularly striking case was that of Friedrich
Wilhelm Foerster, who wrote in response to Freud’s essay, “Sexuality and
Modern Nervousness” (in Sexual-Probleme in 1908), that ethics had to be
founded on eternal truths, not on whatever “point of view is currently fashionable” in the sciences.80 But Samuel Keller of the AKDS had assured his
colleagues already in 1894 that “I won’t submit to modern science any more
than to Social Democracy or to the Pope. All three are traps that . . . seek to
make us . . . slaves.”81
Some conservative Christians did embrace race hygiene, attempting to construct eugenic arguments for traditional moral notions. They were happy to
borrow from the race hygienists’ denunciations of feminism, for example, as
a threat to the quality of the race, or to deplore the degeneration of the race
as a consequence of alcoholism, syphilis, homosexuality, urban life, and sexual excess. Der Volkswart even suggested in 1913 that Germany should follow the American state of Indiana in introducing sterilization as a penalty
for sex crimes, to stem the “enormous rise” in the number of the “mentally defective.”82 And yet, in aggregate, such passages were mere asides in
the broader literature of the morality movement. The morality campaigners
were primarily interested in morality, not biology. And some Christians explicitly rejected the whole idea that there should not be imperfect people in the
world. One Protestant critic asked in 1910, for example, whether “an inner
enhancement of life” did not accrue to those who “care and sacrifice” for
