the sick, because caring for the disabled awakened “slumbering moral energies. . . . Nations live from this spirit of sacrifice.”83 Friedrich Wilhelm Foerster held in the same year that “care for the weak” was the greatest teacher
of “social culture” – for example, selflessness, solidarity, compassion, and
mutual aid – and “liberates the strong from the tyranny of their instincts and
passions.”84
As we have seen, leading figures in the mainstream women’s movement often
championed similar ideas. Their position was that culture was more important
than biology. As one article in the IAF’s journal in 1911 put it, eugenics was
a moral danger because it encouraged reasonable – if unthinking – people to
imagine that national greatness rested on purely material foundations, whereas
in fact “a nation is made great by its ideas, by its ideals, by its striving,” and
not by mere biological qualities.85
As medical sexology opened to the loopier racist Right after 1908, this
animosity deepened. The third edition of Foerster’s Sexual Ethics and Sexual Pedagogy, published in 1910, retained, for example, his earlier denunciation of sex-reform ideas as an invitation to erect a “dictatorship of mere
erotic passion,” but he added a critique of Christian von Ehrenfels’s advocacy
of polygamy. Von Ehrenfels’s obsession with demographics and the “Yellow
Peril” showed merely that he had lost “any clear notion of . . . moral forces
and cultural values” and their role in relations between peoples. The truth
was that the “undeveloped races” would “bow before everything right and
spiritual in the white race just as once upon a time the Nordic races bowed
before the majesty of the cross.” As for race hygiene, Foerster conceded that
people had to recognize their “responsibility with respect to very serious and
unquestionable hereditary dangers” but rejected the “brutal and superficial
hereditarian terrorism . . . with which certain race hygienists want to impose a
regime of human breeding.”86 Other conservative critics were more straightforwardly dismissive. Der Volkswart described Hentschel’s Mittgart as a “human
thoroughbred stall such as could scarcely be more shamelessly and tastelessly
imagined.”87 The conservative Protestant Kreuzzeitung saw Hentschel’s ideas
as a “grotesque reversion to the zoological.”88 And the IAF’s journal, in 1911,
remarked of such schemes that “if this is the only way to save our nation, our
race, our culture, then we are absolutely doomed to go under. Because we’ll
never be won over to such monstrosities. And no harm done, because a nation

and a culture that could only be saved at this price would certainly not be

VI. The Failure of Monist Unity
The challenge of naturalist ethics, then, increasingly drove religious activists of
all stripes – men and women, Catholics, conservative and liberal Protestants,
and Jews – to find common ground in the years before 1914. And there was
a similar circling of the wagons among their opponents, as sex reformers,
monists, psychoanalysts, neo-Malthusians, the WHK, and others (for example,
in the Weimar Cartel) built networks and connections. In one crucial respect,
however, that effort obviously failed, and indeed momentum was building in
the opposite direction. For the champions of a “natural” sexual morality failed
completely to reconcile male and female versions of that vision.
In particular, as we have seen, the hostility of sexologists toward sex reform
was palpable and deepening in the years just before World War I. Again,
sexology was quite divided, and the new Journal of Sexual Science launched in
1914 was very supportive of the agenda of the BfM and WHK. But the other
major sexology journals were ever more critical of sex reform in the years
before World War I. Both journals increasingly opened their pages to race
theorists who argued that feminism and sex reform were an existential threat
to the biological nation – as, for example, when Christian von Ehrenfels argued
in Sexual-Probleme in 1909 that the ideas of the BfM “point us in the direction
of the swamp of racial ruin and the abyss of national death.”90 And hostility
toward the homosexual rights movement, too, intensified among conservative
sexologists after 1908.
For their part, the sex reformers regarded the entire sexological theory of
absolute sexual difference as hopelessly mired in male prejudice – at best myopically masculine, at worst deliberately mendacious. Already in 1903 Helene
Stöcker had found it laughable that it was so “difficult to make it comprehensible to the other sex that we are in possession of a fully functional brain.”91 By
1913 she dismissed as “empty phrases” the sexologists’ nonsense about absolute sexual differences between men and women.92 In the same year, Katharina
Werner observed in the BfM’s journal that, for all its scientific rhetoric, sexology
amounted to date merely to a “merging of medical knowledge and the subjective masculine perspective on sexual life.”93 Ernst Schur held the ideology of

absolute gender difference to be an “inadmissibly primitive standpoint.”94 And
Grete Meisel-Hess suggested already in 1904 that it was “downright terroristic
to declare certain tendencies, characteristics or predispositions only ‘masculine’
or only ‘feminine,’” because they were in fact “often neither the one nor the
other, but rather merely human.”95 Sex reformers’ response to the ideas of
the race theorists was similarly derisive. Helene Stöcker called von Ehrenfels a
“passionate advocate of the right of the man to the greatest possible number
of women” and called him and Hentschel “unworldly fools” suffering from
“blindly masculine-egotistical . . . naive doctrinarism.”96 Even Bruno Meyer –
who was drifting gradually out of the intellectual orbit of the BfM in the decade
before 1914 – called von Ehrenfels a “race fanatic” and observed that the Asian
peoples von Ehrenfels found so terrifying were increasingly “saturated with our
culture,” and their military triumph was therefore not likely to destroy it. More
probable was a “new blossoming of culture on the foundation of the new racial
mixing,” which would be all the more creative because the Chinese were the
“fathers of their own ancient and very high culture.”97
This bitter split in monist ranks may well have been a critical reason for
the growing success of moral conservatives in driving legislative and regulatory
agendas. The views of moral conservatives were increasingly converging by
the 1910s; in the opposing camp, in contrast, the divisions between Left and
Right and between men and women were only deepening. Moral conservatives
therefore had growing success in building effective coalitions around particular
issues; the monists were mired in embittered debates about the meaning of their
primary postulates.
VII. Three Sexualities
The extent to which the lines in the debate over sexuality and sexual morality
had hardened by 1914 into impermeability should not be exaggerated. Sexology
in particular was relatively amorphous; some leading sexologists were closely
associated with sex reform, whereas others detested it as feminist claptrap, and
others still took moral positions quite close to those of Christian conservatives.
And some people and organizations were able to build bridges across organizational and intellectual divides. The DGBG’s Albert Neisser, for example,
was a member of the BfM throughout the prewar years.98 Bruno Meyer continued to publish in Die Neue Generation, Sexual-Probleme, and Geschlecht
und Gesellschaft right up to 1913. The IAF in particular was a meeting place

Ernst Schur, “Ueber das Erotische,” NG 4 (1908): 49.
Grete Meisel-Hess, Weiberhass und Weiberverachtung (Vienna: Wage, 1904), p. 8.

Polygamie,” NG 8 (1912): 55, 54.
97 Bruno Meyer, “Etwas von positiver Sexualreform,” SP 4 (1908): 715, 720, 791, 807, 810–811.

for people with quite diverse ideas. Its governing board in 1908 included not
only Katharina Scheven (a prominent moderate) and Anna Pappritz (who had
close ties to Paula Mueller and the DEF) but also Käthe Schirmacher (who
was intellectually though not politically close to the sex-reform leadership). Its
1908 general meeting was addressed not only by Pappritz and Scheven but also
by Otto Juliusburger, Marie Stritt, Käthe Schirmacher, Maria Lischnewska,
and Rosa Mayreder, all of whom were close to sex reform; by Alfred Blaschko
of the DGBG; by Agnes Bluhm, the eugenics expert; and by Friedrich Bohn of
the AKDS.99 And rather bizarrely, given how divergent the views of most in the
DGBG were, that organization included in its traveling exhibition after 1911
some graphics prepared by the IAF.100
Nevertheless, we can identify several specific senses in which the various positions in the broad debate over sexuality were becoming increasingly
entrenched by 1913.
First, the number of organizations involved was ramifying rapidly. The
decade and a half before the outbreak of the war saw the emergence, in addition to the Protestant morality associations (AKDS, WSV, White Cross, VFJM,
and so on) that were already active, also of the Catholic morality associations;
the DEF, JFB, KDF, KFV, BDF, and IAF; the DGBG; the WHK and the Gemeinschaft der Eigenen; the BfM; and the ÄGSE and the IGS. As these organizations
multiplied, they articulated the ideas that appealed to their constituencies more
clearly – which of course also clarified their differences with other groups doing
the same thing.
Second, the increasingly intense and complex debate between these rapidly
clarifying positions only further energized and mobilized the individual groups
involved, particularly where specific policy or legislative initiatives were at
stake. Reporting on efforts to introduce Kasernierung in a growing number of
municipalities in 1910, for example, the IAF’s Dresden branch observed that
“new life and a fresh energy have come into our movement because of it.”101
But of course this was a dynamic that had already been at work at the very
birth of the Christian morality movement in the 1880s, when women’s advocacy of abolitionism helped spark the emergence of Protestant men’s morality
organizations.
Third, the clash of ideas and organizations also drove a rapid evolution of
the ideas of those involved – a tendency that helped to build the urgency of
the conflict both by further clarifying differences and by driving the emergence
of broader, and hence more threatening, political and ideological coalitions.
The leadership of the BfM stressed the theme of eugenic responsibility partly

“Die zweite Generalversammlung des deutsche Zweiges der I. A. Föderation,” Abolitionist
7 (1908): 50–52.

to avoid the charge of individualist sexual anarchism, thereby building bridges
to the DMB and associated groups. Sexology opened to the ideas of radical
racial theorists partly in response to the successes of the women’s movement,
thereby further alienating both Christian conservatives and sex reformers. The
BDF leadership discovered common ground with confessional women partly
in response to the challenge of sex reform. Conservative Protestant men drifted
toward abolitionism as their female colleagues grew more influential and articulate on the issue – in part in the course of their own conflict with the DGBG.
These broader coalitions or groupings remained themselves divided internally – between more liberal and more conservative Protestant women in the
DEF or the IAF, between revisionists and more orthodox Marxists in the SPD,
between Nietzschean women and self-identified realist men in the BfM, between
abolitionists and neoregulationists in the DGBG, and between the ÄGSE and
the IGS. And yet, as members of various and diverse organizations sought to
strengthen their position by building alliances, broader sides or camps were coalescing. This was most obvious among the various organizations committed to
more conservative sexual mores, and specifically to the idea that the moral self
was the authentic self. The process was less clear among sexual radicals in the
BfM, the WHK, and the SPD – the detonations within the BfM and the WHK
in 1906–1909 muddied the issue substantially, as did bruising debates between
orthodox Marxists and revisionists in the SPD. Nevertheless, there was in fact
a growing density of connections and exchanges within the broader social and
intellectual milieu of sexual radicalism. Sexology was least coherent of all – it
was organizationally amorphous, its advocates published in widely disparate
journals, and it was pulled in multiple ideological directions. But here too the
development of the discussion in the two key journals – Sexual-Probleme and
Geschlecht und Gesellschaft – clearly suggests that there was at least a significant minority in sexology that was increasingly antifeminist, increasingly
open to racial thought, increasingly antidemocratic, and increasingly paranoid
(whether the focus of fear was a wave of lesbianism, the Americanization of
women, the yellow peril, the Slavic menace, or racial degeneration).
By 1913, then, there were three broad activist camps or sides in the debate
over sexuality: the morality campaigners, the sex reformers, and the sexologists. Hostility and fear between and among these groupings was rising. They
were, deliberately or unconsciously, moving to stake out ever clearer and more
mutually exclusive positions. On the eve of World War I, the issues they debated
were among the most contentious in German politics – so much so that already
in 1908, for example, the Prussian minister of justice told his cabinet colleagues
that reform of the regulation of prostitution “is at present the most hotly contested question in the area of criminal law. The whole nation takes the liveliest
interest in this matter.”102
102

“Sitzung des königlichen Staatsministeriums,” Berlin, 30 November 1908, in GSAPKB, Rep
84a, no. 8407, fol. 45–48, p. 2.

Confrontations, 1908–1914

303

World War I struck this complex of ideas and forces like a sledgehammer. It
disrupted organizational life; it created new problems that called old assumptions into question; it transformed the legal and political environment in which
all sides operated; and the severe social strains it created generated a new and
unprecedented urgency in multiple legislative and policy arenas. Much of what
happened during and immediately after the war was quite unexpected. Nevertheless, by the early 1920s, the three-way struggle that was developing in
the years around 1910 emerged once again, with new clarity and intensity,
and dominated the even more politicized, intense, embittered, and still further
escalating struggle over sexuality that was one of the distinctive features of
political and cultural life in the Weimar Republic.
That will be the subject of the sequel to this study.

Conclusion
Sex, Politics, and Modernity II

The most striking feature of the struggle over sexuality, sexual morality, and
decency in Germany in the three decades before World War I is surely the
extraordinary and expanding variety of views championed by the many different parties to that debate. The philosophical foundations of these organizations,
the agendas they pursued, their social bases, and the language they employed
varied wildly. Many of these organizations and movements saw their competitors and opponents as posing existential threats to the social order, to national
power and indeed national existence, and certainly to individual and social
health and well-being. They denounced and berated one another with steadily
rising vehemence. Viewed as a whole, the debate over sexuality resembles a
Hollywood saloon brawl that starts at one table and expands outward into
chaos.
This picture contradicts a venerable tradition in European social theory
that sees modernization as a process of homogenization. Premodern societies
were societies of particularity, locality, and caste; in modern societies, mass
schooling, mass politics, massive social organizations, massive corporations,
the massive penetration of society by regulatory agencies and institutions (public and private) and their experts, mass culture and the mass media, and the
universal standards of rational organization and rational behavior have all converged to produce greater uniformity. One of the most extreme formulations
of this view is that of Zygmunt Bauman, who held in 1991 that modernity
is about order, about the desire to subject everything to rational bureaucratic
management according to scientific principles and abstract instrumental logic.
Intolerance of variety (disorder) is therefore “the natural inclination of modern practice. Construction of order . . . calls for the denial . . . of everything that

304

Sex, Politics, and Modernity II

305

cannot be assimilated.”1 Such ideas are commonplace today; historians often
use the metaphors of “weeding” society, or of “engineering” it.2
Empirically, in the case examined in this book, this view does not seem to
hold up at all. This study instead confirms the description of modern society
developed by Don Slater, in his study Consumer Culture and Modernity. Slater
argues that modern societies are marked by
pluralization. In place of a secure order of values and social positions there
is a bewildering variety and fluidity of values, roles, authorities, symbolic
resources and social encounters . . . modernity involves a “pluralization of
life-worlds” . . . modernity replaces traditional authority with “methodological
doubt” . . . ever more “lifeworlds” are made visible to us, become possible choices
of identity. . . . Modernity, then, involves the vertiginous production, display and
interaction of myriad possible ways of life, none of which has indisputable cultural
authority or value.3

That is a nice brief summary of the most obvious finding of this book. What
appears to have been happening in the debate over sexuality was not the
flattening out of difference, not the progressive articulation and imposition
of norms and normalcy, but the progressive articulation, organization, and
politicization of difference.
With respect specifically to sexuality, furthermore, the picture that emerges
here contradicts one of the central elements of the Foucauldian understanding of the place of sexuality in modern society (discussed in the introduction).
Foucault held that it was not true that “Victorian” society – European society
in the nineteenth century – was characterized by sexual repression, a taboo
on talking about sex. Instead, he believed, in modern societies people were
increasingly compelled to talk about sex to an expanding universe of medical
and psychological experts. This was how the new bourgeois social order disciplined itself – by eliciting confessions, defining pathologies, and prescribing
regimes of self-care or of medical intervention. This view does not adequately
capture the complex roles of class and gender in the politics of sexuality in this
period. Many moral conservatives and some sexologists in the decades around
1900 did insist on the need for men of the educated and governing classes to
talk more about sex. But they were very disturbed when male members of those
classes spoke to or wrote for anybody else about the topic. And as we have
seen, the taboo against women saying anything about sex, much less in public,
was intense; that against homosexuals doing so was even more so; and outside
1

Zygmunt Bauman, Modernity and Ambivalence (Ithaca, NY: Cornell University Press, 1991),
pp. 29, 8, 39.
2 For a discussion and references, see Edward Ross Dickinson, “Biopolitics, Fascism, Democracy:
Reflections on Our Discourse Concerning ‘Modernity,’” Central European History 37 (2004):
1–48.
3 Don Slater, Consumer Culture and Modernity (Cambridge: Polity, 1997), pp. 83–84.

Sex, Freedom, and Power in Imperial Germany, 1880–1914

of socialist circles, most regarded the opinions of working people as at best
irrelevant and at worst pernicious.
This is not to say that Foucault was simply wrong about the matter, or
that Lawrence Birken was simply right. It is certainly true that there was a
growing “institutional incitement to speak about” sex – or at least multiplying
opportunities to do so. It is also true that there were multiplying efforts at
“displacement, intensification, reorientation, and modification of desire itself,”
and that many of these efforts sought to subject sexuality to “systems of utility,
regulated for the greater good of all, made to function according to an optimum.
Sex was not something one simply judged; it was a thing one administered.”4
All the movements examined here sought to “administer” sexuality – to direct,
shape, contain, regulate, and define it, to make it socially and politically useful.
All certainly agreed that sexuality is a central and decisive part of human
identity, and that therefore the fate of humanity – social and political order,
economic and military power, and individual health and happiness – depends
in large part on our ability to manage sexuality appropriately. Specifically,
they all appear to have believed that freedom and power go hand in hand,
and that sex is the key to both. There were of course wildly varying models
of how this triad was structured. Conservative Christians held that conquering
sexual desire secured the inward freedom of the spiritual man, and that doing
so made him manly enough to defend liberty against its internal and external
enemies. Sex reformers believed that liberating sexual desire would make people
creative, joyful, and inwardly free and would thus sweep away the foundations
of the authoritarian order and unleash reproductive and cultural forces that
would guarantee national security. Hypervirile homosexuals, venereologists,
mainstream feminists, and so forth all had their own variations. But all agreed
on the world-historical importance, the sheer potency, of sex.
To that extent it makes sense to argue, as some historians have recently
done, that there was a rough consensus regarding sexuality, and particularly
regarding its political significance.5 But we should be precise about what we
know when we know that. Knowing that modern people think this way about
sexuality helps us to define a particular field of contention central to the life
of modern societies. What that field of contention creates is possibilities, however, and not outcomes. A growing number of social groups and individuals
were actively and determinedly claiming the authority to speak about sex for
themselves, often in quite self-conscious assertion of their own sexual “subjectivity,” the legitimacy and authenticity of their own experience of sex. Many
4

Michel Foucault, The History of Sexuality: An Introduction, vol. I (New York: Vintage, 1990),
pp. 18, 23, 24.
5 See, e.g., Annette Timm, The Politics of Fertility in Twentieth-Century Berlin (New York:
Cambridge University Press, 2010), pp. 10, 12; Atina Grossman, Reforming Sex: The German
Movement for Birth Control and Abortion Rights, 1920–1950 (New York: Oxford University
Press, 1995), p. 47.

Sex, Politics, and Modernity II

307

of them did so in the face of attempts to silence them with very intense prohibitions, taboos, and even punishments. And the whole discussion among these
interlocutors certainly did not add up to something coherent, to a regime of
sexuality. There was no deeper coherence or logic to the multiple divergent
strategies for managing sexuality that they advocated, or the multiple political
agendas to which they hitched their conceptions of sexuality. There is indeed
a logic at work in a society wracked by contention between advocates of
free love, polygamy, serial monogamy, “trial marriages,” abstinence followed
by lifelong monogamous marriage, hygienically sound prostitution, “physiological friendship,” prohibition of contraceptives and the right to abortion,
eugenics and pronatalism, authoritarian monarchy, liberal democracy, social
democracy, and racial-eugenic totalitarianism. But it is a logic of conflict, not
of coherence.6 There was consensus only as to what to disagree about.
Foucault himself defined this perspective neatly, in an early essay in which he
urged historians not to look for the coherence hidden behind social complexity
“because this search assumes the existence of immobile forms that precede the
external world of accident and succession”; it aims to “compose the finally
reduced diversity of time into a totality fully closed upon itself.” In truth,
instead, Foucault held that the “forces operating in history are not controlled
by destiny or regulative mechanisms, but respond to haphazard conflicts.”7
Bruno Latour made the same argument, suggesting that we should stop trying to
identify monolithically coherent calculations, interests, agendas, or imperatives
hidden behind the apparent complexities of modern social life – that we should
“no longer seek to be even cleverer, even more critical, even deeper into the
‘era of suspicion’” but rather take those complexities seriously, and “sort out
instead of debunking.”8 And Margaret Archer has referred to the approach
both were rejecting as “downwards conflation” – the idea that the messy
details of individual and social life don’t matter because society and culture
have a deeper, coherent structure that actually determines everything. In such
a construct, “the course of social change is never pictured as a wild zigzag,
as social groups struggle to wrest the wheel from one another.”9 This latter
description of course precisely fits the findings of this book – and the history
of Germany in the twentieth century.
It should be said, in this context, that the debate over sexual morality was
driving some people in Germany toward a new kind of authoritarianism. In
1908, for example, a prominent member of the Catholic morality movement in

Sex, Freedom, and Power in Imperial Germany, 1880–1914

Munich argued that sex reformers constituted a “moral revolutionary movement that is advancing methodically, conquering ever more new terrain,” and
should be suppressed no less rigorously than would a movement that preached
“regicide or the confiscation of private property.”10 Helene Lange remarked in
1909 that “right about now it would not be a bad thing if a censor would forbid
any philosophizing about love and allow discussion of the sexual question only
in strictly scientific terminology.”11 In 1910 Ludwig Weber even suggested
that he would like to lynch the sex reformers.12 Already in 1907 Max von
Gruber had argued that the “overloud fools” in the sex-reform movement
should be “silenced,” and that the “disgusting brood of perverts and homosexuals” should be “stamped out.”13 And as we have seen in Chapter 11, even
some men active in sexology (Paul Näcke, Otto Adler, and Erich Lilienthal)
argued that it might be better if not so many people were interested in discussing
the topic. But the obvious point here is that the desire to make everyone shut
up was the product not of a homogenizing, bureaucratic, instrumental-rational
dynamic of modernity but precisely of its opposite. These people were sick of
arguing, of brawling, of the multiplicity of opinions, of the endless expansion
of public discussion and debate, and above all of being increasingly and multifariously disagreed with. They were sick of the pluralization and mobilization
that modernity creates.
But why was there pluralization and mobilization? Why was there a brawl?
The foregoing chapters suggest that a whole range of quite obvious and concrete
social, cultural, and indeed technological changes were crucial in fueling this
process – a process that was, moreover, characteristic of almost all aspects of
European life in this period.14
First, the ideas of those who took part in the major organizations involved
can often be derived directly from their social background. We cannot find it
extraordinary that high clergy and government officials believed that in sexual
matters everyone should fear God and be obedient to authority. It is hardly
surprising that many medical men thought that everyone should submit to a
benevolent medical “tyranny” (as Albert Neisser put it). That doctors launched
relatively effective organizational efforts to persuade people to do so merely
reflects the growing social weight of the profession: the number of doctors in
Germany grew about three times as fast as the population as a whole between
1880 and 1910, and the proportion of doctors who were members of the
major professional associations grew from less than 60 percent to more than

Sex, Politics, and Modernity II

309

80 percent.15 Nor is it surprising that many people active in journalism, the
arts, and cultural administration believed that freedom of expression (including
sexual self-expression) was essential to the health of the social order, and that
they organized to advance that view – for example, in the WHK or the BfM.
These professions, too, were rapidly expanding in the period – in tandem with
the expansion, for example, of the press, libraries, and museums.16 That socialist intellectuals should hold the sexual mores of the bourgeoisie to be corrupt
is not astonishing, either; and the explosive growth of the socialist movement
in both numbers and cultural competence lent their opinions growing weight.
The political position of the misogynist sexologists is less easy to read, except
insofar as they too were doctors. But a large proportion of them were also academics of one sort or another, and it makes sense both that they would try to
position themselves as having access to privileged knowledge about what was
good for the nation (or “race”) and that they would, in effect, try to preserve
the male monopoly over access to higher education and academia by insisting
that women were ineradicably stupid.
The expansion of women’s white-collar employment was clearly a particularly important instance of this broader pattern. The key role of teachers in
all the major women’s movements – including, for example, Gertrud Bäumer,
Hedwig Dransfeld, Maria Lischnewska, and Katharina Scheven – is symptomatic of a broader social development. Whereas the number of male teachers doubled between 1861 and 1891, the number of female teachers almost
quintupled.17 Other women’s professions (for instance, in health care or sales)
expanded at similar rates. And it is hardly surprising that professional women
would find objectionable laws that subjected them to arbitrary arrest – for
example, on their way home from work in the evening – and medical inspection,
or laws that required that many of them (as civil servants) be fired if they got
married.
Clearly, then, the debate over sex was in part simply a reflection of the growing complexity and diversity of German society. The rapid expansion, rising
level of organization, and expanding political activity of many professions was
generating new interests; it was also giving a growing number of people the
financial means, disposable time, and social capital to pursue those interests
through organized activism. In some important cases, those people came from
social groups – the working class or women – who had historically had far less

access to those resources, and had therefore been far less able to articulate their
views and interests and project them in public discussion.
Second, however, a good deal of the complexity of German society in this
period derives from the fact that it was modernizing but still far from modern.
There were still major and powerful social groups that were firmly rooted in
nineteenth-century culture and values. Again, it is no surprise that members of
the clergy, in particular, responded negatively to the cultural transformations
that formed an important part of the broader modernization process. The clergy
was very clearly in decline relative to other professions – theology students, for
example, made up about a third of those enrolled at German universities in the
1830s, a fifth in the 1880s, and a tenth in the 1910s. But the clergy was still
highly influential among the political and social elite; and some two-thirds of
the Protestant clergy identified with the orthodox Lutheran tradition, rather
than with more liberal variants.18
It is tempting to see the clergy and particularly the conservative Christian
morality campaigners as champions of premodern values. Charles Taylor, for
example, offers a description of “premodern moral order” that seems to fit the
morality movement rather well: it was “organized around a notion of a hierarchy in society that expresses and corresponds to a hierarchy in the cosmos,” in
which “some had greater dignity and value than others” and “a human being
can be a proper moral agent only when embedded in a larger social whole.”
(He sees the modern moral order, in contrast, as characterized by “an ethic
of freedom and mutual benefit” – which might be a good one-line summary
of sex reform.)19 Don Slater’s characterization of the response of traditional
society to the rise of modern consumerism fits even better: “Consumer culture . . . comes to stand for all sorts of slavery: to desire and insatiable needs,
to social scrutiny and competition, to political as well as cultural despotism
and tyranny. Liberation from social restraint really means the loss of natural
feeling and of stable social values and therefore the weakening, disorientation
and subjugation of the individual.”20
It should be obvious, however, that to view the morality campaigners as
somehow not modern would be to completely misunderstand them. The morality campaigners used modern techniques without hesitation – associations, consumer actions such as boycotts, the press, conferences, parliamentary politics,
state intervention, and so on. They did so to gain a degree of influence over
policy, public opinion, and popular behavior that they had never had before.
And they were not defending the sexual status quo, the “traditional” order of

311

sexual relations; they were in insurrection against it – for example, against the
commonsense brutalism of male sexual culture, against the regulation of prostitution, and against the tradition of the nude in Western art. They were using
very modern techniques to make a grab for very modern forms of power. Their
campaign was no less conditioned by the opportunities created by modernity
than were sex reform or the campaign against venereal diseases.
Third, specific changes in the organization of German culture were also
clearly of critical importance. Many of the publications in which views and
interests were articulated were entrepreneurial initiatives that took advantage
of the explosive growth of the commercial market for the printed word. This
was true, for example, of Die Frau, a project of the leadership of the moderate
faction in the BDF; Stöcker’s Mutterschutz/Die Neue Generation; Vanselow’s
Geschlecht und Gesellschaft; Marcuse’s Sexual-Probleme; and the Zeitschrift
für Sexualwissenschaft at least in its 1908 incarnation. These journals could
bring new viewpoints to the public debate because there literally was a new
market for them. But the same was true of the expanding pamphlet and monographic literature on issues relating to sex and sexuality.
This point can be generalized. Moral conservatives were in fact responding
to real changes in their society; and those changes were congenial to their
opponents. The simple fact of urbanization was obviously of great importance
as an engine of diversification and debate. The formation of a homosexual
subculture specifically in Berlin, for example, played an important role in
giving rise to the homosexual rights movement – and, as we have seen, was
among the more effective “arguments” Magnus Hirschfeld used to influence
peers such as Iwan Bloch and Paul Näcke. The expanding urban market really
did support the massive growth of the media, commercial entertainments, and
prostitution. Urban people in Germany’s rapidly expanding cities – whether
working class or white-collar middle class – also had to innovate furiously to
build new lives in their new environments; among the things they developed
were new modes of courtship and sexual relationships, as well as new
forms of entertainment and socialization. The birthrate really was declining,
particularly in Germany’s cities.
Real changes in the information available to activists also played an important role in shaping the debate over sexuality. One particularly curious feature
of the debate is that very few of the bourgeois and upper-class people involved
appear to have had much notion what sexual practices in their society actually looked like. Iwan Bloch, for example, was astonished by how matter-offact most working-class people were about contraception and abortion; and
he remarked somewhat bemusedly that working people even “regard sexual
anomalies as something natural” and were not terribly bothered by anal sex or
homosexuality.21 In 1909 the Munich police, on asking registered prostitutes in
that city who their customers were, discovered that most men who paid for sex

were not young, single men at all, as most assumed, but married men in search

to their own sex. Social statistics on the proportion of young men and women
who were unmarried helped to undermine the belief that the conservative code
of sexual morality was realistic at all. The expansion of medical knowledge too
played a crucial role in at least one case: the development of the Wassermann
test and the discovery of the true extent and social cost of venereal diseases
was an important factor in sparking the formation of the DGBG. In short,
the development of new, specifically modern forms of knowledge played an
important role in helping to inspire, and build support for, new initiatives –
although of course different groups drew diametrically opposed lessons from
such discoveries.
Fourth, the growing extent and intensity of international communications
and travel may also have played an important role in activating the debate
within Germany. The Swede Ellen Key was the single most influential theorist
of sex reform in Germany; her compatriot Anton Nyström delivered perhaps
the most articulate defense of the idea that abstinence was bad for one’s health
(at the DGBG conference of 1911); Ellen Sundström/Ammann became the
leader of the KDF in Bavaria; and Seved Ribbing was highly influential in more
conservative sexological circles.23 Josephine Butler, the key leader in the British
abolitionist movement, played a major role in motivating the German abolitionists, the most influential of whom met her personally on trips to London –
where Lida Gustava Heymann gave her a personal promise “to take up the
struggle in Germany,” and where Anna Pappritz first learned that prostitution was regulated in her own country.24 Edward Carpenter and Havelock
Ellis were very influential in German sex reform. The German National Committee Against the Traffic in Women was founded partly on the initiative of
the English National Vigilance Association; the chairman of the latter was

Sex, Freedom, and Power in Imperial Germany, 1880–1914

have had a lively debate about sex even if left to their own devices; but it
is equally clear that the debate in Germany was so varied and intense in part
because it was very much a European debate played out on German soil. Again,
that fact was partly a result of the rapid development of the communications
and transportation infrastructure in the late nineteenth century.
Finally, the opportunities and challenges created by the expansion of the
German state in this period played also an important role. In almost every
area of life – policing, public health, economic regulation, social welfare, and
the military – the role of the state was expanding, largely in response to rising demands for intervention from an increasingly mobilized, organized, and
politically active citizenry. As a result, public expenditures rose by 40 percent
relative to Germany’s GDP between 1880 and 1910.28 As we have seen, all the
parties to the debate over sex tried, with varying degrees of success, to make
use of the expanding state to advance their own agendas. To the extent that
they were successful, they elicited escalating responses from their opponents.
In fact, one of the features of the period around 1900 that fueled the escalation of the debate over sexuality was that the complexity and rapid expansion
of the German state and its social functions permitted almost everyone to make
real, concrete gains in shaping public policy. At the time, almost all reformers
expressed frustration at the conservatism and inertia of the Imperial state. In
fact, however, both their social profile and close ties to the major political parties and public institutions (the courts, army, bureaucracy, city government,
etc.) gave a number of reform organizations considerable leverage on various
parts of the Imperial, state, and local governments. Thus, for example, opponents of the regulation of prostitution were able to secure important changes in
the way the police treated (or at least were directed to treat) women suspected
of prostitution, and they gained some local victories against regulation; but at
the same time the advocates of regulation were able to move other cities to
adopt an even more coercive form of regulation (Kasernierung). Conservative
Christians were able to secure the introduction of important censorship measures, whether in the form of revisions to the Criminal Code or through local
police ordinances and licensing practices. Radical feminist sex reformers were

unable to gain any purchase on legislation, but they did make gains in local
government: the explosive growth of the system of public legal guardianship,
for example, revolutionized the position of single mothers and their children,
at least in many larger cities. (Again, that provoked horrified responses from
conservatives in the charitable establishments of the two Christian confessions,
who feared that although public officials might be more successful in securing
child support payments from fathers, they would not secure for their wards a
strong moral and religious education – and so would merely contribute to the
spiritual crisis that lay at the root of extramarital sex in the first place.)
This, then, is what modernization does: it creates greater social complexity,
while giving more people the wherewithal to articulate and assert their identities, their values, and their agendas. It creates a brawl. By 1914 the contours of
three moderately distinct coalitions, built around broadly overlapping values
and agendas, had begun to emerge from the brawl of German modernity. But
even the most coherent of these coalitions was still quite diffuse and was in fact
often wracked by internal disagreements.
Indeed, in some cases, elements of coherence, fundamental overlaps in values or ideas, merely testify to the profound depth of the hostilities that the
debate over sexuality reflected. In no case is this truer than in that of what
is surely among the most disturbing features of the broad discussion of sexuality in Germany society before World War I: the deep, pervasive hostility
toward women expressed across almost the entire spectrum of male opinion.
This hostility could be wrapped in the language of chivalrous patriarchalism, as
among conservative Christians; or in the language of cynical medical authoritarianism, as within the DGBG; or in the language of frank and aggressive
misogyny, as among sexologists; or even in the well-meaning male feminism
of reform-friendly sexologists like Iwan Bloch. But whatever the peculiarities
of intellectual and institutional codes and contexts, it seems that men almost
everywhere in German society simply had a hard time imagining that women
were, or could be, fully human. Femaleness appears to have been for most men
an essentially alien condition, a state of difference, a state specifically of deficit,
of absence. This lack might make women dangerous; it might make them inferior; it might make them mysterious; but it always made them, so to speak, not
men. For women, this hostility must have been subliminally suffocating. But
there was of course an opposite equivalent: the somewhat less pervasive conviction that men were by nature animalistic, undisciplined, violent, destructive,
and therefore unlike women. In this view men either were not entirely human
or at least represented that in humanity which turns its face from the Divine
(whether God or Life).
Taken to these extremes, in fact, the debate about the significance and
imperatives of sex suggests how fundamental the problem of sex ultimately
was to Germans in this period. What is politically possible and necessary is
fundamentally a question of what man is, and is not. That question appears to
have been, for many Germans in this period, a question about the difference

316

Sex, Freedom, and Power in Imperial Germany, 1880–1914

between men and women – perhaps because for so many people the boundary
between the sexes was instinctively felt to be precisely that fundamental but
hazy definitional boundary between the human and the not-so-human.29 At
the root of the matter, then, in a sense we can construct a closed conceptual
circle: for Germans in this period sex was “about” politics because politics
was “about” the nature of humankind, which was “about” sex. Small wonder,
then, that the stakes in the debate over sexuality seemed so high.
